webTitle: Comment: Living on credit

fields.headline: Living on credit
fields.standfirst:
Research reveals that the student loans system is encouraging an alarming culture of borrowing

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Research reveals that the student loans system is encouraging an alarming culture of borrowing.
fields.body:
While David Blunkett bemoans the materialism of TV game shows, it is his own department which is probably doing most to turn our young people into a generation of debt-dependent high spenders. Research on student finances, by Prof Claire Callender of South Bank University and NOP Research, is published today. It suggests that "the distinction between borrowing to finance current consumption and borrowing to invest in the future appears to have become blurred. The expanded provision of loans as part of government student support policies may be fostering a student culture unworried by debt".

The evidence is alarming. In the three years of the study, between 1996 and 1999, student expenditure rose above the rate of inflation, fuelled by a massive 66% increase in money borrowed from commercial banks and credit card companies, in addition to their official student loans which are currently running at £4-5,000 a year.

A student I spoke to last week is fairly typical. He had already spent his student loan for the term and borrowed extra, which will have to be repaid from next term's money - but he still didn't have enough money to eat. I told him how he could apply for a small grant via the government backed Access funds which are administered by the college. Two days later he was looking far more cheerful. His bank had kindly agreed to loan him another £1,000. I pointed out that a loan incurs interest and has to be repaid. But a loan which doesn't have to be repaid for three years just feels like a gift; he was unruffled and disappeared, with his mates, in the direction of the student union bar.

Judging by his accent he didn't come from a working-class home and yet, like a growing number of students, he preferred to notch up his own level of debt rather than phone home for a hand-out. Indeed, according to the research, if there is one group of people more stingy than the government in its treatment of students, it is their parents. Those mostly middle-class baby boomers, whose own education came courtesy of the taxpayer, seem remarkably uninclined to fill the funding gap left by New Labour.

Baby boomers may well have high aspirations for their children but they show little inclination to pay for them. As the grant declined, and student loans were introduced, the proportion of student income paid by parents actually dropped by 17%. The parents of one in every five students failed even to stump up their full contribution towards their children's fees, leaving them to fork out for a shortfall of on average £579 a year out of their own pockets. Nor were these parents on low incomes. Fees in the UK (outside Scotland) are means tested and the poorest 42% pay no fees at all.

Not that low income students are faring any better. They too have had to survive on loans since the abolition of grants and, not surprisingly, they are even more likely than their better-off peers to take out every penny that the loan companies offer. Research into Scottish students, by Alasdair Forsyth and Andy Furlong for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, has found that low-income students, afraid of the consequences of high debts, are avoiding the prestigious universities and longer, honours courses, and going for shorter vocational courses, at colleges close to home.

But it is lone parents, with absolutely no one to turn to for extra cash, who have the highest debts of all. The government has agreed to pay nursery fees for their children from next year, but it has done nothing to offset the need for them to take out potentially crippling loans in order to stay alive while they study. These young parents are also the group least likely to be able to boost their income through the alternative of night work. Lecturers are growing used to finding that early morning lectures are half full - not because students are watching day time TV but because they are too shagged out after working all night in a bar, or on a telephone sex line, to turn up.

There has been remarkably little protest about the abolition of grants. The National Union of Students initially trained all its fire power on the introduction of fees (a problem for middle-class students) virtually ignoring the matter of how students would survive while they studied. While it is clear that mass higher education requires a different approach to funding, the speed with which the grant system was abolished - without allowing parents to build up savings, providing working-class students with access to alternative funding, or even building up the alternative of part-time courses - is likely to create serious problems for the future as a generation of college leavers enter the job and housing market already mired in debt. Perhaps more worrying will be the affect on those who fear debt. The research found that 61% of full-time students (and an even higher proportion of black and working-class students) agreed with the statement: "changes to student funding have deterred some of my friends".

 Angela Phillips is a lecturer at Goldsmiths College, University of London

webTitle: A man who can sell anything except Sugar

fields.headline: A man who can sell anything except Sugar
fields.trailText: At Spurs, Alan Sugar was never forgiven for not being a football man. His inability to sell Alan Sugar will surely go down as his greatest failure.
fields.body:
Alan Sugar will always be remembered as the man who started out by flogging aerials from the back of a van, à la Del Boy Trotter, and went on to make millions selling his Amstrad computers - and as the man who could never sell himself.

He said this week that he had never failed in anything before - presumably apart from his pronounced lack of success in finding a decent razor. But his inability to retail Alan Sugar will surely go down as his greatest failure.

He will continue to gather dust in the shop window until he is remaindered like something that did not catch on in the Christmas shopping spree. Despite his tough East End background and his gruff and grumpy image this is a disappointment he feels keenly because he can hardly launch a new model, unless it is his son, who is already deeply involved with Tottenham Hotspur.

This is unfortunate because there have been many worse chairmen than the man who presides, for the moment at least, at White Hart Lane. He did not asset strip. In fact he poured a fortune into the club, or bankrolled those who did, making millions available for a succession of feckless managers.

Today Spurs are in mid-table in the Premiership, which is about their rightful place for this is not a Manchester United or an Arsenal, whatever their supporters might claim. There is a fine new stadium and, if George Graham is frugal, both with money and with his knowledge of the romance of the game, he is still one of the nation's most respected football managers.

Sugar has also done his best to court popularity even though, when he made the wise decision to dispose of the services of Terry Venables, he said that he "felt like the man who shot Bambi".

He replaced Venables with another popular favourite, Ossie Ardiles, and, when he blew up, with yet another in Gerry Francis. He flopped too, just as another people's choice, Kevin Keegan, was to go belly-up in the England job. When it comes to judging a good manager, "the people" are about as adroit as those of us who dispense hackery for a living.

At Spurs, though, Sugar, despite his best efforts, was never forgiven for not being a football man. He never truly understood the awfulness of the fact that Arsenal were not only more successful but played with more style. And did no one tell him that Graham used to be manager at Highbury?

At the start he was hopeless. When someone mentioned the club's great league and FA Cup double in 1961 he responded: "Double? What double?" Then there was the occasion when, fine-tooth combing through the club accounts, he discovered that someone was being paid 20 grand a year. "Who's Bill Nicholson?" he inquired with some asperity.

He made no attempt to conceal his ignorance. "I'm not a football fan," he once said, famously. "I know more about schmaltz herring than I do about football."

Anywhere else - or most places anyway - they would have been happy with a chairman with a pocketful of spondulicks as well as a sound business nous. But at Spurs, where the style of play is always a factor, whatever the results, this was never going to be enough.

Sugar never understood this, just as Spurs supporters, in their quaintly dreamy way, could never come to terms with his brutal pragmatism. Neither party should be blamed for both seem a little out of touch.

But if this reads a little like a football obituary of Sugar it is not meant to be. After all, we have been through all of this before and Sugar has been left grinning as the share prices have risen.

One thing is certain. If anyone does take Spurs away from Sugar he will have paid a good price. "He's an animal to deal with," said a former business associate.

When he fell out with the Dixons chain and decided to sell direct to the public, one particular business executive thought he had done a deal. But a couple of days later Sugar phoned the said executive, made a hugely reduced offer and gave him one hour to accept. Sugar never was a candyman.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Polished Posh set up Chelsea clash

fields.headline: Polished Posh set up Chelsea clash
fields.trailText: Oldham 0 - 1 Peterborough
fields.body:
The goalkeeper Mark Tyler produced a spellbinding performance to guarantee Peterborough a third round date with FA Cup holders Chelsea.

The 23-year-old enjoyed the kind of performance usually reserved for comic strip heroes as he pulled off a catalogue of sensational saves to frustrate Andy Ritchie's team.

David Eyres, in particular, had reasons for cursing the performance of Tyler. But for Peterborough's longest-serving player, Eyres would surely have scored a hat-trick.

Oldham had spent £24,000 on pitch improvements in the build up to the game to ensure that the tie would go ahead. The financial reward of a clash with Chelsea at Stamford Bridge would dwarf the expense of laying a new piece of lush grass, but the prospect of a cash windfall for the Latics was dashed by Richard Forsyth's fifth-minute goal for Peterborough.

The in-form Tyler denied a determined Oldham with three superb saves early in the second half. Eyres headed John Sheridan's far post cross into the bottom left hand corner, but Tyler stretched out to tip the ball behind for a corner. Allott then saw a volley saved from 20 yards before Eyres was denied again.

Peterborough should have guaranteed a date with Claudio Ranieri's Premiership superstars by half-time after creating and spurning a series of clear-cut chances.

Clarke was the main culprit as the visitors made life difficult for themselves. The former Wimbledon striker shot wide after escaping his marker on nine minutes, but he capped that miss by shooting straight at the 'keeper from six yards after 20 minutes.

Mark Allott went closest for Oldham ten minutes before half-time, but his shot from 12 yards was well saved by Peterborough goalkeeper Mark Tyler.The winger fired Danny Boshell's cross goalwards, but Tyler pulled off another terrific block as Peterborough held on to claim their lucrative prize.

webTitle: Hunting bill clears first hurdle

fields.headline: Hunting bill clears first hurdle
fields.trailText: A bill which could ban hunting with hounds cleared its first major hurdle tonight, when MPs voted overwhelmingly, by a majority of 215, to allow it to continue to progress through parliament.
fields.body:
A bill which could ban hunting with hounds cleared its first major hurdle tonight, when MPs voted overwhelmingly to allow it to continue to progress through parliament. The House of Commons agreed to give the hunting bill a second reading by 373 votes to 158, a majority of 215.

Earlier, a crowd of about 1,500 countryside protesters staged a vocal demonstration outside parliament. Police vans blocked off the entrance to the Commons as the demonstrators massed, and mounted police joined colleagues on foot in keeping order.

MPs were voting only on whether to allow the Bill to proceed through its next parliamentary stages. It contains three options - an almost total ban on hunting with dogs, compulsory licensing of hunts, or self-regulation. MPs will get a free vote on the options, though that choice will not be put before them until the bill's committee stage early next year.

There has, however, been a solid majority in favour of a ban since Labour's 1997 general election victory. It is expected that any move to ban hunting will spark fierce opposition in the Lords, making the legislation a possible casualty if a general election is called in the spring.

Leading off tonight's debate, home secretary Jack Straw told MPs that the passions aroused by the hunting issue had been reflected in the 100,000-plus letters on the subject sent to the home office since the 1997 general election.

Mr Straw himself came out in favour not of an outright ban, but of regulation of hunting through a licensing system. Mr Straw, who has never voted one way or the other in previous bids to ban hunting during 21 years as an MP, came off the fence to tell the Commons that he would support a scheme of regulation, as put forward by the Middle Way Group of MPs.

Under the scheme, hunting would become a licensed activity, with anyone wishing to take part having to apply to a Hunting Authority for a licence. Tory spokesman David Lidington told the Commons that Conservative MPs would have a free vote on the issue, but he said that in his opinion the bill was "misguided and unnecessary".

"The evidence that hunting is unacceptably cruel would need to be overwhelming, based on substantial and compelling evidence, in order to justify a ban. The case for a ban on animal welfare grounds is in my view shaky," said Mr Lidington.

Former Tory prime minister John Major accused Labour of staging the hunting bill to win votes by turning the nation against a minority of "red faced toffs". Mr Major claimed the bill was "a breathtaking example of political self-interest overriding the natural justice of a minority".

However Michael Foster, the Labour MP for Worcester, whose private member's bill to ban hunting was supported by 411 MPs in November 1997, told colleagues that the "beginning of the end" of fox hunting had arrived.

Earlier, outside parliament, the protesters - describing themselves as "rural freedom fighters" - blew hunting horns, jeered and whistled as their numbers spilled on to the road and blocked traffic. The demonstrators, who earlier staged a mass rally in Trafalgar Square, planted several banners into the green at Parliament Square, each carrying a message demanding that the government drop the bill.

One banner read "Blair, Blair doesn't care, rural England says hunting is fair", and another alleged "Blair destroys England". Simon Hart, director of the Campaign for Hunting, said: "We are delighted with the turnout. Over 70, 50-seater coaches came from all over Britain.

"The fact that the Home Secretary has concluded that there is no case for a ban should be the clearest signal to his parliamentary colleagues, that they should think very seriously about which way they should vote."

webTitle: Millwall are floored by McCarthy

fields.headline: Millwall are floored by McCarthy
fields.trailText: Wycombe 2 - 1 Millwall
fields.body:
Wycombe's solid defending and goals from Andy Rammell and Paul McCarthy earned them a shock win over Millwall and a home third-round tie with Grimsby.

The Wandererers began the better and never looked back. After a patient build-up, Michael Simpson tested the Millwall keeper Tony Warner, who saved well diving to his right. Then Niall Thompson spooned a shot over the bar from Simpson's free kick.

But the pressure told in the 18th minute when Steve Brown speared a free kick from the right on to the head of Thompson, who nodded down for Rammell to lash home his seventh goal of the season.

Millwall, who are top of the Second Division, were finally stirred into action and took just six minutes to equalise. After an extended goalmouth scramble, the defender Joe Dolan stabbed the ball home.

They scarcely deserved it but it brought a true cup-tie feel to Adams Park. First Steven Reid went on a lone sortie through the Wycombe defence, only to shoot straight at the keeper Martin Taylor, and at the other end Brown's prospective lob from the left touchline almost caught Warner unawares.

As the first half entered stoppage time, Wycombe regained the lead. Brown's corner eventually fell to McCarthy and, with a spectacular bicycle kick, he found the corner of the net.

After the break Richard Sadlier thought he had equalised but the referee Uriah Rennie spotted a push in the area.

The Lions huffed and puffed as the rain fell harder and the substitute Christophe Kinet looked particularly sharp on the left to keep Wanderers on the back foot.

Even so, Brown could have sealed victory on the counter but he nudged wide. At the other end Millwall pushed again and Matt Lawrence was denied a goal after Rennie ruled that Taylor had been impeded.

webTitle: Hatters restore some civic pride

fields.headline: Hatters restore some civic pride
fields.standfirst: FA Cup second-round replays
fields.trailText: Luton 2 - 0 Darlington
fields.body:
Hell hath no fury like a football team whose civic dignity has been affronted. Making it into the third round of the FA Cup and a home tie with Queens Park Rangers represents a rare shaft of light in an otherwise miserable time for this part of Bedfordshire. To have gone out to a struggling Third Division team, coming on top of the closure of the huge Vauxhall plant - admirably, the football club are offering car workers free tickets - and the rejection of the bid for city status, would have been beyond a joke even for these long-suffering supporters.

Luton started well enough, passing the ball cleanly and at times incisively. Liam George stung Andy Collett's hands from the edge of the area, and the goalkeeper was fortunate shortly afterwards when he failed to hold a similar effort from Paul McLaren, Andrew Fotiadis being ruled offside as he slid in the rebound.

webTitle: Barnsley and Bassett part company

fields.headline: Barnsley and Bassett part company
fields.trailText: Dave Bassett has been sacked by Barnsley, but with vacancies at both Wolves and Norwich it is likely that his exile will be minimal in duration.
fields.body:
Dave Bassett is not noted for giving in easily. His sacking by Barnsley yesterday, surprising perhaps after their run to the First Division play-off final last season and after only 18 months in all, will not deter him at 56 from seeking another post in management.

A "parting of the ways" was the official description but, given the vacancies at both Wolves and Norwich, it is likely that Bassett's exile will be minimal in duration.

He admits he has no intention of retiring and, following the recent departures of Colin Lee and Bryan Hamilton, the 56-year-old Londoner is odds-on for a speedy return to full-time employment.

Despite guiding Barnsley to fourth place in the First Division last season before a 4-2 defeat by Ipswich at Wembley, Bassett has been unable to build on the foundations this season. That defeat led to the £2.25m departure of Craig Hignett to Blackburn and, despite public pleas, Bassett has failed to loosen the purse-strings of the Barnsley chairman John Dennis in order to strengthen the squad.

However, Bassett maintains there is no bitterness towards Dennis and said: "I had a chat with John at the weekend and we came to the conclusion that this was the best course of action. John was concerned that it didn't go sour for me here because expectation levels have been hard to live with this season.

"John knows the good job I have done here and there's absolutely no animosity between us. We will stay good friends. I genuinely want the club to prosper and be successful in the future. I am very sad in many ways to be going because I have really enjoyed working with a lively and knowledgeable chairman like John."

"I have said before I want to stay in management until I am at least 60. I am still hungry and enthusiastic. There's a good few years left in me yet."

Saturday's 2-0 defeat at Stockport proved the final straw for Bassett and he leaves the club in 14th place, with the chief coach Eric Winstanley taking temporary charge of first-team affairs.

Barnsley's statement said: "Following a long discussion about the way forward for Barnsley Football Club and David Bassett, the board of directors have reluctantly agreed with David that there be a parting of the ways."

Dennis will now start the process of recruiting yet another new manager, who will become the club's fourth in the last three years, during which time Bassett, John Hendrie and Danny Wilson have all taken turns at the Oakwell helm.

webTitle: Jones' comeback may throw him to the Wolves

fields.headline: Jones' comeback may throw him to the Wolves
fields.standfirst: Former Saints manager is ready to take on Black Country's sleeping giant
fields.trailText: David Jones is prepared to relaunch his career by succeeding Colin Lee as manager of Wolverhampton Wanderers.
fields.body:
David Jones is prepared to relaunch his career by succeeding Colin Lee as manager of Wolverhampton Wanderers.

Lee, who guided Wolves to within one place of the First Division play-offs in the past two seasons, became the fourth manager in six years to be sacked by the club after Sunday's home defeat by Birmingham City.

He follows Graham Turner, Graham Taylor and Mark McGhee through the Molineux exit door but Jones, the former Southampton manager who was acquitted of child abuse charges, would have little hesitation in trying his luck.

"I want to get back into management sooner rather than later but I'm sorry it's situations like the sackings of Colin Lee that can help me," said Jones.

"I'm very flattered to be linked with the job and it's gratifying to know I haven't been forgotten. I'd be very interested in it but I don't know if I'll be applying - I imagine that for a job like this you'd be approached."

Despite his enforced sabbatical, Jones has maintained his connections with the game by helping out Gary Johnson, a friend who has been coaching the Latvian national team. The managers of two of Wolves' neighbours, Ray Graydon of Walsall and Jan Molby of Kidderminster Harriers, have also been linked with the position, as has the promotion specialist Dave Bassett who parted company with Barnsley yesterday.

Stuart Baxter, the former coach of AIK Stockholm whose father played alongside Billy Wright, and the club s record goalscorer Steve Bull have also expressed an interest. "Although I've officially retired from playing I know most of the players inside out and if I can't motivate them then who can?" said the 35-year-old Bull, currently coach at the Conference club Hereford United.

With the team just one point above the relegation zone, Lee's position was already tenuous before he practically talked himself out of a job after publicly disagreeing with the chief executive Jez Moxey on a radio phone-in.

Moxey, who has been at Molineux for just six months, said on local radio on Friday that the transfer of Wolves' leading scorer Ade Akinbiyi to Leicester City for £5m during the summer had been made with Lee's full agreement.

Lee, who was listening to the show, not only disagreed but phoned the station to broadcast his version of events. Not only was he adamant he did not agree with the sale of Akinbiyi, but he also criticised the board for not sanctioning his two planned big summer signings - David Burrows and Paul Williams from Coventry City.

After a meeting with Lee before Sunday's game, Moxey played a tape of the radio show to the board. The meeting, which involved the Wolves benefactor and chairman Sir Jack Hayward via a conference call from his Bahamas base, voted unanimously to sack Lee, a decision Moxey denied had anything to do with the phone-in.

"If we'd won the derby game 5-0 this wouldn t have happened, I don t want you to place too much emphasis on the phone-in," Moxey said. "But our current league position - averaging just one point a game - is dangerously close to relegation form.

"We appreciate that Colin has faced problems with injuries, but the entire board felt decisive action needed to be taken. Supporters are voting with their feet, and we must not allow indifference to take hold. Colin has made every effort to bring success to Wolves but sadly, results have not matched his commitment."

Lee's sacking is at odds with the feelings of the supporters. They played a major role in seeing off Turner, Taylor and McGhee but little dissatisfaction has been aimed at Lee, who has not been granted anything like the transfer budget of his predecessors. Instead, Lee had to sell the likes of Robbie Keane and then Akinbiyi before making signings.

More financial constraints have followed since Moxey's arrival which, with the club losing £40,000 a week and Hayward refusing to continue bankrolling the losses after investing more than £40m, were understandable.

More than 1,000 supporters made their feelings clear following last month's home defeat by Crystal Palace when they demonstrated outside Molineux.

Their anger was directed not at Hayward, who tried to calm the crowd, but Moxey. Despite his efforts, Hayward was sworn and spat at. Since then he has not returned to the club from his Bahamas base, although before leaving he assured Lee his job was safe.

"We ve chopped and changed managers too freqeuntly in the past and I can't see the point of doing so again now," he said. "Our biggest mistake was not giving Graham Taylor enough time."

John Ward, Lee's assistant who will take charge of the team until a successor is appointed, was not surprised. "This is something that has been lurking in the background for a while," he said.

webTitle: Bates is ousted in Wembley shake-up

fields.headline: Bates is ousted in Wembley shake-up
fields.standfirst: Foxes' chairman Walker takes the reins with athletics back on agenda
fields.trailText: Following weeks of criticism over his leadership, Ken Bates is to be replaced as head of the Wembley stadium project by Leicester City's chairman Sir Rodney Walker.
fields.body:
The Football Association last night confirmed that the Chelsea chairman Ken Bates is to step down as the head of the Wembley stadium project following weeks of criticism over his leadership.

Bates will be replaced by Sir Rodney Walker, the chairman of UK Sport, Leicester City plc and the Rugby Football League, as chairman of Wembley National Stadium Limited, the FA subsidiary company set up to oversee the project. Bates will now become vice-chairman.

Following negotiations between bankers, the FA and WNSL officials it was decided to appoint Walker because of his track record in the City and in sports politics.

The appointment is a further indication that athletics might return to the national stadium following criticisms that the proposed project had been biased towards football.

Walker, an avid athletics fan, is keen to see a running track installed in the new stadium so that it might form part of a British bid for the 2012 Olympics.

Bates's position came under scrutiny two weeks ago following a report from Chase Manhattan, the bankers appointed to raise £410million in revenue for the project, that said City financiers were unwilling to back the plans.

That led to widespread criticism of Bates' handling of the project and claims that he had kept his fellow FA board members in the dark and had alienated those also involved.

The £660m project was also slammed for being too expensive. Chase also insisted that the FA increased its investment from £20m to £100m following concerns that it was not economically viable and was in danger of becoming a white elephant.

Bates's future was decided at an FA board meeting two weeks ago. One of his sternest critics, the Arsenal vice-chairman David Dein, demanded he be removed but it was decided that, initially at least, his involvement should be marginalised. The FA's chief executive Adam Crozier intends to take a more hands-on role.

Walker's appointment was confirmed in a joint statement by the FA and WNSL last night. Bob Stubbs remains the chief executive officer of WNSL while the Football League chairman Keith Harris becomes a board director.

Crozier said: "We are determined that the 'new Wembley' will succeed and, under Sir Rodney's leadership, we are building a team of people on the board of WNSL which will have the confidence of all parties. The addition of Keith Harris will provide further heavyweight support to Sir Rodney, Ken and Bob."

The FA decided the project should go back to the drawing board and plans for a hotel, office space and banqueting facilities should be scrapped.

Walker, also chairman of the organising committee for the 2002 Commonwealth Games in Manchester, will be responsible for overseeing a redraft of the Wembley plans and persuading financial institutions to back the project.

He held a three-hour meeting with Bates yesterday and emerged confident that the pair could work together, saying: "It is a challenge but I believe the solutions can be found, hopefully sooner rather than later. I am confident that we shall produce an outcome that football, sport and the country will be proud of."

The sports minister Kate Hoey said: "I welcome the appointment of Sir Rodney Walker. I have every confidence that he will drive the project forward successfully and I look forward to working closely with him."

There is no no firm date for demolition of the old stadium but Sport England, the sports lottery money distributors, want to see new plans submitted by the beginning of March.

webTitle: Guthrie's comments anger disability groups

fields.headline: Guthrie's comments anger disability groups
fields.trailText: Disability groups have reacted angrily to the suggestion by Britain's most senior military officer, Sir Charles Guthrie, that disabled people have no right to serve in the armed forces. By Nicola Hill
fields.body:
Disability groups have reacted angrily to the suggestion by Britain's most senior military officer, Sir Charles Guthrie, that disabled people have no right to serve in the armed forces.

In his remarks, which were made last night in a speech at the Royal United Services Institute in London, he said it would be "detrimental" to allow disabled people to serve in the forces.

He said: "Our defence ministers do understand our position and have been robust in the defence of our case during the recent European debate on ending employment discrimination on grounds of age and disability. I fully understand that those proposing this aspect of employment law were acting with good intentions and for entirely laudable aims.

"But if left unchecked the impact would have had a detrimental effect on the forces by insisting that disabled people had a right to serve. We need to guard against such ill-conceived ideas in future."

Agnes Fletcher, head of communications at the Royal Association for Disability and Rehabilitation (Radar), said: "We are both angry and sad at this outdated view. I want an armed service that employs the right person for the job and by imposing a blanket ban on one group this can never be attained."

Policy director at the Disability Rights Commission (DRC) Paul Gemmill, said: "We are not asking the army to accept people who can't do a job but we are asking for fair treatment." Mr Gemmill particularly emphasised the importance of the armed forces continuing to employ personnel who become disabled while serving.

"A fighter pilot who is disabled in action could be used in a civilian capacity rather than being invalided out of the service and wasting his skills and knowledge," said Mr Gemmill. He also challenged the army's right to discriminate against a person with a disability such as facial disfigurement who could still able to engage in armed combat.

A spokesman from the Ministry of Defence (MoD) admitted that, in theory, many support jobs within the armed forces could be done by disabled people, but claimed that all personnel had to be capable of working in a war zone. He said the example of discriminating against someone with facial disfigurement was unfair. "Even if someone was technically described as disabled, we wouldn't preclude them if they were able to fight, run, fire weapons and pass a physical fitness test." But he added: "You can imagine the complications we would have to go through to set up the equipment needed for a blind filing clerk in a war zone."

However, Radar's Ms Fletcher countered this argument. "I'd like to see if this outdated view stands up to scrutiny. In reality, in modern warfare I can't imagine a filing clerk being on the front line."

She also pointed out that Sir Charles said he was more than happy to see women in the army but that they were not suitable on the front line. Fletcher asked: "There is a direct parallel with disabled people, so is his comment about women just political correctness or is there something else going on?"

James Strachan, chief executive of the Royal National Institute for Deaf People (RNID), said: "No one questions the need for operational effectiveness. However, this need not conflict with offering protection for disabled people in non-combative roles."

Given the remarks made, Mr Gemmill questioned why the MoD has recently asked the DRC to join a "diversity panel" chaired by Sir Charles, which is designed to look at increasing the role of women, disabled people and other minority groups.

The DRC is pressing for the removal of the armed forces' exemption from the Disability Discrimination Act.

webTitle: National Trust head hunts for solutions

fields.headline: National Trust head hunts for solutions
fields.trailText: Profile: Fiona Reynolds, new head of the National Trust
fields.body:
The woman set to take the helm of the National Trust claims not to have a personal view on hunting. Yet the hunting bill was one of the priorities in the Queen's speech and the trust still allows hunting on its land. Fiona Reynolds, the 42-year-old director-general designate, insists that "my challenge is to look at a whole range of other things".

These things include managing one of Britain's largest charities with more than 2.5m members, 612,000 acres of land and 600 miles of coastline. On top of this, there is the upkeep of 250 historic houses, gardens and industrial buildings and 60m visitors a year to entertain. Annual expenditure on conservation and maintenance is £148m.

Sitting in an armchair at the trust's headquarters overlooking St James Park in London, Ms Reynolds appears feisty, full of energy and ready to shake off the dusty image of the 105-year-old charity. "The trust has to some extent a caricature image, not necessarily a negative one, but an image of grand country houses," she says. "Whereas the breadth of what we do in relation to the countryside, and the huge responsibility as a land manager, mean we should be seen as a much more influential body.

One of Ms Reynolds's key concerns is what she sees as a general resignation that the countryside is in crisis. "I think the trust has a really powerful role to play in helping to find solutions. In fact she has, joining a regional committee in her early 20s - "probably one of the youngest ever", she lets slip. "That experience was enormously important, understanding how policy is made and implemented and working on issues that cut across different departments," she says.

Although she does not officially start until January, Ms Reynolds has already embarked on a punishing schedule of visits to properties, from tin mines in Cornwall to a lighthouse on the north-east coast. "I've been struck by how we are almost acting like an RDA [regional development agency] or an investment agency, because we raise money through a whole range of mechanisms, including from our members, and then distribute it around the country."

It is an amazing thing to have been here for 100 years and I want to make sure it lasts another 100 when all of us will be gone. webTitle: NHS loses top woman to Oxfam

fields.headline: NHS loses top woman to Oxfam
fields.trailText: Less than two weeks after taking up what had been described as "the second most important job" in NHS management, Barbara Stocking has quit to become director of aid charity Oxfam. The timing of the announcement that she is to leave her post as director of the NHS modernisation agency - the body tasked with rolling out the NHS plan reforms - has stunned the health service.
fields.body:
Less than two weeks after taking up what had been described as "the second most important job" in NHS management, Barbara Stocking has quit to become director of aid charity Oxfam. The timing of the announcement that she is to leave her post as director of the NHS modernisation agency - the body tasked with rolling out the NHS plan reforms - has stunned the health service.

There will also be disappointment that one of the NHS's most experienced, and high-profile, women managers is leaving the service, reinforcing concerns that it cannot hold on to its top female talent and role models.

It emerged this week that NHS chief executive Nigel Crisp knew that 49-year-old Ms Stocking's "hat was in the ring" for the Oxfam job - and that she would take it if offered - when he appointed her in November. Although the modernisation agency job was billed as "for an initial period of six months," and as a "secondment" from her principal job as director of NHS south-east region, there was no suggestion that she had not joined the agency for the long haul. The Department of Health website refers to her as "the new head of the agency".

But Ms Stocking, who had unsuccessfully applied for the NHS chief executive post, which went to Mr Crisp in October, told the Guardian that when he approached her about the job, she had warned him that she was considering "doing something different".

She said: "He was really anxious to get the modernisation agency moving quickly. That was why we agreed it was a secondment and that, in due course, the job would be advertised."

In what now looks ironic, Mr Crisp came under fire at the time for appearing to breach equal opportu nities policy by appointing Ms Stocking without first advertising the job.

A Department of Health spokesman said that her appointment was always intended as a stop gap: "Clearly, we felt that Barbara was an outstanding candidate to get the agency off to a flying start. It was always on the understanding that it was for a start-up period."

This still leaves the questions of why such an important position was not advertised straight away, and whether, if Ms Stocking had decided against the Oxfam job, she would have had to "re-apply" for the modernisation job next spring.

The modernisation agency was set up by Alan Milburn, health secretary, to spread good management practice across the health service and help health professionals implement the NHS plan. It has already sent teams into hospital trusts with the longest out-patient waiting lists, but will equally be working to identify the best performing organisations and reward them with more power to take decisions locally.

At Oxfam, Ms Stocking will manage a £90m budget and a worldwide staff of 2,600. She replaces David Bryer, who is leaving the charity's top job after 10 years. The post was advertised at a salary of £75,000 - some £5,000 less than she was reportedly earning four years ago when director of the NHS Anglia and Oxford region.

Ms Stocking, who lives in Oxford, where Oxfam is based, said: "I was very tempted by the modernisation job, but at the time it came up I had almost made up my mind [that she would leave the NHS]."

The lure of the Oxfam job was too great, she said. "I've always admired it as an influential and humanitarian aid agency that really works for people on the ground, in terms of their own development."

webTitle: Week 3: Aspen

fields.headline: Steaming in the Underworld
fields.standfirst: "I wanted to enter into the spirit of things so I did some heavy breathing, stood up and tried to touch my toes. At this the younger man disappeared for a short time and then reappeared with a long scrubbing brush."  Sam tries a touch of rest and relaxation in the Yampah Vapour Caves
fields.trailText: "I wanted to enter into the spirit of things so I did some heavy breathing, stood up and tried to touch my toes. At this the younger man disappeared for a short time and then reappeared with a long scrubbing brush." Where on earth is Sam?
fields.body:
Have just had one of those strange travelling experiences which I have to tell you about.

I'm in a little mountain town called Glenwood Springs. The town grew up around the natural thermal springs that rise to the surface here and are used by residents and tourists for various therapeutic purposes. My guide book mentioned one of these, the Yampah Vapour Caves, was a sort of sauna and the perfect place to de-stress.

I had had a glorious long day of skiing in Snowmass near Aspen, and my legs were hurting pretty bad. A sauna would be an excellent way to ease those aching muscles.

The Caves were located at the end of a long dark road underneath the freeway. As I approached I could see a number of neon signs above the entrance offering massages in an attempt to entice motorists off the road. This gave the place a rather seedy feel, which wasn't dispelled when I entered and queued up behind a two greasy-looking men.

Inside there was a little reception. A small woman took my $4.75 entrance fee, gave me a towel and directed me down the end of a carpeted corridor to the locker rooms. I got changed into my swim shorts, crossed the corridor, pulled back a plastic curtain and stepped gingerly down into the caves.

It was quite extraordinary, and reminded me of those mediaeval pictures of Hades (but without the screaming devils and people being flayed). It was dark, very steamy and silent, except for the sound of dripping water. The ceiling was low and I had to bend my head as I walked through an archway carved out of the rock.

I was presented with a choice of three caves. I chose cave number three and stepped in. The ceiling was much higher and dimly lit. There were four marble slabs on which lay two men and one woman all sweating heavily and looking very serious. I felt I should introduce myself, but this was clearly not cave etiquette, so I just sat down and joined in the sweating.

No one said anything. After a while the woman began to make huffing puffing noises and stretched her limbs into various impressive yogic positions. In response, the younger of the two men hawked up some flem and spat it into a cup which he'd handily thought to bring with him.

This routine continued for some time. The older man, obviously feeling left out, then sat up and began to loudly click various parts of his spine. I too wanted to enter into the spirit of things so I did some heavy breathing, stood up and tried to touch my toes. At this the younger man disappeared for a short time and then reappeared with a long scrubbing brush. He sat down and proceeded to scrub himself from head to toe making small moans of ecstasy (and occasionally hawking into his cup).

I was getting a bit hot by this stage, so I moved to the 'cooling' cave where the temperature was considerably lower. I then went back to try cave number two, but the occupants were much less interesting and just lay there in silence. I didn't stay there much longer.

Back upstairs I had a freezing cold shower, got dressed and walked back down the corridor into the solarium. This was rather nice with a fountain, Chinese-style music playing softly, incense burning and little Christmas lights round the edge - it is the festive season after all. There was an interesting selection of reading material too: The Wall Street Journal, Aspen Times, Better Homes and Sky and Telescope, just in case any astronomers popped in.

The whole effect was in fact very relaxing and my aches and pains were replaced by a warm tingling glow and a dreamy smile on my face. Then my friend with the excess flem problem walked in and I decided to leave.

It was gently snowing outside so I went into the open air hot springs pool next door. With snowflakes coming down, steam billowing off the water and classical music playing in the background, this was about as close to a spiritual experience as I'll ever get.

After all that, I haven't really got time to tell you about my three-day train journey from Washington DC and the fantastic time I've had skiing in and around Aspen. But some vivid images:

 Sitting on the train slowly rolling though the night, looking out the window at the small American towns with their houses and yards bright with Christmas lights.

 Playing hangman with my new friend Keenan in the lounge car as the train, already four hours late, slows to a crawl over the mountains of the continental divide with a blizzard raging outside.

 Jiri (laid back Belgian guy) turning into a snowman after wiping out on the slopes at Snowmass and going headfirst in the powder.

 The red cliffs of the snowy mountains being lit up by the dropping sun as the sky turns from blue to purple to black.

I'll be in San Francisco by the weekend to spend Christmas with my friends Roy and Sal. Then it's Fiji. Which reminds me, I'll be arriving on New Year's Eve night, so it might be sensible to book some accommodation in advance. Any ideas?

webTitle: Grassroots advocacy can boost participation

fields.headline: Grassroots advocacy can boost participation
fields.trailText: Taking the grassroots approach has helped a small breast cancer charity to gain more supporters and bring in investment. Kate Wilkinson reports
fields.body:
It's becoming received wisdom that too many cancer charities are competing for money. Breast cancer is increasingly a politicised issue. So what significant impact can a small breast cancer organisation hope to make?

"We are a specialist organisation with a grassroots approach," explained Elisabeth Davies, director of the UK Breast Cancer Coalition (UKBCC). "We equip people with the knowledge of how the NHS works, the concepts behind the acronyms, and then look at what is needed locally."

This advocacy model has its roots in the National Breast Cancer Coalition, based in Washington, DC. "Patients in the States are far more consumers within the healthcare process, and are happy to call themselves advocates," said Ms Davies. "Here, people are more likely just to say, 'I know about this'."

As part of enabling individuals to lobby for change, UKBCC recently became the first organisation to offer online campaign support through the interactive site Advocacy Online. "A key question for campaigners now," said Advocacy Online's Mark Flanagan, "is how to connect individuals with decision makers. The most credible organisations' campaigns will be those where individuals can speak for their own interests."

Individuals have always been at the heart of UKBCC, founded in 1995 from six women's personal experiences of breast cancer. When they compared their treatments, they were shocked by the unfairness of access to services.

Even with clear aims, the foundation years were sometimes difficult. "When people have become involved precisely because they want to be active, it's alienating suddenly to find that board meetings are taken up by the details of a constitution and procedures," explained Ms Davies, then a volunteer with the coalition. "But you absolutely have to do it."

After three years the coalition had around 1,000 members, but frustratingly few resources. "We were all volunteers," said Ms Davies. "We couldn't invest the time to turn members from passive supporters into active advocates."

October 1998 proved a turning point for the group, which now has pharmaceuticals company Roche among its corporate supporters. High-profile events staged with support from the Daily Express attracted investment, and enabled the coalition to recruit for the first time. It put strategic support before administration, and appointed Ms Davies as its first director.

Two years later, the coalition has 3,000 supporters and 500 active advocates, and growth is bringing new challenges.

Close relations with advocates are central to the organisation, which currently has personal contact with all active members. "We have to maintain that as we grow," insisted Ms Davies, "because we're asking a lot of people." Communication is designed to ensure that the organisation remains patient-focused, and its constitution includes the unusual specification that a majority of board members must have personal experience of breast cancer.

But the strength of personal experience needs to be set in a broader context, the coalition argues. It works to develop advocates' objectivity, and is wary of relying on personal experience at the expense of organisational development.

"I know the fact that my mother died of breast cancer is a good story for journalists," said Ms Davies. "But internally we try to be very inclusive. It has to be that you bring skills but you share them, so that when you're no longer there, the direction still is."

The key challenge now is to promote further development of grassroots advocacy: personal, well-informed pressure for change. Can it flourish in the UK? Many would argue that at least a breeze of change is stirring in the NHS, with a new language of reform and the establishment of patient advocacy and liaison services. Its time may have come.

 Kate Wilkinson is a communications consultant.

webTitle: Blood transfusions 'extremely safe'

fields.headline: Blood transfusions 'extremely safe'
fields.trailText: Blood transfusions are "extremely safe", despite evidence that at least 14 people have died in the past seven years as a result of receiving unsafe blood during operations, says a government auditor.
fields.body:
Blood transfusions are "extremely safe", despite evidence that at least 14 people have died in the past seven years as a result of receiving unsafe blood during operations, says a government auditor.

The National Audit Office (NAO) said the National Blood Service has taken "effective measures" to ensure blood safety, despite public fears over theoretical risks of variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

It also reported that the service fully met demand from hospitals for blood products in 1999-00 - a significant improvement on the previous year, when shortages caused many hospitals to cancel operations.

But although blood donations from the public currently meet demand, it says there is a risk that collections "may decline" and more should be done to make it easier for the public to donate, including shortening the length of time it takes to give blood.

A survey of public attitudes to donation found that most people accepted that there was a "continuing need to give blood" and that the service therefore "did not have to put a lot of effort into selling the merits of giving blood".

It also found that the principle of giving blood for free was still strong. Only 1% of those people who did not donate, or who had lapsed, said they would be attracted back by payment.

The blood service believes that seven verifiable deaths due to unsafe transfusions of blood were reported between 1993 and 1998, when around 5m transfusions took place.

A separate report quoted by the audit office, published in April 2000 by the Serious Hazards of Transfusion Group, said seven deaths were "definitely attributed" to transfusion during 1998-99, two of which were due to contamination.

The blood service has spent £60m a year since 1998 introducing a process called leucodepletion, which removes white cells from blood to reduce the risk of infection from variant CJD.

The audit office report said that the blood service, which until 1994 was split into several regional authorities, was now fully integrated into a national service.

It said that since the reorganisation, the service's performance of collecting blood from donors and delivering it to hospitals "is as good as, and in many areas, better" than before.

webTitle: Kurdish protesters occupy London Eye

fields.headline: Kurdish protesters occupy London Eye
fields.standfirst: London Eye webcam
fields.trailText: Twenty-two Kurdish protesters have taken over the London Eye and are threatening to set themselves alight.
fields.body:
Twenty-two Kurdish protesters have taken over the London Eye and are threatening to set themselves alight.

The group began their protest at about 3pm and 350 passengers had to be evacuated from the other pods on the 450-ft high ferris wheel on the south bank of the Thames in London. Other groups have also occupied the London offices of the European Commission.

Police are negotiating with the protesters who are situated in two separate pods and the fire brigade are standing by in case they go ahead with their threat to set fire to themselves.

The protest was sparked when soldiers stormed 20 prisons in Turkey yesterday in an effort to stop hunger strikes. Fifteen inmates and two soldiers died in the action after the prisoners set fire to themselves.

Soldiers and riot police used tear-gas during the operation in an effort to remove the fasting prisoners to hospitals, as well as to transfer others.

Around 200 prisoners had been on hunger strike in Turkish jails for two months over plans to move them from dormitory wards into smaller cells where they say they will be at risk of abuse from guards.

James Millard, who was on the Eye at the time, described what he saw:"We'd got right the way round and just as people were getting out of the pod in front of us a load of what looks like Turkish people piled on with banners. They started chanting and putting their fists out," he told Capital FM. "All we knew about it was an intercom message in our pod saying that 'there is an incident going on the ground'."

Metropolitan Police deputy assistant commissioner Andy Trotter said: "They are making certain demands, no food or water has yet been delivered to them and everything is quite peaceful at the moment."

Speaking at the scene he added:"There has been a suggestion that they have some petrol with them but we cannot confirm this at the moment. We are not in the business of meeting demands but we are in discussion with one of the pods."

The Eye protestors have aldo been linked to a man and a woman who were escorted from prime minister's question time in the Houses of Parliament this afternoon after making a vocal protest as Tony Blair was speaking.

Related story

webTitle: Chile's top court throws out Pinochet indictments

fields.headline: Chile's top court throws out Pinochet indictments
fields.trailText: Chile's supreme court has rejected homicide and kidnapping indictments against former dictator Augusto Pinochet, on the grounds that the case was not properly handled.
fields.body:
Chile's supreme court has rejected homicide and kidnapping indictments against former dictator Augusto Pinochet, on the grounds that the case was not properly handled.

The 4-1 judgment confirms the decision made in a lower court last week to drop the charges, which relate to the murder of 73 political prisoners in the 1973 Caravan of Death.

But the decision keeps open the possibility of new charges against the 85-year-old. The court ordered Judge Juan Guzman, who brought the original indictment, to conduct a formal interrogation of Pinochet within 20 days - a step required for pressing charges.

The lower court had thrown out the indictment because Pinochet had not been questioned first.

"This was a victory with some taste of defeat for Pinochet," said Hugo Gutierrez, one of the lawyers prosecuting the general. "I would say Pinochet remains almost indicted."

Pinochet ousted Marxist President Salvador Allende in a 1973 coup and ruled Chile until 1990.

webTitle: Leeds land Keane

fields.headline: Leeds land Keane
fields.trailText: Leeds have signed Internazionale striker Robbie Keane on loan until the end of the season.
fields.body:
Leeds have signed Internazionale striker Robbie Keane on loan until the end of the season.

The deal is with a view to a permanent £12m deal in the summer for the Republic of Ireland international, who has struggled to make an impact at the San Siro since moving from Coventry for £13million five months ago.

Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale confirmed on the club's website: "We felt it imprudent to spend another £12m immediately. But by structuring a loan formula, we have the player now without impacting on our financial position."

We thank Inter Milan for their co-operation in this matter - there was a huge amount of interest in Robbie and it is to their credit that they asked him as to his preference and we are delighted he chose Leeds."

Keane will arrive in England tomorrow for a medical and should be registered as a Leeds player in time for their match against Aston Villa on Saturday

webTitle: Sahara jumps Mediterranean into Europe

fields.headline: Sahara jumps Mediterranean into Europe
fields.standfirst: Global warming threatens to create dust belt around the globe
fields.trailText: Global warming threatens to create dust belt around the globe.
fields.byline: Paul Brown, environment correspondent in Bonn
fields.body:
The Sahara has crossed the Mediterranean, forcing thousands to migrate as a lethal combination of soil degradation and climate change turns parts of southern Europe into desert.

A major UN conference was told yesterday that up to a third of Europe's soil could eventually be affected.

A fifth of Spanish land is so degraded that it is turning into desert, according to figures released for the first time yesterday, and in Italy tracts of land in the south are now abandoned and technically desert.

Portugal, Spain, Italy and Greece are the four EU countries already so badly affected that they have joined the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (CCD) which is meeting in Bonn this week.

One expert, Maurizio Sciortino, said that there were many causes of the soil degradation, including changing weather patterns and the rise of global farming, which is making it uneconomic to run smallholdings and is driving people from the land.

"Land that has been carefully cultivated and preserved for 2,000 years, with terracing for soil conservation and careful irrigation to keep up productivity, is being abandoned and lost," he said. "The walls of the terracing break down, the soil is washed away and we are left with bare rock. Once that happens there is no way back.

"The conditions are particularly bad in southern Italy, Spain and Greece. Even southern France is not immune but so far they do not admit it for political reasons."

The problem is not confined to the EU. Bulgaria, Hungary, Moldova, Romania and Russia have all reported signs of desertification. Experts say Moldova in particular is "highly vulnerable" to desertification, with about 60% its farmland degraded.

Beyond the Black Sea, there are belts of fast-degrading land stretching as far as Mongolia. China, for example, has said that land deterioration in its northern provinces is costing its economy £4bn a year.

In places such as drought-stricken Sardinia and Sicily, economic conditions are accelerating the problem. "In many places tourism is making things far worse," Mr Sciortino said.

"Water is pumped from below ground, pulling salt water from the sea into the aquifers. Imagine how much water it takes to keep an 18-hole golf course going for the tourists. The trouble is they use the money to buy petrol to drive the desalination plants for more water and that makes global warming worse. In the end it means more deserts. We have to stop this cycle."

Italy has a programme of helping the countries of North Africa to combat desertification, partly in order to stem the increasing tide of refugees attempting to reach Europe.

Valareo Calzolaio, the Italian environment minister, said that at first people migrated from the country to the cities and then "toward remote western mirages - migrants fall to the network of criminal traders in human beings."

He is also concerned about the a rise in the number of refugees from the east: "If we do not take urgent action then within 10 years millions will be forced to migrate from their degraded land and they will be heading for Europe."

Klaus Töpfer, the former German environment minister who is now executive director of the UN Environment Programme, said: "Although often overlooked, soil is a natural resource that is no less important to human wellbeing and the environment than clean water and clean air, the two things that most people in the EU have been focusing on.

"The sustainable use of soil is one of Europe's greatest environmental, social and economic challenges."

Domingo Jimenez-Beltran, executive director of the European Environment Agency, said: "In some parts of Europe, the degradation is so severe that it has reduced the soil's capacity to support human communities and ecosystems and resulted in desertification. Because it can take hundreds or thousands of years to regenerate most soils, the damage occurring today is, for all purposes, irreversible."

In a report published yesterday the agency said the first stages of serious soil degradation were being noted in parts of Europe and 150m hectares are at a high risk of erosion. Deterioration is at a critical point in Mediterranean countries.

Meanwhile, the situation is no better in eastern Europe, where 41% of agricultural land in Ukraine is at risk of erosion.

Currently, 172 countries have ratified the the CCD, as it is known in UN jargon, and this is the fourth annual meeting of members. It is a sister organisation to the Climate Change Convention - which recently had a disastrous meeting in the Hague - and the Biodiversity Convention, which attempts to preserve habitats and species.

Hama Arba Diallo, the executive secretary of the convention, said most schemes to com bat desertification were small-scale and concentrated in border areas in Africa to prevent migration and conflict.

"Most of our schemes cost between $20,000 and $50,000, and involve local communities identifying what needs to be done and doing it. I can take people to schemes in China where $20,000 has turned 15 hectares of desert into valuable agricultural land. If we had 100 times as much money we could do 100 similar schemes to push back the deserts."

However, Mr Diallo said it was difficult to attract finance for such small local schemes.

Action Plan
At this year's Convention to Combat Desertification (CCD), countries in southern Europe produced action plans to deal with:

• Seasonal droughts, very high rainfall variability and sudden high-intensity rainfall

• Poor, highly erodable soil, prone to surface crusts

• Crisis conditions in traditional agriculture with associated land abandonment

• An increase in forest fires

• Concentration of economic activity in coastal areas

webTitle: Knowledge Unlimited

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk. We'll do our best to answer them
fields.trailText: BOXING NOT-SO-CLEVER
fields.body:
BOXING NOT-SO-CLEVER

"I vaguely remember waking up on Boxing Day morning a couple of years ago (with a massive hangover) and seeing a caption on Football Focus with an old list of Boxing Day fixtures and an awful lot of goals. Was it something to do with the DTs or did this really happen?" asks Ken Davro.

We're not doctors, so our lawyers have advised us to make no comment about the floating spots in front of your eyes. But we can help you with the Boxing Day thing.

On December 26 1963, an amazing 66 goals were scored in the old First Division, leaving some teams wishing there had been a repeat of the previous season's Big Freeze (which had wiped out nearly all the football between Boxing Day and March). Here are the classifieds:

Blackpool 1 - 5 Chelsea

Burnley 6 - 1 Man Utd

Fulham 10 - 1 Ipswich

Leicester 2- 0 Everton

Liverpool 6- 1 Stoke

Nottm Forest 3 - 3 Sheff Utd

WBA 4 - 4 Tottenham

Sheff Wed 3- 0 Bolton

Wolves 3 - 3 Aston Villa

West Ham 2 - 8 Blackburn

If that wasn't weird enough, the results two days later - when many of the teams played the "return leg" - beggar belief. West Ham, who had lost 8-2 at home to Blackburn, won 3-1 at Ewood Park. Manchester United, fresh from a 6-1 thrashing at Burnley, turned the tables at Old Trafford with a 5-1 win.

And poor Ipswich, who had clearly been on the Christmas Day pop, avenged their 10-1 defeat by Fulham with a 4-2 victory over the Cottagers at Portman Road. Much good the two points did them, mind you: they finished bottom.

THE KOP: A SUB-EDITOR'S DREAM

Why are areas of football stadiums called the Kop? asks Ian Hallam.

In 1904, Arsenal opened a mound of terracing at their Manor Ground. Regulars soon nicknamed it the Spion Kop, which means "look-out" in Afrikaans and was a hill in South Africa where 322 British soldiers were killed during the Boer War.

Two years later, Liverpool opened their own version. Within sixty years, people were singing along to She Loves You whilst slipping around in rivers of their own urine, and a legend was born.

FASTEST HAT-TRICK EVER

Who holds the record for the fastest-ever hat-trick? asked Mark McKenna.

"Gary Talbot scored a hat-trick for Chester City in the FA Cup in three and a half minutes in 1965," reckons Tom Farrell. That would beat Robbie Fowler and Nigel Clough's efforts mentioned last week.

And he's right. A report on the official Chester website says: "Chester led Crewe Alexandra 2-0 with just a few minutes remaining in the first round. Fans began to drift away, and those who did must have regretted their decision as Talbot netted the fastest ever FA Cup hat-trick ever, taking just over three and a half minutes.

"Sensationally, Gary announced just after the game that he would be quitting football at the end of the season, such were the rigours of combining his job (as a photographer) with his football. On the advice of his father, Gary reverted his decision and opted to become a full-time player with Chester."

LATEST SCORES (SORT OF)

I was watching a rather spiffing video entitled Super Spurs or some such the other day and noticed that in olden times the letters of the alphabet were positioned on the side of the pitch taking up (what would be today) prime advertising space. Can you tell me, were these an early form of educational device and why aren't they in use today? asks Peter Slade

The answer to this one is nearly as simple as David Beckham. The letters in question corresponded to a list of fixtures printed in the match programme, and were used to display the half-time and full-time scores.

During the break, a chap in tatty overalls would waddle up and prop some numbers up by each letter - and sometimes, if you were lucky, he could be bothered to do the job properly. Most of the time, however, you would spend the entire second half wondering whether he really meant to put the numbers 5 and 7 upside down, exactly between letters C and D.

ENGLAND'S LAST PENALTY BEFORE ITALIA 90

In the quarter-final match in Italia 90, England beat Cameroon with Gary Lineker scoring twice from the spot. When was the previous penalty award to England before this game? Was it in the 1986 World Cup qualifiers against Turkey or Finland? Or someone else? asks Chris Stevenson.

To answer this question you have to go back to February 1986, when Bryan Robson slotted home a penalty as England won 2-1 away against Israel. Hope that helps.

THE WORLD'S FASTEST BOOKING

A few years ago I remember that Wimbledon's Vinnie Jones up-ended Man City's Niall Quinn within about three seconds of the start of the game, and it was said at the time to be a new world record for the fastest-ever booking. Is this true, what was the official time and has anyone managed to break the record since? asks David Scott.

Yes, Vinnie still holds the world record for the quickest booking, according to the FA's David Barber -a distinction he "earned" after a foul on Dane Whitehouse three seconds into Chelsea's game against Sheffield United in 1992. "I must have been too high, too wild, too strong or too early, because, after three seconds, I could hardly have been too bloody late!" remembers Vinnie fondly in his autobiography.

EUROPEAN PLAYERS WHO HAVE MADE IT IN SOUTH AMERICA

"Have ever been any European players of note who have moved to any of the South American leagues and made it big?" asks Vikram Karekatte

"Charles Miller was born in Brazil of an English father and Brazilian mother," says Seamus McCann. "However, he attended Bannister Court School near Southampton and began to organise football when he returned to Brazil at the turn of the century. He was a star forward with Sao Paulo Athletic Club and played international football for Brazil. He became a referee in 1910 and died in 1953 in Sao Paulo.

Meanwhile, Dave Gibbs says: "The 1950 exodus to Colombia was probably the most notable example of British players playing in South America in the post war period. Neil Franklyn (Stoke and England) and Charlie Mitten (Man Utd), amongst others, took the money and ran.

"The authorities weren't impressed and I know Franklyn never played for England again," he continues.

"Also, Maurizio Gaudino moved to a Mexican club side after his spells in Germany and at Man City. Read The Beautiful Game by Chris Taylor, a great book on the history of Latin American Football. I'm sure the answers are in there somewhere."

HIGHEST PREMIERSHIP NUMBER "What is the highest shirt number that has been used in the Premiership or Nationwide League? I have seen in the Italian League that somebody wears the number 99 shirt, but has the trend for crazy numbers spread over here yet? Or do those doddering gentleman at the FA insist that we don't go higher than 50?" asks Matthew Gerrard

Both Sam Reisman and Jarrod Lythgoe point out that the FA certainly don't insist on going over 50, as Les Ferdinand was offered the 99 shirt after Newcastle signed Alan Shearer, but instead wore the next available number.

CAN YOU HELP?

"Can you tell me who holds the world record for the fastest sending off (excluding substitutes)?" asks Candy Stephens

"Was Taffarel, the Brazil keeper during the last World Cup, playing as a striker for some remote European team prior to the tournament? I have a vague memory of one of the commentators saying something about it but I'm not sure. Can anyone help?" asks Simon Cook

Anyone who knows can mail their answer to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can use the same address to send your questions: we'll do our best to answer them.

Two years later, Liverpool opened their own version. Within sixty years, people were singing along to She Loves You whilst slipping around in rivers of their own urine, and a legend was born. FASTEST HAT-TRICK EVER Who holds the record for the fastest-ever hat-trick? asked Mark McKenna. "Gary Talbot scored a hat-trick for Chester City in the FA Cup in three and a half minutes in 1965," reckons Tom Farrell. That would beat Robbie Fowler and Nigel Clough's efforts mentioned last week. And he's right. A report on the official Chester website says: "Chester led Crewe Alexandra 2-0 with just a few minutes remaining in the first round. Fans began to drift away, and those who did must have regretted their decision as Talbot netted the fastest ever FA Cup hat-trick ever, taking just over three and a half minutes. "Sensationally, Gary announced just after the game that he would be quitting football at the end of the season, such were the rigours of combining his job (as a photographer) with his football. On the advice of his father, Gary reverted his decision and opted to become a full-time player with Chester." LATEST SCORES (SORT OF) I was watching a rather spiffing video entitled Super Spurs or some such the other day and noticed that in olden times the letters of the alphabet were positioned on the side of the pitch taking up (what would be today) prime advertising space. Can you tell me, were these an early form of educational device and why aren't they in use today? asks Peter Slade The answer to this one is nearly as simple as David Beckham. The letters in question corresponded to a list of fixtures printed in the match programme, and were used to display the half-time and full-time scores. During the break, a chap in tatty overalls would waddle up and prop some numbers up by each letter - and sometimes, if you were lucky, he could be bothered to do the job properly. Most of the time, however, you would spend the entire second half wondering whether he really meant to put the numbers 5 and 7 upside down, exactly between letters C and D. ENGLAND'S LAST PENALTY BEFORE ITALIA 90 In the quarter-final match in Italia 90, England beat Cameroon with Gary Lineker scoring twice from the spot. When was the previous penalty award to England before this game? Was it in the 1986 World Cup qualifiers against Turkey or Finland? Or someone else? asks Chris Stevenson. To answer this question you have to go back to February 1986, when Bryan Robson slotted home a penalty as England won 2-1 away against Israel. Hope that helps. THE WORLD'S FASTEST BOOKING A few years ago I remember that Wimbledon's Vinnie Jones up-ended Man City's Niall Quinn within about three seconds of the start of the game, and it was said at the time to be a new world record for the fastest-ever booking. Is this true, what was the official time and has anyone managed to break the record since? asks David Scott. Yes, Vinnie still holds the world record for the quickest booking, according to the FA's David Barber -a distinction he "earned" after a foul on Dane Whitehouse three seconds into Chelsea's game against Sheffield United in 1992. "I must have been too high, too wild, too strong or too early, because, after three seconds, I could hardly have been too bloody late!" remembers Vinnie fondly in his autobiography. EUROPEAN PLAYERS WHO HAVE MADE IT IN SOUTH AMERICA "Have ever been any European players of note who have moved to any of the South American leagues and made it big?" asks Vikram Karekatte "Charles Miller was born in Brazil of an English father and Brazilian mother," says Seamus McCann. "However, he attended Bannister Court School near Southampton and began to organise football when he returned to Brazil at the turn of the century. He was a star forward with Sao Paulo Athletic Club and played international football for Brazil. He became a referee in 1910 and died in 1953 in Sao Paulo. Meanwhile, Dave Gibbs says: "The 1950 exodus to Colombia was probably the most notable example of British players playing in South America in the post war period. Neil Franklyn (Stoke and England) and Charlie Mitten (Man Utd), amongst others, took the money and ran. "The authorities weren't impressed and I know Franklyn never played for England again," he continues. "Also, Maurizio Gaudino moved to a Mexican club side after his spells in Germany and at Man City. Read The Beautiful Game by Chris Taylor, a great book on the history of Latin American Football. I'm sure the answers are in there somewhere." HIGHEST PREMIERSHIP NUMBER "What is the highest shirt number that has been used in the Premiership or Nationwide League? I have seen in the Italian League that somebody wears the number 99 shirt, but has the trend for crazy numbers spread over here yet? Or do those doddering gentleman at the FA insist that we don't go higher than 50?" asks Matthew Gerrard Both Sam Reisman and Jarrod Lythgoe point out that the FA certainly don't insist on going over 50, as Les Ferdinand was offered the 99 shirt after Newcastle signed Alan Shearer, but instead wore the next available number. CAN YOU HELP? "Can you tell me who holds the world record for the fastest sending off (excluding substitutes)?" asks Candy Stephens "Was Taffarel, the Brazil keeper during the last World Cup, playing as a striker for some remote European team prior to the tournament? I have a vague memory of one of the commentators saying something about it but I'm not sure. Can anyone help?" asks Simon Cook Anyone who knows can mail their answer to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can use the same address to send your questions: we'll do our best to answer them.
