webTitle: Business: Royal Bank bangs the drum

fields.headline: Royal Bank bangs the drum
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: If Lloyds TSB needs reassurance on the merits of, making a bid hostile or otherwise, for Abbey National, which was up 13p to £11.84 yesterday, then it might want to cast an eye over the recent performance Royal Bank of Scotland.
fields.body:
If Lloyds TSB needs reassurance on the merits of, making a bid hostile or otherwise, for Abbey National, which was up 13p to £11.84 yesterday, then it might want to cast an eye over the recent performance Royal Bank of Scotland.

Since winning the battle for control of NatWest in March, the bank has seen its reputation in the Square Mile go from strength to strength. After rising 57p to £15.95 yesterday, its stock price has improved almost £8 since the deal was completed. In the past six months its shares have outperformed the FTSE All-Share index by 27%.

The reason is simple: Royal Bank has delivered the promised benefits of the deal and it has not been shy about telling people.

Royal Bank is heading into its quiet period ahead of full-year figures in March and has been busy briefing analysts on the merits of the deal.

One broker to recently receive a visit from Royal Bank's top brass was SG Securities. In a note published yesterday, SG analyst John Tyce predicted that Royal Bank would have no difficulty demonstrating a substantial improvement NatWest's cost/income ratio by 2002.

Furthermore, Mr Tyce reckoned there is still upside to be had from working the NatWest franchise even harder - potentially a £300m upgrade to his pretax profits forecasts for 2003. All of which could justify a share price of £20.60 in Mr Tyce's opinion, something Lloyds TSB might want to note. Its shares closed 10p higher at 725p, nearly 60p off their year's high.

The whole banking sector was in positive territory yesterday. The Asia-focused banks - HSBC, up 38p to £10.10, and Standard Chartered, 4p higher at 950p - fared particularly well. Both were lifted by hopes Fed chairman Alan Greenspan might abandon his leaning toward higher interest rates. That also assisted Barclays, up 20p to £21.13, and Halifax, 28.5p better at 671.5p.

All of which assisted the FTSE 100 index of leading shares to recover from an early 47 point decline to end the day 48.5 stronger at 6,295.

Oil group Shell, up 21.5p to 534.5p, also gave the index a boost as analysts belatedly welcomed Monday's half-yearly update. Both CSFB and Schroder Salomon Smith Barney were said to be putting their clients into the stock.

Such moves could not dis guise what had been a lacklustre day of trading, with most of the big institutions refusing to deal in the run-up to the Christmas break. This did not stop brokers trying to drum up a bit of business.

A couple of this year's favourite takeover tales were dusted down and given another airing. Controls and automation group Invensys picked up 5.25p to 163p on talk that a bid will arrive in the new year. Another tale - one dealers were taking slightly more seriously - was a bid for BG, off 2.25p to 261.5p. In a fresh twist, the bidder for the gas group is not thought to be Shell but a US company.

On the downside, prospective merger twins Glaxo Wellcome, down 37p to £18.55, and SmithKline Beecham, 21.5p lower at 835.5p, had another rough session on talk Schroder Salomon Smith Barney was placing a large line of Glaxo stock in the market at a discount to Monday's closing price.

Apparently Schroder was looking to offload 6m shares for a client at £18.50 each ahead of completion of the merger, which is expected this week. Approval of the deal means there will be a spare place in the FTSE 100 and on last night's closing prices it will go to building materials group Hanson, up 6.25p to 430p.

The performance of Hanson helped the FTSE Mid 250 close 10.2 points higher at 6,480.5, although most traders were concentrating on the performance of rival RMC, down 2p to 554p, ahead of a trading statement on Thursday. The gossips reckon it will not make pleasant reading.

webTitle: In brief: Meet the Parents tops Grinch at UK box office

fields.headline: Meet the Parents tops Grinch at UK box office
fields.standfirst: Plus: Michael Douglas uses internet auctions to help charity; Chris Rock sued for failing to supply copy for website; Olympia Dukakis heads for London stage
fields.trailText: Plus: Michael Douglas uses internet auctions to help charity; Chris Rock sued for failing to supply copy for website; Olympia Dukakis heads for London stage
fields.body:
 Meet the Parents has toppled The Grinch from the top spot at the UK box office. The comedy, which stars Robert De Niro and Ben Stiller, took £2.3m during its first weekend on release, compared to The Grinch's £1.6m. 102 Dalmatians held tight at number three, while Charlie's Angels fell to number four. Arnold Schwarzenegger's new sci-fi film The 6th Day failed to attract many UK cinema-goers, taking just over £500,000 to reach number five.

 Michael Douglas is to sell off some of his personal possessions on his official website to raise money for his favourite charities. A spokesman for the star implied to reporters that the auction would be ongoing. "We want him to write journals from the sets of his movies and there will be exclusive pictures posted on the site. He'll also be going through his movie archives and selling stuff via internet auctions. We've asked him to go through his wardrobes and closets and see if there are clothes and posters he can sell off."

 Comedian Chris Rock is being sued by an internet company who claim he owes them $1m (£680,000) in repayment of fees given to him for content which was never delivered. Z.com has filed a lawsuit in the Los Angeles Superior Court alleging that the Nurse Betty star entered into a preliminary agreement to provide the site with content in April. Rock was advanced $1,075,000 on April 10 with an agreement that it be repaid within 45 days if a final agreement was not reached by June 30. A spokesman for Z.com says, "Despite said actions by plaintiffs, defendants did not execute the agreement by June 30, or at all".

 Ananova reports that Olympia Dukakis is to return to the London stage next February to star in a new play at the Royal Court. Dukakis, who won a Best Supporting Actress Oscar in 1987 for Moonstruck, will appear in Credible Witness by Timberlake Wertenbaker, a story of love and loss in contemporary Britain. Dukakis last appeared in the West End two years ago.

webTitle: General under fire over forces' disabled ban

fields.headline: General under fire over forces' disabled ban
fields.standfirst:
¥ Government back general

Special report: European integration
The issue explained: disabled people in the armed forces
fields.trailText: Human rights campaigners today criticised Britain's most senior military officer after he said disabled people had "no right" to serve in the armed forces.
fields.body:
Human rights campaigners today criticised Britain's most senior military officer after he said disabled people had "no right" to serve in the armed forces.

The chief of the defence staff, Sir Charles Guthrie, said plans to allow disabled people to enter non-combat roles were "ill-conceived".

Disability campaigners attacked his comments and argued he had completely misunderstood the concept of equal opportunities.

Sir Charles told the Royal United Services Institute in London last night that it would be "detrimental" to allow disabled people to serve in the forces.

He said: "Our defence ministers do understand our position and have been robust in the defence of our case during the recent European debate on ending employment discrimination on grounds of age and disability. "I fully understand that those proposing this aspect of employment law were acting with good intentions and for entirely laudable aims.

"But if left unchecked the impact would have had a detrimental effect on the forces by insisting that disabled people had a right to serve.

"We need to guard against such ill-conceived ideas in future."

However, the Royal Association for Disability And Rehabilitation (Radar) said Sir Charles's comments were "inappropriate and patronising".

Spokeswoman Agnes Fletcher said: "He has completely misunderstood the concept of equal opportunities. He seems to think that giving jobs to disabled people is a charitable act.

"Equal opportunities is about getting the right person for the job, and why cut out great swathes of people who might have something very important to contribute?"

Downing Street today stressed that the prime minister, Tony Blair, backed Sir Charles' comments.

A spokesman for Mr Blair pointed out Britain had secured in October an opt-out for armed forces from a clause in Article 13 of the EU Treaty of Amsterdam, which forbids employment discrimination on the grounds of disability or age.

"The prime minister's view, which is shared within Government, is that the armed forces cannot be just another employer.

"If you have people in the military they have to be prepared to fight and there is no such thing as a non-combatant job," said the spokesman. "Anybody who is serving in the armed forces has to be ready to fight."

However, No 10 acknowledged exemptions were made already for women, who are barred from front-line jobs in the services, and for serving military personnel who were permanently injured in the course of their duties.

The spokesman said: "In those instances the armed forces make every effort to ensure they (injured personnel) are re-integrated in some way - always with the proviso that combat effectiveness cannot be compromised."

However, Colin Low, a member of the Disabled Rights Commission, said there was nothing unreasonable about disabled people wanting to be able to serve in the armed forces.

He said: "The general says it is the height of political correctness, but it is not nearly so unreasonable as it might seem at first.

"All we are against is the absolute bar on disabled people serving in the armed forces. We are fully mindful of the need for combat effectiveness."

Lord Ashley of Stoke, chairman of the All Party Parliamentary Disablement Group, said: "By seeking to exclude all disabled people from the armed forces, the generals are besotted with the trench warfare of the First World War.

"Disabled people can make a useful contribution to many areas of service life, especially in this computer age."

However, others leapt to the general's defence.

The Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said: "I have a great deal of sympathy for what he said.

"It's a hard, unpalatable, brutal fact that soldiers have got to be able to fight and if necessary kill, and if you have got a disability that stands in the way of that, then you not only put yourself at risk but all those around you."

In his speech, Sir Charles also warned of the "creeping advance" of a litigation culture and raised the prospect of a subaltern being sued by his platoon for making a decision in the heat of battle.

He said: "What really concerns me about the creeping advance of litigation is that it will breed a group of leaders who may step back from courageous decisions for fear that they will be pursued through the courts if it all goes wrong."

webTitle: Bishop accuses Hague of breaking pledge on race

fields.headline: Bishop accuses Hague of breaking pledge on race
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Macpherson report - one year on
fields.trailText: William Hague suffered a damaging blow yesterday when a Church of England bishop accused him of reneging on a commitment to refrain from making political capital out of the Macpherson report.
fields.body:
William Hague suffered a damaging blow yesterday when a Church of England bishop accused him of reneging on a commitment to refrain from making political capital out of the Macpherson report.

Tom Butler, the Bishop of Southwark, expressed surprise that the Tory leader had criticised the report months after assuring a group of church leaders that he would accept Sir William Macpherson's findings into the murder of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence.

In an interview with Radio 4's Today programme, the bishop said Mr Hague had been "very firm" during the meeting in September that the Tories would not play the race card.

"William Hague actually raised the question of the Macpherson report and said that some people were critical. But he said: 'We haven't said anything about this and we don't think it would be helpful to do so.' I agree with what he said to us in September. I do not think it is helpful."

The bishop said Mr Hague was wrong to criticise the report which had transformed relations between the police and members of ethnic minorities. "Yes there are fewer numbers [of police] but they are policing with the greater support from the community and therefore they are getting the intelligence," he said.

His remarks were an embarrassing blow to Mr Hague who sparked a storm when he said Sir William Macpherson's description of the Metropolitan police as institutionally racist had led to a collapse in police morale.

Tory officials last night angrily rejected the bishop's claim. Central Office produced a written note of the meeting in which Mr Hague reportedly gave no assurance on his stance.

The decision to release minutes of a private meeting demonstrated the determination of Mr Hague to hit back at criticisms of his views on crime. He surprised many Tories on Monday when he dismissed calls for restraint from Damilola Taylor's parents to warn that another Labour government would lead to more tragedies in the inner cities.

The bishop, whose diocese covers Peckham, where Damilola was killed, said it was "foolish" to link falling police numbers to Damilola's death. "With this particular crime, we don't know what happened. It is very foolish to speculate."

The commission for racial equality is to write to the political parties expressing its fear that the row over police numbers, stop and search and the murder of Damilola will break the political consensus not to use the race card in the election.

The CRE chairman, Gurbux Singh, has been in private talks with the parties to persuade them to again sign the compact they agreed prior to the 1997 general election. The compact was a publicly agreed understanding that no party would use raceto gain votes.

webTitle: Comment: Sudden care for our morale

fields.headline: Sudden care for our morale
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The customary practice of politicians in experimenting with the variables that impact on the lives of citizens is nothing new. However, there is something unusual about the current debate on race and policing.
fields.body:
The customary practice of politicians in experimenting with the variables that impact on the lives of citizens is nothing new. However, there is something unusual about the current debate on race and policing.

It is bewildering how the public has been misled about the effects of the Macpherson inquiry on police morale. William Hague, the Tory leader, fiercely argues that the correlation between the inquiry and low police morale is undisputed. The Police Federation, which purportedly represents the views of the rank and file, would go as far as blaming the poor health of the station cat on the Macpherson report.

The question that has yet to be asked is: what is the motive? There is an unprecedented interest in police morale - a problem hitherto deemed by politicians to be merely part and parcel of doing police work.

It is fact borne out by history that when minorities begin to challenge the rituals and practices which have served a homogenised society for the benefit of the dominant group, that challenge is seen as a threat.

The Kerner report was completed after the 1960's riots in the United States. It condemned and exposed police racism in many of the US police departments, in the way they dealt with the minority ethnic communities.

But the report led to powerful condemnation by a number of politicians of the day. The police unions representing white officers followed the same theme, relentlessly arguing about unfair criticism and claiming that the police had lost confidence in policing the streets.

The social unrest continued as police administrators remained in denial mode. They were relying on the backing of the politicians in claiming that the existence of racism was a figment of people's imagination, only asserted by the crimogenic sections of the black community.

There is a simple lesson to be learned from those US events by British politicians who complain that the pendulum has swung too far in favour of the "liberal elite" who prescribe racial sensitivity. Trivialising for political gain the outcomes of any public inquiry that aims to act as a change agent to improve the quality of lives of all citizens is counterproductive.

Comments of this kind, benevolent as they may be, will be used (and already have been) by the rightwing lobby as a licence to reclaim turf and return to the "good old days".

In policing, that will mean the resurrection of the past. The police will do many more stop and searches but understand little about the ideas underpinning their actions. The ineffective "drag net" technique, where a net is cast over a community and then pulled in the hope of catching muggers, will become a legitimate police tactic. This was the very tactic that led to the riots in Brixton in 1981.

"Driving whilst black", a fictional offence which many black people will have encountered, will again become the subject of routine practice for some officers. Furthermore, the important inroads the police have made because of the Macpherson report in investigating race hate crime and winning the confidence of all sections of the community, will be seen as an unaffordable luxury. It will become regarded as a byproduct of political correctness and discarded.

Last but not least the torrent of racism which black and Asian police officers face internally but are now confident in challenging, will increase. The assertion that such officers have a "chip on their shoulders" when they confront racism will be back on the agenda.

As to the sudden interest in police morale, when the Sheehy inquiry in 1993 comprehensively recommended against preserving the very few perks such as rent allowance which young officers got in joining the police - recommendations which led to a tangible and not a fictional drop in morale - the then home secretary did not bat an eyelid.

When police pay failed to keep up with the challenges of policing in a way which has led to the current recruitment crises, very few politicians paid attention to the drop in police morale - even as many officers became eligible to claim social security to boost their income.

The public is now told and expected to believe that police morale is regarded as important, and that a return to the golden age of policing is within our grasp if only the Macpherson report hadn't come along and if only the acceptance of institutional racism can now be edited out from police and political vocabularies.

 Dr Ali Dizaei is a superintendent in the Metropolitan police, currently head of operations in Notting Hill, Kensington and Chelsea. He is on the executive and legal advisor to the National Black Police Association.

webTitle: Disabled people in the armed forces

fields.headline: Disabled people in the armed forces
fields.standfirst:
Who should fill the ranks of Britain's armed forces? The chief of the defence staff, Sir Charles Guthrie, thinks that inclusion of disabled people would be "detrimental". So should they be allowed to serve? Mark Oliver examines the issues
SocietyGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Who should fill the ranks of Britain's armed forces? The chief of the defence staff, Sir Charles Guthrie, thinks that inclusion of disabled people would be "detrimental". So should they be allowed to serve? Mark Oliver examines the issues.
fields.body:
What's all the fuss about?
Sir Charles Guthrie, Britain's most senior military officer, triggered a debate about who should be allowed into the forces after he told the Royal Services Institute in London that disabled people had "no right" to serve.

There was more to being a soldier, Sir Charles argued, than "cradling babies".

Disabled groups have branded the comments a misunderstanding of the concept of equal opportunities. The government has supported the views of Sir Charles, as have the Tories, who said judgments need to be made case by case and not by a European "rights agenda".

What is the current policy on disabled people in the army?
Many desk jobs and other types of work within the forces which do not require the fitness levels of active service personnel are carried out by civilians and are open to the disabled, according to senior army sources.

However, all uniformed personnel have to be capable of carrying out military tasks.

The prime minister's spokesman said today: "If you have people in the military they have to be prepared to fight and there is no such thing as a non-combatant job."

What prompted the general's comments?
He expressed concern at European moves which some have interpreted as an attempt to give disabled people the legal right to join up. A year ago the European commission proposed a non-discrimination package based on article 13 of the Treaty of Amsterdam. The package included a proposal for a directive prohibiting discrimination in employment on grounds of racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.

However, Downing Street pointed out today that Britain had secured in October an opt-out for the armed forces from the relevant clause in article 13.

"The prime minister's view, which is shared within government, is that the armed forces cannot be just another employer," a spokesman said.

But could the treaty realistically force the services to accept disabled applicants?
Jo Sawyer, a human rights lawyer at Liberty, thinks not. She said: "General Guthrie's comments appear a little misconceived. The European Convention doesn't mean everyone has a right to serve in the armed forces in any capacity. "It simply means that everyone has a right not to be discriminated against. There's a balancing exercise. Clearly it depends on the nature of the job and the individual's capacity, and the extent of their disability."

What are the benefits of allowing disabled people into the services?
Supporters say that opening the ranks to disabled people would achieve two goals: it would allow hitherto-excluded patriots to serve their country in uniform, and help the military to overcome its recruitment problem.

Agnes Fletcher, spokeswoman for the Royal Association for Disability and Rehabilitation (Radar) said: "He has completely misunderstood the concept of equal opportunities. He seems to think that giving jobs to disabled people is a charitable act.

"Equal opportunities is about getting the right person for the job. And why cut out great swathes of people who might have something very important to contribute?"

Aberdeen South MP Anne Begg, who uses a wheelchair, said: "What really annoys us is when someone who doesn't know us or know what we are capable of says we can't do a job, simply because they themselves can't imagine how we could do it. That is what has held disabled people back for so long."

What do disabled war heroes think?
Falklands hero Simon Weston, who received horrific burns when HMS Sir Galahad was hit, dismissed the row as "a lot of noise about nothing".

"When you join the army you have to go through rigorous training whether you are a cook, whether you are a medic, whether you are a bandsman. There is no scope for making an assault course easy for disabled people."

Mr Weston urged campaigners to keep the issue "in context". He added: "There are disabled people within the armed forces but I think a lot of those guys were injured and allowed to stay on. "I was offered to continue serving as a storeman but I couldn't see myself handing out equipment I could never use, so I decided to leave.

"I do not think he meant anything in any way derogatory to disabled people. I think his sentiments are correct in the fact that we can't have disabled people on the frontline but there are disabled who work for the MoD."

What about women and homosexuals in the forces?
Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, lifted the ban on gays and lesbians in the armed forces earlier this year and has said that the army will soon have to allow women to fight in the infantry.

Mr Hoon said that he was becoming increasingly convinced that women wanted to serve as combat soldiers and should be allowed to do so. They already occupy frontline roles in artillery regiments and other areas.

The Tories, however, have said they would consider repealing the government's moves on homosexuals in the services.

Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, told the Conservative party conference in October that the party will not tolerate "political correctness" in military matters and will counter European rules on defence.

He said: "Our only aim is to have a professional fighting force for this country. The suggestion of women on the front line is PC gone mad. The most professional fighting force in the world, the Israeli army, has had to repeal rules on women in combat because it didn't work."

Is the make-up of the forces an issue elsewhere?
In America there was a similar debate when Duncan Hunter, a Republican congressman from California, pressed the Pentagon - without overt success - to overthrow what he regarded as outmoded standards requiring all soldiers to be able to carry a pack and slog across rough country.

He said: "Everybody doesn't hike over the hill and everyone doesn't have to be able to run five miles."

His idea is that the disabled could be recruited for work behind the lines, where, he argued, the battle is as likely to be fought on computers as in foxholes.

webTitle: 'Neil won't be sidelined' says Scotsman chief

fields.headline: 'Neil won't be sidelined' says Scotsman chief
fields.trailText: 5pm: The Scotsman's new editor-in-chief has denied that his appointment will sideline publisher Andrew Neil, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
John McGurk, new editor-in-chief at the Scotsman and Scotland on Sunday, has rebuffed reports that he has been appointed to sideline the papers' publisher, Andrew Neil.

Mr McGurk rubbished reports that the paper's proprietor, Aidan Barclay, had brought him in to "clip the wings" of Mr Neil.

He also dismissed as "newspaper tittle-tattle" reports that Scotsman editor Rebecca Hardy had been sidelined by Mr Neil, who wanted her to move to the job of group features editor across the Scotsman titles.

Mr McGurk told MediaGuardian.co.uk that his appointment was to "help provide support for senior editorial staff, including Andrew Neil and Rebecca Hardy".

Ms Hardy joined earlier this year from the Daily Mail after the sudden departures of editors Tim Luckhurst and Alan Ruddock.

webTitle: Inquest on nerve gas victim may be reopened

fields.headline: Inquest on nerve gas victim may be reopened
fields.trailText: The inquest into the death of a young airman in a nerve gas experiment 47 years ago could be reopened, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
The inquest into the death of a young airman in a nerve gas experiment 47 years ago could be reopened, it emerged yesterday.

In a surprising twist, Wiltshire police officers, who have been investigating chemical warfare experiments on humans, are referring back to the local coroner the death of Ronald Maddison, 20.

The move implies that detectives believe the misadventure verdict of the original inquest, held in secret in 1953, was wrong.

Only a handful of inquests are reopened in any year. Ultimately, it is up to the high court, with the consent of the attorney general after a report from the coroner, to decide whether to hold a new inquest.

For months a Wiltshire police squad has been investigating the death which happened during the cold war at the Ministry of Defence's Porton Down chemical warfare establishment near Salisbury.

Yesterday, Alan Care of the solicitors Russell Jones and Walker said on behalf of the Maddison family: "The only reason I can see to reopen this inquest is for the coroner and jury to consider an unlawful killing verdict. I cannot envisage anything more serious for the MoD who ran Porton Down for many years."

Maddison was part of an experiment involving 396 men which was aimed at establishing the amount of nerve gas which when applied to the clothed or bare skin of men would cause incapacitation or death.

But the experiment went tragically wrong when he died 40 minutes after liquid nerve gas was deliberately dripped on to his arm by Porton scientists in a gas chamber.

Ten days after his death, an inquest was held behind closed doors "in the interests of national security". Only officials and Maddison's father were allowed to attend, but he was sworn to secrecy by the authorities.

According to his family, he never told his wife or any relatives what he heard in the secret inquest.

Porton Down now admits that the government hushed up details of the death as it wanted to hide from the public the extent of the human experiments and British work on nerve gas during the cold war. The coroner's papers on the death have never been published. A fresh inquest would almost certainly be held in public.

More than 20,000 human guinea pigs have taken part in experiments at Porton Down since 1916. The establishment has conducted the longest running programme of chemical warfare experiments on humans in the world.

Wiltshire police are also examining claims that human guinea pigs were duped into taking part in poison gas tests when they thought that they had volunteered for research to find a cure for the common cold.

webTitle: Blair and Hague clash over police

fields.headline: Blair and Hague clash over police
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The Conservative leader, William Hague, today maintained his controversial criticism of the government over the Macpherson report and policing policy, clashing with the prime minister, Tony Blair, in the Commons.
fields.body:
The Conservative leader, William Hague, today maintained his controversial criticism of the government over the Macpherson report and policing policy, clashing with the prime minister, Tony Blair, in the Commons.

Mr Hague, who was criticised this week for linking his attacks on home office policy to the murder of schoolboy Damilola Taylor, resumed his offensive asking the prime minister if he agreed police morale was low.

Mr Blair, during the last prime minister's question time before Christmas, responded that the main reason for low morale was the previous government's cutting of the police's housing allowance.

Mr Hague reprised his opinion that the police had been undermined by the Macpherson report into the killing of the black teenager Stephen Lawrence, and that its effectiveness has been curtailed by fears at stopping and searching people from minority groups.

However, Mr Blair said: "I said after the Macpherson report that it is extremely important for police to continue to use their stop and search powers these powers are still in use. They are in use as much concerning ethnic groups as the white population."

Against a backdrop of a rowdy Commons, Mr Blair commented for the first time on the affair involving Mr Hague's Macpherson comments which has seen him labelled a racist in some quarters. Mr Blair said: "I am not suggesting the honourable gentleman is a racist, I am suggesting he is an opportunist", which triggered an angry reaction from the opposition front bench.

The prime minister added that during the Christmas period, perhaps an appropriate slogan for Mr Hague was: "Stop and think."

Mr Blair conceded that while the numbers of policing had gone down during his term in office, levels had been falling in London for ten years. He said upcoming figures would show that recruitment levels would rise and that currently in Greater Manchester 1,700 applications were being processed.

The prime minister said that his was the party investing in the police and demanded Mr Hague reveal whether he intended to match the government's level of investment.

Mr Hague said the prime minister was "off his head" if he thought the Conservatives would cut policing budgets.

The Tory leader began his attack on the government's crime policy with an accusation that its electronic tagging policy had led to 1,000 crimes being committed, including two rapes by people released early and tagged.

Mr Blair said that while it was true some crimes had been committed, tagging was an additional resource and that all governments, including the opposition's, used early release schemes.

Mr Hague said: "There has been no clearer demonstration of this government's complacency on crime."

During question time there was a disturbance in the public gallery as a protestor, reportedly a foreign national, shouted down onto the Commons but was ignored by Mr Blair as he delivered his answers.

webTitle: Lap dancer, Pop star, and Sinister drag act

fields.headline: Lap dancer, Pop star, and Sinister drag act
fields.trailText: LLOYD'S SELL HELL
fields.body:
LLOYD'S SELL HELL

Good effing afternoon, top trader Lloyd Fiver of London here again. Well, there's been nobody in the office for the last two days except for muggins. The Fiver was feeling a touch melancholy earlier today. Teamtalk reported that cunning old Egyptian fox Mohammed Al-Fulham was planning a Harrods deposit-box style raid on the Catalan capital. His target? webTitle: Business: Fed caution disappoints

fields.headline: Rates decision:  Fed caution disappoints
fields.trailText: The US central bank surprised many by keeping interest rates unchanged yesterday but indicated that the risks of a recession might have replaced those of inflation as a result of the sharp slowdown in the US economy.
fields.body:
The US central bank surprised many by keeping interest rates unchanged yesterday but indicated that the risks of a recession might have replaced those of inflation as a result of the sharp slowdown in the US economy.

US investors had expected the Federal Reserve to issue a less equivocal statement on the chances of an interest rate cut early next year. Share prices gave up some of their earlier gains immediately after the Fed released its decision.

In keeping interest rates at 6.5% and insisting that "some inflation risks" persist, the federal open market committee disappointed some . Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at ING Barings, called the decision "dreadful and stupid" .

Others took solace from the committee view "that the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future".

The FOMC said that it would continue to watch developments keenly, suggesting that it would be minded to act at its next meeting, at the end of January.

In a speech that fuelled optimism about a rate cut earlier this month, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, suggested that the board had changed course.

Yesterday's statement echoed his speech when it stated: "The drag on demand and profits from rising energy costs, as well as eroding consumer confidence, reports of substantial shortfalls in sales and earnings, and stress in some segments of the financial markets suggest that economic growth may be slowing further.

"While some inflation risks persist, they are diminished by the more moderate pace of economic activity and by the absence of any indication that longer-term inflation expectations have increased."

Ian Shepherdson at High Frequency Economics said the profits warnings and signs of a slowdown had led the US markets to expect a more pronounced policy shift.

webTitle: Parents: kids are tougher than we think

fields.headline: Nightmare before Christmas
fields.standfirst: How far do children base their fears on the anxieties of their parents?  Julie Myerson  on a macabre Yuletide experience that reassured her of one thing: kids are tougher than we think
fields.trailText: How far do children base their fears on the anxieties of their parents? Julie Myerson on a macabre Yuletide experience that reassured her of one thing: kids are tougher than we think
fields.body:
Three Christmases ago, we almost gave our three children the fright of their lives. We never meant to lead them into something so horrific. Nothing I have seen before or since has matched it for sheer, ludicrous, Hammer Horror hideousness.

We left the stark glare of a Rome morning and descended a flight of stone steps. At the bottom, amid ivory crucifixes and the standard blood-weeping Madonna, a plump priest was handing out pamphlets and warning, "No photographs."

"Goodness." We shivered, holding tight on to our little ones, noticing the shadows and then the smell. "This looks... interesting."

We walked along a passageway and into the first chapel. And then, "My God," from Jonathan.

"What?" I whipped my head around and immediately traced the source of the odour.

Everywhere we looked, from wall to wall, across every lintel - even strung from the ceiling - were human skulls, human bones, entire skeletons. Piles of them sunk into every wall. Where most baroque chapels boast filigree plasterwork, this one had filigree bone collage.

On one wall, someone had been witty with - what? Femurs? On another, ribcages joined end to end to produce a bizarre leaf effect. Over there, a pile of skulls, stacked in a neat six-foot totem, still boasted cracked, yellow-toothed grins, as well as ghastly, greying remnants of skin and hair.

The children just stared.

We'd made a mistake. The kids' section of our (normally reliable) Time Out Guide had encouraged a family trip to Santa Maria della Concezione. We'd believed them, and now here we were in Pol Pot City. Frantically, we lurched into Responsible Parent Mode. There was no question of grabbing our babes and running from this charnel house; instinctively, we knew that would transform this trip into the fuel for a lifetime's nightmares. So, breezily: "Wow, how clever, to think up such a fun and interesting use for all those dead people!"

Jonathan gave a fake, compliant laugh and launched into a struggling translation of the leaflet, explicating the history of the chapels, the honour of being "buried" here, how it gives homage to God and so on. Oh, how he tried.

"I like it, it's... nice," said Chloë, uncertainly.

"Better than being all lonely and buried," remarked Jacob.

"And someone," I added enthusiastically, "has worked really hard to make all these pretty patterns."

"And then his bones got put in too!" guessed Chloë presciently.

"I like the whole ones!" shrieked Raphael, five, as he ran into the adjoining chapel.

By the time we stumbled back up into the bright streets, Jonathan and I were shaken. The kids wanted an ice cream. We wandered up the Via Veneto and talked about Roman emperors.

There are bone churches all over Italy, we later learned. Monks used to deem it a great honour to have their remains boiled down and used in this Blue Peter-ish way. Even so, in our family, "bone church" has become the standard by which you gruesome things are measured. "Not as bad as the Bone Church" is a phrase you frequently hear in the Myerson household. Strange, then, that the experience seemed to leave no scars, no nightmares.

Is it that children at that age - or any age - look to us for their responses and tend only to feel bad, scared or upset when we tell them they should? Or are they just innocent of the brute finality of so many stacked human remains?

A bit of both, probably. But I do know this: while I'm not advocating that anyone rush their toddlers to the nearest bone church, it is sobering and comforting to realise the extent to which our offspring's emotional outlook is shaped by what we grown-ups suggest it should be. How many parents have we overheard solicitously asking a child whether she or he is sad or worried because the au pair is going back to Hungary, a new baby is coming, or someone called the Princess of Wales is dead?

In fact, it rarely occurs to young children to find these things alarming or upsetting of their own accord. Left to themselves, they rightly shrug them off as immaterial. So why do so many parents seem to want their children to emote like Victorian heroines? Am I alone in finding it as ill-judged a bit of parenting as, well, taking your kids to a chapel filled with stripped human carcasses?

webTitle: Move over Jesus - Santa's coming to town

fields.headline: Move over Jesus - Santa's coming to town
fields.standfirst: A new survey has revealed that more young people associate Santa Claus with Christmas than they do Christ.  Joanna Moorhead  wonders how the son of God lost out to an obese OAP
fields.trailText: A new survey has revealed that more young people associate Santa Claus with Christmas than they do Christ. Joanna Moorhead wonders how the son of God lost out to an obese OAP
fields.body:
Poor old St Nicholas. According to legend, the fourth-century priest was a self-effacing chap who preferred to be out of the limelight. A dab hand at good works, he wasn't the sort of character who went looking for praise. So when he saw a pauper's family in dire need, he decided to climb on their roof and lob a few coins down the chimney by way of an anonymous gift.

So far so good, but when the coins landed on a stocking drying in the fireplace the family heard the noise and discovered their philanthropic visitor. Alas for St Nick, far from slipping away quietly into the shadows, he earned himself a place in history: 16 centuries on, his name is known to children everywhere as the generous, cheery Christmas present-bearer.

So far, so depressing for the bashful do-gooder, but now things have gone from bad to worse. A new poll reveals that, at the dawn of Christianity's third millennium, he has overtaken his boss as the embodiment of Yuletide. Of 1,200 eight-to-16-year-olds questioned by media buying agency MediaCom TMB, 67% said they associate this time of year with the red-suited, white-bearded version of St Nick, Santa Claus; only 8% link Christmas with Christ himself.

At first sight, this would seem further confirmation that Christmas is crassly commercialised, merely materialistic. But irony piles on irony because, in this post-Christian age, there are signs that Father Christmas, the figure bequeathed us by St Nicholas, is achieving a quasi-religious status. This has gone so far that church leaders have now launched a campaign to end what they call "the cult of Father Christmas" and restore St Nicholas as the symbol of the festive season. Are we moving towards a time when Santa Claus is regarded as more sacred than God?

Obviously his own son Simon, eight, is fully in the picture, and Evans assumed that everyone else's kid would be, too.

How wrong he was. Within hours of Evans's clanger, lips were quivering all over the village of Long Buckby in Northamptonshire. Not the children's, of course: most of them took the news on the chin and merely rerouted their wish lists away from Santa's website and towards Dad's mobile phone. No, it was the parents who were devastated: they had hoped their little babes would still believe in Father Christmas at 18, presumably. Or at least until secondary school.

"He did upset a lot of people, I'm afraid," says Jeanette Goddard, head teacher of Long Buckby Junior School. "And most of the comments came from parents - I think it's fair to say that the reference to Father Christmas passed a lot of the children by. But parents do get very irate about their children being told Father Christmas doesn't exist."

Some people, she said, had also got annoyed about why the vicar had been allowed to address the school, which is non-denominational. "But these days most children get so little religious input, if we didn't let the vicar talk to them, it would be missing from their lives completely."

Why did the parents care so much? If the vicar had told the children there was no God, it is hard to imagine there would have been more of an outcry. Perhaps less: while some children are raised as non-believers in God, almost none are raised as non-believers in Father Christmas. It is no coincidence that Santa's stature has grown over the last four or five decades in inverse proportion to the decline of belief in God because, however happy we've all been to cast off the idea of deity and church, we are not quite so comfortable with the idea of bringing up children whose lives are untouched by spirituality.

We love the idea that they believe in this godlike figure who sweeps through the whole world bringing good fortune to all because, in our hearts, we mourn the fact that we don't believe in him any more: we love the simplicity of the tale because, in an unfair and complex world, the story of Father Christmas is a powerful parable about equality, justice, and putting children first.

"I think most adults secretly would like to believe in Father Christmas, too. I know I would," says mother-of-three Delia Perry. "So, of course, you make a lot of it, and when they find out, you're a bit upset. My son Carl, who's 10, found out last year. I was very angry to discover that he was being teased by other children in his class over it. Carl came to talk to me about it and I found it difficult to just say it wasn't true - we talked about him being a spirit, and about how the spirit of Father Christmas definitely exists even if the man himself doesn't."

The reasons for this are not hard to fathom: parents want to give their children a glimpse of that magic and mysticism that so infused the lives of our ancestors but which seems so lacking in our own age.

"As GK Chesterton said, when people stop believing in God they don't believe in nothing, they believe in anything," says Catholic priest Father Dominic Allain of the Holy Ghost parish in Balham, south London. "There's a part of our psyche that needs something beyond our own experience to believe in, and Father Christmas fits the bill. It seems to represent a kind of primitive need in parents. It's almost like: how lovely that children can believe - and how awful that we grow out of it."

Even parents who go to tortuous lengths to avoid lying to their children buy into the fib, backing it up with visits to a grotto and letters to Lapland. An NOP survey for Woolworth's published this week shows not only that 77% of 7-9-year-olds still believe in Father Christmas, but also that three-quarters of 4-6-year-olds think he spends the rest of the year drinking tea, making toys with the elves and getting ready for next year. No wonder some adults seem to have become a bit confused about what the church's role is in the whole Father Christmas hoo-ha - why else would an outraged Long Buckby mother, Rosemary Bateman, have told the Daily Mail that it was "outrageous" for anyone to have spilled the beans to the children, "let alone anyone from the church"? Since when has spinning pagan myths been central to a priest's job description?

When our little darlings start to smell a rat, we are mortified. We phone each other up to pass on the sad news: little Emily doesn't believe in him any more. Seems only yesterday she was hanging up her stocking for the first time, and now she's cottoned on. We see it as a rite of passage, and mourn the loss of "innocence" in our children: but we don't stop to think what it means to them to discover we've been telling them porkies for years. After all, if mum and dad have been lying through their teeth about Father Christmas, what else have they been lying about? It is probably the first time in a child's life when the landscape changes, and things that seemed cast-iron suddenly aren't cast-iron any more.

The only places where Father Christmas hasn t made it big, unsurprisingly enough, are in those families and cultures which retain a strong faith-basis. For them, Santa is usually relegated to a walk-on part. After all, if you really do believe in angels singing and a star leading the way to a tiny baby born to save the world, then a fellow in a red suit who was spotted on a fourth-century rooftop probably doesn t hold a candle, does he?

webTitle: Childish things

fields.headline: Childish things
fields.standfirst: Board games
fields.trailText: Board games
fields.body:
There is a tradition in this country that Christmas isn't complete unless the family has sat round the table and played "a game". It is as much part of the ritual as the Queen's speech, Only Fools and Horses reruns and the dog choking on half a cracker. Except that it is far more sinister. I have noticed that people aren't at their best when playing games and have discovered sides to members of my family and friends during Trivial Pursuit that I would rather had remained undisclosed. No kid ever gets over the sight of Grandma flinging the board across the sitting room. So, in the interests of avoiding unseemly episodes in living rooms across the land on December 25, we've picked the good, the bad and the potentially ugly games as a rough guide to keeping the peace. Our youngest player is six, and our oldest has a bus pass.

All the games listed are available from www.etoys.co.uk, or from leading toy shops.

Electronic Spin the Bottle
Character Games, £12.95

Who can play:
"Ages 9 to 99", but the six-year-old enjoyed it most.

The rules:
Too simple. Think of a forfeit and spin the bottle. One of three options lights up: Truth, Dare or Kiss. The player to whom the bottle points then takes up the challenge issued by the electronic voice. Tasks include "Name the person with the worst nose", "Kiss the player on your left's feet", and my favourite, "Sing Three Blind Mice like a rapper".

How long?
As long as you like.

Any good?
Probably a giggle after a sherry or two. Offence could be taken by the person with the worst nose.

Fun rating:
5/10

Sulk rating:
5/10

Stare
Ravensburger, £16.99

Who can play:
Sold for 6-12s, but adults joined in successfully.

The rules:
Pretty simple. You have 30 seconds to study a picture, on which you must then answer questions. The more correct answers, the further you move round the board.

How long?
About 20 minutes - short enough for nobody to get twitchy.

Any good?
Yes. Stare is harder than it looks; the pictures can be anything from a Batman comic strip, to a photo of a pizza, to a masterpiece by Manet. Unfortunately, reproduction is poor. Anyone can play and there isn't much scope for a row.

Fun rating:
7/10

Sulk rating:
1/10

Who Wants to Be a Millionaire (Junior)
Upstarts, £24.95

Who can play:
Box states 8-12, but good for adults too.

The rules:
To win the crispy million-pound-note prize, answer 15 questions.

How long?
Half an hour to an hour.

Any good?
A few tantrums over who got to be the questionmaster, and questioned loyalties when using the Ask the Audience lifeline. Some scope for cheating on the 50/50. Lots of bank-notes to lose, but ample opportunity to ham it up as Chris Tarrant. The question card was too easy to see. Would have been more fun if the kids hadn't sulked so much.

Fun rating:
7/10

Sulk rating:
9/10

Mr Potato Head Says
MB Games, £19.99

Who can play:
Up to four players, aged from 3 upwards.

The rules:
To follow Mr Potato Head's instructions along the lines of Simon Says. If you follow the instruction, you win two chips.

How long?
A game lasts for about 10 minutes, when Mr PH calls time.

Any good?
The kids' favourite, which we had to play again and again. Adults initially thought it was too easy, but many were caught out when they least expected it. Mr PH has an impressive number of phrases and manages to be quite funny - for a potato. On the down side, there is masses of scope for parts getting lost, and the box in which the game arrives is hopeless for keeping everything together. Expect to find parts in the hoover.

Fun rating:
7/10

Sulk rating:
2/10

Rapidough
London Game Company, £24.99

Who can play:
Box says 8 to 80, but was adaptable so our six-year-old could join in.

How long?
About 20 minutes.

The rules:
Easy. Like Pictionary, but using dough. A card determines whether teams are modelling the same piece or separate ones. Team-mates guess what the model is; the first to guess wins. The "dough plugger" takes some dough from the losers - first to lose their dough is out.

Any good?
Easily the favourite. The words range from the simple, like bone, to harder ones, like galleon. Rapidough has all the right elements - funny, requires lots of shouting out, has an element of suspense, and all are on an equal footing. Watch out for bits of dough in the carpet, though.

Fun rating:
10/10

Sulk rating:
1/10

Speechless
BV Leisure, £12.99

Who can play:
Age 10 to adult, although we adapted it so that our six-year-old could join in. Four to 16 can play.

The rules:
Charades, using paper and pen - only much more complicated. Players move pieces round a board and the colour of the square they land on determines the category of word to draw.

How long?
Too long.

Any good?
Tears, quarrels and sulks - and that was just the adults. Some words are impossible; the timer supposedly allows 60 seconds, but it seemed much shorter. Looks like a great game, but won't fulfil the family criteria. Could still be excellent fun for grown-ups, or very patient over-10s.

Fun rating:
2/10

Sulk rating:
9/10

webTitle: The panel

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Tomorrow's white paper proposes to relax restrictions - including whether prospective parents are smokers or overweight - to speed up the adoption procedure. Is this a good idea?
fields.trailText: The Question: Tomorrow's white paper proposes to relax restrictions - including whether prospective parents are smokers or overweight - to speed up the adoption procedure. Is this a good idea?
fields.body:
Felicity Collier
Chief executive, British Agencies for Adoption

There needs to be far better support in place for adoptive parents - and the children they adopt from local authority care who have more complex needs than the newborns adopted 30 years ago. The prevailing mythology is that politically correct social workers block wonderful, loving parents from adopting. In our experience, that is not the case. If parents want to adopt, they are putting themselves on the line and it is important that they get a fair hearing, but it is also important to remember that the children in the care system need protecting.

Verdict: Yes

Christine Freeman
British parent who adopted from abroad

My adopted son is from Mexico. I adopted him in Canada, rather than here, because there is a much more open policy on adoption there. Here, inter-country adoption is shaped by immigration policy. Reforms to the present system are a good thing: the reason why so many parents have to adopt abroad is because they have been excluded from adopting here because of the restrictive policies. The one restriction here I am in favour of is the one on adoptive parents who smoke because I think it is bad for a child to go into an environment where parents smoke.

Verdict: Yes

Sean Galligan
Chair, Albert Kennedy Trust

The government has made adoption too complicated and has ruled out far too many prospective adopters. These rules were originally established to make sure that the right kind of parents were chosen, but turning someone down because they are overweight or live in the wrong area is taking things to extremes and does not put the best interests of the child first. Sexuality should not be a factor which stops people from adopting. Saying gays and lesbians can adopt is saying they have the same legal rights as heterosexuals. It is a long, slow battle towards equality.

Verdict: Yes

Monica Duck
Director, Post-Adoption Centre

I support the idea of improved adoption services. It is very important to ensure that all parties in the adoption have the sort of services that will meet the children's needs. One of the most important things for parents is to have a package of post-adoption support to help support the child through their formative years. Adoptive children are now older and more likely to have emotional problems. The most important thing is to recruit families that are child-centred and able to meet the complex needs of these children, rather than focusing on matters that are irrelevant.

Verdict: Yes

Ann van Meeuwen
Principal policy officer, Barnardo's

We would like to see more children benefiting, but adoption these days is not straightforward because it is rarely of newborn babies. We would like to see the government provide post-adoption support and the money to pay for this support. If parents knew that adopting didn't mean just being left to get on with it and that financial and other forms of support were available, it might encourage more to come forward. The majority of parents who adopt are white, middle-class and childless; and more people from minority groups and single parents are needed.

Verdict: Yes

webTitle: Parents: Children and advertising

fields.headline: To insolvency and beyond
fields.standfirst: In Sweden advertising aimed at children is banned. Here it's open season.  Daniel Lee  asks how parents can manage their kids' expectations - and whether they can afford not to
fields.trailText: In Sweden advertising aimed at children is banned. Here it's open season. Daniel Lee asks how parents can manage their kids' expectations - and whether they can afford not to
fields.body:
Have you managed to buy a Bob the Builder figure yet? Manufacturers may have plastered ads all over comics, billboards, TV, films and the internet, but I can't find one local shop with any member of the construction team for my son.

It is testament to the power of marketing that the demand for a particular toy can be so inflamed that its popularity burns out the country's supply. And, as with the infamous Buzz Lightyear sell-out of Christmas 1997, the more rare and unobtainable a toy becomes, the more rampant the children's desire for the toys they have set their hearts on will be.

At Christmas, marketing campaign temperatures, for these toys for younger children and for fashion or lifestyle accessories aimed at older children, soar off the thermometer. It is not hard to understand why. Many toy stores, such as Hamleys, make approximately 50% of their annual profit in December. Britain's toy market is worth about £1.66bn a year, while designer clothes and CDs aimed at kids are also multi-million-pound industries. Ultimately, parents are the target for this commercial blitz and it can be difficult to know how to handle it, particularly if money is tight.

Jan Thompson, a 34-year-old single mother in Willesden, north London, explains how marketing affects her and her 13-year-old daughter Gill: "When we see ads for Nike or Reebok trainers, it's very hard to explain that we can't afford them while half of Gill's classmates wear them. It makes her feel as if she isn't as good her friends."

Besides being strapped for cash, there are other reasons for people resisting commercialism. Elizabeth Peck, 37, a writer and her TV producer husband Mike, 45, live in Bristol, They try to control carefully what their children Amelia, four, and Joe, two, watch and read.

"I allow them to watch only Teletubbies and Tweenies," Elizabeth says. "We keep a close eye on what they see and would never let Amelia on the internet on her own. I don't want their play and toys to be determined by adverts. We want them to find their own way of playing."

Keeping control while you are bombarded by hard-sell messages can, however, be difficult. The Llewellyns, in Wimbledon, prefer to concentrate their efforts on defusing "pester power" rather than shielding their sons Thomas, eight, and Hector, six, from commercial pressures.

"TV ads don't seem to have a significant effect," says 36-year-old mother Philippa Llewellyn. "Even though Hector may be influenced by them, it is for only a short time. Thomas seems more influenced by peer pressure than adverts. Older children at school seem to give him the idea that Pokemon or Gameboy is the must-have toy."

The peer-pressure phenomenon is well observed. "It is from upper primary school and above that children get into wearing the same gear and get prone to peer pressure," comments educational psychologist Jenni Smith, "but for younger children marketing pressures tend to go over their heads."

Not all advertisers agree: earlier this year, the Co-op announced its decision to stop promoting high-sugar, high-fat, "unhealthy" foods during children's viewing times; and the Tesco supermarket chain operates a similar voluntary code. In Sweden, a ban on television advertising aimed at children under 12 has been in effect for the past decade, and there have been moves in Ireland this year to follow suit.

But television is not the only battle-ground. The Internet is a rapidly-growing forum for child-oriented marketing, with sites ranging from pokemon.com and barbie.com to lego.com. Richard Marshall is a director of Tullo Marshall Warren, a leading direct marketing agency that is increasingly targeting web users. He argues that these types of sites "provide a safe environment for children to play online".

"Today's children are highly computer-literate," he continues, "and if the internet empowers them to influence what they want for Christmas, so be it - even if it is a bit more clinical than the letter to Santa."

So just how ethical is it for businesses to use advertising to pitch to children - people whom in most other spheres (voting, sex and legal documents, for example) are treated as being incapable of making important decisions? Mike Jempson, director of media ethics charity Presswise, is in no doubt. "These ads are pernicious," he argues. "Their message is, 'If you haven't got this product, you are abnormal.' And the poor are most vulnerable to this because they already feel excluded by society. The aim of most marketing is to sell goods, but ads aimed at children are designed to get kids to pressurise their peers and parents. This is divisive, no matter how wealthy the family."

According to Jempson, advertising reinforces social exclusion by holding up a constant taunt to those who cannot afford to buy into the fantasy world it creates. In November, chancellor Gordon Brown made a public attack on child-targeted adverts, while Sweden is trying to get the European Union to follow its lead in banning this type of marketing.

But to Amy Lawson, stepmother of two boys and managing director of ad agency Wieden and Kennedy, whose clients include Nike, Virgin Interactive and Diet Coke, such action would be an extreme restriction on personal liberty. "We live in a free society where consumers have rights to choose, and ads enable children to make comparisons," says Lawson. "If we prevent a whole section of the population from seeing something, what will we censor next? At some point, children have to learn how to choose, and if they don't have experience of this as they are growing up, they won't be able to handle it later.

"Parents need to teach them to manage expectations," Lawson concludes. "So if they can't have a product now, they understand about waiting."

For the time being, at least, child-targeted advertising is simply a reality that parents have to face - by being realistic. In Jenni Smith's view, we should get away from the feeling that we will damage a child by refusing them something they have fallen in love with on the TV. "It is more important to lay down boundaries for children about what they can and can't have, rather than what they can and can't watch," she says. "If parents can explain why something has been refused, this helps children understand how to make their own choices."

So, stick to your boundaries. But before you do, if you find a store that has a Bob The Builder, please let me know.

webTitle: Warm wishes

fields.headline: Warm wishes
fields.standfirst: Tired of the traditional versions? Guardian writers tell some of the big stories of the year through alternative Christmas carols
fields.trailText: Tired of the traditional versions? Guardian writers tell some of the big stories of the year through alternative Christmas carols
fields.body:
In the Warm Midwinter

In the warm midwinter

Travellers made moan

Earth was under water

Trees were overblown

Rain had fallen

Rain on rain

Rain on rain on rain

In the warm midwinter

With no trains.

To the climate conference

The world's great leaders came

They struggled night and day to

Find someone else to blame

After nigh a fortnight

These earnest men agreed:

Though the world is dying they would

Pay no heed.

Bangladesh will founder

Africa will starve

Goodbye Polynesia

Watch the icesheets calve

Even here in Britain

Our destiny is plain:

All the future holds for us is

Endless rain.

George Monbiot

Once in Johnny Prescott's City

Once in Johnny Prescott's city

Was the hope of streets so fair

Carfree roads and loads of buses

Railways cheap, congestion rare

Four years on that dream's in tatters

Cars for all is still what matters

Gus McDonald comes with bypass

trunk road upgrades, airports new

Loads more shops and sheds and houses

Need good land on which to spew

Concrete is a human right

Developers must all have sites

Michael Meacher keeps his head down

Knows full well this makes no sense.

It must impact on plant and climate,

Must degrade environments.

This is not what we promised you

Compromise is what we do

Andrew Simon

Good John Prescott

Good John Prescott last looked out

Through his two-jags window

Troubles he saw all about

But nothing worried him though.

Trains are knackered, roads are worse

Country's under water

Tabloid headlines are his curse

They give him no quarter

Off he totters to The Hague

(Not William, the one in 'Olland)

And though the language is so vague

Good John is on a roll, and

Summut to do with planting trees

Pollution and the climate
"I'll talk, luv, you make the teas

Macho man? Not moi, mate."

Paul Evans

God Rest Ye Multinationals

God rest ye multinationals

Let nothing you dismay

The WTO is not reformed

and Gats is on its way

And Mr Bush is coming in

He'll see that we're OK!

Oh tidings of mon-opo-lies

Oh tidings of do as-you-please!

We set trade rules to suit ourselves,
Ignore the poverty

We suffer no protection

By Chads or Malawis

We love indebted nations

But let's keep them on their knees

Oh tidings of mon-opo-lies

Oh tidings of do as-you-please

Environmental standards?

We couldn't give a dam.

Investment in economies?

Now that we understand.

So subsidise our movements

While we take your land

Oh tidings of mon-opo-lies

Oh tidings of do as-you-please

We have the ear of governments

We love democracies

They pay for us to set up shop

With sweeteners and with fees

And then we bugger offwards

And do just as we please

Oh tidings of mon-opolies

Oh tidings of do as-you-please

Ralph Nader's just a pile of pants

These protests just a fad

Naomi Klein is out to lunch

And Monbiot's quite mad

The Boveistes are all in jail

Reclaim the Streets are sad

Oh tidings of mon-opolies

Oh tidings of do as-you-please

John Vidal

We Love Thee White Paper

Away in a manger

No crib for its bed

The Rural White Paper

Lays down its sweet head

The stars in the bright sky

Nowhere to be seen

Above affordable housing

The new road lights gleam

We'll roam where we want to

And work on the Net

Our wildlife kept safely

In theme parks, no sweat

Buy chips from the post office

Trains run on time

There's no rural poverty

No rural crime

We love thee White Paper,

Under thy guiding hand

The countryside's sorted

So get off my land.

Paul Evans

Santa Straw is Coming to Town

You better watch out

While he's on the pry

Better not shout

I'm telling you why

Santa Straw is sneaking around

He's making a list

And checking it twice;

Gonna find out Who's naughty and nice

Santa Straw is sneaking around

He sees you when you're toking

He knows when you're online

He'll find out if you're bad or good

And levy instant fines

He really isn't joking

If you're a refugee

You'll go back when he says you should

'Til then you'll work for free

He loves to go round poking

His nose in your affairs

Official secrets must be good

But private ones he shares

You should live in Woking

Get married, go to church

Since if you live in Peckham

He'll leave you in the lurch

You better watch out!

While he's on the pry

Better not shout

I'm telling you why

Santa Straw is sneaking around

Santa Straw is sneaking around

Ian Wilmore

While shepherds watched

While shepherds watched their subsidies

Get swallowed by the bank

The Angel of the Lord came down

And said this is all rank

If sheep were gone from these here hills

The forests would return

And soothe the waters raging down

The country brooks and burns

It's raining cats and dogs all right,

The worst we've ever known.

Cities flooded, fields are drowned

We're soaked right to the bone.

The year began with mighty dread

The millennium bug would hit.

Instead it's Nature kicked our bum

And now we're in the ****
Paul Evans

Ding Dong Merrily

Ding dong, verily The Hague

Is riven by carbon trading.

Planting trees to save the sky

Won't stop our hopes from fading.

Glo-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-

o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-ria,

John Prescott in extremis.

A touch of your machismo

Leaves Dom'nique feeling stung-en,

And Loy a pie in his eye-o

By angry lady swungen.

Glo-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-

o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-o-ria,

John Prescott in extremis

Caspar Henderson

Do You Hear What I Hear?

Said the newsman to the camera crew,

Do you see what I see?

Come to save the talks, charging through

Do you see what I see?

Prescott, Prescott on a mercy trip

In a suit the size of a ship,

In a suit the size of a ship.

Said the camera crew to the diplomat

Do you hear what we hear?

Howls of US stooge! and Sexist rat!

Do you hear what we hear?

A full and frank exchange of views

Prescott versus Madame Voynet,

Prescott versus Madame Voynet

Said the diplomat to Mr Pronk,

Do you know what I think?

US sinks could leave a nasty stink

Do you know what I think?

A sandbag, a sandbag, that will set the tone

It will melt Frank Loy's heart of stone

It will melt Frank Loy's heart of stone

Said Pronk to the people everywhere

Listen to what I say!

Look at the sandbag, people everywhere,

Listen to what I say!

The sandbag's a symbol of our climate fight

It will bring us laughter and light,

It will bring us laughter and light.

Said the people back in a mighty shout

Do you see what we see?

Prescott's storming out, storming out

Do you see what we see?

Shouting gutted, wobbling left and right

Frankly it's not a happy sight

Frankly, it's not a happy sight

Ian Wilmore

webTitle: Disabled people on the frontline

fields.headline: Disabled people on the frontline
fields.trailText: Who should fill the ranks of Britain's armed forces? The chief of the defence staff, Sir Charles Guthrie, thinks that inclusion of disabled people would be "detrimental". So should they be allowed to serve? Mark Oliver examines the issues
fields.body:
What's all the fuss about?
Sir Charles Guthrie, Britain's most senior military officer, triggered a debate about who should be allowed into the forces after he told the Royal Services Institute in London that disabled people had "no right" to serve.

There was more to being a soldier, Sir Charles argued, than "cradling babies".

Disabled groups have branded the comments a misunderstanding of the concept of equal opportunities. The government has supported the views of Sir Charles, as have the Tories, who said judgments need to be made case by case and not by a European "rights agenda".

What is the current policy on disabled people in the army?
Many desk jobs and other types of work within the forces which do not require the fitness levels of active service personnel are carried out by civilians and are open to the disabled, according to senior army sources.

However, all uniformed personnel have to be capable of carrying out military tasks.

The prime minister's spokesman said today: "If you have people in the military they have to be prepared to fight and there is no such thing as a non-combatant job."

What prompted the general's comments?
He expressed concern at European moves which some have interpreted as an attempt to give disabled people the legal right to join up. A year ago the European commission proposed a non-discrimination package based on article 13 of the Treaty of Amsterdam. The package included a proposal for a directive prohibiting discrimination in employment on grounds of racial or ethnic origin, religion or belief, disability, age or sexual orientation.

However, Downing Street pointed out today that Britain had secured in October an opt-out for the armed forces from the relevant clause in article 13.

"The prime minister's view, which is shared within government, is that the armed forces cannot be just another employer," a spokesman said.

But could the treaty realistically force the services to accept disabled applicants?
Jo Sawyer, a human rights lawyer at Liberty, thinks not. She said: "General Guthrie's comments appear a little misconceived. The European Convention doesn't mean everyone has a right to serve in the armed forces in any capacity. "It simply means that everyone has a right not to be discriminated against. There's a balancing exercise. Clearly it depends on the nature of the job and the individual's capacity, and the extent of their disability."

What are the benefits of allowing disabled people into the services?
Supporters say that opening the ranks to disabled people would achieve two goals: it would allow hitherto-excluded patriots to serve their country in uniform, and help the military to overcome its recruitment problem.

Agnes Fletcher, spokeswoman for the Royal Association for Disability and Rehabilitation (Radar) said: "He has completely misunderstood the concept of equal opportunities. He seems to think that giving jobs to disabled people is a charitable act.

"Equal opportunities is about getting the right person for the job. And why cut out great swathes of people who might have something very important to contribute?"

Aberdeen South MP Anne Begg, who uses a wheelchair, said: "What really annoys us is when someone who doesn't know us or know what we are capable of says we can't do a job, simply because they themselves can't imagine how we could do it. That is what has held disabled people back for so long."

What do disabled war heroes think?
Falklands hero Simon Weston, who received horrific burns when HMS Sir Galahad was hit, dismissed the row as "a lot of noise about nothing".

"When you join the army you have to go through rigorous training whether you are a cook, whether you are a medic, whether you are a bandsman. There is no scope for making an assault course easy for disabled people."

Mr Weston urged campaigners to keep the issue "in context". He added: "There are disabled people within the armed forces but I think a lot of those guys were injured and allowed to stay on. "I was offered to continue serving as a storeman but I couldn't see myself handing out equipment I could never use, so I decided to leave.

"I do not think he meant anything in any way derogatory to disabled people. I think his sentiments are correct in the fact that we can't have disabled people on the frontline but there are disabled who work for the MoD."

What about women and homosexuals in the forces?
Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, lifted the ban on gays and lesbians in the armed forces earlier this year and has said that the army will soon have to allow women to fight in the infantry.

Mr Hoon said that he was becoming increasingly convinced that women wanted to serve as combat soldiers and should be allowed to do so. They already occupy frontline roles in artillery regiments and other areas.

The Tories, however, have said they would consider repealing the government's moves on homosexuals in the services.

Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, told the Conservative party conference in October that the party will not tolerate "political correctness" in military matters and will counter European rules on defence.

He said: "Our only aim is to have a professional fighting force for this country. The suggestion of women on the front line is PC gone mad. The most professional fighting force in the world, the Israeli army, has had to repeal rules on women in combat because it didn't work."

Is the make-up of the forces an issue elsewhere?
In America there was a similar debate when Duncan Hunter, a Republican congressman from California, pressed the Pentagon - without overt success - to overthrow what he regarded as outmoded standards requiring all soldiers to be able to carry a pack and slog across rough country.

He said: "Everybody doesn't hike over the hill and everyone doesn't have to be able to run five miles."

His idea is that the disabled could be recruited for work behind the lines, where, he argued, the battle is as likely to be fought on computers as in foxholes.
