"The prime minister's view, which is shared within government, is that the armed forces cannot be just another employer," a spokesman said. But could the treaty realistically force the services to accept disabled applicants? Jo Sawyer, a human rights lawyer at Liberty, thinks not. She said: "General Guthrie's comments appear a little misconceived. The European Convention doesn't mean everyone has a right to serve in the armed forces in any capacity. "It simply means that everyone has a right not to be discriminated against. There's a balancing exercise. Clearly it depends on the nature of the job and the individual's capacity, and the extent of their disability." What are the benefits of allowing disabled people into the services? Supporters say that opening the ranks to disabled people would achieve two goals: it would allow hitherto-excluded patriots to serve their country in uniform, and help the military to overcome its recruitment problem. Agnes Fletcher, spokeswoman for the Royal Association for Disability and Rehabilitation (Radar) said: "He has completely misunderstood the concept of equal opportunities. He seems to think that giving jobs to disabled people is a charitable act. "Equal opportunities is about getting the right person for the job. And why cut out great swathes of people who might have something very important to contribute?" Aberdeen South MP Anne Begg, who uses a wheelchair, said: "What really annoys us is when someone who doesn't know us or know what we are capable of says we can't do a job, simply because they themselves can't imagine how we could do it. That is what has held disabled people back for so long." What do disabled war heroes think? Falklands hero Simon Weston, who received horrific burns when HMS Sir Galahad was hit, dismissed the row as "a lot of noise about nothing". "When you join the army you have to go through rigorous training whether you are a cook, whether you are a medic, whether you are a bandsman. There is no scope for making an assault course easy for disabled people." Mr Weston urged campaigners to keep the issue "in context". He added: "There are disabled people within the armed forces but I think a lot of those guys were injured and allowed to stay on. "I was offered to continue serving as a storeman but I couldn't see myself handing out equipment I could never use, so I decided to leave. "I do not think he meant anything in any way derogatory to disabled people. I think his sentiments are correct in the fact that we can't have disabled people on the frontline but there are disabled who work for the MoD." What about women and homosexuals in the forces? Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, lifted the ban on gays and lesbians in the armed forces earlier this year and has said that the army will soon have to allow women to fight in the infantry. Mr Hoon said that he was becoming increasingly convinced that women wanted to serve as combat soldiers and should be allowed to do so. They already occupy frontline roles in artillery regiments and other areas. The Tories, however, have said they would consider repealing the government's moves on homosexuals in the services. Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence secretary, told the Conservative party conference in October that the party will not tolerate "political correctness" in military matters and will counter European rules on defence. He said: "Our only aim is to have a professional fighting force for this country. The suggestion of women on the front line is PC gone mad. The most professional fighting force in the world, the Israeli army, has had to repeal rules on women in combat because it didn't work." Is the make-up of the forces an issue elsewhere? In America there was a similar debate when Duncan Hunter, a Republican congressman from California, pressed the Pentagon - without overt success - to overthrow what he regarded as outmoded standards requiring all soldiers to be able to carry a pack and slog across rough country. He said: "Everybody doesn't hike over the hill and everyone doesn't have to be able to run five miles." His idea is that the disabled could be recruited for work behind the lines, where, he argued, the battle is as likely to be fought on computers as in foxholes.

webTitle: Awards to recognise youth involvement

fields.headline: Awards to recognise youth involvement
fields.standfirst: The Young Partners Award will hold its first award ceremony in May 2001 to recognise voluntary organisations that have shown commitment to youth participation. Muna Ahmad, a member of the judging panel, talks about her involvement
fields.trailText: The Young Partners Award will hold its first award ceremony in May 2001 to recognise voluntary organisations that have shown commitment to youth participation. Muna Ahmad, a member of the judging panel, talks about her involvement.
fields.body:
This year the National Council for Voluntary Youth Services (NCVYS) and Whitbread have joined forces to sponsor the first annual Young Partners Awards. Organisations will be awarded for their management style in encouraging youth participation and overcoming barriers.

As a member of the judging panel, the main attraction of the project (besides awarding positive youth work) was that the panel itself is made up of young members of society. For once it seemed as if we were in control.

Unfortunately, like many young people of today, I have rarely become involved in youth projects, let alone heard of any. Therefore, my experience and knowledge was extremely minimal. Societies such as the school council seem to overlook that we as students need real power to make significant changes.

I arrived at the training feeling slightly apprehensive. My peers, some of whom, unlike me, have and continue to participate in the youth sector, at first made me feel anxious about my ignorance. The first hurdle I had to overcome was the jargon - the abbreviations of organisations I had never heard of. The second was my fear of sounding stupid - voicing my opinion on matters I had only started to talk about five minutes ago somehow didn't seem right.

After much discussion and brainstorming, I realised that my ignorance was an asset to the group, rather than a liability, and added a different perspective on ideas and decisions.

As there is a pressure on our group to meet deadlines, we have to stay focused in meetings. Our team has therefore developed a unique level of communication and dedication, allowing us to participate in all aspects of the project. In turn we all contribute our own qualities and experiences to the panel. We are a group of cosmopolitan, innovative young adults, learning, while we work, the true meaning of teamwork.

Although the main objective of our team is to award positive youth work, it has also established positive work within our panel.

Deadline for nominations for the award is 31 January 2001. If you want to nominate your organisation for the Award please contact Esta Orchard at NCVYS for a nomination form on 020 7422 8636 or e-mail esta@ncvys.org.uk

Cash for youth projects

Action Pays is now looking for groups of young people to take action in their communities.

Action Pays, managed by NCVYS and Changemakers, aims to support young people to plan and manage their own projects. A central aim of Action Pays is to provide an environment and opportunity where young people can:

 Explore and express their own interests, values and opinions

 Develop personal skills and the attributes to thrive in a rapidly changing economy

 Gain a greater understanding of the communities in which they live

At present, 19 different voluntary organisations, ranging from national bodies such as the British Red Cross and The Scout Association, to local advisory centres and youth cafes, have joined Action Pays and will be providing support and small grants to groups of young people who want to develop their own projects. A number of grants have been set aside to specifically target young people from black and ethnic minorities.

Grants are aimed at:

 Groups of young people aged between 14-25 years

 Projects that are youth led

 Projects that have an identified community benefit - members of the group should decide and define their own community

For more information about how you can get involved in the scheme please contact Esta Orchard at NCVYS on 020 7422 8636 or e-mail on esta@ncvys.org.uk

webTitle: Castaway to relocate to tropical island

fields.headline: Castaway to relocate to tropical island
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: The BBC is hoping to lure viewers to a second series of Castaway by moving it to a tropical island, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The BBC is hoping to lure viewers to a second series of Castaway with a new tropical island location.

The corporation confirmed today that the next series of Castaway will take place in the rather more comfortable surrounds of an exotic island - a far cry from the weather-beaten Scottish island of Taransay where the last series was filmed.

But volunteers for Castaway 2001 should not expect an easy ride. The BBC described its plans for the new generation of castaways as "extreme".

Lorraine Heggessey, BBC1 controller, said: "BBC1 led the field with Castaway, a unique sociological experiment. Now we are pushing the boundaries still further in an exciting new adventure, not for the faint-hearted."

The latest series of Castaway proved disappointing for the BBC. The last episode, broadcast last night, attracted just 5.2m viewers.

The new series is being planned at a secret location and is expected to last only about two months, making it much shorter than the year-long Castaway.

webTitle: Revolution round-up

fields.headline: Revolution round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: December 20
fields.trailText: December 20: Front of Mind, the electronic publishing house, is to activate its first two ventures in early January.
fields.body:
Front of Mind, the electronic publishing house set up by former Associated New Media editor-in-chief Martin Dunn, is to activate its first two ventures in early January.

BA has pulled the plug on a lifestyle portal it was developing in conjunction with online service provider Affinity Internet.

Internet radio station Storm Live has partnered with Health Media Group in a joint content deal.

The chief financial officer of collapsed pan-European entertainment e-tailer Boxman, Mike Griffiths, has left the dot.com arena to take up the same post at Terence Conran's company, Conran Holdings.

New-media agency Hyperlink claims its staff headcount will treble over the course of 2001 following last Friday's acquisition by Cable & Wireless.

Digital post-production house The Mill, which has handled the special effects on Gladiator and Tomb Raider, is launching an interactive arm to its business in the new year.

webTitle: Capital set to sign Vidler

fields.headline: Capital set to sign Vidler
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Andria Vidler, former BBC head of sports marketing, is set to be named managing director of Capital Radio London, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Capital Radio is poised to name Andria Vidler, the former BBC head of sports marketing, as managing director for Capital Radio London.

A Capital Radio spokesman refused to deny press reports that Ms Vidler has been appointed to manage Capital FM, Capital Gold and events.

He said: "There has been no signing of contracts yet. We will make an announcement in the new year."

The company is still putting the finishing touches to the contract with Ms Vidler, who quit the BBC this autumn during a review of the corporation's marketing and PR services.

fields.body:
Lima, Peru
October, 1997

The naked parrot looked like a human fetus spliced onto a kosher chicken. It was so old it had lost every single one of its feathers, even its pinfeathers, and its bumpy, jaundiced skin was latticed by a network of rubbery blue veins.

"Pathological," muttered Switters, meaning not simply the parrot but the whole scene, including the shrunken old woman in whose footsteps the bird doggedly followed as she moved about the darkened villa. The parrot's scabrous claws made a dry, scraping noise as they fought for purchase on the terra-cotta floor tiles, and when, periodically, the creature lost its footing and skidded an inch or two, it issued a squawk so quavery and feeble that it sounded as if it were being clucked, whether in sympathy or disapproval one could not tell, for she never turned to her devoted little companion but wandered aimlessly from one piece of ancient wooden furniture to another in her amorphous black dress.

Switters feigned appreciation, but he was secretly repulsed, all the more so because Juan Carlos, who stood beside him on the patio, also spying in the widow's windows, was beaming with pride and satisfaction. Switters slapped at the mosquitoes that perforated his torso and cursed every hair on that hand of Fate that had snatched him into South too-goddamned vivid America.

Boquichicos, Peru
November 1997

Attracted by the lamplight that seeped through the louvers, a mammoth moth beat against the shutters like a storm. Switters watched it with some fascination as he waited for the boys to bring his luggage up from the river. That moth was no butterfly that was certain, It was a night animal, and it had a night animal's mystery.

Butterflies were delicate and gossamer, but this moth possessed strength and weight. Its heavy wings were powdered like the face of an old actress. Butterflies were presumed to be carefree, moths were slaves to a fiery obsession. Butterflies seemed innocuous, moths somehow ... erotic. The dust of the moth was sexual dust. The twitch of the moth was a sexual twitch. Suddenly Switters touched his throat and moaned. He moaned because it occurred to him how much the more resembled a clitoris with wings.

Vivid.

There were grunts on the path behind him, and Inti emerged from the forest bearing, somewhat apprehensively, Switter's crocodile-skin valise. In a moment the other two boys appeared with the rest of his gear. It was time to review accommodations in the Hotel Boquichicos. He dreaded what he might find behind its shuttered windows, its double-screened doors, but he motioned for the boys to follow him in. "Let's go. This insect -" He nodded at the great moth that, fan though it might, was unable to stir the steaming green broth that in the Amazon often substitutes for air. "This insect is making me feel -" Switters hestitated to use the word, even though he knew Inti could understand no more than a dozen simple syllables of English. "This insect is making me feel libidinous."

Central Syria
May 1998

Trekking towards al Qaz-as in a late spring rain, the nomads were soaked and nearly giddy. Behind them, at lower elevations, the grass was already yellowing and withering, fodder not for flocks but for wildfires; ahead, the mountain passes conceivably could still be obstructed by snow. Whatever anxieties the band maintained, however, were washed away by the downpour. In country such as this, hope's other name was moisture.

Even the sheep and goats seemed merry, lighter of hoof, although individual beasts paused from time to time to shake rainwater from their coats, vigorously, stiffly, causing them to look like self-conscious burlesque queens. Their leathery black muzzles, glistening with rain, were pointed - not so much by their drivers as by a migratory instinct older than humanity - towards distant pastures.

Switters was one of four men - the Khan, the Khan's eldest son, an experienced pathfinder, and himself who travelled on horseback, at the head of the procession. The rest were on foot. They had been on the move, dawn to dusk, for almost a week.

About two miles back, prior to beginning their gradual ascent, they had passed a large compound, an oasis, undoubtedly, completely surrounded by a high mud wall. The boughs of orchard trees rose above the wall, and the scent of orange blossoms boosted to a higher power the already intoxicating small of the rain. From inside the compound, Switters thought he heard the wild sugary shriek of girlish laughter. Several of the young men must have heard it, too, for they turned their heads to stare wistfully at the remote estate.

The band pressed on. That is what nomads do. Forward the march. The burden and the bleating.

Switters, however, could not get the mini-oasis out of his mind. Something about it - is mysterious walls, its lush vegetation, its auditory hint of young women splashing in the rain - had gripped his imagination with such steady pressure that eventually he announced to his hosts his intention to return and investigate the place. One might say they were shocked, except that his very presence among them was in and of itself so extraordinary that they were partially immune to further bewilderment.

The khan shook his head and his eldest son, who spoke passable English, objected, "Oh Sir, we must not turn back. The flocks-"

Switters who spoke passable Arabic, interrupted to explain that he meant to go alone.

"But Sir," sad the eldest son, wringing his hands and screwing up his forehead until it looked like the rolled-back lid of a sardine can, "the horse. We have only these four, you see, and we - "

"No, no, good buddy. Assure your papa I had no notion of galloping off with his fine nag. Now, he can let his next eldest son hop up and take a load off his tootsies."

"But, sir"

"I'll just zip on back there in my starship. If you boys'll be so good as to ready it for me."

The khan waved the procession to a halt. At that exact moment the rain stopped as well. Two of the tribesman unfastened Switter's chair from behind the saddle, unfolded it, placed it on a reasonably level patch, and set its brake. Then they helped him off the horse and lifted him gently into the seat. They strapped his croc-skin valise to the chair back and laid his computer, satellite telephone, and customized Beretta 9-mm revolver, each wrapped in a separate plastic garbage bag, on his lap.

Elaborate farewells were exchanged, after which the nomads watched for many minutes in nothing short of awe as Switters, laboriously, precariously - but singing all the while - manoeuvred the rickety, hand-operated wheelchair over the brutal rocks and ensnaring sands of a landscape so harsh in its promise that a mere glimpse of it would propel a Romantic poet to therapy or a developer to gin.

Slowly he dissolved into the wilderness.

He seemed to be singing "Send in the Clowns."

Vatican City
May 1999

The Cardinal ordered Switters and his party to queue up single file. The garden path was narrow, he explained, and besides, it would be unseemly to approach His Holiness all in a bunch. Switters was to go first. If his weapon had not been confiscated at the last security check-point, he might have insisted on bringing up the rear, but now it didn't matter.

Because of his "disability", Switters needn't feel obliged to kneel upon reaching the throne, the cardinal had generously conceded. Switters wondered if, nevertheless, he would be expected to kiss the pope's ring. Only way I'm smooching that ring, he thought, is if they paste a crumb of hashish on it, or else smear it with pussy juice or red-eye gravy.

As he thought that, he was remembering an actress he used to know, who, in order to entice a tiny trained terrier to follow her around during a movie scene, had had to have scraps of raw calf's liver stapled to the soles of her high-heeled shoes.

Thinking of that terrier magnitized by meat-baited slippers reminded him then of the old bald parrot that had waddled after its mistress in a Lima suburb many months before - and for a moment Switters was back in Peru. That's the way the mind works.

That's the way the mind works: the human brain is genetically disposed towards organisation, yet if not tightly controlled, will link one imagerial fragment to another on the flimsiest of pretence and in the most freewheeling manner, as if it takes a kind of organic pleasure in creative association, without regard for logic, or chronological sequence.

Now, it appears that this prose account has unintentionally begun in partial mimicry of the mind. Four scenes have occurred at four different locations at four separate times, some set apart by months or years. And while they do maintain chronological order and a connective element (Switters), and while the motif is a far cry from the kind of stream-of-consciousness that makes Finnegans Wake simultaneously the most realistic and the most unreadable book ever written (unreadable precisely because it is so realistic), still, alas, the preceding is probably not the way in which an effective narrative ought properly to unfold - not even in these days when the world is showing signs of awakening from its linear trance, its dangerously restrictive sense of itself as a historical vehicle chugging down a one-way street toward some preordained apocalyptic goal.

Henceforth, this account shall gather itself at an acceptable starting point (every beginning in narration is somewhat arbitrary and the one that follows is no exception), from which it shall then move forward in a so-called timely fashion, shunning the wantonly tangential influence of the natural mind and stopping only occasionally to smell the adjectives of kick some ass.

Since this new approach should render chapter headings (those that designate date and place) unnecessary, they will from now on be scratched. If the next chapter were to have a heading, however it would read:

Seattle
October 1997

It was on a mist-bearded Saturday morning, grey as a ghoul and cool as clam aspic, that Switters showed up at his grandmother's house. En route from the airport, he had stopped by Pike Place Market, where he bought a bouquet of golden chrysanthemums, as well as a medium-sized pumpkin. Now he was forced to juggle these items in order to free a hand with which to turn up his trench coat collar against the microdontic nipping of the drizzle. He had also purchased a capsule of XTC from a hipster fish merchant he knew, and as he walked from the rental car to the stately mansion, he managed to get it to his mouth and swallow it without the benefit of liquid. It tasted like snapper.

He punched the bell. After a brief interval, his grandmother's voice crackled out of the speaker. "Who is it? What do you want? This had better be good." The woman refused to keep a downstairs maid, although she was eighty-three years old and had the wherewithal.

"It's me. Switters."

"Who?"

"Switters. Your favourite relation. Buzz me in, Maestra."

"Heh! 'Favourite relation' in your dreams, maybe. Do you come bearing gifts?"

"Absolutely"

He heard the electronic loosening of the latch. "I'm advancing. Brace yourself, Maestra."

"Heh!"

When Switters was less than a year old, his grandmother had stood before his highchair, her hands on her still glamorous hips. "You're starting to jabber like a damn disk jockey,' she said. "Pretty soon you'll be having a name for me, so I want to make this clear: you are not to insult me with one of those declasse G words, like granny or grams or gramma or whatever, you understand; and if you ever call me nannie or nonna - or moomaw or big mamma or mawmaw I'll bust your cute little chops. I'm aware that it's innate in the human infant to produce M sounds followed by soft vowels in response to materialistic stimuli, so if you find it primally necessary to label me with something of that ilk, then let it be 'maestra' or 'teacher'. I don't know if I'll ever teach you anything worthwhile, and I sure as hell don't want to be anybody's master, but at least maestra has got some dignity. Try saying it."

Little more than a year later, when he was two, the child had marched up to his Grandmother, pinned her with his already fierce, hypnotic green eyes, planted his hands on his hips, and commanded "Call me Switters." Maestra had studied him for a while, had puzzled over his sudden identification with his non too illustrious surname, and finally nodded. "Very well," she said. "Fair enough."

His mother continued to call him Baby Dumpling. But not for long.

Continue

Switters was one of four men - the Khan, the Khan's eldest son, an experienced pathfinder, and himself who travelled on horseback, at the head of the procession. The rest were on foot. They had been on the move, dawn to dusk, for almost a week. About two miles back, prior to beginning their gradual ascent, they had passed a large compound, an oasis, undoubtedly, completely surrounded by a high mud wall. The boughs of orchard trees rose above the wall, and the scent of orange blossoms boosted to a higher power the already intoxicating small of the rain. From inside the compound, Switters thought he heard the wild sugary shriek of girlish laughter. Several of the young men must have heard it, too, for they turned their heads to stare wistfully at the remote estate. The band pressed on. That is what nomads do. Forward the march. The burden and the bleating. Switters, however, could not get the mini-oasis out of his mind. Something about it - is mysterious walls, its lush vegetation, its auditory hint of young women splashing in the rain - had gripped his imagination with such steady pressure that eventually he announced to his hosts his intention to return and investigate the place. One might say they were shocked, except that his very presence among them was in and of itself so extraordinary that they were partially immune to further bewilderment. The khan shook his head and his eldest son, who spoke passable English, objected, "Oh Sir, we must not turn back. The flocks-" Switters who spoke passable Arabic, interrupted to explain that he meant to go alone. "But Sir," sad the eldest son, wringing his hands and screwing up his forehead until it looked like the rolled-back lid of a sardine can, "the horse. We have only these four, you see, and we - " "No, no, good buddy. Assure your papa I had no notion of galloping off with his fine nag. Now, he can let his next eldest son hop up and take a load off his tootsies." "But, sir" "I'll just zip on back there in my starship. If you boys'll be so good as to ready it for me." The khan waved the procession to a halt. At that exact moment the rain stopped as well. Two of the tribesman unfastened Switter's chair from behind the saddle, unfolded it, placed it on a reasonably level patch, and set its brake. Then they helped him off the horse and lifted him gently into the seat. They strapped his croc-skin valise to the chair back and laid his computer, satellite telephone, and customized Beretta 9-mm revolver, each wrapped in a separate plastic garbage bag, on his lap. Elaborate farewells were exchanged, after which the nomads watched for many minutes in nothing short of awe as Switters, laboriously, precariously - but singing all the while - manoeuvred the rickety, hand-operated wheelchair over the brutal rocks and ensnaring sands of a landscape so harsh in its promise that a mere glimpse of it would propel a Romantic poet to therapy or a developer to gin. Slowly he dissolved into the wilderness. He seemed to be singing "Send in the Clowns." Vatican City May 1999 The Cardinal ordered Switters and his party to queue up single file. The garden path was narrow, he explained, and besides, it would be unseemly to approach His Holiness all in a bunch. Switters was to go first. If his weapon had not been confiscated at the last security check-point, he might have insisted on bringing up the rear, but now it didn't matter. Because of his "disability", Switters needn't feel obliged to kneel upon reaching the throne, the cardinal had generously conceded. Switters wondered if, nevertheless, he would be expected to kiss the pope's ring. Only way I'm smooching that ring, he thought, is if they paste a crumb of hashish on it, or else smear it with pussy juice or red-eye gravy. As he thought that, he was remembering an actress he used to know, who, in order to entice a tiny trained terrier to follow her around during a movie scene, had had to have scraps of raw calf's liver stapled to the soles of her high-heeled shoes. Thinking of that terrier magnitized by meat-baited slippers reminded him then of the old bald parrot that had waddled after its mistress in a Lima suburb many months before - and for a moment Switters was back in Peru. That's the way the mind works. That's the way the mind works: the human brain is genetically disposed towards organisation, yet if not tightly controlled, will link one imagerial fragment to another on the flimsiest of pretence and in the most freewheeling manner, as if it takes a kind of organic pleasure in creative association, without regard for logic, or chronological sequence. Now, it appears that this prose account has unintentionally begun in partial mimicry of the mind. Four scenes have occurred at four different locations at four separate times, some set apart by months or years. And while they do maintain chronological order and a connective element (Switters), and while the motif is a far cry from the kind of stream-of-consciousness that makes Finnegans Wake simultaneously the most realistic and the most unreadable book ever written (unreadable precisely because it is so realistic), still, alas, the preceding is probably not the way in which an effective narrative ought properly to unfold - not even in these days when the world is showing signs of awakening from its linear trance, its dangerously restrictive sense of itself as a historical vehicle chugging down a one-way street toward some preordained apocalyptic goal. Henceforth, this account shall gather itself at an acceptable starting point (every beginning in narration is somewhat arbitrary and the one that follows is no exception), from which it shall then move forward in a so-called timely fashion, shunning the wantonly tangential influence of the natural mind and stopping only occasionally to smell the adjectives of kick some ass. Since this new approach should render chapter headings (those that designate date and place) unnecessary, they will from now on be scratched. If the next chapter were to have a heading, however it would read: Seattle October 1997 It was on a mist-bearded Saturday morning, grey as a ghoul and cool as clam aspic, that Switters showed up at his grandmother's house. En route from the airport, he had stopped by Pike Place Market, where he bought a bouquet of golden chrysanthemums, as well as a medium-sized pumpkin. Now he was forced to juggle these items in order to free a hand with which to turn up his trench coat collar against the microdontic nipping of the drizzle. He had also purchased a capsule of XTC from a hipster fish merchant he knew, and as he walked from the rental car to the stately mansion, he managed to get it to his mouth and swallow it without the benefit of liquid. It tasted like snapper. He punched the bell. After a brief interval, his grandmother's voice crackled out of the speaker. "Who is it? What do you want? This had better be good." The woman refused to keep a downstairs maid, although she was eighty-three years old and had the wherewithal. "It's me. Switters." "Who?" "Switters. Your favourite relation. Buzz me in, Maestra." "Heh! 'Favourite relation' in your dreams, maybe. Do you come bearing gifts?" "Absolutely" He heard the electronic loosening of the latch. "I'm advancing. Brace yourself, Maestra." "Heh!" When Switters was less than a year old, his grandmother had stood before his highchair, her hands on her still glamorous hips. "You're starting to jabber like a damn disk jockey,' she said. "Pretty soon you'll be having a name for me, so I want to make this clear: you are not to insult me with one of those declasse G words, like granny or grams or gramma or whatever, you understand; and if you ever call me nannie or nonna - or moomaw or big mamma or mawmaw I'll bust your cute little chops. I'm aware that it's innate in the human infant to produce M sounds followed by soft vowels in response to materialistic stimuli, so if you find it primally necessary to label me with something of that ilk, then let it be 'maestra' or 'teacher'. I don't know if I'll ever teach you anything worthwhile, and I sure as hell don't want to be anybody's master, but at least maestra has got some dignity. Try saying it." Little more than a year later, when he was two, the child had marched up to his Grandmother, pinned her with his already fierce, hypnotic green eyes, planted his hands on his hips, and commanded "Call me Switters." Maestra had studied him for a while, had puzzled over his sudden identification with his non too illustrious surname, and finally nodded. "Very well," she said. "Fair enough." His mother continued to call him Baby Dumpling. But not for long. Continue

webTitle: Clinton's last hurrah: a trip to North Korea?

fields.headline: Clinton's last hurrah: a trip to North Korea?
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText:
White House officials have confirmed that President Clinton's diplomatic 
swansong may be a trip to North Korea.
fields.body:
White House officials have confirmed that President Clinton's diplomatic swansong may be a trip to North Korea.

It may seem an oddly unglamorous place to take a last bow on the world stage, but the Democratic People's Republic of Korea has long played a leading part in Clinton's diplomatic strategy.

To the dismay of rightwing critics who advocate a more robust approach, he has thrown the prestige of the presidency behind intensive US efforts to wheedle, flatter and cajole the North Koreans into cutting down their enormous arms programme.

Pyongyang maintains a colossal army, and while the country periodically faces devastating famine, the regime has poured scarce resources into developing and producing long range missiles.

Efforts to drag the last Stalinist dictatorship into the modern world have made some progress. This year saw an unprecedented meeting between President Kim Jong Il and his South Korean counterpart, President Kim Dae Jung, and only a couple of months ago US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright made a historic first visit to Pyongyang.

It is that visit which President Clinton wants to follow up. It is highly unlikely, however, that he will risk the prestige of his presidency, unless he can put his name to a concrete agreement.

The other factor which could keep him in Washington - or possibly propel him to a last visit to the Middle East - is the continuing frantic effort to revive the Israel-Palestine peace process. A US-brokered deal there would be a shinier prize by far than an agreement with North Korea.

Still, Air Force One may yet darken the skies over Pyongyang. In spite of the significant thawing of relations, North Korea remains in many ways a pariah state in Washington's view, and one which threatens America's most valued allies in the region, Japan and South Korea.

Technically, the two Koreas are still at war. Their relentless haggling over the terms of a peace treaty has been going on, at snail's pace, since the summer of 1953 when the Korean War was halted by an armistice. Violations of the ceasefire are less frequent now, but they still happen.

The north of the peninsula remains in the iron grip of an unreconstructed communist regime, personified by Kim Jong Il, the "Dear Leader". He is the son of the founder of the state, the redoubtable Kim Il Sung or "Great Leader".

The cult of personality has rarely been so manifest as in the reign of the two Kims. The style of it can best be gauged from the turgid prose of the official news agency, which laces its reports with shameless praise of the Dear Leader.

Here is an example, hot off the wire: "General Secretary Kim Jong Il on Monday gave on-site guidance to the land levelling and realignment project in South Hwanghae Province. He went round Yonan and Chongdan counties and other parts of the province and acquainted himself in detail with the progress of land realignment project.

"Feasting his eyes on the vast expanse of standardized fields, he was greatly satisfied to note that soldier-builders and people intensely loyal to the party and the revolution have done a lot of work in such a short span of time by fully displaying the revolutionary spirit of fortitude, the revolutionary spirit of soldiers, and highly praised their proud feats."

webTitle: Livingstone to rule on BBC 'media village'

fields.headline: Livingstone to rule on BBC 'media village'
fields.standfirst:
Dec 19: BBC unveils 'media village'
Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
1.30pm: London mayor Ken Livingstone will have a say on whether the BBC's proposed £200m 'media village' gets the go-ahead, writes Jason Deans.
Dec 19: BBC unveils 'media village'
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone, the mayor of London, will have a say in whether the BBC's proposed £200m White City "media village" development gets planning permission.

Mr Livingstone will rule on whether the 130,000 square metre project on Wood Lane, west London, should go ahead after the local council, Hammersmith & Fulham, has assessed the BBC's planning submission.

If the mayor and the council give conflicting rulings, environment minister Michael Meacher could be called in to make a final decision on the media village proposal.

The proposed BBC development comes under Mr Livingstone's jurisdiction because of its size.

Hammersmith & Fulham council is not expected to complete its assessment of the BBC's plans until next summer.

webTitle: G2: Real Lives

fields.headline: Who's  what girl?
fields.standfirst:
Madonna has turned Dornoch into the most famous town in Scotland. But Selina Mills who has a family home there, finds the locals more concerned with tagging sheep than the big wedding
The Dunhill look: it's a Guy thing
fields.trailText: Madonna has turned Dornoch into the most famous town in Scotland. But Selina Mills who has a family home there, finds the locals more concerned with tagging sheep than the big wedding.
fields.body:
Sutherland - and its royal town of Dornoch - is one of the most beautiful, remote and least populated places in Britain. Tourist guides mention the famous golf course, sandy beaches, some lovely hotels, and a handy stop on the way up to John o'Groats. But in the winter Dornoch is a vibrant and active community that serves the needs of a strong agricultural workforce. It may be besieged by television crews and reporters sticking microphones under unsuspecting shopper's noses but locals, apart from the odd chuckle at journalists trying to get their mobile phones to work (many have been seen walking to tops of hills to get reception), are very much unperturbed by the arrival of the queen of pop. They are too busy feeding their cattle, their sheep, their families and organising their Christmas festivities.

On my first night home, for my Christmas visit to my family, the press missed one of the best parties of the year, down at the neighbouring Rogart town hall, where the British Legion was holding its annual Christmas dinner for senior citizens. Just a few miles from where Madonna and her beloved were preparing themselves for their wedding at Skibo Castle, a group of farmers and their wives were enjoying Highland dancing, an award-winning bagpipe player, Gaelic singing, and watching wee lasses from the village school showing off their dancing prowess to very proud grandmothers. Right in the middle of it, and not wearing his family tartan, was our very own Mr Ritchie asking me to dance. Throwing ourselves into the Dashing White Sergeant, and the Gay Gordons, I decided dancing with James Ritchie of Rogart, secretary and treasurer of the village hall and chairman of the parish council, was certainly more exciting than the visit of the other Mr Ritchie.

Reverend Susan Brown, mother of two and the Church of Scotland minister who is to marry the famous couple (and hopefully me one day), told me after Sunday church that the contrast between the media attention and the local community is very clear. "Local folk are largely unfazed by the arrival of Madonna. It's just the media that are being so silly." The most burning issue in her mind at the moment is Christmas Day, where she will have to balance the midnight service a morning family carol service and cook dinner for 14.

While Susan takes care of the spiritual side of the community, the local solicitor John Gunn, who also functions as a notary, vice-chairman of the local school and treasurer of the local Imperial Cancer Research Fund, reminds me of how local people work as part of a tradition that spans centuries. "We have a fragile working rural community," he says. "Farming is getting harder all the time, and tourism is really a main source of economy, so this is a great opportunity for us to get on the map. Essentially, it's great publicity."

About 10 minutes away from Dornoch is Skibo Castle, where the Madonna wedding party is staying. It has had a long tradition of high society revelry since the late 19th century. Scottish-born Andrew Carnegie,who made millions from steel in Pittsburgh and became one of the richest men in the world, missed his homeland and bought Skibo Castle so he could bring people as varied as Helen Keller, the Rockefellers, Rudyard Kipling and Edward VII together. Edward even granted the property permission to fly a double sided flag that shows the Union Jack on one side and the stars and stripes on the other.

Yet only a stone's throw from the grandeur of the castle gates lives Margaret Thomson, Carnegie's great-grand daughter and also one of the first women of her generation to run a farm. Over lunch, she admits not to be that worried about the arrival of one of the world's greatest pop icons - at the moment she is more concerned with tagging her sheep according to the new EU regulations. "I think it's brilliant Madonna has come up here," she says, throwing another Labrador off her lap, "and I think it will bring the area a lot of attention. But I have to admit half the time up here I'm not sure what planet I'm on except the farm."

As we drive home past the Skibo Gates where photographers are shivering in the cold, I wonder if the press really have any clue about the world they are currently occupying. Of course, they are not here for that, and if they were, it would be easy to paint a charmingly quaint picture of life up here, full of sheep, and funny crofting characters whose family have been in the area for generations (and we do have them).

But this is not the point. The point is that up here we are far removed from the madness of London life, and maybe, despite the ratpack, that is why Madonna is here too.

webTitle: General under fire over forces' disabled ban

fields.headline: General under fire over forces' disabled ban
fields.trailText: Human rights campaigners today criticised Britain's most senior military officer after he said disabled people had "no right" to serve in the armed forces.
fields.body:
Human rights campaigners today criticised Britain's most senior military officer after he said disabled people had "no right" to serve in the armed forces.

The chief of the defence staff, Sir Charles Guthrie, said plans to allow disabled people to enter non-combat roles were "ill-conceived".

Disability campaigners attacked his comments and argued he had completely misunderstood the concept of equal opportunities.

Sir Charles told the Royal United Services Institute in London last night that it would be "detrimental" to allow disabled people to serve in the forces.

He said: "Our defence ministers do understand our position and have been robust in the defence of our case during the recent European debate on ending employment discrimination on grounds of age and disability. "I fully understand that those proposing this aspect of employment law were acting with good intentions and for entirely laudable aims.

"But if left unchecked the impact would have had a detrimental effect on the forces by insisting that disabled people had a right to serve.

"We need to guard against such ill-conceived ideas in future."

However, the Royal Association for Disability And Rehabilitation (Radar) said Sir Charles's comments were "inappropriate and patronising".

Spokeswoman Agnes Fletcher said: "He has completely misunderstood the concept of equal opportunities. He seems to think that giving jobs to disabled people is a charitable act.

"Equal opportunities is about getting the right person for the job, and why cut out great swathes of people who might have something very important to contribute?"

Downing Street today stressed that the prime minister, Tony Blair, backed Sir Charles' comments.

A spokesman for Mr Blair pointed out Britain had secured in October an opt-out for armed forces from a clause in Article 13 of the EU Treaty of Amsterdam, which forbids employment discrimination on the grounds of disability or age.

"The prime minister's view, which is shared within Government, is that the armed forces cannot be just another employer.

"If you have people in the military they have to be prepared to fight and there is no such thing as a non-combatant job," said the spokesman. "Anybody who is serving in the armed forces has to be ready to fight."

However, No 10 acknowledged exemptions were made already for women, who are barred from front-line jobs in the services, and for serving military personnel who were permanently injured in the course of their duties.

The spokesman said: "In those instances the armed forces make every effort to ensure they (injured personnel) are re-integrated in some way - always with the proviso that combat effectiveness cannot be compromised."

However, Colin Low, a member of the Disabled Rights Commission, said there was nothing unreasonable about disabled people wanting to be able to serve in the armed forces.

He said: "The general says it is the height of political correctness, but it is not nearly so unreasonable as it might seem at first.

"All we are against is the absolute bar on disabled people serving in the armed forces. We are fully mindful of the need for combat effectiveness."

Lord Ashley of Stoke, chairman of the All Party Parliamentary Disablement Group, said: "By seeking to exclude all disabled people from the armed forces, the generals are besotted with the trench warfare of the First World War.

"Disabled people can make a useful contribution to many areas of service life, especially in this computer age."

However, others leapt to the general's defence.

The Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said: "I have a great deal of sympathy for what he said.

"It's a hard, unpalatable, brutal fact that soldiers have got to be able to fight and if necessary kill, and if you have got a disability that stands in the way of that, then you not only put yourself at risk but all those around you."

In his speech, Sir Charles also warned of the "creeping advance" of a litigation culture and raised the prospect of a subaltern being sued by his platoon for making a decision in the heat of battle.

He said: "What really concerns me about the creeping advance of litigation is that it will breed a group of leaders who may step back from courageous decisions for fear that they will be pursued through the courts if it all goes wrong."

However, Colin Low, a member of the Disabled Rights Commission, said there was nothing unreasonable about disabled people wanting to be able to serve in the armed forces. He said: "The general says it is the height of political correctness, but it is not nearly so unreasonable as it might seem at first. "All we are against is the absolute bar on disabled people serving in the armed forces. We are fully mindful of the need for combat effectiveness." Lord Ashley of Stoke, chairman of the All Party Parliamentary Disablement Group, said: "By seeking to exclude all disabled people from the armed forces, the generals are besotted with the trench warfare of the First World War. "Disabled people can make a useful contribution to many areas of service life, especially in this computer age." However, others leapt to the general's defence. The Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, Menzies Campbell, said: "I have a great deal of sympathy for what he said. "It's a hard, unpalatable, brutal fact that soldiers have got to be able to fight and if necessary kill, and if you have got a disability that stands in the way of that, then you not only put yourself at risk but all those around you." In his speech, Sir Charles also warned of the "creeping advance" of a litigation culture and raised the prospect of a subaltern being sued by his platoon for making a decision in the heat of battle. He said: "What really concerns me about the creeping advance of litigation is that it will breed a group of leaders who may step back from courageous decisions for fear that they will be pursued through the courts if it all goes wrong."

webTitle: View from Johannesburg: South Africa's 'guilty' reluctant to sign up

fields.headline: South Africa's 'guilty' reluctant to sign up
fields.standfirst: White people in South Africa are being asked to acknowledge that they benefited from apartheid but, says Chris McGreal, many are unwilling to go that far
fields.trailText: White people in South Africa are being asked to acknowledge that they benefited from apartheid but, says Chris McGreal, many are unwilling to go that far.
fields.body:
For a long time it has been hard to find very many white people in South Africa who admit they actually supported apartheid. So it is probably no great surprise that so few seem keen to sign what has become known as the "guilt list" - a declaration that calls on whites to admit they benefited from racial discrimination and to take steps to make amends.

Quite a few whites will admit that they did do fairly well under apartheid. It is hard to deny the benefits of well-funded white schools compared to dilapidated black ones; the reservation of many jobs for a racial minority; and the group areas act which confined blacks to overcrowded and ill-maintained townships to keep them out of the hair of those in the plush white suburbs - except when they were required as maids and gardeners.

But there is a wholesale reluctance among the white population to admit individual responsibility for the system that imposed apartheid. Many whites will say they did not support it. Some claim they were really secret ANC supporters. It is hard to imagine where the National Party found all the votes that kept it in power for more than four decades.

Just 500 of South Africa's 4.5m whites have signed the declaration drawn up by truth commissioner Mary Burton and former African National Congress parliamentarian Carl Niehaus - two people with a long and creditable history of anti-apartheid activism. The statement is no more than an acknowledgement of what many black people take as a truism.

"We acknowledge that apartheid inflicted massive social, economic, cultural and psychological damage on black South Africans," it reads.

"We acknowledge the white community's responsibility for apartheid since many of us actively and passively supported that system. Some white people were deeply involved in the struggle against apartheid but they were very few in number. We acknowledge our debt to fellow black South Africans since all whites benefited from systematic racial discrimination. We therefore believe that it is right and necessary to commit ourselves to redressing these wrongs. We pledge to use our skills, resources and energy ... [toward] promoting a non-racial society whose resources are used to the benefit of all its people," it states.

But while few have signed, almost every white person has an opinion on it. Among those who agree with the declaration's sentiments are the writer Andre Brink, the actor Richard E Grant, and the grandson of Hendrik Verwoerd, the architect of apartheid. Most of the South African rugby team has also signed, although there are reports they were effectively ordered to do so by the management.

Others - including the former president, FW de Klerk, who released Nelson Mandela from prison a decade ago and won the Nobel peace prize - have denounced the exercise. The Mine Workers Union, which represents white miners who for many years benefited from the classification of jobs by race, dismissed the list as a new form of racism against whites.

Many of the dissenters are far from racist, and raise legitimate concerns about the point of the exercise by noting that those willing to sign are likely to be the whites who made the strongest stand against apartheid. They also say that to blame all whites, and only whites, for apartheid will reinforce racial divisions.

Mr de Klerk said he has already apologised to the truth and reconciliation commission and that "group judgement" would cause ethnic tension and prejudice. Former human rights commissioner, Rhoda Kadalie, who is of mixed-race, said it is too late for whites "to say sorry now" and warned that the declaration is aimed at silencing the government's white critics.

The respected poet, Breyten Breytenbach, who went to jail for opposing apartheid, said that after reading the declaration he went to the bathroom "for a quiet and sad puke".

But that cannot shield the reality that many whites will not sign because they resent being held responsible for apartheid, whether they voted for it or not. Large numbers believe that they atoned for that sin by giving up political power, if not economic control. And while whites cling to their large cars and homes in the face of a crime wave they blame not on the legacy of apartheid but black rule, many have come to see themselves as the new victims of the "new" South Africa.

webTitle: Transport trouble in Trolleywood

fields.headline: Transport trouble in Trolleywood
fields.standfirst: Everyone wants their own wheels in Los Angeles, reports Duncan Campbell, and for the homeless that means shopping carts
fields.trailText: Everyone wants their own wheels in Los Angeles, reports Duncan Campbell, and for the homeless that means shopping carts.
fields.body:
So bad is public transport in this 'capital of the 21st century', as mayor Richard Riordan insists on calling the city, that everyone needs their own wheeled vehicle to get around.

This means the proliferation of the suburban tank, otherwise known as the sport utility vehicle, ordinary cars, motorbikes, bicycles and now, of course, scooters which surely must be about to go the way of the yo-yo and CB radio. It also means, for the homeless, shopping carts.

The shopping cart or trolley is the preferred method by which homeless people can transport their belongings as they move from patch to patch, and in them they can store their clothes, blankets, sleeping bags, newspapers and all the necessities of life on the street.

Traditionally, they have helped themselves to these vehicles from outside the wealthy supermarkets of the city but the disappearance of shopping trolleys is one of those urban problems to which an extraordinary amount of time is dedicated. This week it was announced that the 'uncart' had been developed, a trolley that, when wheeled outside a supermarket's parking lot, will seize up and go no further, its little wheels locking up.

In the meantime, police have been arresting people for having stolen shopping Trolleys, so in a bid to save homeless people from going to court, local charities are buying trolleys and giving them free to the homeless.

But the 'uncart' is not the only imaginative development in the transport policies of the city. Science fiction writer Ray Bradbury, author of the classic Fahrenheit 451, was invited by LA's Metropolitan Transport Authority to address them on what the future should hold for them. Bradbury is 80 now and he gave them what for.

Looking at the MTA headquarters, a spiffy building that cost $500 million to build, he told his hosts: "it's ridiculous, this building. You could build a transit system for the cost of putting this place up." He suggested that the board could just as easily hold their meetings in a nearby cafe, Clifton's Cafeteria.

Bradbury said that he had suggested a monorail for the city 40 years ago but had been given short shrift. Now he was still recommending it as a way to escape the gridlocked freeways and the minimal subway system.

It would have to be an improvement on the current system, which is used by only 5 per cent of commuters. The current chaos on the roads goes back to dark days half a century ago when an unholy alliance of automobile, oil and tyre interests, including Firestone, General Motors and Standard Oil, bought up land in order to kill off public transport and allow their own interests to flourish.

The perpetrators of this scheme were punished under the anti-trust laws in 1949 with a laughable fine of $37,000, by which time the damage had been done (the scheme provided part of the plot for the film, Who Framed Roger Rabbit?).

Now we have come full circle and transport is once again provoking anger and invention in equal measure. Wheels on fire indeed.

webTitle: Vodafone buys stake in Japan Telecom

fields.headline: Vodafone buys stake in Japan Telecom
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Vodafone is to go head-to-head with BT for control of Japan Telecom, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Vodafone is set to go head-to-head with BT in a battle for control of Japan Telecom, after buying a stake in the company.

Both companies have a 15% stake in Japan Telecom, but want a stronger foothold in the lucrative Japanese market.

Vodafone's £1.5bn payout for the holding is the second largest investment in Japan by a foreign company.

Japan Telecom is the second largest telecoms company in Japan. Its mobile phone subsidiary, J-Phone, is number two in the wireless market. Vodafone now owns 32% of J-Phone, compared with BT's 20%.

US telecoms operator AT&T is said to be keen to sell its 15% interest, which could spark a bidding war between Vodafone and BT.

"We are getting involved because we want J-Phone to be a real contender. Consumers will benefit because they will get a better deal from our extensive supplier relationships," said a Vodafone spokesman.

Analysts said Vodafone was better positioned to win control of the stake because it has less debt. BT's debt burden is expected to reach £30bn by the middle of next year.

Mark James, telecoms analyst at Nomura, said: "BT has no money, and this deal does not fit in with its intention to tighten focus on the Japanese market."

A BT spokesman denied a clash with Vodafone was imminent, but said that the company has identified Japan as a key market after announcing a radical restructuring process last month.

"In an important market such as Japan we will seek to buy where the opportunity arises and where it will enhance shareholder value," said the spokesman.

Japan is seen as an ideal testing ground for the next generation of mobile phones, with more than 16m subscribers to mobile internet services.

The massively popular I-mode service, run by NTT DoCoMo, is seen as an ideal model for 3G services.

webTitle: Toshiba feels effect of Chinese hostility

fields.headline: Toshiba feels effect of Chinese hostility
fields.standfirst: Longstanding anti-Japanese feeling hits sales
fields.trailText: Sales of Toshiba laptops in China have fallen sharply after a media campaign against the corporation earlier this year which was strongly tinged with anti-Japanese anger.
fields.body:
Sales of Toshiba laptops in China have fallen sharply after a media campaign against the corporation earlier this year which was strongly tinged with anti-Japanese anger.

Statistics from the International Data Corporation show a fall in Toshiba's share of China's laptop market from 19.4% to 15.4% in the second quarter of the year. A Toshiba spokesperson admitted that hostile Chinese media reports may have been a factor.

Toshiba came under heavy fire not only from computer experts but from Chinese nationalists after it was reported that compensation paid by the corporation in the US for an alleged defect would not be available to Chinese purchasers.

Toshiba explained in vain that the compensation had only been paid because it risked facing a high punitive award in the state of Texas not because it admitted liability for the alleged defect.

It also claimed that laptops sold in China did not have the same potential problem in the floppy disk controller.

A barrage of hostile comments was quickly posted on Chinese website discussion groups. In September a Chinese hacker organisation calling itself the "Bayonet Group" successfully attacked the homepage of Toshiba (China).

Several hundred approving messages appeared in the space of two days on sina.com, one of China's most prominent sites.

"I express the greatest respect towards this hacker and actions," declared a typical message. "The Japanese cruelly massacred the Chinese, looted the wealth of China, and never stopped from the time of the Japanese pirates of the 14th century to now!"

Japan's wartime atrocities have left a strong undercurrent of popular hostility which Beijing sometimes encourages but at other times tries to keep under control. Last week it flared up again in the city of Nanjing, scene of the notorious 1937 massacre when occupying Japanese forces killed at least 100,000 innocent civiliansin well-documented atrocities. China maintains that the death toll was as high as 300,000.

On December 13, the anniversary of the massacre, several thousand local people smashed windows at a new restaurant which had been erected on the site of a commemorative monument. The memorial stone had been shifted, apparently by the builders, and lay broken a short distance away.

The popular anger was intensified because the restaurant had only opened on the previous day at a ceremony attended by top government leaders.

About 2,000 angry residents maintained a vigil outside the restaurant complex over the weekend, demanding to know why the monument had been moved.

Some Chinese have expressed concern at the ease with which nationalistic hostility is aroused by cases such as that of Toshiba.

Such cases, a commentator wrote in the Beijing Youth Daily, "do not harm the national pride of the Chinese nation at all, because true national pride is based on national strength, economic prosperity and cultural development instead of smiles on foreigners' faces".

"If we believe that civilisation will conquer ignorance," wrote another contributor criticising the hackers, "we must start from ourselves and first learn to be civilised."

But majority public opinion is incensed by recurring attempts by Japanese rightwing historians to minimise the extent of the Nanjing massacre, and by a succession of real or fancied insults today.

In a typical incident last year, a Japanese company president in Shenyang asked his Chinese workers to hold up both hands when they came to a meeting hall with their hands in their pockets.

The furious workers complained that they were once again being asked to "surrender to Japan".

webTitle: Population not Taiwan 'is China's challenge'

fields.headline: Population not Taiwan 'is China's challenge'
fields.trailText: China has singled out population growth as the key factor restricting its future economic and social development. It says it represents the country's number one challenge this century.
fields.body:
China has singled out population growth as the key factor restricting its future economic and social development. It says it represents the country's number one challenge this century.

A white paper on population control coincides with the publication yesterday of a 12-point list of government priorities in which population pressure comes top and reunification with Taiwan does not even get a mention.

The white paper admits that China has "a huge population but a weak economic foundation" and that although over 300m births "have been averted" in the past 20 years by population controls, a net rise of at least 10m people a year for the next decade is forecast - a figure many experts believe will prove to be an underestimate.

The 12 "challenges for the new century" were published in the Communist party's organ, the People's Daily, yesterday. Top of the list was "population pressure which will rise to an estimated 1.6bn [from the current 1.3bn] by the 2030s", the newspaper said.

The next priorities were: economic competition with the developed world; China's deteriorating environment; the need to develop more rational economic structures; and the need to reduce the gap between China's rich and poor.

The fight against "world hegemonism and power politics" comes in at the bottom of the list.

But the population paper also strikes a realistic footnote, detailing a formidable range of social and economic problems which the Chinese government has barely begun to tackle.

It states that the sharp rise in the adult labour force has placed great pressure on the job market, that the social security system cannot cope with the number of people living longer, and that the gap between rich and poor provinces is hard to eradicate.

The white paper also warns that the increase in China's "floating population" of migrant workers from the countryside - estimated unofficially at 150m to 200m - will make it harder to keep the birth rate down.

There is an enlightened willingness to acknowledge the seamy side of modern Chinese society and the continuing discrimination against female births, warning that "any action of maltreating, drowning and discarding girls is forbidden, and such crimes as mistreatment and trafficking of children should be severely punished".

Help for female children, disabled girls, children in single parent families and in poverty, and street children should also receive government attention.

International aid groups in Beijing say that over the past two to three years, their counterparts in Chinese ministries have become much more willing to discuss such problems frankly.

But they warn that obstruction at the local level, either through incompetent or corrupt officials, is still a serious problem.

In a candid assessment of China's current social strains , the white paper focuses on the need to improve health provision, particularly in the countryside so that farming families can ensure that their children will survive. It also calls for "strenuous efforts" to check the spread of Aids and other sexually transmitted diseases.

The importance of education was also acknowledged as a vital ingredient.

"The rate of illiteracy should be further reduced", the paper says. "The right to education of minors, women, ethnic minorities, the handicapped and poverty-stricken people should be protected."

webTitle: Vinnie Jones 'quit PR firm in gay row'

fields.headline: Vinnie Jones 'quit PR firm in gay row'
fields.trailText: Actor Vinnie Jones refused to work with a PR firm after an apparently naked picture of him appeared in a gay magazine, a court heard. By Linus Gregoriadis.
fields.body:
Vinnie Jones, the actor and former footballer, refused to work with a public relations firm after an apparently naked picture of him appeared in a gay magazine, a court heard yesterday.

Jones, who was promoting the Penny Black fragrance in a campaign by Tonic PR, became incensed when his son was teased at school after the picture appeared without his knowledge in Attitude magazine, Oxford crown court was told.

The makers of the fragrance objected because Jones, who has appeared in the films Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels and Snatch, was chosen for his "hard man" image and the magazine was not appropriate.

Penny Black Ltd sacked Tonic PR after the advert appeared. But the PR firm sued Penny Black for breach of contract, claiming it had not stipulated where they should promote the product. Penny Black made a counter-claim against Tonic for £80,000, a loss they claim they incurred when they were forced to change PR companies.

Penny Black, based in Birmingham, claims the placing of the advert in Attitude was inappropriate. Maria Aldridge, who runs Penny Black with her husband, Jason, told the preliminary hearing: "The placing of this advert in a homosexual magazine lost us as much as £80,000 because Vinnie refused to work with Tonic PR." A representative for Tonic PR argued that no restriction had been made on where adverts would be placed.

The case will be heard in full in the spring.

webTitle: Student debt trebles since end of grants

fields.headline: Student debt trebles since end of grants
fields.trailText: Student debt has trebled to nearly £2,500 per year since grants were phased out, the Department for Education admitted today.
fields.body:
Student debt has trebled to nearly £2,500 per year since grants were phased out, the Department for Education admitted today.

A study conducted by Claire Callender, professor of social policy at South Bank University, found that nearly nine out of 10 students complained of some financial difficulties, and six out of 10 believed these had harmed their academic work.

While the vast majority of students felt that their qualifications would help them get better jobs, one in 10 thought of dropping out of study because of lack of funding, while nearly two thirds were convinced the funding system had deterred friends from going to university. This was most marked for those from poorer backgrounds, black students and women over 25. On average the amount students owed at the end of the academic year rose from £777 in 1995/96 to £2,473 in 1998/99 - equal to £7,584 over a three-year course.

Slipping the report out quietly just before Christmas, the Education and Employment minister Tessa Blackstone said that student income had grown in real terms over the three years. Most students received enough financial support to meet all their essential costs, she said.

"The survey evidence confirms that the great majority of full-time students are taking out new fairer income loans which are interest-free in real terms, with repayment linked to income. Students are generally receiving the support they need from loans, grants and contributions from their parents, but we recognise that further, targeted support is needed for some disadvantaged groups," said Baroness Blackstone.

But the National Union of Students said the study was conducted when some maintenance grants were still available to the poorest students so the true position was even worse.

Owain James, NUS national president, said: "The department's own survey is a damning indictment of the governmentÕs student funding system. Their figures show student hardship is widespread with 87% of students experiencing difficulty. What more evidence does the government need? The Scottish parliament has rejected their funding system. In England applications from poorer students have fallen. The government must act now to return maintenance grants to those from poorest backgrounds, as received by Scottish students."

However the figures show that while students spent over £300 more on average on entertainment in 1999 than three years before, they were spending less on accommodation and food Ð possibly because more are living at home.

The proportion of students who failed to receive their full parental contribution doubled in over the three years to three in 10 students. This left students to make up the outstanding amount of £719 calculated as a mean figure.

Among full-timers in the survey, student loan take-up was 72%. The most common reason given for not taking out a loan was that the student did not need the money. Other students preferred not to take out loans for personal or other reasons. There were no significant differences in take-up rates by gender or class, but among ethnic groups, Asian students had a relatively low take-up rate (51%).

 Meanwhile, vice-chancellors are launching their own study of student debt and attitudes towards funding, Universities UK announced today.

Diana Warwick, chief executive, said that heads of universities were taking these issues very seriously: "Universities want their students to succeed and will be concerned about any evidence of debt which affects academic performance or causes hardship. They also want to reach out to new students, particularly those from poorer backgrounds who are currently not taking up higher education in sufficient numbers.

"If fear of debt is one of the factors deterring such applications - we will address this issue urgently as part of our current funding review."

Useful links

webTitle: Murder conviction quashed after 50 years

fields.headline: Murder conviction quashed after 50 years
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Iain Hay Gordon today had his conviction quashed for murdering a judge's daughter almost 50 years ago.
fields.body:
Iain Hay Gordon today had his conviction quashed for murdering a judge's daughter almost 50 years ago.

In the Northern Ireland court of appeal, Lord Chief Justice Sir Robert Carswell delivered an hour-long judgment which concluded that a verdict of acquittal must be found.

Speaking immediately afterwards 68-year-old Mr Gordon said: "I feel a great burden has been lifted off my shoulders. I am overjoyed to have my name finally cleared and become an ordinary individual once again."

In 1952 Mr Gordon was convicted of murdering 19-year-old Patricia Curran, whose father was a Northern Ireland high court judge. He was found guilty but insane.

Curran's body was found with multiple stab wounds in the grounds of her family home in Whiteabbey, Co Antrim, the previous November. Mr Gordon, from Stirling, had been doing his national service at a nearby RAF base.

After his arrest, he signed a confession after three days during which he was subjected to intensive questioning. He insists the admission was forced out of him when he was mentally and physically exhausted.

Following his conviction Mr Gordon was sent to Holywell mental hospital in Co Antrim. He was freed after seven-and-a-half years to return to Glasgow under an assumed name. But his nightmare was far from over. "I was released into my mother's care on the understanding that I wouldn't talk about the case to anyone."

He secured a job with a publishing company but was ordered to change his name from Iain to John. "For 33 years I was a non-person. I didn't even have my name," he said.

The binding agreement was broken, however, when he took voluntary redundancy in 1993. "That meant I was my own boss," he said. "I had decided I had had enough. I wanted to tell people."

Two people prepared to listen were lawyer Margot Harvey and journalist John Linklater, who have campaigned to clear Mr Gordon's name.

Mr Gordon insists he has not been left bitter by his ordeal. Nor will he be drawn on who actually carried out the brutal murder of Patricia Curran. "I have always refused to speculate on this," he said. "My main purpose was to clear my name and I have never got involved in who might have killed her."

At Belfast's court of appeal in October three senior judges heard that the officer who led the murder investigation, Detective Superintendent John Capstick, lied in the original trial by claiming that Mr Gordon had voluntarily dictated his statement. Ronald Wetherup QC, for the crown, accepted that the confession was unreliable.

webTitle: Indonesia's president in bid to thwart Irian Jaya uprising

fields.headline: Indonesia's president in bid to thwart Irian Jaya uprising
fields.trailText: Indonesia's President Abdurrahman Wahid is to visit troubled Irian Jaya province in a bid to quell violent separatism, officials said today.
fields.body:
Indonesia's President Abdurrahman Wahid is to visit troubled Irian Jaya province in a bid to quell violent separatism, officials said today.

Details of the trip were released a day after President Wahid made a brief visit to Aceh, the predominantly Muslim province in north-west Sumatra that is also the scene of a bloody independence struggle.

When he visits Irian Jaya on December 25, Wahid hopes to meet with community and religious leaders and take part in Christmas celebrations, presidential palace official Pria Sambadha said.

Unlike much of Indonesia, where 90% of people are Muslim, Irian Jaya is home to many Christians

Rebels in the province, located on the western half of New Guinea island and also known as West Papua, have been fighting for independence since Indonesia took control of the former Dutch colony in 1963.

There has been an upsurge in violence recently, with at least 19 people killed in clashes this month.

Police arrested five separatist leaders ahead of a December 1 ceremony to mark the 39th anniversary of a failed, unilateral declaration of independence from Dutch rule.

Irian Jaya community leader Sofyan Wandgai met with President Wahid in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta today and said the president repeated demands that the five be released.

President Wahid's earlier requests have been ignored by security officers and hardline members of his government.

The five men, including head of the Papua Presidium Council Theys Eluay, have been accused of subversion and face up 20 years in prison if convicted.

Yesterday, President Wahid visited Aceh and admitted that he had made mistakes in handling the separatist crisis that has claimed at least 432 lives since a ceasefire came into effect between Aceh rebels and government forces in June.

In a nationally televised speech, he said peace negotiations with the rebel Free Aceh Movement must continue even if the cease-fire lapses when it expires on January 15.

He countered threats from the military and cabinet ministers who have called for tough action. President Wahid ordered Indonesian troops to stop attacking civilians and start building trust.

However, in an ominous turn, Defense Minister Mohammad Mahfud said direct peace talks with the rebels will end after the ceasefire expires.

"From that time on there will be no more direct negotiations with the rebels, but if they like they can take part in talks between the government and Acehnese leaders," he told journalists.
