webTitle: In brief: Downey Jr given parole, but still faces jail term

fields.headline: Downey Jr given parole, but still faces jail term
fields.standfirst: Plus: Helen Hunt and Hank Azaria divorce after less than two years; Billy Bob Thornton and Angelina Jolie tie the knot for second time in one year
fields.trailText: Plus: Helen Hunt and Hank Azaria divorce after less than two years; Billy Bob Thornton and Angelina Jolie tie the knot for second time in one year
fields.body:
 If it's Wednesday (or Friday, or Monday, etc) it must be another Robert Downey Jr (pictured) news story. The latest instalment in the troubled actor's ongoing soap opera occurred yesterday when he was officially given parole in a brief court hearing presided over by Judge Lawrence Mira. The granting of parole was the final disposition in the drugs and guns case of 1996 which resulted in a lengthy jail sentence. But the actor is not out of the woods yet. He now faces arraignment on charges relating to a separate drugs bust in Palm Springs on November 25. If found guilty, Downey Jr could face a maximum sentence of four years, eight months.

 Helen Hunt has filed for divorce from her husband Hank Azaria, although they have reportedly been separated for six months. Hunt, 37, and Azaria only married 17 months ago but had been dating for several years before that. Hunt won an Oscar for her role in As Good as it Gets (thanking Azaria in her acceptance speech) and will soon be seen in Play it Forward, Dr T and the Women, What Women Want and Cast Away. Azaria is perhaps best known as the voice of a galaxy of Simpsons characters, including Moe the bartender, Montgomery Burns, Smithers and steady Neddy Flanders.

 Billy Bob Thornton and Angelina Jolie are set to marry again. The eccentric couple tied the knot in a hasty ceremony in Las Vegas earlier this year but are planning a more leisurely repeat of their vows this Christmas. Thornton hints that this re-affirmation of their love could develop into something of a habit "In fact we really want to get married every six months," he told reporters.

webTitle: Sorry, but it's not you . . .

fields.headline: Sorry, but it's not you . . .
fields.trailText: Branson may launch court challenge after accusing government of betraying voters by leaving Camelot in charge. David Teather reports
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson yesterday launched a bitter attack on the government and the national lottery commission after losing to Camelot in the contest to run the game for the next seven years.

The founder of the Virgin empire was abject after watching his hopes of running the lottery slip from his grasp. He said he was "extremely disappointed and baffled" by the outcome which overturned a decision in the summer naming his non-profit making People's Lottery as preferred bidder.

He raised the possibility of legal challenge and said he would be meeting lawyers overnight.

By reversing the earlier decision Lord Burns, the commission chairman, added to the embarrassment of culture secretary Chris Smith who had backed the original judgment. Shadow culture secretary Peter Ainsworth said yesterday's outcome "sets the seal on Chris Smith's 'annus horribilis'".

Sir Richard, who has now failed twice in his long-held ambition to run the lottery, said he would not make a third attempt. He accused the government of betraying voters by allowing Camelot to remain in office and said it effectively now had a licence for life. He was also sharply critical of Lord Burns, who took office in October.

"A non-profit making lottery was an election pledge which is not being honoured and it is sad that one civil servant can be appointed to a commission and change everything dramatically," he said.

For Camelot the victory meant an astounding comeback after being ruled out of the contest in August and only muscling its way back in to the running through the high court.

Its successful campaign owed much to the resilience of Dianne Thompson, who was officially installed as Camelot chief executive when the result was announced.

She said she was "absolutely delighted" at yesterday's outcome: "The past year has been a very stressful time for both bidders. It has been a very long process which needs to be re-evaluated and I think Lord Burns knows that."

Sir Richard accused Lord Burns of imposing his will on the other commissioners. One of the four, Hilary Blume, resigned over the decision, continuing the form of a process which has been marred by controversy. "I could not agree with the decision to award the licence to run the lottery to Camelot. I believe the lottery needs a relaunch to arrest declining sales," she said in a statement.

Sir Richard added: "We have no idea what Lord Burn's reasons were. The previous commissioner spent months with us, analysing our game plans and marketing strategy. All that Lord Burns has done is come in, read the documents and change the other commissioners' minds. The reality is that people, the players, wanted the People's Lottery to win."

In a long statement of reasons for rejecting the People's Lottery, the commission returned repeatedly to the suggestion that it was more risky to appoint a new operator.

The commission also said it believed Camelot would register higher sales. Camelot which has run the lottery since its launch six years ago has so far raised more than £9bn for good causes.

There was inevitable speculation that the publication of a critical biography of Sir Richard by investigative journalist Tom Bower may have had some influence.

The process of awarding the next licence which runs from October next year has been plagued with difficulty. The former chairwoman of the commission, Dame Helena Shovelton, resigned after her decision to pursue exclusive negotiations with Sir Richard's bid was overturned in court and described as "conspicuously unfair". Camelot has promised to raise £15bn for good causes during the next seven year licence, almost 50% higher than the current term.

It will keep the existing game format of six numbers from 49, as well as Thunderball and the Instants scratchcards. New elements will include at least four additional online games and a greater choice of ways to play through the internet, mobile phones and interactive television.Ms Thompson promised £1bn of investment in new terminals, marketing and infrastructure.

webTitle: Nickelodeon appoints new UK managing director

fields.headline: Nickelodeon appoints new UK managing director
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Nickelodeon has appointed ex-Turner Broadcasting marketing executive Nicky Parkinson as UK managing director, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Nickelodeon has ended a six-month search by appointing a Turner Broadcasting marketing executive to be its new UK managing director.

Nicky Parkinson is the second female boss in a row for the children's cable TV channel. She replaces Janey Grace, who left in July to be head of children's and youth programming for ITV.

Ms Parkinson joins from Turner Broadcasting Systems Europe, where she has been marketing Cartoon Network, TNT and TCC since 1995.

Before joining Turner Broadcasting she worked for the advertising agencies Saatchi & Saatchi and Grey Advertising.

Nickelodeon UK faces stiff challenges from the BBC's planned new children's digital channels, which it has opposed vehemently.

Earlier this autumn it submitted to the Department for Culture, Media & Sport a report claiming that the new channels would distort the market and could put one of its channels, Nick Jnr, out of business.

Ms Parkinson has been appointed above the station's existing general manager, Paul Lindley, and head of programmes Howard Litton.

She said she had "great respect for their leadership in helping to build one of the UK's most respected and successful operations".

Mr Lindley and Mr Litton have been promoted to a new senior management team alongside Ms Parkinson.

fields.headline: How the woman from Ratners turned the fight in Camelot's favour
fields.trailText: At 8.30am on Monday, the five members of the National Lottery Commission locked themselves away to assess the two bids for the next seven-year licence to run the game.
fields.body:
At 8.30am on Monday, the five members of the National Lottery Commission locked themselves away to assess the two bids for the next seven-year licence to run the game.

Four of them had been there before. On that occasion, in mid-August, they came to the unanimous conclusion that the commission should proceed with exclusive negotiations with Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery, consigning Camelot to history.

By the time they emerged from a gruelling 12-hour meeting late on Monday evening, however, all but one commission member had changed their minds. The lottery was back in Camelot's hands. The lone voice of dissent, Hilary Blume, resigned from the commission to express her dissatisfaction.

Two things had happened in the intervening months. The first was the appointment of Lord Burns, who was parachuted in as commission chairman after Dame Helena Shovelton's dramatic resignation. Second was probably the most spirited piece of scrapping that the corporate world has seen from Camelot, which culminated in Dame Helena's departure from office.

If ever there was an example of victory being snatched from the jaws of defeat, then Camelot's Lazarus-like recovery was it. Capitalising on the commission's mishandling of the bidding process, it underwent a transformation from one of the most vilified companies in Britain to being cast as the underdog in an unfair contest for the licence. The groans which might otherwise have been expected on its victory yesterday were replaced with nods that justice had been done.

The lengthy negotiations on Monday seem to suggest that this may not have been as clear cut a decision as some reports made out.

When he was appointed in October Lord Burns was warmly welcomed by both camps, but Sir Richard was yesterday left cursing what he described as the whim of one civil servant defeating his long held ambitions. Simon Burridge, chief executive of the People's Lottery, was incandescent over the role that Lord Burns had played. "He has imposed his own will on the rest of the commission. Our bids haven't changed and suddenly everything's turned around. It was a fantastically shoddy performance."

Lord Burns clearly demonstrated in his judgment that he was risk averse, choosing the safer option of the tried and tested operator. There was, he said, "more uncertainty" surrounding the People's Lottery. He appeared to suggest that it would be highly unlikely that any company could successfully challenge Camelot.

The statement of reasons also suggested that Camelot was likely to achieve higher sales, that Sir Richard's bid had underestimated the costs of starting up and that his changes to the game format were too risky. The financial robustness of the People's Lottery was also questioned. The decision, however, may have compromised Lord Burns's fellow commissioners who had lent towards the People's Lottery bid in the earlier decision.

No substantive changes had been allowed in either bid between the August pronouncement and yesterday's decision - Camelot and the People's Lottery were merely given the chance to belie very specific concerns. For that reason, the People's Lottery believes that it may be able to fight the latest decision in the courts.

There was one figure who proved even more influential than the commission chairman. Lord Burns would not have been appointed had it not been for the efforts of Dianne Thompson, the feisty chief executive-designate who waged Camelot's campaign. For her, yesterday's decision was a personal triumph.

She owns to having met Sir Richard only twice. The first time was on the sofa at GMTV. After they left the studio, his one remark to her was allegedly that she was very short. On the second occasion, at a party, he spoke with confidence about his chances of winning, before she reminded him that they had met before, and that she worked for Camelot.

Sir Richard, it would seem, underestimated his diminutive opponent. He yesterday conceded that she had put up a "great fight".

A single mother and self avowed straight talking Yorkshire woman, she did much to dispel the fat cat, profiteering image that had blighted the company. A Co-op butcher's daughter from Batley, the impression she left was instead of a passionate and fair minded campaigner.

Infamous

Her career included a spell as marketing director of Woolworths and then Signet, the retailer which owned the Ratners jewellery chain, where she had the task of turning the business around in the wake of the infamous "crap" comment.

Before taking the top job at Camelot she had been commercial operations director at the company. She unsurprisingly noted that Lord Burns was a man "with the courage to make the right decision".

The invitation to tender for the licence from October next year was made in November 1999 and the outcome was twice delayed before events turned in mid-August.

Despite running what experts argue is the most successful national lottery in the world, Camelot began the fight against Sir Richard with the odds stacked against it.

It has to date raised £9.2bn for good causes, but its stewardship of the lottery has been dogged with controversy. From dramatic slumps in the sale of scratchcards, to front page headlines crying foul play over the size of its profits and fatcat accusations over its directors' high pay, Camelot has not had an easy ride.

But the real damage was done by Camelot's chief software supplier, the US firm GTech. In February, a whistleblower informed the commission that GTech had covered up a software glitch which had caused some winners to be shortchanged. The story proved incendiary.

Neither was this the first time that GTech had sullied Camelot's reputation. Guy Snowdon, the former chairman, was forced to resign after losing a libel case against Sir Richard, who alleged that GTech had attempted to bribe him to withdraw during the last round of bidding in the early 1990s.

On the decision day in August, Camelot's bid was dismissed because of fears over the probity of GTech, despite the resignations of the men responsible for covering up the software problems. The prevarications of the commission worked in Camelot's favour, by making the company look as though it had been wronged. Dame Helena also left a chink of light for Camelot by giving Sir Richard one month to allay the commission's concerns about the robustness of his bid, instead of simply awarding the licence to the People's Lottery and continuing discussions on the fine print in private.

Within two days Camelot had applied for a judicial review that was to prove pivotal. Dame Helena's decision was thrown out in a judgement that the commission had been "conspicuously unfair". Camelot was back in the game and had a month to revise its bid.

Bruising

The bruising encounter between Camelot and the commission that followed resulted in Dame Helena's resignation. A relentless campaign in the media ensued, culminating in the contention that Dame Helena had subjected the company to a "gratuitous insult" with a half-hearted apology signed by one of her aparatchiks.

When Camelot scheduled a board meeting to decide whether to call for Dame Helena's resignation, she quit, claiming she had been a target of "personal vilification" in the media.

Camelot had already done much to repair its public image. Ms Thompson's £330,000 salary is a third lower than her predecessor's, and further bonuses have been ruled out. Dividends to shareholders have been halved.

In the additional month, Camelot severed its relationship with GTech by buying its UK operation.

Its bid was backed by the Post Office and a promised £15bn will be raised for good causes during the life of the licence.

The suspicion among some that the commission had been coloured by political values which preferred Sir Richard's non-profit making bid also probably aided Camelot. The real loser in the process though was not Sir Richard but the commission itself, and, by association, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, who appointed its members. The questions about how the process could so desperately lose credibility are only just beginning.

webTitle: Commission's Thatcherite chairman is no stranger to controversy

fields.headline: Commission's Thatcherite chairman is no stranger to controversy
fields.trailText: Lord Burns, 56, the former Treasury mandarin who became chairman of the National Lottery Commission in October, is well used to controversy. Prior to taking the job he chaired the government's inquiry into hunting, which was widely viewed as giving grist to the anti-hunting lobby.
fields.body:
Lord Burns, 56, the former Treasury mandarin who became chairman of the National Lottery Commission in October, is well used to controversy. Prior to taking the job he chaired the government's inquiry into hunting, which was widely viewed as giving grist to the anti-hunting lobby.

The appointment of one of Whitehall's most experienced figures was viewed as a signal that the culture secretary, Chris Smith, hoped to restore some credibility to the tarnished bidding process. Whether he has managed to do so will depend largely on whether Sir Richard Bran son decides to challenge the commission's decision in the courts.

The merits of a non-profit making bid such as the People's Lottery's were always likely to be lost on Lord Burns. He was a Thatcherite appointee to the Treasury, where he worked for almost 20 years. When the chancellor, Gordon Brown, took control in 1997, he was "retired" a year later with a peerage.

He managed to negotiate a 50% increase in salary over his predecessor at the lottery commission, to £48,000. He is also a non-executive director of the media group Pearson, and Legal & General.

Lord Burns clashed with Hilary Blume who resigned from the lottery commission yesterday because she disagreed with the outcome. Ms Blume, 55, a leading figure in the charity world refused to fall in line with the argument that Sir Richard's bid was more risky. She also believed he would raise more cash for good causes.

Ms Blume is vice-chairwoman of the Finnart House Trust, which works with deprived and vulnerable Jewish youngsters, and is also a founder and director of the Charities Advisory Trust, which gives trading advice to charitable organisations.

The other members of the commission are Brian Pomeroy, 55, former senior partner with Deloitte Consulting, Rosalind Gilmore, 63, a director of the Zurich Financial Services Group, and Harriet Spicer, 49, who helped to launch the publishing house Virago Press.

webTitle: Freeserve deal will put national lottery online

fields.headline: Freeserve deal will put national lottery online
fields.standfirst: Special report: national lottery
fields.trailText: Camelot today struck a deal with internet service provider Freeserve as it moved to capitalise on yesterday's decision to allow it to continue running the national lottery.
fields.body:
Camelot today struck a deal with internet service provider Freeserve as it moved to capitalise on yesterday's decision to allow it to continue running the national lottery.

Under the deal, Freeserve will work with Camelot to develop ways of letting people buy lottery tickets online, and ensure that transactions are secure.

Freeserve will also create a co-branded national lottery website and will initially be the only portal to offer national lottery tickets for sale over the internet.

The national lottery commission yesterday awarded Camelot the licence to continue running the lottery for the next seven years, rejecting the bid by Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery. Sir Richard says he will make a decision early next year on whether to launch a legal challenge to the decision.

Freeserve's chief financial officer, Nicholas Blackhouse, said: "The national lottery operated by Camelot is a phenomenally popular franchise, with sales of over £28bn since November 1994.

"This deal further demonstrates Freeserve's ability to provide well-known brands with distribution to the UK's largest online community."

Freeserve, the UK's largest internet service provider, is being taken over by French rival Wanadoo.

On Monday it posted widening losses for the last half of the financial year, with operating losses, before exceptional items, goodwill and other costs, increasing from £9.4m to £20.6m.

webTitle: Tough on toys, tough on the causes of toys

fields.headline: Tough on toys, tough on the causes of toys
fields.standfirst: Jeremy Hardy: How we ensure that asylum seekers stick to life's bare essentials.
fields.trailText: It behoves me to clarify last week's column, because Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, has written to contradict me on two points. Whenever you see a minister do this, it is worth re-reading the article about which they are complaining, to see which accusations they do not deny.
fields.body:
It behoves me to clarify last week's column, because Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, has written to contradict me on two points. Whenever you see a minister do this, it is worth re-reading the article about which they are complaining, to see which accusations they do not deny.

For example, Ms Roche did not deny that the role of the national asylum support service is to make refugees' lives as miserable as possible or that the government is busy jailing as many as possible. Perhaps most worryingly, she did not deny that she gives children fishfingers as Christmas presents. I admit I was going out on a limb with that one and couldn't have backed it up if challenged, but it seems to be a gamble that paid off, because we must assume it's true.

In fact, she did not deny that the Asylum Support Regulations published this year define toys as not being an "essential living need", which means that the level of support for refugees was calculated expressly to exclude the possibility of their buying toys. Since those were the government's words, Ms Roche is hard-pressed to shake them off, although bolder ministers would try. I believe the correct thing for politicians to say about something like that is: "We were trying to start a debate". Instead, Ms Roche tells us that refugees "can use their vouchers in 23,500 retail outlets on anything they want". I suppose that's true; they could buy the kid a pony if they starved her for a year and Asda had one in stock.

It is hard to develop a clear picture of exactly what's happening nationwide, because the asylum support system is in chaos. Which shops are designated to take vouchers varies from place to place, and the items that shops will exchange for them vary even more. With refugees dispersed to all kinds of remote places, there is no guarantee that they can spend their vouchers anywhere nearby at all. The ones in prison get no vouchers but full board and free racial abuse.

The main point about vouchers is that their function is to humiliate vulnerable people and make them identifiable in communities that might already be reluctant to accept them. The only people who benefit from the scheme are the far right, the supermarkets, the Sodexho corporation which prints the vouchers, and the government, which gets to demonstrate that it is tough on toys and tough on the causes of toys. If, as Ms Roche suggests, the level of support is similar to that provided to other welfare claimants, the scheme is more expensive than paying cash.

In fact, when Ms Roche says that the support given by NASS is "broadly equivalent to income support levels", she is right only to the extent that it's less. It is true that, although the value of vouchers is much lower than income support, refugees get a few other bits and bobs that partly close the gap. When everything is added up, refugees get about 80% of income support, quite a bit less than not very much. Moreover, "free furnished accommodation" is a grandiose way of describing the holes into which asylum seekers and other welfare claimants are dumped. In fact, most of the places laughably called "hotels" have got some furniture in them. Refugees are not disporting themselves on the finest chaises longues while single mums in the same B&B sit enviously on metal spikes. In many cases, the accommodation on offer is much the same, but again, systems vary around the country, and landlords are a law unto themselves.

The dispersal system itself is pure harassment. Recently, a refugee was sent from the Tees Valley to Leicester, away from his best friend and only known contact in the UK, on the pretext that there was no single male accommodation available. The same day, a man in Leicester was dispersed to the Tees Valley.

But, in any case, is not Gordon Brown furious that, while he talks up his munificence, the Home Office brags that all welfare claimants live miserably, not just asylum seekers? In April, Jack Straw reassured the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture that, for all those on welfare, "there is equally no special provision made for toys". Well, praise be.

There is a strong case for saying that displaced people with traumatised children and no extended family around them are even more in need than are other deprived families. The Medical Foundation has cited the particular therapeutic effects of play for refugee children. But the fact that we should even be weighing up the perks of being different kinds of pauper is a woeful indictment of government. Of the ruling that toys are non-essential, Straw says: "The purpose of that provision is to ensure that families are not regarded as destitute simply because they cannot afford toys for their children." Merry bloody Christmas.

webTitle: Gladiator grabs awards in pre-Oscar showdown

fields.headline: Gladiator grabs awards in pre-Oscar showdown
fields.trailText: In the latest end-of-year awards show, Ridley Scott's epic has scooped fiveBroadcast Critics Choice prizes, making it one of the hot contenders for Oscar glory, along with Traffic and Almost Famous
fields.body:
A week is a long time in Hollywood. Just six days after Steven Soderbergh's Traffic cleaned up at the New York Critics Circle Awards, Gladiator (pictured) appears to have stolen its thunder. Ridley Scott's Roman epic was the big winner at last night's Broadcast Critics Choice Awards.

Last night Gladiator took the top prizes for cinematography, soundtrack and production design. Russell Crowe won best actor for the second year running for his role as Maximus (last year he took the prize for The Insider), while Joaquin Phoenix was named best supporting actor.

Gladiator may yet also take Broadcast's award for the best film of 2000, which will not be announced until January 22. The film is one of eleven potential winners, on a list alongside Traffic, Almost Famous, Quills, Thirteen Days, Wonder Boys, You Can Count on Me, Cast Away, Erin Brockovich, Billy Elliot and Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

The current rash of end-of-year awards may be largely small fry, but they are being closely scrutinised by those within the industry. One Academy member likened them to primaries in a presidential race. To perform well at the small ceremonies is to build up a momentum which can lead to Oscar glory at the Academy Awards in March.

After scoring at the Broadcast awards, Gladiator will no doubt have raised its stock among Oscar voters. But other gong shows continue to send mixed messages. On Monday the Boston Society of Film Critics revealed that it's best film of 2000 was neither Traffic nor Gladiator, but Cameron Crowe's Seventies rock odyssey Almost Famous. Clearly there is no cut and dried Oscar favourite as yet.

webTitle: Ousby quits Virgin Radio

fields.headline: Ousby quits Virgin Radio to go solo
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Virgin Radio is to lose its head of online - just as it gears up for expansion into internet radio, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Virgin Radio is to lose its head of online in the new year - just as it gears up for expansion into internet radio.

John Ousby, a well-respected veteran of the UK internet scene, has quit to set up his own internet venture. He said he was going into business with friends but would not give any further details.

He said: "I've achieved a lot of the objectives that I set out to and now I feel it's the right time to move on. It's a scary thought to think I'm going to be out there on my own."

Mr Ousby joined Virgin Radio eight years ago as finance controller but soon became involved in the development of the station's internet strategy.

He launched the radio station's first website in March 1996 and went on to set up Ginger Online in 1998.

Michaela Smith, Virgin Radio managing editor, will take Mr Ousby's place as acting head of online when he leaves in mid-January.

Overall new media strategy at Virgin is now being decided by Scottish Media Group, which bought Virgin Radio earlier this year.

SMG is currently gearing up for the launch of s1, which will operate as an umbrella brand for SMG's new media activities. The first s1 site will be s1jobs.com, followed by s1homes.com and s1travel.com.

S1 is also developing online strategies for Scottish and Grampian TV brands and for SMG newspapers the Herald, the Sunday Herald and the Evening Times.

webTitle: NewMedia Spark posts £1.4m loss

fields.headline: NewMedia Spark posts £1.4m loss
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Internet incubator firm NewMedia Spark is optimistic despite reporting pre-tax losses of £1.4m, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Internet incubator firm NewMedia Spark today reported pre-tax losses of £1.4m for the six months to September 30 but said it remains optimistic about its technology investments.

The losses compared with a profit of £2.8m for July 1999 to March 2000.

The company has written down the value of its portfolio by 30%, including a £45.5m write-off in asset value.

Michael Whitaker, NewMediaSpark chief executive, said: "We continue to concentrate our investments on core software applications, communications infrastructure businesses and certain areas of digital media such as music and financial products."

New media incubators and investment funds have been through a rollercoaster year with many reporting losses following the dot.com shakeout that began earlier this year.

webTitle: Freeserve to sell lottery tickets online

fields.headline: Freeserve to sell lottery tickets online
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Freeserve has teamed up with Camelot to sell lottery tickets on the internet for the first time, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Freeserve has teamed up with Camelot to sell lottery tickets on the internet for the first time.

Under the agreement, announced this morning, Freeserve and Camelot develop a co-branded website for the National Lottery.

The site will, for a limited time, be the only way in which consumers will be able to buy lottery tickets online.

Nicholas Backhouse, Freeserve chief financial officer, said the deal demonstrated Freeserve's ability to provide well-known brands with distribution.

Freeserve, the UK's largest internet service provider with more than 2m users, is being taken over by French rival Wanadoo.

Since announcing the deal two weeks ago, its share price has fallen by 40p, to this morning's new low of 94p.

The announcement follows yesterday's controversial decision to award Camelot the licence to run the National Lottery for another seven years.

Culture secretary Chris Smith today called for a review of the selection process.

webTitle: Embryo research 'is not always wrong'

fields.headline: Embryo research 'is not always wrong'
fields.trailText: The relaxation of the rules governing human embryo research into "stem cell" technologies is not a "crossing of the Rubicon" because the principle was established by legislation in the Thatcher era, reports Michael White
fields.body:
The relaxation of the rules governing human embryo research into "stem cell" technologies is not a "crossing of the Rubicon" because the principle was established by legislation in the Thatcher era, MPs were told yesterday.

As the Commons voted to back new government regulations by 366 to 174, a majority 192, amid high passions on both sides the public health minister, Yvette Cooper , told her colleagues that all views deserved respect, but that she could not accept that "embryo research is always wrong in principle".

Under the provisions of the 1990 Human Fertilisation and Embryolgy Act - passed under Margaret Thatcher, herself a scientist by training - MPs are required to endorse regulation changes to reflect changing scientific possibilities, not then envisaged.

In this instance it will allow stem cells - "clusters of 100 cells that would fit on a pin head" - to be extracted from human embryos when they are five or six days old so that their "pluripotent" potential can be made into anything.

"Brain cells, nervous tissue, heart tissue," the minister predicted, though one Tory MP, Salisbury's Robert Key, likened stem cells to a photocopier which "after a time get a bit dim and start running out of toner". In an impassioned plea to the house to vote through the changes Ms Cooper invoked the prospect of giving hope to people with now-incurable conditions whose damaged tissue does not regenerate as most human tissue does.

"No matter the drugs of treatment applied, there is nothing that doctors can do for the Parkinson's sufferer whose neural cells are destroyed ... for the women who endures a dreadful stroke ... for the child who falls from a horse or bike and breaks his neck," stem cell research was the only way forward, the minister insisted.

"There are immense potential benefits from allowing this research to go ahead, particularly for those suffering from dreadful chronic disease," said Ms Cooper. She faced a battery of sceptical questioning from backbench MPs on both sides, many of them with active religious faith, including Labour's Ruth Kelly , MP for Bolton, who said the changes went beyond both what was envisaged in the 1990 act and the pioneering Warnock report on the ethics of such research.

The prominent Tory Catholic and MP for Gainsborough, Edward Leigh , brushed aside the minister's insistence that Britain was not on the slippery slope to cloning humans. Mr Leigh warned that science is poised to "create a new cloned genetic blueprint for a human being which will, if allowed, grow into a new human being unless it is de stroyed". Was it either wise or right, he asked? Turning to the Conservative health spokesman, Dr Liam Fox - who had already made clear his personal opposition to the rule change - the MP later spoke of "creating dozens of little Liam Foxes as embryos".

Ms Cooper was adamant this was not the case and was backed by a strong contingent of scientists and doctors - both PhDs and medical doctors - also on both sides of the chamber.

"Parliament is not being asked to cross the Rubicon today. Human reproductive cloning is illegal and must stay illegal. Under these regulations it will stay illegal. The idea of cloning babies is completely unacceptable to the house and public opinion as well," the minister insisted. In the third Commons debate of recent weeks, MPs also heard again from Anne Begg , Labour MP for Aberdeen South, who is confined to a wheelchair by a rare degenerative disease which such research may one day cure for others. Future generations should not needlessly be condemned to "a living hell", she argued.

Pro-life groups oppose the experiments, which are backed by groups campaigning for a cure for degenerative diseases - and fertility or contraceptive research - which are monitored by the human fertilisation and embryology authority. Embryo research is only allowed when alternatives are not available, pro-change MPs stressed last night. Most agreed with Ms Cooper that work with adult cells is not yet such a substitute, though it might one day be. She also stressed that there is no guarantee of early results, but there was hope - "false hopes", critics predicted.

Dr Fox, an ex-GP, said he was morally against the use of embryo cells and had not been convinced there was no alternative. But it was unrealistic to think such research could be halted and so tough rules were needed to set the moral boundaries.

"The benefits of the medical revolution are immense from limb grafts and transplantation to the elimination of diseases... But the medical revolution carries with it moral, ethical and philosophical consequences and our ability to deal with these matters sometimes lags behind our technical knowledge."

webTitle: Business: BT rivals rough up Bonfield at loop hearing

fields.headline: BT rivals rough up Bonfield at loop hearing
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText:
Sir Peter Bonfield has been given a rough ride over allegations that BT is obstructing competition for high-speed internet services, writes Andrew Clark.
Dec 19:BT slated by telecom rivals
fields.body:
Sir Peter Bonfield was given a rough ride at a Commons select committee hearing last night over allegations that British Telecommunications is obstructing competition for high-speed internet services.

The BT chief executive was forced on the defensive at the trade and industry committee after critical evidence from competitors.

Rivals say BT is allocating insufficient resources to unbundling the local loop - the process which enables rivals to install their equipment in local telephone exchanges.

Bill Allan, chief executive of Thus, said BT was threatening his company's plans to compete on DSL internet services - which accelerate connections over ordinary phone lines by a factor of 10 - despite intervention by the telecoms regulator, Oftel.

Anne Machin, head of carrier relations at Energis, told MPs that delays in unbundling were forcing her company to reduce its ambitions for DSL. "They're certainly being scaled back somewhat because of the uncertainties and the difficulties we're having."

The cross-party committee is investigating criticism of Oftel's handling of unbundling. The regulator has come in for savage criticism from many senior figures in the industry.

In written evidence, Cable & Wireless said Oftel had failed to devise the right structure or to be sufficiently involved in implementing unbundling. "It has become apparent that the failure of Oftel to become closely involved in the process has been a major factor in the current state of affairs."

Emma Gilthorpe, vice-president for European public policy at C&W, said it would be hard to prove BT was deliberately obstructing unbundling "but they are doing very little to facilitate this process".

A C&W engineer had seen two empty rooms at an exchange BT said had no space for competitors' equipment.

Mr Bonfield denied BT was being obstructive but admitted it did not have the resources needed for unbundling. The company would hire 2,600 people to help cope with the change.

He challenged cable companies Telewest and NTL to unbundle their networks.

webTitle: Voucher chaos leaves refugees hungry

fields.headline: Voucher chaos leaves refugees hungry
fields.trailText: Asylum seekers in Britain are being left hungry because of bureaucratic breakdowns in the government's voucher system, a report covering the work of more than 50 charities claimed yesterday. Alan Travis reports
fields.body:
Asylum seekers in Britain are being left hungry because of bureaucratic breakdowns in the government's voucher system, a report covering the work of more than 50 charities claimed yesterday.

The survey looking at the system introduced in April which gives vouchers for spending at certain shops only, came as the Transport and General Workers' Union, Oxfam and the Refugee Council urged the Home Office minister, Barbara Roche, to abolish the entire scheme and bring back cash benefits instead.

Bill Morris, the TGWU general secretary, said yesterday he feared that the outcome of a government review of asylum vouchers to be announced next month would do little more than tinker with the scheme, only scrapping the rule preventing supermarkets giving change to refugees in money or in lower denomination vouchers.

"The voucher system is expensive, bureaucratic and humiliating for asylum seekers. This survey shows that they have been experiencing hunger and cannot maintain good health. The scheme has failed and we do not want a review that is a political whitewash," said Mr Morris, who said he knew, having accompanied asylum seekers to the shops, what a "grotesque experience" they faced.

Under the scheme, single asylum seekers get vouchers worth £26.54 a week, as well as £10 cash. The vouchers must be spent at 21,000 designated shops and any change after a purchase can be pocketed by the retailer.

Mrs Roche promised to review the scheme in the face of a threatened revolt at this year's Labour party conference, with the outcome to be announced next month.

Forty-one of the 50 groups surveyed, including children's charities, local authorities, refugee agencies and others working with asylum seekers, said they had come across refugees unable to buy enough food and going hungry.

The Scottish Refugee Council said: "We have cases too numerous to list of emergency vouchers not turning up and people surviving on no income."

The Barnet Refugee Health Access Project reported the comments of a Sri Lankan man in his 60s: "The amount I get is hardly sufficient to meet our needs. I am diabetic and cannot afford to buy the special food I need. I suffer from arthritis. I need more heating and more warm clothing. I need thermal underwear, but cannot afford it."

Many charities, such as the Family Welfare Organisation, said that they were providing hardship grants for cots, winter coats and shoes and even pencils. Nearly all organisations reported that asylum seekers were finding it very difficult to stay healthy while living on vouchers and many did not have the money to pay for items such as underwear, babies' milk, nappies and toys.

Phil Bloom of Oxfam, which has boycotted the voucher scheme in its charity shops, said the vouchers had marked out asylum seekers as targets for abuse in supermarkets. He said there was little evidence to suggest that the introduction of vouchers had deterred economic migrants.

Since the cash benefits system was scrapped in April, asylum applications had risen from 5,890 to 6,970 in October.

Jack Straw was yesterday stopped from deporting hundreds of asylum seekers after law lords agreed the home secretary had acted unlawfully by ordering the return to Germany of Lul Adan, 28, from Somalia, and of Hamid Aitseguer, 33, an Algerian, to France, since these countries were not safe for refugees facing persecution from forces other than their own state. Usually, refugees can be sent back to the first safe country they arrive at, but France and Germany only recognise as refugees those facing state persecution in their own country. Lord Steyn said Mr Straw accepted that if the two asylum seekers were returned to these European countries, they would probably be sent to Somalia and Algeria to perhaps face torture and death.

webTitle: Mother sacked by firm wins test case for parents

fields.headline: Mother sacked by firm wins test case for parents
fields.trailText: A single mother who was sacked after asking to leave work to collect her sick son from school won a claim for unfair dismissal yesterday reports Angelique Chrisafis
fields.body:
A single mother who was sacked after asking to leave work to collect her sick son from school won a claim for unfair dismissal yesterday in the first case to test regulations allowing parents time off if their child falls ill.

Julie Percy, 35, from Baguley, Manchester, is the first parent to win a claim under the maternity and parental leave regulations which came into force last year, giving parents the right to take a "reasonable amount" of time off to care for a dependant.

In March, Ms Percy, who worked as a secretary for Metcalfe and Co, chartered surveyors, received a call from her eight-year-old son's school telling her he had a temperature and a discharge from his ear and needed to see a doctor. She immediately told her boss, Michael Oates, who appeared "irritated". Five minutes later, a colleague told her she was being sacked for being unreliable.

An employment tribunal in Manchester reached a unanimous decision in favour of Ms Percy, after reserving judgment in October. A compensation payout, based on loss of earnings, is to be decided. But Ms Percy found a new job one day after being dismissed from the £11,000 a year post, so she will receive only one day's pay.

"This claim is not about money, it is about the principle of parents' rights," she said yesterday. "It is wrong to say that single mothers are the only ones who suffer.

"The issues of sick children affect any couple where both parents work. I realised I had my commitments to work and I did not want to leave them without a secretary but Thomas had a very infectious complaint. I just wanted to do what was best."

Ms Percy had worked at the company for six weeks. Mr Oates told the tribunal he sacked her because she was unreliable, impolite and had an attitude problem. She had arrived 30 minutes late for work on another occasion because her son was ill. But she had also been praised by the firm and had been given two bottles of wine as a reward for good work.

Mr Oates said Ms Percy did not ask to go and pick up her son, but told him she was leaving, presenting the decision as a fait accompli. He said he regarded this as an example of a bad attitude and "the last straw".

The employment tribunal rejected the company's claim that Ms Percy was sacked not because she had to pick up her child, but because of the way she asked.

Her solicitor, John Cook, said three similar claims had been lodged in different parts of the country but this was the first ruling under the regulations which were added to the 1996 Employment Rights Act. He said the case would set a precedent for parents.

"There has been a plethora of changes in employment law in the past two years and companies need to be aware of this before taking such drastic action," he said.

"Employees now have more rights than ever, regardless of how long they have worked for the company."

Christine Gowdridge, director of Maternity Alliance, which campaigns for balance between work and childcare, said: "This case is quite extraordinary because there is a very straightforward legal right to take time off if your child is sick and particularly in an emergency.

"It is quite right that the claim was won and maybe it will publicise this little known right that everyone has to care for a sick dependant, even an elderly relative."

webTitle: Pregnancy fear on epilepsy drugs

fields.headline: Pregnancy fear on epilepsy drugs
fields.trailText: Women who take one of the commonest medications for epilepsy while they are pregnant are at risk of having a child with impaired brain development, according to research published today reports Sarah Boseley
fields.body:
Women who take one of the commonest medications for epilepsy while they are pregnant are at risk of having a child with impaired brain development, according to research published today.

There have been concerns for some time that epilepsy drugs could harm the foetus, but scientists have found it difficult to assess whether any damage is caused by the medication, the disease itself or other factors.

A study of 721 women with epilepsy carried out by researchers at the university department of neurology in Liverpool has now pointed the finger at the drug valproate which has been prescribed in the UK for 25 years.

Writing in the Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery and Psychiatry, David Chadwick and colleagues said their findings suggest use of the drug in pregnancy "carries particular risks for the development of children exposed in utero".

The findings have serious implications for women with epilepsy of childbearing age, who make up a third of all those taking anti-epileptic medicines. One in 250 pregnant women is estimated to be on anti-epilepsy medication.

Hardly any of the 721 women who took part in a survey had changed the epilepsy drugs they were on during pregnancy, indicating that neither they nor their GPs were aware that their baby may be at risk of impaired brain development.

The scientists asked the women, who were all registered with the Mersey regional epilepsy clinic, about their medication and about the educational development of their children.

Children whose mothers had taken anti-epilepsy drugs while pregnant were 50% more likely than others to have additional educational needs, including extra help in mainstream schools or attendance at a special school.

The numbers were particularly significant among women who had taken valproate alone. Their children had a threefold increased risk of additional needs. Those who had taken a combination which included valproate had over twice the risk.

The authors point out that over 90% of pregnancies among women with epilepsy are problem free. They also say that their findings must be viewed with caution because of the retrospective nature of the study.

Yet they are clear that "women are at increased risk of adverse outcomes".

They are undertaking further research to establish the effects of current medication on pregnant epileptics, but they also want to see more work done on new drugs arriving on the market.

webTitle: Doctor struck off over genital surgery

fields.headline: Doctor struck off over genital surgery
fields.trailText: A GP was struck off the medical register yesterday for serious professional misconduct in offering to carry out genital mutilation at £50 a time reports Sarah Boseley
fields.body:
A GP was struck off the medical register yesterday for serious professional misconduct in offering to carry out genital mutilation at £50 a time.

Abdul Ahmed, 63, was videotaped agreeing to circumcise an eight-year-old and "circumcise and stitch" two older girls. The "stitch", it was alleged, referred to the practice, common among the Somali community, of excising the female external genitalia, including cutting away part of the labia.

Dr Ahmed denied all the charges against him at the professional conduct committee of the General Medical Council, and argued that the videotape had been edited.

The GMC did not believe him. Denis McDevitt, a professor chairing the disciplinary hearing, said: "The committee is appalled by the evidence they have heard of your offer to perform an abhorrent mutilation and illegal operation on female children."

A Somali woman went under cover to make the Channel 4 documentary Cutting the Rose, screened in 1997. Named only as Amena on film, she had been circumcised herself as a young girl and wanted to help expose those flouting a law outlawing the practice passed in 1985; the British Medical Association estimates 3,000 to 4,000 girls are still circumcised in the UK each year.

Amena told the GP, who was working in Manchester at the time, that she wanted him to perform "sunna" - the Somali word for removal of the head of the clitoris - on her daughter and two daughters of friends. Dr Ahmed was recorded on the tape concealed in Amena's handbag as saying: "I will do the circumcision at my home today. It will not be free, it will cost £50." When asked about the friend's two daughters, he said: "I can do the circumcision and the stitch, because they are older."

Dr Ahmed, now a senior partner in a practice in Stoke Newington, north London, denied he had ever carried out such operations on girls. "I told her [Amena] that I did not do female circumcision," he told the hearing. "Part of the tape when I tell her this is missing." His counsel, Alan Jenkins, claimed the GP was hard of hearing and thought they were discussing boys. The GMC rejected his explanations. "The committee do not find credible your account, given both in your police interview and in your evidence today."

He has 28 days to appeal.

webTitle: Government presses ahead with mental health reforms

fields.headline: Government presses ahead with mental health reforms
fields.trailText: Sweeping reforms to mental health laws which will give doctors new powers to lock up patients and force them to have treatment were proposed by the government today.
fields.body:
Sweeping reforms to mental health laws which will give doctors new powers to lock up patients and force them to have treatment were proposed by the government today.

The white paper for reform of the Mental Health Act proposes that people with severe and untreatable personality disorders should be detained indefinitely if experts consider they are a danger to the public.

The paper received a mixed reception. Some mental health organisations welcomed the new proposals but other campaigners warned the new powers would prompt a return to Victorian-style asylums, with innocent people locked up.

Care in the community patients who refuse to take their medication could be forcibly detained under the new laws. And victims of violent crime by mentally ill people will be given the right to know when their attacker is released.

The radical overhaul of the law in England and Wales is designed to close legal loopholes after more than 10 years of what some see as high-profile failings in care in the community policy.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, said: "These changes amount to the biggest shake up in mental health laws in four decades.

"They will strengthen the current law. They will introduce new safeguards for patients. They will improve protection for the wider community.

"Taken with the major investment and reforms that are now taking place in our mental health services these proposals will enhance the safety both of patients and of the public."

At present, people who are mentally ill but deemed untreatable by psychiatrists, such as people with personality disorders or psychopaths, cannot be detained under the Mental Health Act.

The legal loophole was highlighted by the case of Michael Stone, who had a severe personality disorder, but despite being diagnosed for several years could not be treated in a secure unit. In 1996, he bludgeoned Lin Russell and her six-year-old daughter Megan to death as they walked through fields near their home.

The new proposals remove the "treatability" criteria from the mental health laws. It means that if a doctor considers patients to have a personality disorder and thinks they are a danger to themselves or other people, they can be detained for up to 28 days after an assessment. After that month, a new mental health tribunal consisting of experts will review the case and could order the patient to be detained for a further six months.

The tribunal can continue to make the orders indefinitely as long as the case is reviewed and rigorous assessment criteria are applied. But experts are still trying to develop the criteria to assess whether someone is "dangerous" and needs to be detained.

Two pilot projects are still ongoing to develop the criteria and campaigners are concerned innocent people could be detained. More than 2,000 people in the UK are considered to have a dangerous and severe personality disorder.

Most of them are men and the majority are in prison, but around 600 are believed to be in the community.

Mr Milburn said: "At present neither the law nor services are geared to cope with the risks posed by dangerous people with severe personality disorder. "As a consequence there has been a gap in the protection mental health laws should afford the public - a gap we will now close."

The white paper proposals also include plans to ensure mentally ill patients released into the community are managed properly.

Failings in the policy were highlighted recently by the case of Anthony Joseph, a mentally ill man who killed a woman after refusing to take his medication. Under the new law, patients released into the community will agree a care plan to take their medication either at a doctor's surgery or under the care of a psychiatric nurse who could visit them in their home. If they refuse to comply with the agreement, they could be forcibly detained in hospital and treated.

The proposals also included the setting up of a Mental Health Commission to protect patients' rights.

Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health
Matt Muijen, Sainsbury Centre director, said the white paper was a "step forward" and an improvement on the green paper. "The overall vision I like, but some of the detail will be challenging. On its own it won't work but if it's backed up with proper resources it begins to make sense."

Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health
Matt Muijen, Sainsbury Centre director, said the white paper was a "step forward" and an improvement on the green paper. "The overall vision I like, but some of the detail will be challenging. On its own it won't work but if it's backed up with proper resources it begins to make sense."

National Schizophrenia Fellowship (NSF)
NSF chief executive Cliff Prior called the white paper a "step in the right direction" in so far as it seeks to reduce the number of individuals who are subject to the use of powers for compulsory care and treatment. But he added that extra investment was needed: "There is no buy-now, pay-later period when it comes to investing in mental health."

Sane
Marjorie Wallace, chief executive of Sane, said she welcomed the white paper as a "move forward" that was long overdue. But she added: "We are very concerned about this whole idea of compulsion. We have been fighting to say that compulsion must be used as a last resort." She said she would much prefer to see people treated in a clinical setting rather than the community if they have to be given some form of treatment against their wishes.

Zito Trust
Jayne Zito, the founder of the trust, said: "The reforms that it (the government) is announcing today will enable patients who do deteriorate when they don't take their treatment, to be treated in the community and to sustain a level of mental health so they don't have to be recalled to hospital.

"It is important that the public recognise that there is a small minority of patients within our mental health system who do not comply with their treatment orders. This legislation will ensure that these patients are followed up with tight supervision and, if they do not comply with their treatment, that risk will be minimised."

Mind
Chief executive Judi Clements said the charity was "delighted" that the government had listened to its concerns about compulsory treatment, and accepted the need for specialist independent advocates for psychiatric patients.

She added: "It is, however, deeply disappointing to see the government waste the best opportunity for decades to 'shore up the gaps' in mental health services by giving people the right to a psychiatric assessment, and a right to get the mental health services they need."

NHS Confederation
NHS Confederation chief executive Stephen Thornton said: "The proposals for dangerous severe personality disorder must be based on rigorous definitions of dangerous severe personality disorder and treatability.

"They must also be acceptable within the constraints imposed by the European convention on human rights and the Human Rights Act 1998. At present mental health services have no reliable evidence on which to make the link between the severity of personality disorder and dangerousness."

Kings Fund
Angela Greatley, fellow in mental health at the Kings Fund, said the government needed to make sufficient resources available to implement its white paper, and called on ministers to publish an estimated of how much the reforms would cost. She added that there were concerns over compulsory treatment. "The minister's statement does not allay our concerns over these aspects of the proposed new act, especially when people are to be treated on a compulsory basis in the community."

Mental Health Foundation
Nigel Duerdoth, director of programmes at the foundation, said the white paper plans to introduce compulsory treatment in the community were "unworkable and impracticable, as well as against the spirit of human rights". He added that the compulsory powers element was likely to damage the relationships between mental health users and staff.

Mental After Care Association (MACA)
Gil Hitchon, MACA chief executive, said she doubted whether the compulsory community treatment orders would be effective - and might even make things worse. "More compulsory powers could harm the vital relationship of trust between users of services and care professionals, and drive people away from services, thereby increasing risk of harm to themselves or others."

webTitle: Psychiatrists may boycott white paper's treatment powers

fields.headline: Psychiatrists may boycott white paper's treatment powers
fields.trailText: Ministers are expected today to set out in a white paper how they aim to make it easier to administer compulsory treatment of people with serious mental disorders. But a survey has suggested that a majority of psychiatrists disagree with the plans and a sizeable minority may even be prepared to boycott them.
fields.body:
Ministers are expected today to set out in a white paper how they aim to make it easier to administer compulsory treatment of people with serious mental disorders. But a survey has suggested that a majority of psychiatrists disagree with the plans and a sizeable minority may even be prepared to boycott them.

The impetus for some of the proposed changes has come from high-profile cases such as that of Michael Stone, who in 1996 attacked Josie Russell and killed her mother and sister after his personality disorder was deemed untreatable.

According to draft proposals, new legislation would allow detention of people with such severe anti-social disorders - even if they could not be diagnosed with a specific clinical condition and even, in some cases, if they had committed no crime. For people with treatable mental illness, doctors would be able to force them to take medication even if they were living at home. At present, this can be done only if they are admitted to hospital.

The survey, part of which was recently published in the British Journal of Psychiatry, involved nearly 1,200 psychiatrists. Almost two-thirds disagree with the plan for detaining people with personality disorders, and almost a third said they might boycott it.

The plan for compulsory community treatment was less vehemently opposed, but a third said they disagreed and more than a sixth would consider a boycott.

Mike Crawford, a psychiatrist at St Mary's hospital, London, who carried out the survey, is personally worried that there is no clinical evidence of treatment of personality disorder. "I don't think anyone can say with any confidence that anti-social people can be treated," he said. While welcoming some government reforms, he believes that in this case ministers are being too heavy-handed.

"The government is focusing on preventing very rare incidents," he said. "Is it right to impose legislation on thousands and thousands of people with mental illness because a few commit crimes? We don't have specific legislation to imprison people with alcohol problems."

Dr Crawford also said compulsory drug regimens for people living at home is the wrong approach. He said: "My experience is, if you spend more time building relationships with people it's better in the long run. I don't think you can ever force any one to have treatment outside of hospital - people can always refuse to turn up for their appointments. If you can develop a partnership with the patients, and develop a treatment plan, there's a greater likelihood they'll carry that through."

The number of cases of compulsory treatment would rise under the new system, Dr Crawford said, as availability of hospital beds would no longer limit the number of patients sectioned. "At the moment, the limited number of beds does make you think carefully about whether they should be admitted," he said.

Some of the government's proposals are welcomed by groups such as the Zito Trust. Michael Howlett, director of the mental health charity, said community treatment orders could help mentally ill people avoid admission to hospital. "At the moment they have had to be ill enough to be sectioned. These could help them get treatment before that happens."

But most other groups in the sector are less supportive of the proposals. Dr Crawford said: "There's a moral issue about whether society should be able to make somebody do something they don't want to do. It should not be done lightly."

webTitle: White paper a worry to mental health professionals

fields.headline: White paper a worry to mental health professionals
fields.standfirst: Detaining patients who are thought to present a serious risk, but who have committed no offence, is a tricky area, writes Ray Rowden
fields.trailText: Comment: Detaining patients who are thought to present a serious risk, but who have committed no offence, is a tricky area, writes Ray Rowden.
fields.body:
This afternoon's much heralded white paper on mental health legislation will play well to middle England in the run-up to an election - but it will worry many people using mental health services and many of the professionals working with them.

The main idea in the white paper seems to be that a person living with serious mental health problems, such as schizophrenia, should be compelled to comply with treatment, and failure to do so will lead to enforced admission to a place where such treatment can be given under a new care and treatment order.

The white paper is clear that when civil powers are used the individual has a clear and legal right to a proper care plan, which must spell out the goals of the service enforcing the treatment. Those entering the system with a diagnosed personality disorder and deemed dangerous seem to have less right to this clear plan.

In addition, the white paper proposes new arrangements for advocacy services for people detained under the new order. A revamped Mental Health Act commission, coupled with an automatic review after 28 days by independent tribunals with a legal chair, will oversee this.

Many will welcome a properly resourced advocacy service overseen by an independent body. Too often advocacy services have been patchy and poorly resourced, with muddled lines of accountability.

However, people using the services will want assurances that such care plans go beyond the narrow issue of compliance with medication and are genuinely holistic in catering for a wide range of needs, including housing, education, employment, social networks and other support.

The danger lies in over-emphasising medication. Too many people complain of being too reliant on high doses of anti-psychotic drugs, often given as a cocktail. People with serious health needs also often find themselves on older-style drugs, which have appalling side-effects.

They are denied access to newer medications, which can offer less risk of such side-effects. For these people, the NHS is all too often not the best option.

If the paper leads to robust advocacy, better inspection of services and clearer rights to adequate care then many will welcome these changes. If these things do not happen those using the services will see the white paper as wholly negative.

The suffragettes were subject to a nasty piece of law that let them out of prison but could put them back in at any time on the slightest pretext. This became known as the "Cat and Mouse Act". Failure to deliver real improvements in the NHS and other statutory services could lead to the creation of such a law for the mentally ill. The government must ensure that adequate funding finds its way into mental health budgets.

The white paper attempts to tackle the difficult issue of people who are seen to be a serious danger to the public, and living with a personality disorder. The government proposes the application of the care and treatment order, using specific criteria to determine levels of dangerousness and places of detention. Those judged to be dangerous can be held indefinitely in specialist services.

Where people with such problems have committed serious offences I am sure many will accept that society has the right to be protected from such individuals for as long as they pose a threat to public safety. The white paper, however, goes further and suggests that people labelled with a personality disorder and thought to present serious risk, who have committed no offence, can also be detained in such services indefinitely.

This is risky territory and will make the legal profession a good deal richer. The government will argue that this will rarely happen and that the order will only apply where the risks to the public are severe.

The problems lie in the diagnosis, treatment and risk assessment of such people, which is flimsy. How can we justify indefinitely detaining a citizen who has committed no offence based on a poorly constructed diagnostic label?

People with personality disorder detained under these conditions are allowed the same rights to review by a tribunal as those detained with any other mental illness, but this is not adequate. Tribunals offer good safeguards but can become institutionalised into the mental health system.

People detained with severe limits on their civil liberties, especially where treatment outcomes are less than clear, should at least be subject to regular and robust judicial review, especially where no offence has been committed.

Thankfully the Home Office and Department of Health are not rushing to approve a model to support people living with personality disorder who become dangerous.

In a written answer to a parliamentary question in October, the home office minister, Paul Boateng, accepted that this whole area needed more thorough research, and as a result a number of well researched models are to be tested in both the NHS and the prisons system.

The research for these pilots is encouraging and could do a lot to improve our understanding of how a democratic society actually deals with some of its most complex, challenging and often vulnerable citizens.

 Ray Rowden is a former specialist adviser to the Commons Health Select Committee Inquiry into Mental health and a former director of the High Security Psychiatric Services Commissioning Board in the NHS executive. He is currently a visiting professor at the University of York.

webTitle: Canal Plus set for top-level shake-out

fields.headline: Canal Plus set for top-level shake-out
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Speculation is mounting that French pay-TV channel Canal Plus will announce a management clearout following a strategic review, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Speculation is mounting that French pay-TV channel Canal Plus will announce a management clearout following a strategic review.

Canal Plus has been stalked by reports of management upheaval ever since it merged with media giant Vivendi and Seagram of Canada, with French newspapers reporting that heads will roll tomorrow.

Le Monde said chairman Pierre Lescure wants a free rein as head of film and television at the new company, to be called Vivendi Universal, and has decided on a staff reshuffle.

Analysts have demanded "new blood" at Canal Plus, saying that its financial performance is consistently below par. So far, the channel has only confirmed that director of programmes Alain de Greef would have wider responsibilities.

Mr Lescure has said that Canal will boost its performance through cost reduction, improved marketing and interactive web services. He added that this would be carried out by structural change at the company.

Vivendi Universal boss Jean-Marie Messier has reportedly had clashes with Mr Lescure over the future direction of Canal Plus, but both men have repeatedly denied any cracks in their relationship.

However, industry observers say the real power behind Canal Plus is Denis Oliviennes, who worked at parent company Vivendi before its merger and is close to Mr Messier.

webTitle: FA seeks brand expert

fields.headline: FA seeks brand expert to shake off 'loutish' image
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Football Association is set to hire a brand expert in a bid to give its members' club a trendy upmarket image, writes Daniel Rogers.
fields.body:
The Football Association is set to hire a brand expert in a bid to give its members' club a trendy upmarket image.

The FA is desperate to shake off its image as a "club-for-louts" and is striving to turn the England Members Club into a major club for fans worldwide.

As part of chief executive Adam Crozier's root-and-branch modernisation of the organisation, the FA is this week holding final pitches for an agency to rethink the Members Club concept.

Six agencies have been shortlisted for the work and a decision is expected early next year.

Presently the club has 27,000 members and acts as a basic ticket allocation resource, but Mr Crozier believes it can be turned into a million-strong modern fan club with lucrative merchandising opportunities.

One agency head who pitched for the account said: "The FA wants to change the existing supporters club, which has received bad publicity in connection with fanatical neo-Nazis. It now wants the club to serve the wider community of football fans."

Since becoming FA chief executive in January, Mr Crozier, former Saatchi & Saatchi joint chief executive, has tried to shake off the organisation's staid image.

In October he appointed the organisation's first marketing director, Paul Barber, and hired three senior sports marketeers to restructure its marketing department.

Last month he moved the FA from its traditional home in Lancaster Gate in west London into modern offices in Soho Square, near the heart of the advertising industry.

Mr Crozier believes the FA's top properties are the England international team and the FA Cup. It believes they can help football's governing body generate a tenfold increase in revenues.

webTitle: Beenz denies global closure speculation

fields.headline: Beenz denies global closure speculation
fields.trailText: 8am: Web loyalty points company Beenz has denied rumours that it planned to close its global operations, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Web loyalty points company Beenz has moved fast to quash rumours that it planned to close all its global operations apart from its UK office.

Founder and chairman Charles Cohen said the rumours were born out of the company's decision to undertake a review of its global operations on a country-by-country basis.

Beenz was launched almost two years ago in the UK and quickly established itself as de facto internet currency with online shoppers picking up loyalty points on a network of sites.

Mr Cohen stressed that the board of Beenz had not yet decided which markets would be affected, but that a decision would be made by March.

However, he did say that some offices would be shut down and staff laid off.

Mr Cohen said there had already been some job losses in the US but would not give the number of people involved.

The UK offshoot has already instigated a voluntary redundancy programme aimed at cutting 20 of the 90 personnel.

"We're looking at all options as we evaluate all operations in every country we're in. The state of the market has forced these decisions on us. What I can categorically say is we're not going bust," said Mr Cohen.

One of the options is a strategic partnership with an offline company taking a stake in the business.

Beenz, which has raised £89m in funding in two years, operates 10 offices globally.

webTitle: New focus planned for ITV2

fields.headline: New focus planned for ITV2
fields.trailText: 8am: ITV2 has bought two hit TV dramas as part of a bid to beef up its programming line-up for 2001, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV2 has bought two hit TV dramas, Felicity and Beggars & Choosers, as part of moves to beef up its programming line-up for 2001.

Felicity, which follows the trials and tribulations of the eponymous 17-year-old, is due to go out on weekday afternoons from January 8.

ITV2 has ordered 61 episodes of the hour-long Disney show, which goes out on the WB network in the US.

The channel has also bought 42 episodes of Beggars & Choosers, a comedy drama centred on power hungry US TV executives and their illicit relationships, which will go out on Thursday nights at 10pm from January 4.

Andrew Chowns, ITV2 commercial director, said the acquisitions formed part of a "significant" increase in the channel's programming budget for 2001.

The station has suffered from an incredibly low profile despite airing programmes such as Trevor McDonald's interview show and contemporary repeats of Coronation Street.

It has also fared poorly in the ratings because of its absence from the Sky digital network of channels. However, there is now a concerted effort to improve the channel in the wake of the consolidation at ITV.

Mr Chowns said: "Overall we're positioning ITV2 as ITV and more."

He said ITV2 was moving away from low-cost original production. Instead, the money will go on exclusive UK windows for bought-in shows such as Felicity and Beggars & Choosers.

But ITV2 will also concentrate on developing a smaller number of original commissions with higher budgets that could make the move to ITV.

Mr Chowns said the broadcaster was particularly interested in developing comedy and interactive shows. ITV2 will also look to do co-productions with ITV and programming that supports ITV shows.
