webTitle: Last son of Citizen Kane dies, 85

fields.headline: Last son of Citizen Kane dies, 85
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Randolph Hearst, the last surviving son of one of the world's most infamous media magnates - and the model for Orson Welles's Citizen Kane - has died aged 85. By Duncan Campbell.
fields.body:
Randolph Hearst, the last surviving son of one of the world's most infamous media magnates - and the model for Orson Welles's Citizen Kane - has died aged 85.

His death comes just as the family re-entered the public spotlight, with the media dynasty's firm controversially selling its flagship newspaper, the San Francisco Examiner, and with Hearst's daughter, Patty, set to testify against an alleged ex-member of the revolutionary group that kidnapped her.

Randolph Apperson Hearst, died on Monday in the New York Presbyterian hospital after suffering a stroke. He was listed 145th in the Forbes list of America's richest people with a $1.6bn (£1.1bn) fortune.

It was such wealth that, in 1974, attracted a tiny revolutionary group called the Symbionese Liberation Army (SLA) to kidnap Patty, then a student at Berkeley.

The SLA demanded $400m for her release and to distribute some of the money in the form of free food to the poor. Hearst went on television to say that he did not have the money but he did pay for and sanction the food handouts.

Then his daughter, who had taken on the nom de guerre Tania, was forced to denounce her father in a tape-recorded statement. Ms Hearst was arrested in 1975 and jailed for 21 months for an SLA robbery in which she took part, to the great distress of her father, outraged that his daughter was punished for being kidnapped (as he saw it). President Carter later pardoned her.

Hearst's nephew, William Randolph Hearst III, recalled the 1974 kidnapping yesterday, saying: "Randy was the centre of calm in a very turbulent period."

Next month, Sara Jane Olson goes on trial for conspiring to kill police officers, thrusting Ms Hearst, now married to her former bodyguard and living with her family in Connecticut, back into the public eye.

Hearst's death draws fresh attention to the latest acts of the media empire started by his father. The Hearst Corporation now owns 12 newspapers, 16 magazines and 27 television stations. Randolph Hearst chaired the corporation from 1973 to 1996 but was not at the helm to see the company buy its great rival, the San Francisco Chronicle, for $660m and sell its flagship Examiner earlier this year.

The death of the three-times married Hearst prompted tributes from friend and associates. "He was a greatly admired colleague and a true friend," said the Hearst Corporation president, Frank Bennack. A family friend, William Coblentz, said Hearst had tried to escape the shadow of his famous father. "He was a very bright, thoughtful, caring guy," he said.

Randolph Hearst's body will be taken to California tomorrow for burial after today's funeral service in New York.

webTitle: Equitable inquiry 'too late'

fields.headline: Equitable inquiry 'too late'
fields.standfirst: MPs demand wider investigation into roles of regulators and Treasury
fields.trailText: MPs demand wider investigation into roles of regulators and Treasury.
fields.body:
The financial services authority bowed to pressure from MPs and policyholders yesterday and announced it was holding an investigation into the crisis that has engulfed the insurer Equitable Life.

Treasury officials said the conclusions of the review would be published early next year, but the inquiry was slammed as "too little, too late" by policyholders, while shadow paymaster general Richard Ottaway said a wider investigation was needed to examine the role of other regulators, including the Trea sury. The investigation will only look at the City watchdog's handling of the matter since it took over responsibility for policing insurance companies in January 1999 - despite the fact that the FSA was warned more than two years ago about Equitable's financial difficulties.

MPs lined up to criticise the company, and the handling of the debacle, during a Commons debate yesterday.

The 238-year-old company has left more than 1m policyholders facing lower investment returns after it warned them they will have to foot the bill for its failure to win a £1.5bn legal battle involving so-called guaranteed annuities, sold as part of pension plans between 1957 and 1988.

Policyholders have already forfeited seven months' worth of bonuses.

Equitable tried to renege on the promises it made by cutting the final bonus payments for those who chose to exercise the guarantee, but the House of Lords ruled in July that this approach was illegal.

The announcement of an investigation into the world's oldest mutual insurer by Treasury economic secretary Melanie Johnson represents something of a U-turn.

Little more than a week ago FSA chairman Howard Davies said it was "too early" to talk about an inquiry.

Yesterday he said the FSA board would be discussing the Equitable case, and any lessons to be learned from it, at a meeting tomorrow.

The watchdog has been criticised for not taking earlier action against Equitable and for allowing it to continue selling new policies until earlier this month, but has said it acted "appropriately".

Equitable shut its doors to new business on December 8 and imposed new terms on existing policyholders.

During yesterday's Commons debate, Vincent Cable, the Liberal Democrat trade and industry spokesman, held out the prospect of compensation if it is proved the regulators failed in their duty. He highlighted a leaked memo sent to the FSA by the Treasury in November 1998 which revealed that even then, the Treasury was worried about Equitable Life's solvency.

Later, Mr Ottaway said the government's announcement did not go far enough. "We want to see a wider investigation into the Equitable Life pensions situation, one which examines the role of the regulatory authorities before the establishment of the FSA in January 1999. Most importantly, we demand an investigation into why the Treasury withdrew guidance, issued in December 1998, which condoned Equitable Life's management methods."

Equitable policyholder David Hyman, 70, who brought the court action which led to the House of Lords ruling, said of the inquiry: "It is too little, too late. Why weren't they [the FSA] doing something when they were first set up and they could see there was a problem staring them in the face?"

webTitle: Sketch: Simon Hoggart

fields.headline: Tough questions stem the flow of argument
fields.trailText: Sketch, Simon Hoggart: The main debate was about stem cell research on embryos, one of those intractable moral questions which arouse terrific passions.
fields.body:
The medieval schoolmen who debated how many angels could dance on the head of a pin are thought these days to have devoted their futile lives to meaningless argument. Yet the topic wasn't quite as silly as it sounded. What they were really discussing was whether heavenly beings had physical substance, and in the context of the time it made sense.

But those theologians were like two blokes arguing the merits of Owen and Heskey over pints of Boddingtons compared to the House of Commons yesterday.

The main debate was about stem cell research on embryos, one of those intractable moral questions which arouse terrific passions. I felt we needed Dr David Starkey to shriek at us what idiots we are.

But first they debated another intractable moral question. This was their new "deferred divisions", which are votes on minor issues. Instead of trooping wearily through the lobbies, MPs just bung a cross on a piece of paper and the clerks tot them up. It saves a lot of time. But last week no fewer than 80 voted both "aye" and "no" on the same question. Not surprisingly, the Speaker ruled their papers out. The MPs who'd voted twice complained. We had the makings of a Florida situation here, with chads being held up to the light and lawyers on $500 an hour.

But it turns out the MPs were doing it on purpose. As Howard Stoate put it, "it is done so one's constituents can see that you are positively abstaining, and are not merely absent from the vote". Eh? Wossat about? Again, I wanted a snatch squad of metaphysicians to remove these intellectual hooligans.

Having failed to solve this one, the House moved on to the even tougher question of stem cell research. The job of making the government's case - to widen the limits of permitted research - fell to the slight yet determined figure of Yvette Cooper, a junior health minister.

Trimly dressed in a trouser suit, earnest of mein and only 31 years old, Ms Cooper is the perfect model of a keen young Blairite minister. Yet her clarity and her passion shone through the brief she was reading, so that even the Tories who disagreed with her praised her in extravagent terms.

All except for one. She pointed out that sufferers from many dreadful diseases might soon have hope of a cure rather than a controlled descent into misery and death. A child who had fallen from a bike or a horse could have their spinal tissue repaired. A boy paralysed at rugby might walk again.

All this was too much for some. As she described the woman with Parkinson's who now "can never sing to her grandchildren", a single Tory voice let out a tremendous "Harrumph" of disgust, as if this argument from instances was unfair and misleading.

How strange that those who are most morally squeamish are quickest to scorn the moral concerns of others.

Edward Leigh was fearful of cloning. He waved at his own frontbench spokesman, and alleged, "we could create a dozen little Liam Foxes, purely in order to destroy them!" Why, I mused cruelly, do we need to clone them first?

An early speaker was Anne Begg from Aberdeen, the first MP to be a wheelchair-user. She suffers from Gaucher's disease, which causes the bones to crumble away, and she spoke calmly yet emotionally for a change in the law. Perhaps the fact that she's rather closer to the ground than most MPs means that the people who voted against her won't be obliged to look her in the eye.

And today it's fox hunting. Couldn't we have a good old Local Government Finance (number 2) order to chew at? They're so much simpler.

webTitle: Lawrence family accepts £320,000 payout from Met

fields.headline: Lawrence family accepts £320,000 payout from Met
fields.standfirst: Special report: Stephen Lawrence
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan Police has agreed to pay £320,000 compensation to the parents of Stephen Lawrence for its failures during and after the investigation into the teenager's racist murder, the Guardian can reveal.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan Police has agreed to pay £320,000 compensation to the parents of Stephen Lawrence for its failures during and after the investigation into the teenager's racist murder, the Guardian can reveal.

A deal was reached last Friday following protracted talks between lawyers for the parents and the Metropolitan Police Authority. It ends the gruelling seven-year battle Doreen and Neville Lawrence have fought with the Met.

Under the terms of the "full and final" settlement, the service has not admitted it was negligent in its handling of the inquiry or in the way its officers treated Stephen's parents.

Police hope that the case will not set a legal precedent allowing others to sue for alleged negligence.

Scotland Yard, however, said the ex-gratia sum was recognition of the "unique circumstances" of the case, and the "strength and determination" of the Lawrences, who have campaigned tirelessly since their 18-year-old son was stabbed in Eltham, south London, by a group of white youths on April 22 1993.

A police statement added: "Public apologies have been made to Mr and Mrs Lawrence for the failings of the Metropolitan Police Service."

The £320,000 figure was agreed after the Lawrences refused an offer of £250,000 in the autumn, and follows pressure from Ken Livingstone, the mayor of London, who urged a swift resolution to the claim.

The Lawrences decided to launch a civil action against the Met after Sir William Macpherson's report into the the investigation, published in February 1999, which concluded that it had been mishandled by the force.

They issued writs against 41 officers, including the then commissioner Sir Paul Condon, using the race relations act as the backbone of the claim.

They demanded more than £500,000 compensation for "alleged negligence, and or conspiracy, and or misfeasance in public office and or breach of statutory duties".

In statements to the high court, they claimed for psychological damage, the cost of their son's funeral in Jamaica, and the cost of the campaign to achieve justice for Stephen.

Mrs Lawrence, 47, also asked for money to pay for trips she took to America and South Africa to try to get over the murder and the cost of taxi fares to take her son Stuart to his part-time job.

The Met remains hopeful that the killers will be caught. A team of detectives under Deputy Assistant Commissioner John Grieve, head of the racial and violent crimes task force, is still working on the case.

webTitle: Labour may use parliament law to impose hunting ban

fields.headline: Labour may use parliament law to impose hunting ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Labour will promise in its election manifesto to invoke the Parliament Act to ensure fox hunting is banned by 2002, if time runs out on the hunting bill, due to have its second reading in the Commons today.
fields.body:
Labour will promise in its election manifesto to invoke the Parliament Act to ensure fox hunting is banned by 2002, if time runs out on the hunting bill, due to have its second reading in the Commons today.

Both sides in the debate believe time is too short and resistance in the Lords too entrenched for the present multi-option bill to reach the statute book by April 8, the last date on which parliament will sit in the event of the expected May 3 election. The Home Office confirmed yesterday that the Parliament Act could be invoked even if an election intervenes. Senior Labour offi cials have decided that anything short of a pledge to invoke the act would cause outrage among Labour MPs.

The act allows the imposition of a bill on the Lords within 13 months of MPs first supporting a measure at second reading. MPs will have a free vote early in January on three options - licenced hunts, the status quo, or an outright ban. The vote was 411 to 151 for a ban the last time they debated the issue.

The expected preferred option of a ban will then be debated in standing committee. It is hoped the bill could reach the Lords in late February. A final version would then come back to MPs around the time of a huge Countryside Alliance rally set for March 18.

webTitle: Crackdown on 'blood' diamonds

fields.headline: Crackdown on 'blood' diamonds
fields.standfirst: African leaders trading gems for arms must be punished, says UN panel
fields.trailText: African leaders trading gems for arms must be punished, says UN panel.
fields.body:
The United Nations is finally to mount an onslaught on the trade in "blood" diamonds from Africa, according to a report into the links between gems and arms leaked to the Guardian.

The uncompromising report recommends a series of punitive measures against west African countries linked to the civil war in Sierra Leone.

The 58-page report also points a finger of blame at Switzerland, a transit point for almost half the rough diamonds entering Britain. Switzerland is listed as "country of origin", even though it produces no diamonds of its own.

The UN panel recommends that a first-ever international embargo on diamonds should be applied to Sierra Leone's neighbours, Liberia and Gambia.

The panel singles out Charles Taylor, the president of Liberia, saying he "is actively involved in fuelling the violence in Sierra Leone, and many businessmen close to his inner circle operate on an international scale, sourcing their weaponry mainly in eastern Europe".

It adds: "In short, Liberia is actively breaking [UN] security council embargoes regarding weapons imports into its own territory and into Sierra Leone. It is being actively assisted by Burkina Faso. It is being tacitly assisted by all the countries allowing weapons to pass through or over their territory without question, and by those countries that provide a base for the aircraft used in such operations."

Additional measures against Mr Taylor include the immediate grounding of all Liberian-registered flights and a travel ban on him and his inner circle.

Widening the net, the panel proposes giving Guinea and the Ivory Coast six months to introduce proper certification schemes proving their diamonds are clean. If they do not, they too will face an international diamond embargo.

The panel also wants increased scrutiny of diamond exports from Uganda, the Central African Republic, Ghana, Namibia, Congo-Brazzaville, Mali, Zambia and Burkina Faso.

The report is due to be published in New York tomorrow after being scrutinised in the UN security council, which will meet again next month to discuss implementation.

The diamonds and arms trade have long been intertwined in Africa. In March, Robert Fowler, the Canadian ambassador to the UN, carried out an initial investigation into diamond smuggling by the Angolan rebel movement Unita, which led to the naming of individual businessmen involved in illicit trade.

The diamond industry, afraid of consumer reaction against "blood" diamonds, has promised tougher scrutiny but the UN report concludes that this is inadequate.

The report estimates that the rebel movement in Sierra Leone, the Revolutionary United Front, which has gained notoriety for chopping off the arms and legs of victims, deals each year in diamonds worth between £25m and £125m, more than enough to sustain its forces.

Ranged against it is the Sierra Leone army supported by a UN force and a British contingent. The bulk of the RUF diamonds leaves Sierra Leone through Liberia, the report said. "Such trade cannot be conducted without the permission and involvement of Liberian government officials at the highest levels."

The report castigated the failure of the industry world-wide to come up with a proper method for determining the origin of diamonds and for tracking their movement. The report found that in 1999 Britain imported £107m in rough diamonds.

"Of this, Switzerland was recorded as the 'country of origin' for 41% or £44.2m. Switzerland, as a non-producer of diamonds, could only have been the country of provenance, importing the diamonds from another country," it said.

It added: "Those diamonds bound for the UK thus become 'Swiss' simply by virtue of having passed through a Freilager [free trade area]." The country of origin is lost.

The panel welcomed the scheme started this year in government-held areas of Sierra Leone which certified that diamonds were mined in legitimate areas. But the panel concluded that the scheme has to be extended worldwide.

The UN panel recommends that a first-ever international embargo on diamonds should be applied to Sierra Leone's neighbours, Liberia and Gambia. The panel singles out Charles Taylor, the president of Liberia, saying he "is actively involved in fuelling the violence in Sierra Leone, and many businessmen close to his inner circle operate on an international scale, sourcing their weaponry mainly in eastern Europe". It adds: "In short, Liberia is actively breaking [UN] security council embargoes regarding weapons imports into its own territory and into Sierra Leone. It is being actively assisted by Burkina Faso. It is being tacitly assisted by all the countries allowing weapons to pass through or over their territory without question, and by those countries that provide a base for the aircraft used in such operations." Additional measures against Mr Taylor include the immediate grounding of all Liberian-registered flights and a travel ban on him and his inner circle. Widening the net, the panel proposes giving Guinea and the Ivory Coast six months to introduce proper certification schemes proving their diamonds are clean. If they do not, they too will face an international diamond embargo. The panel also wants increased scrutiny of diamond exports from Uganda, the Central African Republic, Ghana, Namibia, Congo-Brazzaville, Mali, Zambia and Burkina Faso. The report is due to be published in New York tomorrow after being scrutinised in the UN security council, which will meet again next month to discuss implementation. The diamonds and arms trade have long been intertwined in Africa. In March, Robert Fowler, the Canadian ambassador to the UN, carried out an initial investigation into diamond smuggling by the Angolan rebel movement Unita, which led to the naming of individual businessmen involved in illicit trade. The diamond industry, afraid of consumer reaction against "blood" diamonds, has promised tougher scrutiny but the UN report concludes that this is inadequate. The report estimates that the rebel movement in Sierra Leone, the Revolutionary United Front, which has gained notoriety for chopping off the arms and legs of victims, deals each year in diamonds worth between £25m and £125m, more than enough to sustain its forces. Ranged against it is the Sierra Leone army supported by a UN force and a British contingent. The bulk of the RUF diamonds leaves Sierra Leone through Liberia, the report said. "Such trade cannot be conducted without the permission and involvement of Liberian government officials at the highest levels." The report castigated the failure of the industry world-wide to come up with a proper method for determining the origin of diamonds and for tracking their movement. The report found that in 1999 Britain imported £107m in rough diamonds. "Of this, Switzerland was recorded as the 'country of origin' for 41% or £44.2m. Switzerland, as a non-producer of diamonds, could only have been the country of provenance, importing the diamonds from another country," it said. It added: "Those diamonds bound for the UK thus become 'Swiss' simply by virtue of having passed through a Freilager [free trade area]." The country of origin is lost. The panel welcomed the scheme started this year in government-held areas of Sierra Leone which certified that diamonds were mined in legitimate areas. But the panel concluded that the scheme has to be extended worldwide.

webTitle: The entertainer

fields.headline: The entertainer
fields.standfirst: He never rose above the rank of junior minister. But he'll be remembered long after the Heseltines and Hurds of this world have faded into obscurity.  Michael White  explains why Alan Clark still fascinates us
fields.trailText: He never rose above the rank of junior minister. But he'll be remembered long after the Heseltines and Hurds of this world have faded into obscurity. Michael White explains why Alan Clark still fascinates us
fields.body:
I was once travelling to work on the London Underground when I noticed that the attractive young woman sitting opposite me was reading a copy of Alan Clark's first book, The Donkeys.

This was his youthful analysis of incompetent British generalship in the First World War ("lions led by donkeys", as the Germans put it), the book which first brought him fame - and the attention of Lord Beaverbrook - as well as inspiring Joan Littlewood's ironical musical, Oh, What A Lovely War!

At least, so Clark legend had it. But I had never managed to obtain a copy. "Where did you get that book?" I blurted out. She blushed and I knew instantly that it was a personal gift from the author, who later accused me of "trying to pick up my secretary on the tube". Which is, of course, exactly what he'd have done, as the Diaries make gleefully plain.

What is the fascination about a former junior minister of romantic and reactionary views that warrants Colin Spector's film, The Real Alan Clark? It will reveal that, surprise, surprise, not all the Diary entries are true - they create what his Etonian chum, publisher Anthony Blond, calls "a wonderful fiction called Alan Clark".

But why should we care? As the programme shows, Clark was never a very important figure in the government. Far from it. His beloved Margaret Thatcher made him a junior minister in Employment, so her wily chief whip John Wakeham explains to camera, because he advised her that he would be more trouble outside the tent than inside.

In this, Wakeham was mistaken. Spector's film charts a pattern of ministerial incidents ("accidents" would be too kind a word) from drunkeness at the Dispatch Box to the Matrix Churchill arms-sale affair which should have finished him.

"If he can survive this, he can survive anything", thought Archie Hamilton, whose job as army minister Clark coveted, none too subtly. Worse, the film confirms what some of us suspected at the time. Though Mrs Thatcher liked and admired her swashbuckling courtier (around her he behaved "like a slightly wet pussycat", reports Tory MP, Nicholas Soames), she had no intention of promoting him to cabinet.

No, the fact of the matter is that Alan was, in the affectionate description of Anthony Blond, "a prize shit". But, oh, how much more fun to have around than most of this film's middle-aged, male interviewees - stuffed shirts, whose watery eyes gleam with, alas, only vicarious pleasure over his conquests, his cars, his caddish behaviour. The monster once invited me out for a curry and manoeuvred me into paying even though he'd just sold Papa's Turner. The rich are like that.

But fun and a desire to shock (probably to disoblige his terrifying parents) mingled with ambition and vanity to produce diaries that will still be enjoyed in 100 years. Clark was nowhere near as important to British defence strategy as the great Samuel Pepys, but he shares with his fellow scribbler proximity to great events, an eye for detail and a redeeming willingness to make a fool of himself in print, particularly over those two basic impulses, sex and money.

That's why we liked him and forgave him for the kind of crude transgressions which made Enoch Powell (much cleverer, but not very human) the pariah he remains among the progressive classes. The very fact that Clark was a bit of a card, not taken too seriously except (sometimes) by himself, made him far less dangerous - "an upper class Alf Garnett", as this film explains.

Students of sibling rivalry will enjoy the score-settling cameo provided by Clark's younger brother Colin, so different that he once passed up a chance to have Marilyn Monroe. Alan's moving description of the death of Papa - Lord Clark of Civilisation - was actually his brother's brutal moment of final triumph, Colin claims. Ho hum.

But the conspicuous absentee from Spector's piece is the quietly formidable Jane Clark, the diarist's Lolita whom he married at 16 ("she's so young I can mould her"). The groom was 30 and looked surprisingly callow in his morning suit, an Ian Carmichael lookalike. We also learn that Alan persuaded Jane to change her own name, Caroline, to his mother's.

A very bad case of distant-mother fixation, especially since Clark consciously aped his father's womanising self-absorption. But Jane mark II managed to provide the stability the spoilt boy needed to become something: a diarist who will undoubtedly be read for pleasure down the years. Not a bad memorial, that, more impressive even than the 600 matrons who joined Kensington and Chelsea Conservative Association when they heard the retread might get the seat.

When Clark died of a brain tumour in 1999 the family kept it a secret until they had him safely buried in the grounds of Saltwood. "How's Alan?" a reporter rang to ask, with the corpse awaiting the undertaker. "Not as well as we'd like", replied cool Jane. Amen to that.

webTitle: Singer Kirsty MacColl dies

fields.headline: Singer Kirsty MacColl dies
fields.trailText: Kirsty MacColl, whose sweetly ironic voice balanced the gruff romanticism of Shane McGowan in the Christmas classic A Fairytale of New York, has died in a boating accident.
fields.body:
Kirsty MacColl, whose sweetly ironic voice balanced the gruff romanticism of Shane McGowan in the Christmas classic A Fairytale of New York, has died in a boating accident.

A speedboat is understood to have collided with the 41-year-old singer-songwriter while she was on holiday in Mexico, on the eve of the first part of a BBC Radio 2 series she recorded in Havana.

The BBC said it had postponed the series as a mark of respect.

The singer died yesterday in the sea close to the coral island of Cozumel, which is off the Yucatan peninsula.

She was holidaying there with her two sons, who were both with her in the water at the time. The children were said to be unhurt.

MacColl, a keen diver, is believed to have been hit by the boat which was in an area reserved for swimmers.

Her former husband, record producer Steve Lillywhite, was flying to Mexico to comfort the children.

"I was shocked to hear the news," said the disc jockey Johnnie Walker, a friend. "She was one of the true, real characters of popular music and although there has been pressure on women in music to conform to the music business she was always herself and said 'I am what I am'."

But McGowan's Fairytale, recorded by The Pogues in 1987, will be her memorial today. "I think it's the best Christmas record there is," she once said. "I feel that I can say that very modestly, not having written it. I thought 'I'll give it a go and if they don't like it they can get someone else'."

MacColl, the daughter of British folk movement hero Ewan MacColl, had two children with Lillywhite. She had worked with a record store of musicians, including The Smiths, the Rolling Stones, Talking Heads, Robert Plant, Van Morrison and the Wonder Stuff, and appeared at a concert in memory of Ian Dury in London last summer.

Her work had a peculiarly British sensibility, with songs such as There's A Guy Works Down The Chipshop Thinks He's Elvis but she developed a taste for Cuban and Brazilian music in recent years. This was reflected in Tropical Brainstorm, her well-received seventh album, released this year.

"Red hair, sharp tongue - she should be Irish," Bono, of U2, once said. "I think of Kirsty as one in a line of great English songwriters that includes Ray Davies, Paul Weller and Morrissey. The Noelle Coward of her generation.

"I remember Kirsty McColl as just a really brainy, funny girl whose songwriting came from all different traditions."

MacColl's first single, They Don't Know, came out in 1979. She later made the top ten when she recorded Billy Bragg's A New England.

webTitle: Government aims to get tougher on worst driving offences

fields.headline: Government aims to get tougher on worst driving offences
fields.trailText: Drivers found guilty of minor motoring offences face having their cars clamped outside their homes or being sent to driver re-education night school as part of a government package of penalties to tackle car crime unveiled yesterday.
fields.body:
Drivers found guilty of minor motoring offences face having their cars clamped outside their homes or being sent to driver re-education night school as part of a government package of penalties to tackle car crime unveiled yesterday.

Motorists who kill and those who repeat offences will face tougher penalties, with longer driving bans for very drunk drivers.

The package - the outcome of a review of penalties for the 9.5m motoring offences committed every year in Britain - is designed to help reduce the annual 3,400 death toll on the roads by 40% within 10 years.

Motoring organisations last night welcomed the measures, particularly the emphasis on driver improvement and alcohol rehabilitation, as well as increased penalties for the most serious offences.

Ministers are also proposing to shake up the points system with the introduction of a more punitive "second tier" of points for those who drive at excessive speeds, particularly in built-up areas, and extended driving bans. Some banned drivers will be encouraged to retake their tests in return for a reduction of up to 25% of their disaqualification period. Speeding motorists could find themselves banned automatically after a second offence.

Charles Clarke, the Home Office minister, insisted last night that the government was not declaring war on the motorist: "The vast majority of our 30m drivers have a responsible attitude to road safety which we want to build on. The review is carefully targeted on areas where current penalties could be made more effective and where better driving would have a significant impact on road safety."

Among the measures proposed in the consultation paper, which is unlikely to be put before parliament this side of the general election, are:

 Greater use of short-term bans, even as short as a fortnight.

 Temporary forfeiture or im mobilisation of the car involved for a week or a month - it could be clamped outside the offender's home as a "badge of loss of wheels".

 Reviewing the penalty points system, with more points for second offences and a greater threat of a ban.

 Introduction of an automatic six month penalty point "totting up" ban, without a court appearance.

 New two-tier fixed penalty system for speeding, with an increasing threat of a quicker ban for the worst drivers.

 Greater use of compulsory driver retraining programmes.

 Compulsory retesting after lengthy bans.

The package also includes proposals for longer sentences for the most serious driving offences, including a minimum three year ban (instead of two) for death by dangerous driving, and imposing a lifetime ban on those with previous serious convictions.

On drink-driving, ministers want to see a new penalty for those with very high blood alcohol levels (above 160mg per 100mls, twice the current level), with an automatic 18 month ban and the possibility of a six month prison sentence.

The AA last night said the proposals started a discussion on the penalties needed to weed out and punish the worst drivers, many of whom offended repeatedly.

"Without this, although the UK has the safest roads in the world, we will not achieve by 2010 the target of a 40% overall reduction in road deaths and 50% reduction in child fatalities."

webTitle: Analysis: EU rapid reaction force

fields.headline: Intelligence test
fields.standfirst: After the rapid reaction force, the logical step is an EU intelligence policy - and that would be the ultimate test of mutual trust between allies
fields.trailText: After the rapid reaction force, the logical step is an EU intelligence policy - and that would be the ultimate test of mutual trust between allies.
fields.body:
Tony Blair says he wants the European Union to be a "superpower" and to that end member states are planning a joint rapid reaction force capable of operating autonomously. But one key area of cooperation is rarely mentioned - a common intelligence policy, the ties that would really bind, the ultimate test of mutual trust.

Intelligence is an essential tool of military policy-making. As Charles Grant of the Centre for European Reform puts it: "the projected security and defence policy will be handicapped unless there is a high degree of intelligence-sharing among EU governments". The International Institute for Strategic Studies concludes that "the pledge to conduct EU-led military operations necessitates an integrated European intelligence architecture".

But this call strikes at the heart of the UK's special relationship with the United States, and it is nowhere more special than in the field of intelligence - military, political, diplomatic and economic. GCHQ, the government's eavesdropping centre, has a symbiotic relationship with its American big brother, the US National Security Agency. The Americans give more than Britain gives in return. However, an internal GCHQ staff manual notes that the agency's contribution to the relationship must be "of sufficient scale and of the right kind to make a continuation of the Sigint [signals intelligence] alliance worthwhile to our partners". It adds: "This may entail on occasion the applying of UK resources to the meeting of US requirements."

The alliance is spelled out in a secret UK-US treaty signed in 1948 to provide for privileged sharing of signals intelligence between the US, the UK, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand. This Anglo-Saxon club and its worldwide surveillance network, code-named Echelon, makes the French suspicious. Yet the NSA has given France technological help with its (more limited) network of listening stations, dubbed "Frenchelon".

The US wants to preserve its pre-eminent position in satellite imagery and, according to the IISS, it is insisting on the legal right to execute unilateral "shutter control" to block the gathering of images Washington regards as affecting its security interests.

Even the UK cannot rely on the US. While France gave the UK key intelligence during the Falklands war, Washington, seeking a diplomatic solution, held back. And in an episode which left Whitehall officials trembling with shock, Washington stopped passing relevant intelligence to London in December 1994, when the senate voted to lift the UN arms blockade against ex-Yugoslavia.

Two years later President Clinton launched a salvo of cruise missiles against Iraq after Saddam Hussein moved into the northern Kurdish area of the country. France said imagery from its Helios satellite showed the troop movements to be insignificant and refused to support the strikes. The Americans insisted the French were wrong and their satellite was not as good as the US.

Spy satellites are expensive. British intelligence officials ask why they should start paying for European satellites when they can get more accurate imagery from the US for free. France argues that Europe will not be able to have an independent foreign policy so long as it is dependent on the Americans for satellite intelligence.

France is the only European country with its own delivery system - the Ariane base in French Guyana - capable of putting satellites into space. Spain and Italy have contributed to the French-sponsored Helios satellite programme. Germany, as the chart illustrates, is developing a high-resolution satellite in response to American reluctance to share intelligence during the Kosovo war. Intelligence from Helios and SARLupe will be shared among EU partners.

There is also the unsung work carried out by the Western European Union (WEU), now to be subsumed into the EU. The WEU provided valuable intelligence on Kosovo. Its satellite centre at Torrejón in northern Spain is unique in providing collective - supranational - intelligence assessments. Satellites are not only vital in giving up-to-date military intelligence for EU troops on the ground. They provide decision-makers with early warnings, crucial to the EU's future role as crisis preventer and manager.

But satellites are not the only intelligence tool and the military not the only customer. The security and intelligence agencies of EU member states increasingly exchange material obtained from informers, terrestrial surveillance, or electronic eavesdropping - on terrorists, drug-traffickers, money-launderers and on immigration. The Schengen Information System, the centre of the EU's internal security network, already holds over 9m files, 1.3m of them on individuals. Many of the EU's perceived threats, notably terrorism, are also regarded as priorities for action by the Americans and Russians as well as candidates for EU membership in central and eastern Europe.

Charles Grant proposes a European intelligence committee to provide collective assessments based on information from satellites and sanitised intelligence provided by national capitals. Emphasise sanitised: Nato member states, let alone EU governments, do not trust each other sufficiently to provide raw intelligence, and probably never will.

Yet intelligence cooperation depends on mutual trust. For the foreseeable future, it will also depend, at least in the military field, on the attitude of the Americans, whose technology is far ahead of the Europeans. Washington demonstrated its attitude by agreeing to share stealth technology with the UK on condition it is not passed on to the French. But maybe it will begin to realise, as it demands "burden sharing", that a European intelligence capability is as important as military equipment and properly-trained soldiers. Intelligence is now firmly on the EU's agenda.

 Richard Norton-Taylor is the Guardian's security affairs editor

The WEU provided valuable intelligence on Kosovo. Its satellite centre at Torrejón in northern Spain is unique in providing collective - supranational - intelligence assessments. Satellites are not only vital in giving up-to-date military intelligence for EU troops on the ground. They provide decision-makers with early warnings, crucial to the EU's future role as crisis preventer and manager. But satellites are not the only intelligence tool and the military not the only customer. The security and intelligence agencies of EU member states increasingly exchange material obtained from informers, terrestrial surveillance, or electronic eavesdropping - on terrorists, drug-traffickers, money-launderers and on immigration. The Schengen Information System, the centre of the EU's internal security network, already holds over 9m files, 1.3m of them on individuals. Many of the EU's perceived threats, notably terrorism, are also regarded as priorities for action by the Americans and Russians as well as candidates for EU membership in central and eastern Europe. Charles Grant proposes a European intelligence committee to provide collective assessments based on information from satellites and sanitised intelligence provided by national capitals. Emphasise sanitised: Nato member states, let alone EU governments, do not trust each other sufficiently to provide raw intelligence, and probably never will. Yet intelligence cooperation depends on mutual trust. For the foreseeable future, it will also depend, at least in the military field, on the attitude of the Americans, whose technology is far ahead of the Europeans. Washington demonstrated its attitude by agreeing to share stealth technology with the UK on condition it is not passed on to the French. But maybe it will begin to realise, as it demands "burden sharing", that a European intelligence capability is as important as military equipment and properly-trained soldiers. Intelligence is now firmly on the EU's agenda.  Richard Norton-Taylor is the Guardian's security affairs editor richard.norton-taylor@ theguardian.com

webTitle: Blair meets match on return to dome

fields.headline: Blair meets match on return to dome
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: For the hundreds of school children crowded around a giant football table in the Millennium Dome yesterday, it was a surreal day.
fields.body:
For the hundreds of school children crowded around a giant football table in the Millennium Dome yesterday, it was a surreal day.

They were waiting for a good knockaround on the 11-a-side table - the aim being to demonstrate "team work" in the work zone - when they were engulfed in a mass of camera crews, photographers, and cabinet ministers flanked by the prime minister.

"It's Tony Blair. Let's see him try and play football," they cried, as Mr Blair grinned gamely and one youngster yelling "I want to be on TV" yanked him towards the table.

There was no escape. They were all there - Mr Blair, the hapless dome minister, Lord Falconer, deputy prime minister John Prescott, former Tory deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine, and local government minister Hilary Armstrong - to pay a farewell visit to the beleaguered building and for the PM to extend his thanks to the staff who had soldiered on in the wake of dwindling visitor numbers and harsh publicity.

Mr Blair, who had failed to visit the dome since the New Year's Eve tickets fiasco, had earlier told some 150 acrobats, dancers and hosts they could be "proud of all that you have achieved ... whatever the faults of the politicians". He even beamed when Cyberstein - a giant robot manned by two people - lumbered towards him in a cacophony of noise and flashing lights, and continued smiling when two snowmen pranced up to the strains of Frosty the Snowman.

Now, however, the heat was on, and the slightly perspiring prime ministerial brow furrowed as he sought to show his table footballing prowess.

A goal shot in, and the PM's side were in no doubt he had scored it.

"It was Tony," cried Mr Prescott, the relief in his voice tangible as his boss delivered the goods, while the dome's ebullient chief executive, PY Gerbeau, shook his hand energetically.

But sharp-eyed observers claimed the victorious flick belonged to Zaid Noorgat, aged 14, from Forest Gate, east London. Mr Blair graciously turned and congratulated him.

Earlier, the media was rebuked by the dome's fiercest advocate Michael Heseltine, its driving force before the last election, who turned on "ignorant armchair critics", and accused the press of campaigning to curb visitor numbers.

Referring to the recent surge in visitors - to 150,000 a week - he told staff: "They didn't come earlier because too many of our newspapers made it their professional business to try and stop them coming. There has been a lot of criticism, a lot of complaints, many of them based wholly on ignorance from the armchair critics who beset our society".

During his walkabout Mr Blair faltered briefly when he greeted one staff member and asked: "What do you do?"

"You've already met me twice: in 1997 and on New Year's Eve," she informed him. "New Year's Eve was a daze," Mr Blair replied smiling.

On that night the prime minister travelled without disruption to the dome on a special Jubilee line train as 3,000 VIP guests were stranded in the cold outside Stratford station because of a shortage of security scanning.

Yesterday, he was less lucky. Disruption on the line meant he and his party, who were to travel by tube from Westminster to Greenwich, were forced to drive to London Bridge before picking up the service.

webTitle: Voucher chaos leaves refugees hungry

fields.headline: Voucher chaos leaves refugees hungry
fields.standfirst: Call to abolish bureaucratic and shaming token scheme
fields.trailText: Call to abolish bureaucratic and shaming token scheme.
fields.body:
Asylum seekers in Britain are being left hungry because of bureaucratic breakdowns in the government's voucher system, a report covering the work of more than 50 charities claimed yesterday.

The survey looking at the system introduced in April which gives vouchers for spending at certain shops only, came as the Transport and General Workers' Union, Oxfam and the Refugee Council urged the Home Office minister, Barbara Roche, to abolish the entire scheme and bring back cash benefits instead.

Bill Morris, the TGWU general secretary, said yesterday he feared that the outcome of a government review of asylum vouchers to be announced next month would do little more than tinker with the scheme, only scrapping the rule preventing supermarkets giving change to refugees in money or in lower denomination vouchers.

"The voucher system is expensive, bureaucratic and humiliating for asylum seekers. This survey shows that they have been experiencing hunger and cannot maintain good health. The scheme has failed and we do not want a review that is a political whitewash," said Mr Morris, who said he knew, having accompanied asylum seekers to the shops, what a "grotesque experience" they faced.

Under the scheme, single asylum seekers get vouchers worth £26.54 a week, as well as £10 cash. The vouchers must be spent at 21,000 designated shops and any change after a purchase can be pocketed by the retailer.

Mrs Roche promised to review the scheme in the face of a threatened revolt at this year's Labour party conference, with the outcome to be announced next month.

Forty-one of the 50 groups surveyed, including children's charities, local authorities, refugee agencies and others working with asylum seekers, said they had come across refugees unable to buy enough food and going hungry.

The Scottish Refugee Council said: "We have cases too numerous to list of emergency vouchers not turning up and people surviving on no income."

The Barnet Refugee Health Access Project reported the comments of a Sri Lankan man in his 60s: "The amount I get is hardly sufficient to meet our needs. I am diabetic and cannot afford to buy the special food I need. I suffer from arthritis. I need more heating and more warm clothing. I need thermal underwear, but cannot afford it."

Many charities, such as the Family Welfare Organisation, said that they were providing hardship grants for cots, winter coats and shoes and even pencils. Nearly all organisations reported that asylum seekers were finding it very difficult to stay healthy while living on vouchers and many did not have the money to pay for items such as underwear, babies' milk, nappies and toys.

Phil Bloom of Oxfam, which has boycotted the voucher scheme in its charity shops, said the vouchers had marked out asylum seekers as targets for abuse in supermarkets. He said there was little evidence to suggest that the introduction of vouchers had deterred economic migrants.

Since the cash benefits system was scrapped in April, asylum applications had risen from 5,890 to 6,970 in October.

Jack Straw was yesterday stopped from deporting hundreds of asylum seekers after law lords agreed the home secretary had acted unlawfully by ordering the return to Germany of Lul Adan, 28, from Somalia, and of Hamid Aitseguer, 33, an Algerian, to France, since these countries were not safe for refugees facing persecution from forces other than their own state. Usually, refugees can be sent back to the first safe country they arrive at, but France and Germany only recognise as refugees those facing state persecution in their own country. Lord Steyn said Mr Straw accepted that if the two asylum seekers were returned to these European countries, they would probably be sent to Somalia and Algeria to perhaps face torture and death.

webTitle: Comment, Polly Toynbee:The Independent Police Complaints Commission

fields.headline: Another police reform for Hague to get his teeth into
fields.standfirst:
This truly independent complaints commission is a real step forward

Special report: Macpherson report - one year on
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: This truly independent complaints commission is a real step forward.
fields.body:
The most remarkable aspect of William Hague's ill-judged outburst against the Macpherson report was his complete obliteration of what happened to Stephen Lawrence, what happened to the Lawrence family in their struggle for justice and finally what happened to the police who failed so abysmally to prosecute the killers. (Nothing). Hague has wiped out all three shameful events and replaced them with the charge that the Labour-instigated Macpherson report is instead the chief culprit.

Macpherson, claims Hague, undermined police morale and law and order on the streets: accused of institutional racism, police fled the service, new recruits were hard to attract. The government admits Macpherson dealt a severe shock to the police. The truth hurt, but it was necessary and accepted by senior police officers. Police numbers, they say, are no longer declining. However Macpherson has entered Tory demonology as another liberal cause of crime.

Undeterred, the government yesterday moved to implement one of Macpherson's most important recommendations. A new genuinely Independent Police Complaints Commission will be in place by 2003. As campaigned for vigorously by Liberty and Inquest (and the Guardian), over the last 20 years, the police will no longer investigate themselves in serious cases. This is what Macpherson said: "Since PCA inquiries, certainly in major cases, are conducted with or through other police forces, the perception is that such investigations of police by police may not be seen to result in independent and fair scrutiny and that justice is not seen to be done". Now at last it will be. No doubt the Tories will see this as yet another unwarranted assault upon the good name of the police, so it is worth recording some of the most serious recent cases.

Since 1990 there have been 548 deaths in police custody. Liberty and Inquest know of no police officer who has ever been prosecuted let alone jailed in relation to any of these events. All of them were investigated by the police themselves. These cases have taken years of dilatory investigation, ending with no police officers in court. Often officers slip off to early retirement on full pensions, signing themselves out with "stress" or "disability" before disciplinary action can be taken. Macpherson reported that at least five officers would have faced disciplinary charges, "but such charges could not be pursued because the officers had retired". He recommended new terms of employment to allow disciplinary proceedings to be brought after retirement, something that still waits to be done.

The many shocking cases that prompted this reform include that of Shiji Lapite. He was stopped by police for "acting suspiciously" and subsequently died from asphyxia as a result of a neckhold. The inquest jury was told that while caught in a fatal neckhold, one officer bit Lapite in the chest and another twice kicked him in the head as hard as he could. Lapite suffered 36 separate injuries, his voice box fractured during strangulation. Yet despite an inquest's verdict of "unlawful killing" there was no prosecution of any of the officers. The man's family took the case up to judicial review, where both the PCA and the crown prosecutor admitted their decision in the case had been "flawed". After that an inquiry into the CPS's handling of police cases ordered all serious police cases to be sent to a central unit - yet still no prosecutions have ever followed.

The files of Liberty and Inquest are packed with such cases: some become famous such as Harry Stanley - the man shot dead for carrying a table leg in a bag - others just add to the statistics of those dead in prison or in police cells, often restrained by six or eight officers, often killed by lethal neckholds - but no one ever to blame. The reason they become famous cases is because they drag on forever, with no just or satisfactory resolution, leaving families in a constant state of public protest.

Dealing day in and day out with the mad, bad and violent inevitably causes some police officers to fly out of control. All police forces will have some dangerous officers or just some very frightened ones. What matters most is how bad cases are handled - transparently, fairly and fast. It matters for the reputation of the police, as well as for the victims. The idea that letting daylight into the police, as Macpherson did, somehow undermines them, lowers their morale or lessens their authority is the exact opposite of the truth. The better they deal with their own miscreants, the more they will be trusted and the more support they will get back from the communities they police. Often complainants just want an explanation and an apology - too rarely given.

Dealing well with complaints (there is a huge disparity between best and worst police forces), will presumably be dismissed by Hague as more of that "paper-work" that keeps bobbies off the beat. But "paper-work" is often what keeps bobbies on the beat. Managerial efficiency includes keeping a stern eye on absenteeism. The Met have cut their sickness rates from an average of 14 days per officer a year in 1996-7 down to only nine days a year last year. That saving is equivalent to an extra 500 officers on the beat.

As the election approaches, Labour is worrying about how to get across the fact that crime has fallen, not risen as people always imagine. Polls show people think their own neighbourhood is safer than it was, but they still think crime "out there" is rising. Hardly surprising since everything they see and read tells them it must be so, local and national press as ever full of crime horrors, Crime Watch pumping it out every week, crime drama making violence seem to lurk everywhere. So far Labour has tried to seize popular support with strings of new laws, more crackdowns, more quick fixes. Child curfews and the like have little measurable effect on crime, but it all helps inflame fear of crime, now rebounding on Labour.

Jack Straw and Tony Blair have used law and order as a cheap vote-getter every bit as cynically as the Tories. It is the issue, after all, that created and defined New Labour. That killer leaked prime ministerial memo said it all: "The government needs something tough with immediate bite which sends a message through the system. Maybe, the driving licence penalty for young offenders. But this should be done soon and I personally should be associated with it." Those five short sharp law-and-order and fraud measures in the pre-election Queen's speech show Labour just as eager to use and abuse fear of crime for its own political ends. But at least yesterday, in introducing a genuinely independent police complaints procedure, here is Labour doing the right thing for the right reason, even if it does give William Hague another chance to accuse them of weakening police morale.

webTitle: Leader: Camelot's second coming

fields.headline: Camelot's second coming
fields.standfirst: The lottery commission played it too safe
fields.trailText: The lottery commission played it too safe.
fields.body:
The national lottery has done a lot of good - £8bn worth, if you deduct a billion or so for the costs of the peninsular folly at Greenwich. But the money-spinning machine that has turned over some £30bn in the past seven years has come to look mud-spattered and yesterday's decision to award the next franchise to Camelot is not going to wash much of the muck away. The assessment made by members of the national lottery commission (bar one, who did the honourable thing and resigned) was highly subjective. There is no science of commercial risk and former Treasury mandarins who in their time have attended such economic disasters as Black Wednesday might show more humility in their reasoning than did Lord Burns, chairman of the NLC.

Appointed panels and committees such as the NLC - quangos in the shorthand - have come to litter the administrative landscape. Many perform vital public service. But the great and good who run them no longer command slavish deference. Had culture secretary Chris Smith made yesterday's decision he would, at the very least, have had to answer in public view. Why should we give Lord Burns and colleagues immunity from cross-questioning and dissent?

Yet many will now breathe a deep sigh of relief and wish Camelot the best in carrying on collecting the golden eggs. They will be glad to see an end to the heavy-handed tactics employed by Camelot's managers which, together with Richard Branson's predilection for sailing close to the edge and amateurism at the NLC, combined to produce, earlier this year, the makings of a classic cock-up. Camelot had to be asked to continue its franchise after the statutory period expired. There will now at least be smooth continuity.

But the People's Lottery - with which, for the record, the former managing director of Guardian newspapers was associated - may not give up yet. The NLC accepts that Branson offered to raise more, to the tune of £110m-£160m more a year. The key question is whether he could have perked up public interest in the lottery and delivered higher revenues. But the NLC said the People's bid carried too many risks, preferring Camelot's market research. It came close to saying that any alternative bid would have jeopardised the sweet flow of funds to the good causes. That is worrying; for in the reletting of franchises for public services possession ought never to be nine points of the law. Unless franchisees genuinely fear loss, what incentives have they to fulfil their promises? A man who this week keenly awaits news of his train franchises had a lot more to lose than Camelot should he underperform as keeper of the lottery.

For the NLC, unimaginative caution seems to have been the watchword in sticking with Camelot. If the bids were, as the NLC implies, Tweedledum and Tweedledee, perhaps they might both have been approved, to run in parallel or in some regional configuration. As things stand we will never know how the People's Lottery might have revived the game. The fatalism about declining revenues that runs through the NLC opinion is dismaying.And even beyond the the lottery, there remain teasing questions about quangodom. What exactly did Dame Helena Shovelton do wrong that Lord Burns has now, apparently, put right? What exactly is the relationship between the quango and the courts, let alone the quango and the state? The independence of Lord Burns and colleagues is a precious attribute. But what if it comes to mean lack of accountability in this highly visible decision?

But the People's Lottery - with which, for the record, the former managing director of Guardian newspapers was associated - may not give up yet. The NLC accepts that Branson offered to raise more, to the tune of £110m-£160m more a year. The key question is whether he could have perked up public interest in the lottery and delivered higher revenues. But the NLC said the People's bid carried too many risks, preferring Camelot's market research. It came close to saying that any alternative bid would have jeopardised the sweet flow of funds to the good causes. That is worrying; for in the reletting of franchises for public services possession ought never to be nine points of the law. Unless franchisees genuinely fear loss, what incentives have they to fulfil their promises? A man who this week keenly awaits news of his train franchises had a lot more to lose than Camelot should he underperform as keeper of the lottery. For the NLC, unimaginative caution seems to have been the watchword in sticking with Camelot. If the bids were, as the NLC implies, Tweedledum and Tweedledee, perhaps they might both have been approved, to run in parallel or in some regional configuration. As things stand we will never know how the People's Lottery might have revived the game. The fatalism about declining revenues that runs through the NLC opinion is dismaying.And even beyond the the lottery, there remain teasing questions about quangodom. What exactly did Dame Helena Shovelton do wrong that Lord Burns has now, apparently, put right? What exactly is the relationship between the quango and the courts, let alone the quango and the state? The independence of Lord Burns and colleagues is a precious attribute. But what if it comes to mean lack of accountability in this highly visible decision?

webTitle: Gunmen attack deputy mayor of Moscow

fields.headline: Gunmen attack deputy mayor of Moscow
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: A senior official in Moscow's city government was wounded in an apparent assassination attempt yesterday when gunmen fired on his car, killing his driver, Moscow police said.
fields.body:
A senior official in Moscow's city government was wounded in an apparent assassination attempt yesterday when gunmen fired on his car, killing his driver, Moscow police said.

Iosif Ordzhonikidze, a deputy mayor, was on his way to work when assailants opened fire with assault rifles equipped with silencers and armour-piercing bullets. He was hit in the leg.

It was the highest profile attack on a Moscow city official since a 1996 bombing which wounded Valery Shantsev, Mayor Yuri Luzhkov's running mate. A close aide to Mr Ordzhonikidze, Vyacheslav Borulnik, was targeted several months ago but escaped harm.

Mr Ordzhonikidze is in charge of the city's relations with foreign organisations, hotels and casinos. He is associated with some of Moscow's most ambitious projects. According to the Itar-Tass news agency, Mr Luzhkov blamed the attack on "a criminal group that doesn't agree with the decisions taken by [Ordzhonikidze's] department".

webTitle: Pregnancy fear on epilepsy drugs

fields.headline: Pregnancy fear on epilepsy drugs
fields.trailText: Women who take one of the commonest medications for epilepsy while they are pregnant are at risk of having a child with impaired brain development, according to research published today.
fields.body:
Women who take one of the commonest medications for epilepsy while they are pregnant are at risk of having a child with impaired brain development, according to research published today.

There have been concerns for some time that epilepsy drugs could harm the foetus, but scientists have found it difficult to assess whether any damage is caused by the medication, the disease itself or other factors.

A study of 721 women with epilepsy carried out by researchers at the university department of neurology in Liverpool has now pointed the finger at the drug valproate which has been prescribed in the UK for 25 years.

Writing in the Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery and Psychiatry, David Chadwick and colleagues said their findings suggest use of the drug in pregnancy "carries particular risks for the development of children exposed in utero".

The findings have serious implications for women with epilepsy of childbearing age, who make up a third of all those taking anti-epileptic medicines. One in 250 pregnant women is estimated to be on anti-epilepsy medication.

Hardly any of the 721 women who took part in a survey had changed the epilepsy drugs they were on during pregnancy, indicating that neither they nor their GPs were aware that their baby may be at risk of impaired brain development.

The scientists asked the women, who were all registered with the Mersey regional epilepsy clinic, about their medication and about the educational development of their children.

Children whose mothers had taken anti-epilepsy drugs while pregnant were 50% more likely than others to have additional educational needs, including extra help in mainstream schools or attendance at a special school.

The numbers were particularly significant among women who had taken valproate alone. Their children had a threefold increased risk of additional needs. Those who had taken a combination which included valproate had over twice the risk.

The authors point out that over 90% of pregnancies among women with epilepsy are problem free. They also say that their findings must be viewed with caution because of the retrospective nature of the study.

Yet they are clear that "women are at increased risk of adverse outcomes".

They are undertaking further research to establish the effects of current medication on pregnant epileptics, but they also want to see more work done on new drugs arriving on the market.

webTitle: Defence chief lays into culture of 'risk aversion'

fields.headline: Defence chief lays into culture of 'risk aversion'
fields.standfirst: Officers could be sued for leading troops into action, says general in speech which also confronted underfunding of armed forces
fields.trailText: Officers could be sued for leading troops into action, says general in speech which also confronted underfunding of armed forces.
fields.body:
General Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of the defence staff, delivered in a speech last night a sweeping attack on what he called a culture of "risk aversion", warning of the prospect of young officers being sued by their platoons for leading men into action which could lead to death or injury.

He said: "If we hamstring our fighting services with inadequate funding, poor equipment, undermanning and inappropriate legislation then we will create a generation of sailors, soldiers and airmen who are little more than a gendarmerie. All symbolism and no substance".

He understood that the debate in Europe about ending employment discrimination on grounds of age and disability was motivated by good intentions and for entirely laudable aims. However, he added: "If left unchecked, the impact would have had a detrimental effect on the forces by insisting that disabled people had a right to serve. We need to guard against such ill-conceived ideas in future but the fact that some thought they should apply to the forces is a reflection of that lack of awareness of military issues".

In a swipe at the "litigious nation" Britain was becoming, Sir Charles expressed surprise that policemen involved in the Hillsborough football disaster were awarded compensation for the horrors they had to cope with.

"I don't doubt the very real problems that can give rise to post traumatic stress disorder," he told the Royal United Services Institute.

He added: "But what really concerns me about the creeping advance of litigation is that it will breed a cautious group of leaders who may step back from courageous decisions for fear that they will be pursued through the courts if it all goes wrong.

"Could we one day see a subaltern being sued by his platoon for making a decision, perhaps in the heat of battle, which subsequently turns out to have been misjudged and resulting in death or injury?

"There is a culture of risk aversion developing in society which is anathema to servicemen. We are not foolhardy but our profession requires a degree of decisiveness, flair and courage which sits badly with some of the more restrictive practices of modern employment legislation."

He made it clear he was strongly opposed to women fighting alongside men on the front line. Referring to a Ministry of Defence inquiry into their suitability for close combat roles, he said: "From my perspective we must ensure that nothing, I repeat nothing, damages the combat effectiveness of the British armed forces."

Sir Charles described the shortages of forces personnel - notably of RAF fast jet pilots - as "critical", given the worldwide operational tasks demanded of them. The shortage of 8,000 personnel in the army was now unlikely to be made good before 2008, he said.

One of the problems, he said, was that defence since the end of the cold war had been a "shrinking business".

In a swipe at the Treasury but praising the speed with which the armed forces had responded rapidly to the Sierra Leone crisis, he said: "We cannot keep on doing more and more for less and less. No one can expect us to keep this up".

 The government was yesterday accused of insulting "some of the bravest men who ever fought for this country" over leaving Gurkhas out of a £10,000 a head compensation package for former PoWs held in Japanese camps in the second world war.

The social security minister, Hugh Bayley, had told the Tory MP Patrick Nicholls that former Gurkhas would get nothing because they were employed by the Indian army at the time.

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Threat to kill charge
fields.body:
Threat to kill charge

George Jones, of Brockley, south-east London, who was injured while helping others when the Brixton nail bomb exploded last year, has been charged with racial harassment and threatening to kill a black woman. He will appear before Woolwich magistrates on Friday.

Hepatitis B jabs scheme

Greater Glasgow health board and the Scottish Centre for Infection and Environmental Health are planning a vaccination scheme that will target 10,000 children between the ages of 11 and 12 for innoculation against hepatitis B.

Stand-in for archbishop

The Pope has ordered the Roman Catholic archbishop of Cardiff to be replaced while he recovers from deep vein thrombosis. The Most Rev John Ward has faced calls to resign amid accusations that he ignored warnings about two paedophile priests in his archdiocese.

'Give blood at work' proposal

Workers should be offered the chance of giving blood at their offices or factories as part of a drive to ensure a regular supply of donors, the national audit office said yesterday. It said industrial sessions in London had helped to increase the number of volunteers compared with other parts of England.

'Coffee risk' in pregnancy

Women risk doubling their chances of having a miscarriage if they drink more than four cups of coffee a day during early pregnancy, according to a Swedish report.

webTitle: Doctor struck off over genital surgery

fields.headline: Doctor struck off over genital surgery
fields.trailText: A GP was struck off the medical register yesterday for serious professional misconduct in offering to carry out genital mutilation at £50 a time.
fields.body:
A GP was struck off the medical register yesterday for serious professional misconduct in offering to carry out genital mutilation at £50 a time.

Abdul Ahmed, 63, was videotaped agreeing to circumcise an eight-year-old and "circumcise and stitch" two older girls. The "stitch", it was alleged, referred to the practice, common among the Somali community, of excising the female external genitalia, including cutting away part of the labia.

Dr Ahmed denied all the charges against him at the professional conduct committee of the General Medical Council, and argued that the videotape had been edited.

The GMC did not believe him. Denis McDevitt, a professor chairing the disciplinary hearing, said: "The committee is appalled by the evidence they have heard of your offer to perform an abhorrent mutilation and illegal operation on female children."

A Somali woman went under cover to make the Channel 4 documentary Cutting the Rose, screened in 1997. Named only as Amena on film, she had been circumcised herself as a young girl and wanted to help expose those flouting a law outlawing the practice passed in 1985; the British Medical Association estimates 3,000 to 4,000 girls are still circumcised in the UK each year.

Amena told the GP, who was working in Manchester at the time, that she wanted him to perform "sunna" - the Somali word for removal of the head of the clitoris - on her daughter and two daughters of friends. Dr Ahmed was recorded on the tape concealed in Amena's handbag as saying: "I will do the circumcision at my home today. It will not be free, it will cost £50." When asked about the friend's two daughters, he said: "I can do the circumcision and the stitch, because they are older."

Dr Ahmed, now a senior partner in a practice in Stoke Newington, north London, denied he had ever carried out such operations on girls. "I told her [Amena] that I did not do female circumcision," he told the hearing. "Part of the tape when I tell her this is missing." His counsel, Alan Jenkins, claimed the GP was hard of hearing and thought they were discussing boys. The GMC rejected his explanations. "The committee do not find credible your account, given both in your police interview and in your evidence today."

He has 28 days to appeal.

webTitle: Brain power 'goes downhill' from age of 45

fields.headline: Brain power 'goes downhill' from age of 45
fields.trailText: The brain starts to slow down when people reach their mid-40s, according to a finding presented yesterday to a British Psychological Society conference in London.
fields.body:
The brain starts to slow down when people reach their mid-40s, according to a finding presented yesterday to a British Psychological Society conference in London.

Even the quickest witted found the mental brakes coming on after 45, said Keith Wesnes, who led a study of more than 2,000 male and female volunteers.

From then on there was a "marked and fairly linear increase" in the time taken to remember names and faces, react to situations, concentrate on tasks, and make decisions.

Professor Wesnes said: "By middle age you can be 10% to 15% slower in a number of functions than your were in your 20s.

"You're not concentrating as well, and you can't focus and ignore distraction to the same extent as you used to. You become slightly forgetful, and might not remember what you walked into a room for, or take a long time to recall someone's name. You're less able to bring things to the front of your mind quickly."

However, accuracy was not affected nearly as much, said Prof Wesnes.

His study was undertaken at Cognitive Drug Research Ltd in Reading, Berkshire, which studies the mental function of people taking part in pharmaceutical trials.

His team recruited 2,282 healthy volunteers aged 18 to 87 and gave them computerised tests designed to assess reaction time, memory for words, pictures and numbers and the ability to maintain concentration. The researchers found a clear pattern. Until the mid-40s mental faculties were unchanged.

After this, thinking speed showed a marked decline which continued at a constant rate into old age. The ability to remember words after a delay was especially affected.

What causes the slowdown is not clear. One theory is that as people get older, brain cells or neurones lose some of their ability to communicate with each other via chemicals called neurotransmitters. This in turn may cause the neurones to wither.

James Semple, from Addenbrooke's hospital, Cambridge, also presented findings at the conference, which showed that patients with Alzheimer's disease lost about 3% of their total brain volume each year, as compared to less than 0.5% lost in normal ageing.

However, commenting on the first finding, Dr Semple said that people should not worry about becoming mentally redundant in middle-age: "Old dogs have strategies and tricks they can use because they have experience working in the system. Maybe they can't process the information as quickly, but they know the short cuts."

Prof Wesnes said there was evidence that herbal supplements could help speed up the over-40s. In a trial, a group of middle aged people showed a 7% mental improvement after taking a combination of ginkgo and ginseng.
