webTitle: Dock manager to be tried for manslaughter

fields.headline: Dock manager to be tried for manslaughter
fields.trailText: The British manager of a Dutch-owned company is to be tried for manslaughter over the death of an untrained casual worker killed by a crane grab at Shoreham docks in West Sussex two years ago, the director of public prosecutions said yesterday.
fields.body:
The British manager of a Dutch-owned company is to be tried for manslaughter over the death of an untrained casual worker killed by a crane grab at Shoreham docks in West Sussex two years ago, the director of public prosecutions said yesterday.

Richard James Martell will face a charge of manslaughter by gross negligence over the death of Simon Jones, 24, whose head was crushed and partly severed within two hours of starting work in April 1998.

The company, Euromin, faces a corporate manslaughter charge.

The move follows a ruling by two high court judges in March that an earlier decision by the director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, and the crown prosecution service, not to prosecute Euromin or its general manager, was "irrational" and should be reconsidered "with despatch".

Mr Calvert-Smith said yesterday that he had examined the evidence and decided that there was "sufficient evidence for a realistic prospect of conviction" and that it was "in the public interest to prosecute".

The case has become a focus for those campaigning against casualisation and for tougher legal action against negligent employers. In September, friends and supporters of Mr Jones demonstrated outside the CPS office in London at the failure to prosecute.

Yesterday, Mr Calvert-Smith defended himself against accusations of unnecessary delay, saying that he and two QCs had had to "consider all the existing evidence from the beginning together with some new material - this was not something that could be done lightly or quickly".

The decision to prosecute Mr Martell and Euromin was welcomed yesterday by George Galloway, the Labour MP who led the campaign in parliament for a prosecution after the death.

The trial is expected to take place next year. There have only ever been six prosecutions for corporate man-slaughter, three of which were successful.

webTitle: Manics to play Cuba in comeback gig

fields.headline: Manics to play Cuba in comeback gig
fields.trailText: The Welsh pop group Manic Street Preachers is staging a comeback concert in Cuba, the first time a western rock band has been allowed to play in the communist country.
fields.body:
The Welsh pop group Manic Street Preachers is staging a comeback concert in Cuba, the first time a western rock band has been allowed to play in the communist country.

The group confirmed it would premiere its album Know Your Enemy on February 17 and would charge 25 Cuban cents (17p) admission to the gig at the Karl Marx theatre in Havana.

The band said they decided on Cuba because it was the "last place that holds out against the Americanisation of the world" - and the admission was set at an affordable level for local people. They added that they were feeling jaded with the whole process of releasing records.

Bassist Nicky Wire said: "It could be a disaster. There might not be a PA or whatever, but it's just the idea that it could be a bit of an adventure. So many bands these days just come back in the usual way and that's one thing we're not going to do this time."

Speaking on Radio 1, he said: "The Manic machine has ground to a halt for too long so now it's grinding into action again. It was my idea back in the summer. We did it all ourselves, no record company involved, just us - it couldn't be more fitting. Cuba is the last place that holds out against the Americanisation of the world so that's why I'd love to go out there and play the gig."

A spokesman for the band said the concert had been organised by their manager, Martin Hall, of Hall or Nothing management, who travelled to Cuba to negotiate terms. The group has been out of the public eye since releasing the single The Masses Against the Classes in January.

In July last year, the band denied they were splitting after failing to show at a 50,000 capacity concert in Belgium. The band later blamed ill health for the cancellation of the performance.

The band said they decided on Cuba because it was the "last place that holds out against the Americanisation of the world" - and the admission was set at an affordable level for local people. They added that they were feeling jaded with the whole process of releasing records. Bassist Nicky Wire said: "It could be a disaster. There might not be a PA or whatever, but it's just the idea that it could be a bit of an adventure. So many bands these days just come back in the usual way and that's one thing we're not going to do this time." Speaking on Radio 1, he said: "The Manic machine has ground to a halt for too long so now it's grinding into action again. It was my idea back in the summer. We did it all ourselves, no record company involved, just us - it couldn't be more fitting. Cuba is the last place that holds out against the Americanisation of the world so that's why I'd love to go out there and play the gig." A spokesman for the band said the concert had been organised by their manager, Martin Hall, of Hall or Nothing management, who travelled to Cuba to negotiate terms. The group has been out of the public eye since releasing the single The Masses Against the Classes in January. In July last year, the band denied they were splitting after failing to show at a 50,000 capacity concert in Belgium. The band later blamed ill health for the cancellation of the performance.

webTitle: 'Love light' promises to electrify libido

fields.headline: 'Love light' promises to electrify libido
fields.trailText: Powergen is claiming that its scientists have come up with a means to get couples in the mood for sex - a giant electric light.
fields.body:
Powergen is claiming that its scientists have come up with a means to get couples in the mood for sex - a giant electric light.

The "love light" is 6ft long and 18ins wide and uses a combination of light, colours and movement to stimulate the brain.

Although designed for the bedroom, it could be placed in any room just like a TV, the electricity firm said yesterday. Couples simply relax as they are covered in colours that play with their emotions.

Powergen's team of scientists came up with the idea after being asked to work out the optimum lighting for work and relaxation. The team discovered that light, colour and movement used at certain intensities and sequences could trigger arousal.

A shimmering red light made couples feel warm, while green could prompt one partner to feel jealous. Yellow, however, was the real hit among couples who were more likely to get physical when that colour was glim mering around them. The light's designer, Jamie Anley, said: "Love as an experience is dictated by the arousal of all five senses; however, for that love at first sight feeling it's the visual that dictates the initial chemistry.

"The light has been designed to simulate the love experience and trigger arousal. It's almost as if it short circuits the brain into an amorous mood."

Powergen said the light could be available in supermarkets as early as May 2002.

webTitle: CJD bill to soar as NHS cuts surgery risks

fields.headline: CJD bill to soar as NHS cuts surgery risks
fields.trailText: The NHS faces the prospect of paying billions of pounds for throwaway surgical instruments as part of the spiralling costs to cut the theoretical risk of patients catching the human form of BSE.
fields.body:
The NHS faces the prospect of paying billions of pounds for throwaway surgical instruments as part of the spiralling costs to cut the theoretical risk of patients catching the human form of BSE.

All tonsil operations in Britain - about 85,000 a year - are soon likely to be performed using £400 sets of once only instruments, and this switch to fully disposable equipment in mainstream surgery is likely to be just the forerunner of a change in surgery procedures at NHS and private and military hospitals.

Surgeons and government officials are investigating the use of more disposable instruments in complicated operations including brain and eye surgery where the risks rise for contamination of instruments with rogue prions - the proteins thought to be responsible for variant CJD. Tonsillectomies, not performed as often these days, are usually carried out only on children with frequent tonsilitis.

Dentists and opticians have already been told to buy more single-use equipment and there are tougher measures for decontaminating non-disposable instruments. Government advisers on BSE and vCJD have said that proper sterilisation can substantially reduce levels of infectivity.

A decision about the surgical changes will be made next month.

Some of the 88 victims of vCJD in Britain, five of whom are still alive, have been teenagers but it is not certain either how they were infected or how long the disease was incubating before they displayed the symptoms, which include depression, anxiety and loss of bodily control.

Cheap beef products are still prime suspects behind the disease. Government advisers have said the risk of transmitting the disease via surgical instruments was still "theoretical and unquantifiable". None of the vCJD cases so far has been linked to surgical contamination and it is understood a risk assessment has suggested that disposable instruments for tonsil surgery may only prevent one extra case of vCJD. But the Phillips inquiry into BSE and vCJD called for a "precautionary approach". Advisers have recognised that some precision equipment for single use could be unaffordable. There could also be problems storing disposables before safely destroyiing them.

The costs of the medical consequences of vCJD are mounting. Measures to cut the risk of vCJD contamination through blood donations are costing £83m a year in England and north Wales alone; the change in tonsil operations would cost another £35m yearly. The treatment of vCJD patients costs beween £6,500 and £40,000. Instruments used on vCJD patients are already destroyed, including medical equipment costing nearly £30,000. Yesterday, France became the latest among countries to ban blood donors who have been to Britain between 1980 and 1996.

The news of the measures coincided with new concerns that loopholes in food regulations allowed manufacturers to get round rules making it illegal to import and sell meat from cattle over 30 months old. Harriet Kimbell, a member of Seac, the spongiform encephalopathy advisory committee, said: "It is not illegal for an English manufacturer to go to Europe, buy meat and make it into products like frozen beefburgers, and sell it in Britain."

 A person in the UK whose blood was used in the production of a polio vaccine administered in Ireland, has been diagnosed with vCJD, the Irish government said yesterday. Between January 1998 and January 1999, 83,500 doses of the oral vaccine were distributed, mostly to the young.

The Irish health minister, Micheal Martin, insisted there was no risk of the recipients getting the disease."This person's donation was one of 22,353 [in] a pool. The final dilution was 1 to 63,866."

People are being advised to contact their GPs to find out about affected batches.

 Steven Lunt, 33, a victim of vCJD who died in April, seldom ate beef, an inquest heard yesterday. John Pollard, the south Manchester coroner, said Mr Lunt, of Stockport, died of variant CJD. Health officials are investigating a possible link between the deaths of Mr Lunt and Paul Dickens, 28, who lived near him.

webTitle: Hit and run car kills roadside policeman

fields.headline: Hit and run car kills roadside policeman
fields.trailText: Three people were being questioned last night about the death of a police constable who was hit head-on by a speeding car as he stood by the side of a road during an operation to stamp out Christmas drink-driving.
fields.body:
Three people were being questioned last night about the death of a police constable who was hit head-on by a speeding car as he stood by the side of a road during an operation to stamp out Christmas drink-driving.

Jon Odell, 30, was struck with such force by a Vauxhall Astra that his shoes, baton and reflective uniform were scattered along 50 yards of tarmac.

The car did not brake or stop. It was abandoned a mile from the scene.

The incident, which occurred at midnight on Monday, was seen by six other officers who were involved in the road safety operation in Margate, Kent.

"Jon heard a vehicle approaching at high speed and held out his radar speed gun to try to stop the car," said Superintendent George Rogers, the area commander. "But it went straight into him. Where Jon was hit his hat was found, a few yards up the road his shoes, then a CS gas canister and his baton, then his utility belt, and at 50 yards a pool of blood where he landed."

Mr Odell, from Margate, was taken to the town's Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother hospital, but died from massive internal injuries four hours later.

Mr Rogers added: "He clearly had internal bleeding and was in the operating theatre when he died. He had broken both legs and arms.

"The hospital staff knew Jon as a traffic officer, so it was a big shock for them."

Police found the silver X-registered Astra at nearby Tivoli Park. It had not been reported stolen and was registered to an address in Herne Bay, Kent

As detectives opened a murder investigation yesterday, Mr Odell's colleagues in Thanet, where he had served for five years, said they had lost a "totally professional" officer who loved his job.

"Thanet is a relatively small police area," said Mr Rogers. "Jon was a valued member of that family.

"He was one of the most personable, hard working and dedicated officers in this area. His file contains dozens of testaments from members of the public who appreciated the help he has given them and a commendation from senior officers about the manner in which he worked."

Mr Odell, who lived with his partner and her 13-year-old son, was taking part in Operation Impact, a local initiative to curb drink-driving and speeding.

Police hope they will be able to determine the exact speed of the car from the radar gun which Mr Odell was holding.

Graham Smirdin, Police Federation representative for Kent, said: "This was a tragic event, and it reminds us that there are police officers up and down the country going about their normal duties, seeking to protect the public, and that in doing so they are risking their lives."

A Kent police spokesman, Mark Pugash, said a 34-year-old woman and a 31-year-old man from Margate, and a 48-year-old man from Herne Bay were in custody at Dover police station on suspicion of murder.

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Arrest made 20 years later
fields.body:
Arrest made 20 years later

Bashir Ahmed, 44, wanted in connection with a murder in Oldham almost 20 years ago, has been arrested while applying for US citizenship in New York. The dismembered body of Tony Price, 31, was found in bin bags at the bottom of a reservoir in 1981.

Thumbs down for Lord Archer

Lord Archer's play The Accused is to close its West End run two months early due to poor ticket sales. The author is to appear before the Old Bailey next year on perjury charges.

No hiding place in West Midlands

Mugshots of three men suspected of violent crimes are being flashed on scoreboards at Aston Villa and Wolverhampton Wanderers football clubs. The trio are on the West Midlands police's top 10 wanted list.

£4.9m award for brain damage

The family of Lesley Wildsmith, 26, were yesterday awarded £4.9m for brain damage she suffered when doctors failed to realise her mother was carrying twins. Berkshire health authority accepted liability in 1998.

webTitle: Man who killed daughter thought he was Christ

fields.headline: Man who killed daughter thought he was Christ
fields.trailText: A doting father who believed he was Jesus Christ plunged a 14in carving knife into his sleeping daughter's heart in the belief she would come back to life after the attack, a jury heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A doting father who believed he was Jesus Christ plunged a 14in carving knife into his sleeping daughter's heart in the belief she would come back to life after the attack, a jury heard yesterday.

A Swansea crown court jury took five minutes to find Phillip Andrew Hall, 41, not guilty by reason of insanity of the murder of his daughter Emma, 12, last June .

The judge, Mr Justice McKinnan, said the verdict allowed him to order that Hall, from Catbrook, Monmouthshire, was locked away in a secure psychiatric hospital without limit of time.

In the meantime, he ordered that Hall be sent to Caswell Clinic, near Bridgend, pending a decision on which hospital he should be sent to long term.

Earlier, the jury had been told that Hall believed he had to kill his own family and commit suicide to save 15 other families from death.

Psychiatrists testified that Hall had been diagnosed as a chronic paranoid schizophrenic who suffered from profound delusions.

Neil Bidder, for the prosecution, said Hall had a history of mental problems.

But a series of hoax emails from a rival company led to him taking a bogus trip to India and might have been the catalyst for the tragedy.

The trip took place while Hall, a marketing manager, was working for a new firm called Molecular Light Technology in June.

The jury heard that Hall had been trained to demonstrate an experiment to the Indian clients. He became convinced that 15 full tubes that he had to take with him represented 15 Christian families which were facing death. A 16th empty tube represented his family which he would have to kill to save the others, he told psychiatrists

He planned to kill Emma, son James, 10, and his wife, Karen, before committing suicide.

The court heard that Hall had studied animal physiology and nutrition and enjoyed a successful career working for several multinational firms.

Hall's first signs of delusional behaviour, it was told, began when he went to America briefly to work in 1992.

He later claimed he had made a profound discovery - that he was Jesus Christ. He still managed to rise in his career despite spending time in psychiatric hospitals.

After the trial, a statement issued by the Hall family said: "Andy was the victim of a cruel hoax perpetrated apparently for business reasons by others.

"The hoax acted as a catalyst for this tragedy and had it not been carried out it seems likely that the awful consequences to the Hall family would not have happened.

"This is a tragedy in the truest sense."

webTitle: Mediation in divorce proves just as costly

fields.headline: Mediation in divorce proves just as costly
fields.trailText: Attempts by the government to cut millions of pounds from the legal aid bill by steering divorcing couples away from lawyers and into mediation have proved a failure, according to official research to be published today.
fields.body:
Attempts by the government to cut millions of pounds from the legal aid bill by steering divorcing couples away from lawyers and into mediation have proved a failure, according to official research to be published today.

The Guardian has seen research showing that measures designed to encourage couples to use mediation have produced no savings over the traditional method of using lawyers paid for by legal aid.

The results, forwarded by a team led by Gwynn Davis of Bristol University, are a blow for the government, which had adopted the last Tory government's blueprint for a less adversarial, no-fault divorce system, with separating couples resolving their disputes amicably through mediation.

The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, is expected to announce that no-fault divorce, passed as part of the Family Law Act in 1996, has been shelved. Mediation is covered by a different part of the act which is already in force, but the research will put a question mark over its future too.

The government is expected to point to a second study, also published today, as justification for abandoning no-fault divorce. That research, by Janet Walker of Newcastle University, found that "information meetings" for such divorces would cost at least £40m.

The mediation research, led by Bristol University and overseen by a steering committee and the National Council for Social Research, was done for the legal services commission (formerly the legal aid board).

The 1996 act requiring divorcing couples wanting legal aid first to explore mediation increased numbers referred to mediation. But only a fraction went through the process and agreement was reached in only 50% of cases involving children.

A typical mediation costs £1,200 compared with an average lawyers' bill of about £1,000 for clients on legal aid. The survey of more than 1,000 couples found most reluctant to resolve their disputes face to face. Interviewees "displayed high levels of mistrust of their former partner".

webTitle: Netanyahu exit boosts Barak

fields.headline: Netanyahu exit boosts Barak
fields.standfirst: Withdrawal leaves opposition with less credible candidate
fields.trailText: Withdrawal leaves opposition with less credible candidate.
fields.body:
Binyamin Netanyahu made a dramatic exit yesterday from Israel's special prime ministerial election, in a departure that hands a gift to the current leader, Ehud Barak.

Hours after the Israeli parliament passed a law to enable Mr Netanyahu to run as a private citizen, the former prime minister of the rightwing Likud party announced he would not after all be standing on February 6.

The announcement, 10 days after Mr Netanyahu's return from self-exile in the US, and a lucrative public speaking career, strips the Likud star of some of his mystique.

Many Israelis said yesterday he had clearly been outwitted by Mr Barak, who calculated correctly that Israel's parliament, or knesset, would balk at the prospect of a general election only 18 months after the last one.

"I could run and I am sure I would be elected," Mr Netanyahu told a press conference. But he said he had no desire to preside over a parliament paralysed by warring coalitions.

"Because the knesset did not have the courage to answer the will of the public and put itself up for new elections I decided to fulfil my promise," he said. "I will consider running once the knesset disperses itself."

Mr Netanyahu would then be prepared to take the plunge and to avenge his defeat by Mr Barak 18 months ago.

Analysts said Mr Netanyahu had squandered a runaway lead in the opinion polls. He also damaged his Likud party, sowing division by parachuting back on to centre stage only to walk out again.

Mr Netanyahu's departure leaves the Likud with a far less palatable candidate in the hardliner, Ariel Sharon. He enjoys a big advantage over Mr Barak in the opinion polls, but his lead could evaporate as Israelis consider seriously the ramifications of electing a prime minister so deeply reviled in the Arab world.

A champion of the Jewish settlers, he wants to keep the isolated outposts in the occupied West Bank and Gaza, all of the Jordan Valley, all of Arab East Jerusalem, all the fresh water aquifers in the West Bank, and complete control over air space.

"Things went according to Barak's plan," said Arian Ashar, a professor of political science and a fellow of the Israel Democracy Institute. "This was a move to preclude Netanyahu from the race, and that is what happened. Barak has certainly gained an advantage here."

Newspaper commentators were blunter. "According to any acceptable Israeli criterion, Netanyahu comes out of this story a real sucker," wrote Chemi Shalev in the Ma'ariv tabloid newspaper.

No matter what the outcome of the contest, Israel's next prime minister will lack the parliamentary backing to lead the country out of its crisis. But that did not stop the Nobel prize winner, Shimon Peres, from consideringthe possibility of standing. "I am weighing it very carefully and I have to weigh it very carefully because it's an appeal by the public and it must be considered seriously," he said.

At 77, Mr Peres has yet to win an Israeli election, and has suffered multiple humiliations. His candidacy could also take leftwing voters from his fellow Labour party contender, Mr Barak, stopping him winning in the first round.

Even without Mr Peres standing, Mr Barak faces a struggle to hold on to non-Jewish voters - whose support was crucial 18 months ago - with Israeli Arab parliamentarians expected to field their own candidate.

The strongest contender is Ahmed Tibi, a vocal member of parliament who could capitalise on deep anger at Mr Barak for the death of 13 Israeli Arab protesters, shot dead by police in October.

Mr Barak's chances in these elections hinge on the progress of the peace talks getting under way in Washington. Israeli and Palestinian negotiators began several days of separate talks with US officials yesterday to explore the prospects of resuming negotiations, and striking a peace deal.

But emotions are running high against a deal on both sides. During the 12 weeks of bloody conflict in the West Bank and Gaza, Israeli public opinion has shifted to the right, and there is strong opposition to making territorial concessions under pressure.

Palestinian public opinion is also against a deal, with protests and strikes throughout the West Bank and Gaza yesterday to mark the start of talks in Washington.

The anger is being fed by the almost daily funerals in the West Bank and Gaza.

Hear Suzanne Goldenberg reporting on the implications at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/israel

"Because the knesset did not have the courage to answer the will of the public and put itself up for new elections I decided to fulfil my promise," he said. "I will consider running once the knesset disperses itself." Mr Netanyahu would then be prepared to take the plunge and to avenge his defeat by Mr Barak 18 months ago. Analysts said Mr Netanyahu had squandered a runaway lead in the opinion polls. He also damaged his Likud party, sowing division by parachuting back on to centre stage only to walk out again. Mr Netanyahu's departure leaves the Likud with a far less palatable candidate in the hardliner, Ariel Sharon. He enjoys a big advantage over Mr Barak in the opinion polls, but his lead could evaporate as Israelis consider seriously the ramifications of electing a prime minister so deeply reviled in the Arab world. A champion of the Jewish settlers, he wants to keep the isolated outposts in the occupied West Bank and Gaza, all of the Jordan Valley, all of Arab East Jerusalem, all the fresh water aquifers in the West Bank, and complete control over air space. "Things went according to Barak's plan," said Arian Ashar, a professor of political science and a fellow of the Israel Democracy Institute. "This was a move to preclude Netanyahu from the race, and that is what happened. Barak has certainly gained an advantage here." Newspaper commentators were blunter. "According to any acceptable Israeli criterion, Netanyahu comes out of this story a real sucker," wrote Chemi Shalev in the Ma'ariv tabloid newspaper. No matter what the outcome of the contest, Israel's next prime minister will lack the parliamentary backing to lead the country out of its crisis. But that did not stop the Nobel prize winner, Shimon Peres, from consideringthe possibility of standing. "I am weighing it very carefully and I have to weigh it very carefully because it's an appeal by the public and it must be considered seriously," he said. At 77, Mr Peres has yet to win an Israeli election, and has suffered multiple humiliations. His candidacy could also take leftwing voters from his fellow Labour party contender, Mr Barak, stopping him winning in the first round. Even without Mr Peres standing, Mr Barak faces a struggle to hold on to non-Jewish voters - whose support was crucial 18 months ago - with Israeli Arab parliamentarians expected to field their own candidate. The strongest contender is Ahmed Tibi, a vocal member of parliament who could capitalise on deep anger at Mr Barak for the death of 13 Israeli Arab protesters, shot dead by police in October. Mr Barak's chances in these elections hinge on the progress of the peace talks getting under way in Washington. Israeli and Palestinian negotiators began several days of separate talks with US officials yesterday to explore the prospects of resuming negotiations, and striking a peace deal. But emotions are running high against a deal on both sides. During the 12 weeks of bloody conflict in the West Bank and Gaza, Israeli public opinion has shifted to the right, and there is strong opposition to making territorial concessions under pressure. Palestinian public opinion is also against a deal, with protests and strikes throughout the West Bank and Gaza yesterday to mark the start of talks in Washington. The anger is being fed by the almost daily funerals in the West Bank and Gaza. Hear Suzanne Goldenberg reporting on the implications at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/israel

webTitle: 'Honoured' Bush meets Clinton

fields.headline: 'Honoured' Bush meets Clinton
fields.standfirst: Party leaders meet in the Oval Office as aides try to dodge responsibility for a weakening US economy
fields.trailText: Party leaders meet in the Oval Office as aides try to dodge responsibility for a weakening US economy.
fields.body:
The US president, Bill Clinton, denied he was bequeathing a recession to his successor, George W Bush, as Republicans and Democrats manoeuvred yesterday to deflect the blame for an economic slowdown.

The president and president-elect met for the first time since the election, in what failed, at least publicly, to live up to its billing as a potentially highly charged encounter. Mr Bush had portrayed his election campaign as a crusade against Mr Clinton's amorality. He once joked on a late night talk-show that his first act in the White House would be to give the Oval Office, where they met yesterday, "one heck of a scrubbing".

Before the meeting began, Mr Clinton appeared before the cameras relaxed and smiling. Mr Bush sat tensely on a chair and rebuffed a series of questions, repeatedly declaring that he was honoured just to be there.

Republican officials, anxious that Mr Bush should not be shouldered with the responsibility for any slump next year, have been anxious to point out the early signs of a slowdown in the weeks preceding the inauguration on January 20.

Mr Bush refused to comment on the issue, but President Clinton defended the health of the economy.

"Well, a recession is two quarters in a row of negative growth. I don't think we're going to have that. But we couldn't keep up 5% growth a year forever. I think 49 of the 50 blue-chip forecasters think that growth will be 2.5% or better next year, and that'll keep unemployment low," the president said.

"But I think there will be things to be managed," Mr Clinton said. "[Mr Bush will] have economic challenges and we ought to give him a chance to meet them, not try to figure it all out in advance."

The two men also discussed another issue left outstanding in the transition period - a proposed visit by President Clinton to North Korea, where he will try to persuade Pyongyang to suspend its missile programme in return for economic assistance.

"No decision has been made on that," President Clinton said. "It's interesting, when I had this meeting eight years ago with the president-elect's father, he told me the biggest problem we were facing was the nuclear programme in North Korea, and we were able to build on the work they had done and put an end to that. And now the big problem there is the missile programme. We may have a chance to put an end to it. And if we can, I think we should."

Once more, Mr Bush had no comment, arguing he had not had the chance to talk to the president.

North Korea is not the only foreign policy loose end in the final five weeks of the eight-year Clinton era. Israeli and Palestinian negotiators are also in town in a bid to clinch an eleventh-hour Middle East agreement before the US transfer of power and next year's Israeli elections.

webTitle: 2000 was hot, say scientists

fields.headline: 2000 was hot, say scientists
fields.trailText: High temperatures in non-tropical areas of the northern hemisphere this year have fuelled fears of global warming, marking the 22nd consecutive year of temperatures above the 1961-90 average and triggering extreme weather conditions around the globe, the World Meteorological Organisation said yesterday.
fields.body:
High temperatures in non-tropical areas of the northern hemisphere this year have fuelled fears of global warming, marking the 22nd consecutive year of temperatures above the 1961-90 average and triggering extreme weather conditions around the globe, the World Meteorological Organisation said yesterday.

It is set to be the fifth warmest year on record , at 0.32C above the long-term average, despite unusually cold temperatures in the Pacific ocean caused by the La Nina weather front.

The WMO estimated that the global mean temperature rose by 0.6C during the 20th century. It has risen persistently since 1910, compared with the relatively stable average through the second half of the 19th century when international measurements began.

All weather stations around the world are continuing to record an increase in greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide. Godwin Obasi, the WMO's secretary-general, claimed the observations backed up scientific conclusions about climate change.

"It is a warm scenario which will promote extreme weather conditions and whatever we are experiencing confirms these predictions," Mr Obasi said, urging climate change negotiations to get back on track after the collapse of talks in the Hague last month.

"I think we have to take it seriously to curtail the emission of greenhouse gases and this accumulation in the atmosphere, that is the only way that, somehow, we start to address the issue of global warming."

Parts of the northern hemisphere experienced abnormally high average temperatures for long periods. In an area stretching from northern Canada to Mexico temperatures remained up to three degrees above average for 10 months.

Spring and summer in eastern Europe were two to three degrees above the average, while an area from Japan to northern Siberia experienced high temperatures between March and August.

The WMO recorded a wild combination of droughts and flooding in all regions of the world, triggering disasters and severe food shortages, although the trend was little worse than in recent years.

Extremes included the first thunderstorm ever recorded on the northern tip of Alaska and 692mm (27 inches) of rain in 24 hours in southern Hawaii, exceeding the previous world record of 566mm.

webTitle: Parliament: Good day, bad day

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.trailText: Bad day (1)
fields.body:
Bad day (1)

Flood victims. They will be deprived of millions of pounds if the Tories win the next election, Labour claimed. Social security secretary Alistair Darling said a leaked document meant the Conservatives would axe the social fund which provides help to needy families. The document said £90m would be cut from the fund to help pay for increases to the state pension. David Willetts, shadow social security secretary, rejected Labour's claims as "a scare story at the expense of deprived families".

Bad day (2)

Older men, 750,000 of whom have failed to apply for backdated winter fuel payments worth up to £140. Men aged 60-64 are eligible for the payments because of a European court ruling that it was discriminatory for women to get the benefits at 60 while men wait until 65.

Bad day (3)

Women needing the morning-after pill. A last-ditch bid to prevent the pill being sold over the counter was launched by the Tories, as William Hague and Liam Fox pledged to reverse the change that will see it available without prescription to women over 16 for the first time from January 1.

Today

Commons: Prime minister's questions. Hunting bill, second reading. Lords: Debates on the environment, EU enlargement, and the pre-budget report

webTitle: Kohl's son is to marry a Turk

fields.headline: Kohl's son is to marry a Turk
fields.trailText: Ironies do not come much richer. For years, as Germany's chancellor until 1998, Helmut Kohl stoutly opposed Turkey's entry into the European Union - an organisation he once memorably and notoriously described as a Christian club.
fields.body:
Ironies do not come much richer. For years, as Germany's chancellor until 1998, Helmut Kohl stoutly opposed Turkey's entry into the European Union - an organisation he once memorably and notoriously described as a Christian club.

His attitude to Germany's Turkish immigrants was just as uncompromising: Mr Kohl outraged the Turkish community seven years ago by failing to attend the funeral in Solingen of five Turkish immigrants, killed in postwar Germany's worst race attack.

Now it has emerged that the former chancellor's son is to marry - and his bride-to-be is Turkish.

Not only that. In order to comply with Turkish tradition, Mr Kohl had to make a special visit to Istanbul to ask her parents to allow the wedding to go ahead.

The marriage of Peter Kohl and Elif Sözen has the potential to transform German attitudes towards race, especially on the right. Despite his immersion in an unresolved power and money scandal, the elder Mr Kohl remains a revered figure among the Christian Democrats he led for a quarter of a century.

The more than 2m Turks in Germany make up what is by far the country's largest ethnic minority. Under a front-page picture of the former chancellor alongside his future in-laws, the tabloid daily, Bild, declared: "This photograph will do more for Turkish-German relations than a thousand state visits."

Mr Kohl's private office confirmed that the former chancellor had flown to Istanbul last weekend to meet the bride's parents and ask for her hand. He was accompanied by his eldest son, Walter, but not by his wife, Hannelore.

No date has been fixed for the wedding.

The younger Mr Kohl, 35, met his future wife in Boston while studying at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Ms Sözen, 32, is a banker and the daughter of an industrialist, Kemal Sözen.

According to media reports this week, Peter and Ms Sözen have for some years been living together in London, where they both work.

There was speculation that they might have postponed their engagement so as not to embarrass Mr Kohl's father while he was chancellor, up to September 1998.

webTitle: Up to 20 die in police raids on Turkish jails

fields.headline: Up to 20 die in police raids on Turkish jails
fields.trailText: A crackdown on prison hunger strikers in Turkey spiralled into a political disaster yesterday when at least 15 inmates burned themselves to death and two paramilitary police died during raids on more than 20 jails throughout the country.
fields.body:
A crackdown on prison hunger strikers in Turkey spiralled into a political disaster yesterday when at least 15 inmates burned themselves to death and two paramilitary police died during raids on more than 20 jails throughout the country.

Human rights groups condemned the operation by security forces which was aimed at ending the hunger strikes, being undertaken mainly by leftwing inmates protesting at plans to transfer prisoners from large dormitories to small cells. They fear a cell regime would make them vulnerable to abuse by jailers.

The justice minister, Hikmet Sami Turk, said: "Fifteen died after setting themselves on fire, 57 were injured, most of them having set themselves on fire, and two of our soldiers were martyred."

He said one member of the security forces taking part in the raids had been killed during clashes with inmates at Canakkale prison in western Turkey and another had been fatally injured during a raid on Umraniye prison in Istanbul. Another three were injured.

Plumes of smoke swirled over Istanbul's Bayrampasa prison, one of several where security forces met stiff resistance to their attempt to end the protest. Witnesses at a police roadblock half a mile away said the wind brought the smell of teargas.

Mr Turk said 1,139 prisoners were taking part in the hunger strike. Some 284 of them were on a "death fast" and have consumed only sugared water for about the last 60 days.

"It is unthinkable for the state to stand by and watch as people bring themselves face to face with death," he said. "The goal of this operation is to save people's lives."

Turkey's independent Human Rights Association and Ozgur Tayad, an association of prisoners' relatives, said that 17 prisoners had died. Officials could not confirm the two additional deaths.

The Human Rights Association added that at least 25 inmates were seriously injured.

"The so-called life saving operation by the justice ministry is causing deaths," she said.

The interior ministry said it had ended the protests at nine of the jails and taken 48 fasters and 198 other prisoners on hunger strike to hospital.

Officials say the transfers to small "F-type" cells are necessary to break the influence of organised gangs, far leftists, Kurdish separatist and militant Islamic groups in the jails.

Near Istanbul University, police waded into a crowd of protesters who were chanting "F-Type is death!" and beat them with batons before detaining several of them.

The storming of the jails came days after the government sent a limited amnesty law, which could halve the prison population, back to President Ahmet Necdet Sezer. He had rejected it as unjust and divisive last week.

Relatives of lefwing prisoners gathered outside Bayrampasa denounced the raids, the transfer plan and the amnesty law. "The goal is clear: they want to kill my children," one woman said.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Paratroopers in neo-Nazi's band
fields.body:
Paratroopers in neo-Nazi's band

The Australian army came under political fire yesterday after it was reported that members of an elite parachute unit were in a rock group with neo-Nazi sympathies.

Three members of the 3rd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment, were said to play in the group Blood Oath, whose leader admits to admiring Adolf Hitler. The regiment is also being investigated for allegations of severe and repeated beatings of members within its ranks.
AP, Canberra

Errant soldiers 'not disloyal'

South Africa's minister of defence denied yesterday that soldiers who had shot at images of President Thabo Mbeki during a shooting drill were "disloyal racists, as a newspaper report had claimed.

Mosiuoa Lekota said the difficult exercise asked troops to shoot on the run at images of enemies threaten ing Mr Mbeki. Under such difficult circumstances, he said, even crack marksmen were bound to miss their intended target. One image of Mr Mbeki had a bullet in its forehead.
Reuters, Pretoria

Iranian publisher summoned

A court has summoned the publisher of one of Iran's few remaining reform newspapers, the daily Hambastegi, for interrogation, according to sources at the paper yesterday.

More than 30 pro-reform publications have been banned by the conservative judiciary, inspired by the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamanei.

In April he declared the publications to be "bases of the enemy".
Reuters, Tehran

Decrease in media murders

Fewer journalists uncovering crime and corruption, or expressing political dissent, have been killed world-wide so far this year, with 62 media professionals believed killed, compared with 86 in 1999, acc- ording to the International Federation of Journalists.

Its annual report listed 37 journalists killed because of their work, with another 20 suspect deaths under investigation. The deaths of five other media staff were also listed.
AP, Brussels

webTitle: Hillary hunts for home close to corridors of power

fields.headline: Hillary hunts for home close to corridors of power
fields.trailText: The Clintons, one of the world's most talked-about couples, might become neighbours of Kitty Kelley, one of its most feared biographers, as Hillary goes shopping for a new home.
fields.body:
The Clintons, one of the world's most talked-about couples, might become neighbours of Kitty Kelley, one of its most feared biographers, as Hillary goes shopping for a new home.

Mrs Clinton needs a new home in Washington DC after she and the president are evicted from the White House next month.

Kelley, whose victims include the British royal family, Elizabeth Taylor and Frank Sinatra, lives next to a house in Georgetown that Mrs Clinton gave the once-over.

The house, valued at $4.4m (£3m), belongs to the Phillips family, scions of the founders of America's first modern art museum, and was once owned by Jackie Onassis's mother.

"I'm about 100ft away and my back doors open up on the Phillips's back door," said Kelley. "I'd be delighted to have Hillary move in. We're both cat lovers and I'm the only girl in Washington with 'meow' on her licence plate.

"So far I haven't written books about my neighbours," said Kelley. "I believe in the good-neighbour policy."

One possible neighbour who obviously does not is Mike Murphy, who worked on the campaign of the Republican Rick Lazio, whom Mrs Clinton beat for her New York seat.

"Our wonderful neighbourhood could become a parking lot for various book agents, defence lawyers, foreign despots and payola artists," he said in an email to friends.

"A very large klaxon horn will soon be stoutly placed on my roof; please send any particularly irritating Xmas and other holiday music my way."

Mrs Clinton had to buy a home in New York to qualify for her Senate contest. Now she needs one in Washington to do the job.

Putative neighbours have made their minds up on whether the Clintons will move in, even if Mrs Clinton has not. "I heard the contract was signed and she got it for $3.4m," said caterer Spencer Abruzzese.

Interior designer Frank Babb Randolph said: "Hillary wants that house because the Clintons are enamoured with the Kennedys."

The president said that the couple had not settled on any house.

But Karen Nicholson of Sotheby's International Realty, which is handling the property, said: "So far she's been looking for things in the $5m, $6m range. What would you expect from someone who doesn't come from money?"

Interior designer Frank Babb Randolph said: "Hillary wants that house because the Clintons are enamoured with the Kennedys." The president said that the couple had not settled on any house. But Karen Nicholson of Sotheby's International Realty, which is handling the property, said: "So far she's been looking for things in the $5m, $6m range. What would you expect from someone who doesn't come from money?"
fields.bylineHtml: Michael Ellison in New York

webTitle: Comment: Jeremy Hardy

fields.headline: Tough on toys, tough on the causes of toys
fields.standfirst:
How we ensure that asylum seekers stick to life's bare essentials

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Jeremy Hardy: How we ensure that asylum seekers stick to life's bare essentials.
fields.body:
It behoves me to clarify last week's column, because Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, has written to contradict me on two points. Whenever you see a minister do this, it is worth re-reading the article about which they are complaining, to see which accusations they do not deny.

For example, Ms Roche did not deny that the role of the national asylum support service is to make refugees' lives as miserable as possible or that the government is busy jailing as many as possible. Perhaps most worryingly, she did not deny that she gives children fishfingers as Christmas presents. I admit I was going out on a limb with that one and couldn't have backed it up if challenged, but it seems to be a gamble that paid off, because we must assume it's true.

In fact, she did not deny that the Asylum Support Regulations published this year define toys as not being an "essential living need", which means that the level of support for refugees was calculated expressly to exclude the possibility of their buying toys. Since those were the government's words, Ms Roche is hard-pressed to shake them off, although bolder ministers would try. I believe the correct thing for politicians to say about something like that is: "We were trying to start a debate". Instead, Ms Roche tells us that refugees "can use their vouchers in 23,500 retail outlets on anything they want". I suppose that's true; they could buy the kid a pony if they starved her for a year and Asda had one in stock.

It is hard to develop a clear picture of exactly what's happening nationwide, because the asylum support system is in chaos. Which shops are designated to take vouchers varies from place to place, and the items that shops will exchange for them vary even more. With refugees dispersed to all kinds of remote places, there is no guarantee that they can spend their vouchers anywhere nearby at all. The ones in prison get no vouchers but full board and free racial abuse.

The main point about vouchers is that their function is to humiliate vulnerable people and make them identifiable in communities that might already be reluctant to accept them. The only people who benefit from the scheme are the far right, the supermarkets, the Sodexho corporation which prints the vouchers, and the government, which gets to demonstrate that it is tough on toys and tough on the causes of toys. If, as Ms Roche suggests, the level of support is similar to that provided to other welfare claimants, the scheme is more expensive than paying cash.

In fact, when Ms Roche says that the support given by NASS is "broadly equivalent to income support levels", she is right only to the extent that it's less. It is true that, although the value of vouchers is much lower than income support, refugees get a few other bits and bobs that partly close the gap. When everything is added up, refugees get about 80% of income support, quite a bit less than not very much. Moreover, "free furnished accommodation" is a grandiose way of describing the holes into which asylum seekers and other welfare claimants are dumped. In fact, most of the places laughably called "hotels" have got some furniture in them. Refugees are not disporting themselves on the finest chaises longues while single mums in the same B&B sit enviously on metal spikes. In many cases, the accommodation on offer is much the same, but again, systems vary around the country, and landlords are a law unto themselves.

The dispersal system itself is pure harassment. Recently, a refugee was sent from the Tees Valley to Leicester, away from his best friend and only known contact in the UK, on the pretext that there was no single male accommodation available. The same day, a man in Leicester was dispersed to the Tees Valley.

But, in any case, is not Gordon Brown furious that, while he talks up his munificence, the Home Office brags that all welfare claimants live miserably, not just asylum seekers? In April, Jack Straw reassured the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture that, for all those on welfare, "there is equally no special provision made for toys". Well, praise be.

There is a strong case for saying that displaced people with traumatised children and no extended family around them are even more in need than are other deprived families. The Medical Foundation has cited the particular therapeutic effects of play for refugee children. But the fact that we should even be weighing up the perks of being different kinds of pauper is a woeful indictment of government. Of the ruling that toys are non-essential, Straw says: "The purpose of that provision is to ensure that families are not regarded as destitute simply because they cannot afford toys for their children." Merry bloody Christmas.

webTitle: Obituary: Mathew Lukwiya

fields.headline: Mathew Lukwiya
fields.standfirst: Devoted doctor who gave his life fighting the Ebola epidemic in Uganda
fields.trailText: Devoted doctor who gave his life fighting the Ebola epidemic in Uganda
fields.body:
Last October, Dr Mathew Lukwiya, who has died aged 43, was studying for his master's degree in public health in Kampala when he received a call from his hospital, St Mary's Lacor, at Gulu, in northern Uganda. He was told that a strange disease had killed several student nurses. He returned immediately and within days alerted the health ministry that an Ebola-like virus had struck the hospital.

Over the next two months, Lukwiya led the efforts to combat the disease, earning the praise of health experts who had flown to Uganda to fight the epidemic. It was agreed that only volunteers should work on Ebola wards because of the risks. Lukwiya led by example, and 25 staff agreed to work alongside him. They turned up for duty, even after some of their colleauges contracted Ebola and died.

Most of the deaths were linked to mistakes in the use of protective clothing, caused by overwork. Last month, Lukwiya himself fell victim to the same fatigue, having been called out of bed to tend a nurse in the final stages of Ebola. The following week he fell sick; he died six days later.

Lukwiya could have worked anywhere, but he chose to stay in northern Uganda, where he had been born, an Acholi, in the remote region of Kitgum. At school, he emerged as one of the best students in the district and, in 1976, went to Makerere University, Kampala, to study medicine.

At the end of his studies, Lukwiya was approached by an Italian doctor, Piero Corti, who, with his surgeon wife, Lucille, had run St Mary's Lacor, an Italian-founded mission hospital in Gulu, since 1961. Corti explained that he wanted to Africanise the institution and invited Lukwiya to work with him. The hospital had an excellent reputation; although small, it was well-equipped, with a highly motivated staff.

When Lukwiya arrived, the district was peaceful, but all that changed in 1986 when the Kampala government was overthrown and the north became a centre for insurgency. Gulu was attacked by rebels, marking the start of four years of turbulence for the region - and the hospital.

In 1987, the rebels raided Lacor in search of drugs. In the same year, government troops and rebels fought a gun battle in the hospital compound. Most non-Acholi staff left in fear for their lives. Lukwiya, however, elected to stay. Two years later, the notorious rebels of the Lords Resistance Army came to the hospital, looted drugs and abducted Lukwiya for a week, forcing him to walk through swamps, carrying heavy loads.

Rebel activity subsided in 1990 and, in the same year, he travelled to England to study for a master's degree in tropical paediatrics at Liverpool University. He returned to Lacor, and in 1995, the rebels resurfaced. The hospital began treating people whose limbs had been blown off by mines or hacked off by machetes. It was a difficult time, made worse by the death, in 1996, of Lucille Corti, who had contracted the Aids virus during her work.

Lukwiya was appointed medical superintendent; he was trusted by staff and revered in Gulu. But, in 1998, he left again for Kampala, to study for a master's in public health. He remained there until the telephone call reporting the Ebola virus outbreak.

He is survived by his wife Margaret, whom he had met while she was a student in Gulu, and five children. At his own request, he was buried next to the grave of Lucille Corti in the grounds of the hospital to which he had devoted his life.

 Mathew Lukwiya, doctor, born November 27 1957; died December 5 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Randolph Hearst

fields.headline: Randolph Hearst
fields.standfirst: US tycoon sobered by his daughter's kidnap
fields.trailText: Randolph Apperson Hearst, who has died aged 85, was the one of the five sons of William Randolph Hearst who looked after the business side of his family's vast American newspaper, magazine and broadcasting empire.
fields.body:
Randolph Apperson Hearst, who has died aged 85, was the one of the five sons of William Randolph Hearst who looked after the business side of his family's vast American newspaper, magazine and broadcasting empire. Quiet and fabulously wealthy, he was catapulted into most unwanted notoriety when his daughter, Patty, was kidnapped in February 1974 by a group of black militants calling themselves the Symbionese Liberation Army.

In a classic example of what has been become known as the Stockholm syndrome, Patty Hearst seemed to have been converted by her captors, and went with them on a bank raid. She was caught by closed circuit television cameras holding a weapon, and subsequently sentenced to seven years in prison, of which she served just less than two years.

At her trial she denied that she had embraced her kidnappers' revolutionary hostility to capitalism. Her father, who, with his wife, had faithfully attended the trial, conspicuous in his sober business suits, surprised many by refusing to condemn his daughter and trying to understand her feelings about the experience.

Randolph Hearst's father, William Randolph Hearst Sr, was himself the son of a rich mining investor with major holdings in the Comstock silver lode in Nevada, the Anaconda copper mine in Montana and rich goldmines in California. The father was flamboyant. He was famous for reproving the western artist, Frederick Remington, hired to cover the Spanish-American war in Cuba but unable to find any fighting to paint, with the words: "You provide the pictures, Mr Remington; I'll provide the war."

The founding father won the San Francisco Examiner in a poker game and gave it as a present to his son, William Randolph Hearst, then a student at Harvard. Hearst Sr, brilliantly caricatured by Orson Welles and Herman Mankiewicz in the film Citizen Kane, built up a chain of rightwing newspapers and other media properties across America.

When he died in 1951, Will- iam Randolph Hearst de clined to leave the properties to his five sons. Instead, he left them to be managed by accountants and editors, with the sons outnumbered on a 13-man board of trustees.

After boarding school at Lawrenceville and Harvard, Randolph worked for various family papers and then served in the air transport command of the United States Army Air Corps, rising to the rank of captain.

After the second world war, he worked his way up in the management of the San Francisco Call-Bulletin to become its publisher, shortly before his father's death. He then moved into the corporation management of the Hearst companies, becoming president, director and chief executive of Hearst Publishing and Hearst Consolidated Publication.

The family business was losing millions of dollars a year. Randolph Hearst backed managers who pruned away unprofitable elements of the business and restored and increased its profitability. From 1973 to 1996, he was chairman of the family's privately-owned holding company. He also occupied important positions in the Hearst family's charitable foundations.

He served on the board of the National Council of Christians and Jews, and was a member of the council of both the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

Until 1974, Hearst and his then wife, Catherine Campbell Hearst, led a cheerful and prominent social life in San Francisco, and his personal fortune grew inexorably. The most recent estimate by Forbes magazine put his net worth at $1.8bn, and shortly before his death he bought the 30,000-ft square Vanderbilt mansion in Manaplan, near Palm Beach, Florida.

Then the thunderbolt fell. His daughter was abducted from her dormitory at the University of California at Berkeley. Her kidnappers demanded that her parents give millions of dollars to poor people in California, and Hearst started a programme called People In Need, to which he pledged $2m. Eventually, more than 90,000 bags of food were distributed to the poor.

For a man of such wealth, who had done so well in business, Hearst was surprisingly shy and retiring. Friends say that he felt he had fallen short of his father's achievement. "He was a nice man," said Frank Bennack Jr, the long-time editor of the San Francisco Examiner. "Probably too nice for his own good."

But when the family catastrophe happened, Hearst insisted on being his own media spokesman, and personally took on the burden of rescuing Patty, while trying to understand her motives - and those of her kidnappers. He was, said Larry Kramer, a former Examiner reporter, "never the same afterwards".

Less than a month ago, the Hearst family sold the Examiner, its first newspaper property, and took over its ancient rival, the San Francisco Chronicle.

Hearst's first marriage ended in divorce in 1982. A second marriage, to Maria Cynthia Scruggs, also ended in divorce. He is survived by his third wife, Veronica de Uribe, and his five daughters.

 Randolph Apperson Hearst, newspaper and media executive, born December 2 1915; died December 18 2000

webTitle: Obituary Kirsty MacColl

fields.headline: Kirsty MacColl
fields.standfirst: Gifted but restless singer ill at ease with an industry she despised
fields.trailText: Gifted but restless singer ill at ease with an industry she despised
fields.body:
Last March, Kirsty MacColl released Tropical Brainstorm, a witty, wise and acerbic work widely hailed as the best album of her career. At the time, she said that “whenever I go into a studio, I operate on the principle that I might get hit by a bus tomorrow. And I’d hate the obituaries to have to read: ‘And her last album was her not-very-good album.’”

She avoided that fate, but her death, at the age of 41, must prompt speculation about the albums she might have made. Tropical Brainstorm bore all the hallmarks of her recent infatuation with South America - even though it was recorded in drizzly old Britain with non-Latin musicians - but throughout her career she proved herself adept at writing or performing in diverse idioms.

MacColl’s first Top 20 hit from 1981, There’s A Guy Works Down The Chip Shop Swears He’s Elvis, was a novelty effort, which suggested she might be a kind of female Chas & Dave. But her collaboration with the Pogues, on the whisky-sodden 1987 Christmas hit, Fairytale Of New York, revealed new musical and dramatic gifts, while later releases found her tripping nonchalantly through country & western, rock and electronic dance music.

Even though she never entirely overcame the stage fright which probably kept her from achieving the success that should have been her due, MacColl was steeped in music and the performing arts. Her father was the folk musician Ewan MacColl, and her mother was the dancer and choreographer Jean Newlove, although, by the time Kirsty was born, her father had married Peggy Seeger. She grew up in Croydon, south London, with her mother, her older brother Hamish and three younger half-siblings. Ewan used to visit them on Sundays.

Her first adventures in the music business found her tiptoeing round the edges of punk rock. In 1978, she sang with a band called the Drug Addix; she dubbed herself Mandy Doubt. The group made an EP called The Drug Addix Make A Record, which came to the attention of Stiff Records. However, Stiff were only interested in Kirsty, and invited her to record a debut solo single, They Don’t Know; it was released in June 1979, after she had dropped out of art college. The disc flopped, but the song became a substantial hit for Tracey Ullman four years later.

Despite the success of A Guy Works, MacColl still could not establish herself, not least because of her fear of live perfor mance. On a tour of Ireland, she once rushed through her material at such a pace that she ran out of songs and had to sing them all again. None- theless, she was back at Stiff Records in 1985, and returned to the UK charts with a version of Billy Bragg’s song, A New England. “She has possession of one of the most distinctive voices in pop,” he said.

By now MacColl was married to the record producer Steve Lillywhite, who was quick to make full use of her talents, which included perfect pitch and a knack for recording harmony vocals on the first take. She appeared regularly as a backing singer on production efforts by Lillywhite and others, and featured on discs by Simple Minds, Happy Mondays, The Smiths, Talking Heads and Robert Plant.

I t was her solo album, Kite (1989), that finally saw MacColl realising some of her potential. The songs were, by turns, funny, tender and furiously political, one of her recurring themes being the treatment of women in the music business. “The music industry packages women,” she said. “You’re either a dolly-bird bimbo or a soapbox sociologist.”

Subsequent releases included Electric Landlady, Titanic Days and the compi lation Galore, but despite the manifest quality of her songwriting - and showers of critical plaudits - sales were disappointing, and MacColl grew accustomed to the chore of shopping for new record labels. She remained visible via regular television appearances with French and Saunders, while her music has been used in several movies and in the TV comedy, Moving Story.

She was never able to reconcile herself fully to working in a music industry she often despised - “It gets slightly less to do with music every year,” she complained. This, perhaps, contributed to the breakup of her marriage in the mid-90s. “She’s brilliant,” Lillywhite once said, “and sometimes she’s not very happy.”

MacColl’s discovery of the delights of South America and the Caribbean had even prompted her to consider giving up music for travelling. “It was like a sudden liberation of my brain,” she recalled. “I had spent so long being unhappy in a very British way, and suddenly there was all this new stuff.”

She leaves two sons, Jamie and Louis.

• Kirsty MacColl, singer, born October 10 1959; died December 18 2000

High on spiky teeth and Cuba

I met Kirsty, with her long red hair and smashing smile, on November 11 in Havana, making Kirsty MacColl’s Cuba, eight music programmes due for transmission on Radio 2. She worked at record pace.

Decisive, with strong opinions, she had been in Cuba several times in the last 10 years. She regaled us with tales of driving, with her sons and a Cuban doctor friend, the length of the island to Santiago in the early 1990s, of giving hitchhikers lifts and avoiding potholes and goats on the road. She was proud that her picture had, just the week before, been on the front page of Granma, Cuba’s main newspaper, for handing in a petition in London supporting the island’s struggle against the US embargo.

Returning from a heavy day recording in Santa Clara, at the new mausoleum for Che Guevara, then down at the Bay of Pigs, she insisted on us buying a bottle of nine-year-old Havana Club rum, which we consumed, while telling all the jokes we knew: Kirsty had more than anyone - and they were the most wicked. We sang her finest piece, an a cappella music-hall ditty learnt from Ewan when she was young: “It’s a great one if the sound goes wrong on stage and you’ve got to keep the audience pacified, it stops them in their tracks.”

She talked gardens; she was passionate about her own, with its two ponds, naming every tree and plant she had. We went to visit Ibrahim Ferrer, of Buena Vista Social Club, then to interview José Luis Cortés, of NG La Banda, Cuba’s most controversial street cred group.

Kirsty was half-hearted about Cortés until she met him. By the time we left, they were talking of writing and recording a song together. She left Havana, enthusing over her extra bag, packed with beautiful etchings of armour fish discovered in the market, and “more papier-maché fish, but these ones have got real spiky teeth”.

Jan Fairley
fields.bodyText: Last March, Kirsty MacColl released Tropical Brainstorm, a witty, wise and acerbic work widely hailed as the best album of her career. At the time, she said that “whenever I go into a studio, I operate on the principle that I might get hit by a bus tomorrow. And I’d hate the obituaries to have to read: ‘And her last album was her not-very-good album.’” She avoided that fate, but her death, at the age of 41, must prompt speculation about the albums she might have made. Tropical Brainstorm bore all the hallmarks of her recent infatuation with South America - even though it was recorded in drizzly old Britain with non-Latin musicians - but throughout her career she proved herself adept at writing or performing in diverse idioms. MacColl’s first Top 20 hit from 1981, There’s A Guy Works Down The Chip Shop Swears He’s Elvis, was a novelty effort, which suggested she might be a kind of female Chas & Dave. But her collaboration with the Pogues, on the whisky-sodden 1987 Christmas hit, Fairytale Of New York, revealed new musical and dramatic gifts, while later releases found her tripping nonchalantly through country & western, rock and electronic dance music. Even though she never entirely overcame the stage fright which probably kept her from achieving the success that should have been her due, MacColl was steeped in music and the performing arts. Her father was the folk musician Ewan MacColl, and her mother was the dancer and choreographer Jean Newlove, although, by the time Kirsty was born, her father had married Peggy Seeger. She grew up in Croydon, south London, with her mother, her older brother Hamish and three younger half-siblings. Ewan used to visit them on Sundays. Her first adventures in the music business found her tiptoeing round the edges of punk rock. In 1978, she sang with a band called the Drug Addix; she dubbed herself Mandy Doubt. The group made an EP called The Drug Addix Make A Record, which came to the attention of Stiff Records. However, Stiff were only interested in Kirsty, and invited her to record a debut solo single, They Don’t Know; it was released in June 1979, after she had dropped out of art college. The disc flopped, but the song became a substantial hit for Tracey Ullman four years later. Despite the success of A Guy Works, MacColl still could not establish herself, not least because of her fear of live perfor mance. On a tour of Ireland, she once rushed through her material at such a pace that she ran out of songs and had to sing them all again. None- theless, she was back at Stiff Records in 1985, and returned to the UK charts with a version of Billy Bragg’s song, A New England. “She has possession of one of the most distinctive voices in pop,” he said. By now MacColl was married to the record producer Steve Lillywhite, who was quick to make full use of her talents, which included perfect pitch and a knack for recording harmony vocals on the first take. She appeared regularly as a backing singer on production efforts by Lillywhite and others, and featured on discs by Simple Minds, Happy Mondays, The Smiths, Talking Heads and Robert Plant. I t was her solo album, Kite (1989), that finally saw MacColl realising some of her potential. The songs were, by turns, funny, tender and furiously political, one of her recurring themes being the treatment of women in the music business. “The music industry packages women,” she said. “You’re either a dolly-bird bimbo or a soapbox sociologist.” Subsequent releases included Electric Landlady, Titanic Days and the compi lation Galore, but despite the manifest quality of her songwriting - and showers of critical plaudits - sales were disappointing, and MacColl grew accustomed to the chore of shopping for new record labels. She remained visible via regular television appearances with French and Saunders, while her music has been used in several movies and in the TV comedy, Moving Story. She was never able to reconcile herself fully to working in a music industry she often despised - “It gets slightly less to do with music every year,” she complained. This, perhaps, contributed to the breakup of her marriage in the mid-90s. “She’s brilliant,” Lillywhite once said, “and sometimes she’s not very happy.” MacColl’s discovery of the delights of South America and the Caribbean had even prompted her to consider giving up music for travelling. “It was like a sudden liberation of my brain,” she recalled. “I had spent so long being unhappy in a very British way, and suddenly there was all this new stuff.” She leaves two sons, Jamie and Louis. • Kirsty MacColl, singer, born October 10 1959; died December 18 2000 High on spiky teeth and Cuba I met Kirsty, with her long red hair and smashing smile, on November 11 in Havana, making Kirsty MacColl’s Cuba, eight music programmes due for transmission on Radio 2. She worked at record pace. Decisive, with strong opinions, she had been in Cuba several times in the last 10 years. She regaled us with tales of driving, with her sons and a Cuban doctor friend, the length of the island to Santiago in the early 1990s, of giving hitchhikers lifts and avoiding potholes and goats on the road. She was proud that her picture had, just the week before, been on the front page of Granma, Cuba’s main newspaper, for handing in a petition in London supporting the island’s struggle against the US embargo. Returning from a heavy day recording in Santa Clara, at the new mausoleum for Che Guevara, then down at the Bay of Pigs, she insisted on us buying a bottle of nine-year-old Havana Club rum, which we consumed, while telling all the jokes we knew: Kirsty had more than anyone - and they were the most wicked. We sang her finest piece, an a cappella music-hall ditty learnt from Ewan when she was young: “It’s a great one if the sound goes wrong on stage and you’ve got to keep the audience pacified, it stops them in their tracks.” She talked gardens; she was passionate about her own, with its two ponds, naming every tree and plant she had. We went to visit Ibrahim Ferrer, of Buena Vista Social Club, then to interview José Luis Cortés, of NG La Banda, Cuba’s most controversial street cred group. Kirsty was half-hearted about Cortés until she met him. By the time we left, they were talking of writing and recording a song together. She left Havana, enthusing over her extra bag, packed with beautiful etchings of armour fish discovered in the market, and “more papier-maché fish, but these ones have got real spiky teeth”. Jan Fairley

webTitle: When the going gets hot, BT calls its lawyers

fields.headline: When the going gets hot, BT calls its lawyers
fields.standfirst: Notebook Corporate tail wags telecom dog
fields.trailText: Notebook Corporate tail wags telecom dog.
fields.body:
It seems to be a reflex - repeatedly, when British Telecommunications is faced with innovation outside its high and mighty corporate walls, its instinctive reaction is to reach for its lawyers.

We watched its ludicrous attempt to persuade the courts to postpone the auction of third generation mobile phone licences earlier this year - trying to delay the nation's technological advancement because it felt its rival, Vodafone, was being given preferential treatment by the auctioneer.

Now it emerges that its legal represen tatives are out in force in New York trying to enforce its alleged patent over hyper-links, which allow users of the internet to switch between pages by clicking on text or pictures.

In the US, BT has demanded unspecified royalties from 18 internet services providers and one of these - Prodigy Communications - has found itself on the receiving end of a full-blown lawsuit. BT wants a test case and presumably, if it is successful, will then go around the world demanding money from every internet developer and service provider in sight.

BT's claimed patent over hyper-links dates from research work carried out in the 1970s on the long-forgotten Prestel information service.

Most of the patents granted at the time have expired, but the one covering hyper-linking went to appeal in the US and did not come through until 1986. It runs, apparently, to 2006.

Now, without getting into an argument about who invented the internet, it seems apposite to point out that this is the same company that on this side of the Atlantic is dragging its feet in allowing British consumers high speed access to the web.

Web-related businesses are folding across the country every day, and it seems fair to argue that BT is at least partially to blame. Slow net access is one big reason why consumers have proved slow to consume online.

The technology for instant page downloads, watchable video streaming and all the other things which make using the web a pleasant experience has been around for years.

But BT has had to be forced to make it available, and even now makes it as difficult and unaffordable as possible - all because it fears its fat margins from handling the bulk of the country's communications will shrink.

Maybe a few more people should start suing BT.

Water test

The message from Ofwat yesterday came over loud and clear. The big water and sewage groups should not regard the regulator's new director-general, Philip Fletcher, as a pushover.

During his first few months in the job he has been making sympathetic noises the industry has interpreted as a green light for its more ambitious schemes.

Now Anglian Water has walked away from its first real tussle with Mr Fletcher with a bloodied nose. He has rejected Anglian's request for an interim price review, in effect telling the company to pull the other one.

The regulatory system is not rigid. Mr Fletcher has agreed to change the price limits for two other companies faced with the same problem - an unexpectedly large number of customers switching from unmetered to metered water supplies.

Water companies lose out when customers switch over to a metered supply. They have to install the meters free of charge, and a customer's annual bill usually falls.

If the regulator's estimate of the number switching is too low then revenue and profits are hit.

Anglian Water has always seen domestic meters as the best way of making the best use of its limited water supplies. But in this case, it appears to have acted prematurely.

Severn Trent, the big Midlands water group, also believes that Ofwat has underestimated the likely rush to meters. But it has decided to wait until next year - when it will have concrete figures rather than projections - before taking the issue up with the regulator.

It hopes to recover the extra costs during next year.

Anglia obviously felt it could not wait so long. The sector has taken a battering since Sir Ian Byatt, the previous regulator, announced tough price controls for the 2000 to 2005 period.

Some of the water companies have complained that the particularly sharp price cuts this year have damaged their financial standing, making it harder for them to borrow the money to fund the huge environmental programme ordered by the government.

Anglian Water has said it may well take the metering issue to the competition commission for a final ruling. Such a move may make sense in commercial terms, but it would be a public relations disaster. The public perception is that there is too much water about at the moment. It is hardly the time, therefore, for a company to ask for a price increase so it can save the stuff.
