webTitle: Diary: Matthew Norman

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 In this of all weeks, with Mr Hague entrapped in a catastrophic row over Damilola Taylor, it could not be more important that senior colleagues do what they can to deflect charges of Tory racism. And so the heartiest of hats offs to shadow health spokesman Liam Fox. What a talent he is, this bumptious ex-GP, and what a charmer. After building a career on the back of dinner with an Australian pop star, Liam now seeks to portray himself as a man of gravitas and bottom. To this end, at a party at Westminster this week, Liam wandered around the room, perhaps having had one or two and being full of Christmas cheer. "Have you heard my new joke?" he puppyishly asked a group of people. "What do you call three dogs and a blackbird?" No one knew. "The Spice Girls," said Liam. Embarrassed shuffling ensued, but either misinterpreting this as collective deafness or perhaps out of exuberant delight at his own wit, Liam told it again. Why he would give voice to such nastery at all, let alone to a group containing journalists, is something we have been unable to ask him. One call to his office and two more to his pager elicit no response. Ah well, early days. Early days.

 I am thrilled to announce the arrival of a new colleague. With Richard Adams moving to the City pages to begin a diary there in the New Year, I am joined by Marina Hyde, formerly a columnist on the Sun. Embarrassingly, this is not something I can claim as an exclusive - the news appeared in last Thursday's Telegraph - and a key part of Marina's brief will be to ensure that we are no longer scooped by so-called rivals on stories about ourselves.

 In the Spectator, Sin Simon recalls his girth. "I used to be spectacularly fat," writes Sin (it is pronounced Sigh-On, as in the "By the rivers of Babylon/ where we sat down/ yea, yea we wept/ when we remember Sigh-on") Simon. "I tend not to do things by halves and, when I set out in my early twenties on a journey to the land that is Fat, it was a decade and the third moon the far side of Fat before I returned." In fact Sin was cited as repository for all the pies earlier than that. A Midlands reader calls to report that his school nickname was "Barrel Boy", confirming rumours that Gordon Grimley, the fat schoolboy in the 70s ITV Brummie sitcom The Grimleys, was modelled directly upon him.

 The Express continues to prosper under Richard Desmond. The purveyor of choice filth to the owners of unwashed raincoats promised to spend "whatever it takes" to rebuild the title, so no surprise at rumours that he has cancelled all the newspapers. (First rule of journalism: don't read the papers.) A further report concerns editor Rizla Rosie Boycott telling him that, to turn the paper round, she needs 400 journalists - some 30-40 more than at present. Eager to fulfill that investment pledge, Richard replied by asking her to cut the number back to 250.

 Despite rumours that her departure may be imminent, Rizla hangs on. Nothing to do with any pay off, this is purely to protect her staff from the brutal invaders from OK! Bless her, Rosie's always been too loyal for her own good. A few years ago, she approved a news story about O'Mandy Mandelson and his boyfriend Reinaldo. When O'Mandy went wild with rage and complained to Clive Hollick, it was Rosie who stayed in the job while waving a fond farewell to Amanda Platell and several others. Loyal to a fault.

 And not just loyal but gifted too. None of the old editing magic has gone since Richard arrived, as one member of staff discovered after rushing into her office with the Christmas card from Mr Tony and Cherie. "Isn't this brilliant?" he said, "We should put it in the paper at once ..." "Oh yeah, I hadn't thought of that," replied Rizla. "I got mine last week." diary@theguardian.com

webTitle: Obituary: Jinzaburo Takagi

fields.headline: Jinzaburo Takagi
fields.trailText: The Japanese scientist, Jinzaburo Takagi, who has died of cancer aged 62, was an internationally renowned critic of the nuclear industry.
fields.body:
The Japanese scientist, Jinzaburo Takagi, who has died of cancer aged 62, was an internationally renowned critic of the nuclear industry. A writer and educator, he was co-founder and a former dir- ector of the Citizens' Nuclear Information Centre (CNIC) in Tokyo.

In his final weeks, Takagi completed a paper, Learning From The Japanese Experience To Prepare For A Sustainable Future, for an international conference on energy policy in Taiwan. Days before his death, he learned with delight that the Taiwanese minister of economic affairs had abandoned plans to build a new nuclear plant and decided to phase out his country's nuclear power programme. It was through such campaigns that Takagi carried out his work as, in his words, a "citizen scientist".

Known as "Jin" to friends and colleagues, Takagi was born in Maebashi, in the Gunma prefecture of Japan. After graduating in 1961 from the University of Tokyo, he spent four years working in the nuclear industry, and another four at the nuclear institute of the University of Tokyo, winning the Asahi Science Encouragement Award in 1967. He gained his doctorate in 1969, and was guest scientist at the Max Planck Institute for Nuclear Physics in Germany in 1972-73.

In his next post, as associate professor of nuclear chemistry at Tokyo Metropolitan University (TMU), Takagi began campaigning on nuclear issues. In 1975, he left TMU to set up the non-profitmaking CNIC, with an important role in Japan, a country fearful of nuclear weapons but obsessed by the need for nuclear power. He reported on the results of the centre's analytical and educational work through its publications, including CNIC Monthly in Japanese and the bi-monthly Nuke-Info Tokyo in English.

Takagi conducted many technical research projects, and wrote extensively on nuclear issues, environmental protection and peace, with special emphasis on the fight against the nuclear threat, as well as in support of human rights. This year he published his analysis of Japan's worst nuclear accident, which killed two plant workers at a uranium-processing plant in Tokaimura in September last year. He was also successful as a writer of children's books, and in 1997 received the Sankei Children's Book Award.

I first met Jin at the first Asia-Pacific nuclear conference, in Hong Kong in 1988. We remained collaborators, and he was a key figure in organising later symposiums, such as the first international conference on plutonium, held at Omiya, Japan, in 1991.

Tagaki also initiated and organised an international research project on the use of mixed plutonium-uranium oxide (MOX) fuel in light water reactors - the IMA project (IMA means "now" in Japanese), for which he remarkably secured funding from the Toyota Foundation. The IMA report, A Compre hensive Social Impact Assessment Of MOX In Light Water Reactors, has become the benchmark document for a complex international technological debate.

Along with his close friend and colleague Mycle Schneider, of WISE-Paris (the World Information Service on Energy), Takagi served as the IMA project leader. For this research, and their persistent work on plutonium issues, Takagi and Schneider received the 1997 Right Livelihood Award, the alternative Nobel prize, in Stockholm.

Typically, he used the prize money to found the Takagi School for Alternative Scien- tists. He devoted much time in his final years to teaching the next generation, and left the school funds to support its continuing work.

He leaves his wife, Hari, and two sons from his first marriage.

 Jinzaburo Takagi, scientist, educator and writer, born August 26 1938; died October 8 2000

webTitle: Body Shop downgrades internet business

fields.headline: Body Shop downgrades internet business
fields.trailText: The new sense of reality about the business potential of the internet was underlined yesterday when Body Shop revealed it had scaled down its online ambitions.
fields.body:
The new sense of reality about the business potential of the internet was underlined yesterday when Body Shop revealed it had scaled down its online ambitions.

The green retailer has pulled out of a joint venture with Japanese internet investment group Softbank and taken its web operation in-house. It will be combined with Body Shop's retail and mail order operations. The venture, called Body Shop Digital, was scheduled for a US launch next spring but has now been postponed by six months.

Eight months ago, when the Softbank deal was announced, Body Shop's chief executive Patrick Gournay said the retailer had a good brand, but it needed Softbank's "expertise, resources and networking opportunities" to develop an "exciting presence". He added: "Softbank manages 150 e-commerce businesses worldwide and clearly knows the industry inside out."

Since then, however, several of the highest profile e-tailers, like Boo.com, Boxman.com and Body Shop rival Clickmango.com, have folded and yesterday Body Shop decided it no longer needed such an exciting presence.

A spokeswoman said: "Today's marketplace is not the one of six months ago. There was a rush of enthusiasm which was probably overcooked. We have re-evaluated and will now build on and upgrade our mail order business."

Body Shop halted the project when it required fresh investment. Softbank had put up the first $15m (£10m) of development capital in return for a 24% stake. Body Shop had 59% with the balance held in employee option plans.

The Body Shop spokeswoman said: "The initial investment would have run out early next year, and to retain our 59% we needed to invest pro rata. But we have other priorities in the business, like Body Shop Direct [the party sales business] and the stores. We have to balance where the best returns are. We can get quicker returns from opening new stores, so we would be mad to put more development capital into something with longer time horizons".

Body Shop is to pay $6m in cash or new shares to Softbank for the assets of Body Shop Digital, including development work so far. Of the 40 US-based staff brought into the company to work on BSD "only a handful" will be retained.

Body Shop operates from 1,783 stores worldwide, of which 458 are company owned. Once a stockmarket favourite, its fortunes have flagged in recent years, but two months ago it announced a strategy to target the US for expansion, online and instore. Mr Gournay said the 290 US stores could be expanded to 1,000 and that BSD would target America's 60m online shoppers. The company said yesterday that it would not offer a full internet operation to British shoppers until it had its US service up and running.

Since then, however, several of the highest profile e-tailers, like Boo.com, Boxman.com and Body Shop rival Clickmango.com, have folded and yesterday Body Shop decided it no longer needed such an exciting presence. A spokeswoman said: "Today's marketplace is not the one of six months ago. There was a rush of enthusiasm which was probably overcooked. We have re-evaluated and will now build on and upgrade our mail order business." Body Shop halted the project when it required fresh investment. Softbank had put up the first $15m (£10m) of development capital in return for a 24% stake. Body Shop had 59% with the balance held in employee option plans. The Body Shop spokeswoman said: "The initial investment would have run out early next year, and to retain our 59% we needed to invest pro rata. But we have other priorities in the business, like Body Shop Direct [the party sales business] and the stores. We have to balance where the best returns are. We can get quicker returns from opening new stores, so we would be mad to put more development capital into something with longer time horizons". Body Shop is to pay $6m in cash or new shares to Softbank for the assets of Body Shop Digital, including development work so far. Of the 40 US-based staff brought into the company to work on BSD "only a handful" will be retained. Body Shop operates from 1,783 stores worldwide, of which 458 are company owned. Once a stockmarket favourite, its fortunes have flagged in recent years, but two months ago it announced a strategy to target the US for expansion, online and instore. Mr Gournay said the 290 US stores could be expanded to 1,000 and that BSD would target America's 60m online shoppers. The company said yesterday that it would not offer a full internet operation to British shoppers until it had its US service up and running.

webTitle: Diageo buys Seagram portfolio

fields.headline: Diageo buys Seagram portfolio
fields.trailText: Diageo sharply increased its lead as the world's biggest drinks company last night by clinching Seagram's spirits and wine portfolio in a $8.15bn (£5.5bn) joint bid with France's Pernod Ricard.
fields.body:
Diageo sharply increased its lead as the world's biggest drinks company last night by clinching Seagram's spirits and wine portfolio in a $8.15bn (£5.5bn) joint bid with France's Pernod Ricard.

The long-awaited transaction was a relief for Diageo's chief executive, Paul Walsh, who took the top job only in September. He staked his credibility on buying the Canada-based business, which made its name supplying US bootleggers with liquor during the Prohibition.

An agreement was signed at the New York offices of Morgan Stanley after an auction lasting nearly six months.

The Anglo-French consortium fought off interest from Allied Domecq, the Bronfman family which founded Seagram and from a tie-up between US firm Brown-Foreman and Bermuda-based Bacardi.

Diageo, which is footing $5bn of the bill, will get the lion's share of Seagram's portfolio. It intends to take Captain Morgan rum, Crown Royal and VO Canadian whiskies, and wine producer Sterling Vineyards.

Pernod Ricard, which is paying $3.15bn, will leapfrog Allied Domecq to take the number two spot in the spirits industry. It acquires Martell cognac and Scotch whiskies such as Chivas Regal, the Glenlivet and Glen Grant.

However, the deal is contingent on approval from regulators, some of which have expressed concern about Diageo's leadership of the drinks industry. The company sold 99m cases of spirits a year before yesterday's deal, more than twice as many as anyone else.

Another doubt surrounds Captain Morgan, which Allied Domecq claims to have bought in a separate transaction with the brand's Puerto Rican founder. This will be thrashed out in the courts and might not be settled until Easter.

Seagram was founded on the Canadian prairies in the 1920s. The firm created Crown Royal, one of its most famous whiskies, to commemorate a tour of Canada by George VI in 1939.

Seagram moved into entertainment by purchasing PolyGram for $10bn two years ago. The firm merged with France's Vivendi this year to put it firmly in the media world, and its new management has decided to withdraw from drinks.

Yesterday's deal could mean up to 3,000 job losses, according to industry sources.

Seagram's leading brands include:

Captain Morgan rum (subject to a legal challenge), Chivas Regal scotch, Crown Royal Canadian whiskey,

The Glenlivet single malt scotch whisky, Martell cognac, Godiva liqueurs, Don Julio tequila, Grolsch lager (in North America) and Oddbins off-licences

webTitle: US banks feel the cold winds

fields.headline: US banks feel the cold winds
fields.trailText: Two leading Wall Street investment banks provided evidence that the US economic slowdown was beginning to bite yesterday when they announced quarterly results sharply lower than a year ago.
fields.body:
Two leading Wall Street investment banks provided evidence that the US economic slowdown was beginning to bite yesterday when they announced quarterly results sharply lower than a year ago.

Morgan Stanley Dean Witter created the greatest disappointment when it reported fourth-quarter profits down 26% compared with last year's record results. The bank blamed weak bond markets, investment losses and "unusual compensation pressure in institutional securities".

Goldman Sachs reported a much smaller decline in the difficult last three months of the year. David Viniar, chief financial officer, said the bank had suffered "no unusual losses" during the the period. Goldman's fourth-quarter results managed to beat analysts' reduced expectations despite falling below last year's level.

Mr Viniar said he was "cautiously optimistic in 2001 and very optimistic looking out to the future".

Goldman earned a record net $3.25bn (£2.2bn), excluding an exceptional $180m charge relating to its October acquisition of market-maker Spear Leeds in the year. Morgan Stanley also reported a record $5.5bn net income, 14% higher than last year.

The recent downturn marks a sharp contrast with the first three months of the year when stock markets were soaring. Both Goldman and Morgan Stanley benefited from high levels of stock market and merger activity in this period and reported record earnings for the year as a whole.

webTitle: Anglian Water row looms

fields.headline: Anglian Water row looms
fields.standfirst: Utility firm may appeal price review rejection
fields.trailText: Anglian Water yesterday threatened to appeal to the competition commission following the industry regulator's rejection of its request for an interim price review.
fields.body:
Anglian Water yesterday threatened to appeal to the competition commission following the industry regulator's rejection of its request for an interim price review.

The company had claimed it was suffering financially because Ofwat, in setting price controls for the next five years, had underestimated the number of customers who would switch from unmetered to metered supply.

But Philip Fletcher, the new director-general of Ofwat, rejected Anglian's request for additional funds to cover the extra cost of customers switching to meters. He said the changes claimed by Anglian were not sufficient to trigger resetting price limits this year.

However, he eased the price controls on Welsh Water and Tendring Hundred, a small water only company, which had complained about the same problem.

Water companies suffer a double whammy when do mestic customers switch to metered supplies. The government has insisted the companies carry the cost of installing a meter, and they lose revenue because metered households tend to have lower bills.

An Anglian spokesman said the company was disappointed by Mr Fletcher's decision. The previous regulator, Sir Ian Byatt, had reduced the company's original estimate of customers likely to switch to meters. It was now installing three times the number predicted by Ofwat.

"Our regulatory team will be putting their view to the board on January 18," he said. "Obviously we are considering whether to appeal to the competition commission."

He said Anglian probably had more experience of metering than any other British water company. "About 50% of our domestic customers are on meters."

Historically the Anglian region has been the driest part of the country, and the company has encouraged its customers to use meters to help conserve its resources.

Since the Competition Act earlier this year, the company can appeal to the competition commission on a single issue. Previously water companies could only appeal against regulatory decisions by requesting a full scale, wide ranging investigation by the monopolies and mergers commission.

webTitle: Unions fear for £344m ship order

fields.headline: Unions fear for £344m ship order
fields.trailText: Union leaders yesterday claimed that Cammell Laird was in danger of losing a £344m order to build two cruise ships because the government was unwilling to provide the maximum permitted aid.
fields.body:
Union leaders yesterday claimed that Cammell Laird was in danger of losing a £344m order to build two cruise ships because the government was unwilling to provide the maximum permitted aid.

Luxus, a new US-based cruise ship company, had agreed to place the order with Cammell Laird provided the Department of Trade and Industry supported the deal with shipbuilding intervention funding and loan guarantees.

The DTI yesterday said that the company had been offered grants of up to £32m, the amount requested by the company. It said a decision on whether to provide Luxus with ship mortgage finance guarantees would be taken within the next 48 hours.

Industry sources said that it would be perverse of the DTI to provide the grants without the loan guarantees.

But a spokesman for the GMB engineering union said that Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, had been advised by officials to offer guarantees for only 50% of the loans, rather than the 80% he is allowed to.

The GMB said that failure to offer the full loan guarantees could lead to Luxus placing the order with another yard, possibly in France, thereby endangering the jobs of thousands of Cammell Laird workers.

Cammell Laird is planning to build the two cruise ships - the first to be built in Britain for 27 years - at its Merseyside, Tyneside, and Teesside yards. Extra fitting-out work would be carried out by Camper and Nicholson, the Gosport yard it acquired seven months ago.

Brett Martin, the deputy chief executive of Cammell Laird, said the DTI had provided the company with all it had asked for.

He said the cruise ship order would be a backbone project, allowing the company to expand its training programmes and continue its ship repair and conversion work.

webTitle: CBI hits out over minimum wage

fields.headline: CBI hits out over minimum wage
fields.trailText: Business leaders took a sideswipe at trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers yesterday for appearing to pre-empt the low pay commission's recommendation on uprating the minimum wage.
fields.body:
Business leaders took a sideswipe at trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers yesterday for appearing to pre-empt the low pay commission's recommendation on uprating the minimum wage.

Annoyed by reports that Mr Byers has already decided to raise the minimum wage in line with average earnings to £4 from £3.70 to woo voters in the run up to the general election, the Confederation of British Industry said the appropriate level should be determined by the commission after weighing up the impact on the economy.

"We believe there is a case for an increase but the increase has to be one that the economy can bear," said John Cridland, the CBI's deputy director general and a business representative on the commission. "We believe that everybody should leave it to the commission."

The commission, led by the academic George Bain, is due to deliver its report to the government by July 2001.

In its evidence to the commission, published today, the CBI says its members could probably live with an increase to £4 but not without pain. A figure in excess of £4 could be damaging. "That is not to say that the commission's considered judgment should be as high as this figure," said Mr Cridland. "There are a whole range of other factors to take into account such as inflation, interest rates and regional issues."

webTitle: EC fury over US Airbus threat

fields.headline: EC fury over US Airbus threat
fields.trailText: Europe and the US are on the brink of a new trade war after Airbus Industrie gave the formal go-ahead to a 555-seat aircraft that will rival American plane maker Boeing's previously unchallenged jumbo jet.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn  in Brussels and Mark Milner  in Paris
fields.body:
Europe and the US are on the brink of a new trade war after Airbus Industrie gave the formal go-ahead to a 555-seat aircraft that will rival American plane maker Boeing's previously unchallenged jumbo jet.

Brussels reacted angrily to US concerns about the level of state aid towards the $10.7bn (£7.3bn) cost of developing the new aircraft, which will be the world's largest airliner and is expected to create up to 20,000 new jobs in the UK and safeguard another 62,000.

Britain is providing £530m towards the cost of launching the renamed A380, and yesterday's decision provided a boost for the government after a series of announcements of job losses in manufacturing.

Wings for the A380 will be built by BAE Systems, a 20% shareholder in Airbus Industrie, at factories in Bristol and at Broughton, north Wales.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said: "This is excellent news and a major landmark in the A380 project."

BAE Systems' chief operating officer, Mike Turner, said: "Today marks the real beginning of the most important civil aircraft project the world has seen in several decades."

But the launch decision - triggered by Airbus reaching its self-imposed target of 50 firm orders - was overshadowed by the latest transatlantic trade spat.

On Monday evening Bill Clin ton had said that the A380 had to be financed on commercial terms, "if we are to head off a serious problem affecting the US-EU relationship". But yesterday the EC insisted the launch investment was in line with international agreements and warned it would retaliate if the US took action.

"If the US was to choose the path of launching legal action in the World Trade Organisation, the commission would not hesitate to propose mirroring that action and questioning so-called indirect subsidies to Boeing," spokesman Gunnar Wiegand said.

The row reflects the continuing rivalry between Airbus and Boeing and the tension between Brussels and Washington over a series of trade issues on bananas, beef, genetically modified foods and exports subsidies.

"Boeing is trying to disrupt the launch by Airbus of the A380 in order to protect the lucrative monopoly it has with the 747," Mr Wiegand claimed.

Officials stressed, however, that Brussels will try to ensure the dispute does not escalate out of hand when the two sides meet for consultations over the issue next month.

webTitle: Business: This is the season for bad news

fields.headline: This is the season for bad news
fields.standfirst: A gruesome year for Wall Street ends with some famous names warning that it is going to get worse
fields.trailText: A gruesome year for Wall Street ends with some famous names warning that it is going to get worse.
fields.body:
What do Microsoft, JP Morgan, Whirlpool and Time Warner have in common? These American household-name companies have all issued profit warnings during the past week.

The flood of bad news from corporate America in the run-up to Christmas has encompassed almost all sectors of the economy, from loss-making dot.coms to some of the most profitable businesses in the world. The series of disappointments has hit confidence in the US stock markets which were already threatening to log their worst performances in years.

Since the beginning of December more than 133 companies in the S&P 500 index of America's largest corporations have issued profit warnings, according to research by Jefferies and Co, the US brokerage. The total of earnings pre-announcements in the last quarter of the year - more than 759 - is 40 % higher than during the same period last year.

Pre-announcements can be positive but are usually negative. As investors face the grim year-end tallies of their portfolios, Art Hogan, the chief market strategist at Jefferies, says: "This is the season for bad news."

Profits warnings came so fast and furious last week that a market which traditionally cheers the election of a Republican government plunged the day after Al Gore conceded. Two stunning announcements provided bookends to George W's first official day as president-elect: a warning from Wall Street merger partners JP Morgan and Chase Manhattan started the day, and one from Microsoft - the software group's first in more than 10 years - ended it. Then, as traders were preparing for the weekend, eToys.com, the online toy company which was one of the earliest stars of the dot.com galaxy, announced on Friday night that it was going to run out of cash sooner than expected because of disappointing sales.

This week brought further bad news: a warning from media group Time Warner. Traders were left hoping that the Federal Reserve Board would provide some support yesterday for a year-end rally by indicating that interest rates would go down rather than up. It remains to be seen whether the decision provided enough encouragement.

Although some of the warnings relate to specific company issues, there are common themes. The underlying motif for most has been that American consumers and corporations have stopped spending as much as they did during the glory days of the 1990s.

One of the reasons the Fed indicated it was softening its anti-inflationary stance was the welter of evidence that the fast-paced US economy has hit a roadblock.

However, yesterday President Clinton gave his vote of support in the economy. He said he did not think the president-elect would face a US economy inching toward recession, but a slower growth period of about 2.5%, half the rate of recent years. "He'll have economic challenges, and you ought to give him a chance to meet with me and not try to figure it all out in advance," Mr Clinton said.

The rash of profit warnings has pointed to a slowdown in consumer spending. Worst hit has been one of President Clinton's most impressive legacies: the new economy. Apple Computer, Compaq, Intel, Dell and Gateway and Microsoft have urged analysts to lower their expectations.

All of these companies provided evidence that, faced with relatively high interest rates, high oil prices and a plummeting stock market, American consumers no longer wants to buy a personal computer for every member of their families or to upgrade their old ones.

Microsoft's warning was particularly disappointing because it pointed to a downturn in the market for corporate spending as well.

Only 10% of the company's earnings come from consumers, the rest from large corporations. Along with signs from media companies such as Time Warner that big companies were clamping down on their advertising expenditure, the announcement provided evidence that other forms of corporate spending were decelerating.

Some analysts have remained optimistic about next year in spite of all the bad news. Gerald Cohen, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, expects the technology sector to increase earnings on average by 15% next year. In 2000, earnings from hi-tech companies leaped an impressive 32%. Even the S&P 500 members are expected to increase earnings by 8% on average, hardly recessionary levels.

Mr Cohen blames the sense of chaos on the sharp slowing of growth in the last half of this year. After setting a buoyant pace of more than 4% for four years, gross domestic product growth has suddenly decelerated to 3%, he says, making comparisons particularly brutal.

At the same time, stock market declines prompted by rising interest rates and the bursting of the internet bubble have dented consumer confidence in spite of low unemployment and continuing growth.

Some analysts also blame the changed securities rules in the US for some of the increase in profits warning.

Under Regulation Fair Disclosure, companies must make all market-sensitive information available to investors at the same time. The rule, designed to stop Wall Street insiders gaining an unfair advantage, means companies have become more sensitive about releasing information privately.

Even the optimists on Wall Street expect the spate of disappointing news to continue for a while.

Chuck Hill at First Call-Thompson Financial points out that most companies wait until after the year has ended to give a definite update on their trading during the last month of the year. If so, we could be in for a very bleak January.

Gerald Cohen, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, expects the technology sector to increase earnings on average by 15% next year. In 2000, earnings from hi-tech companies leaped an impressive 32%. Even the S&P 500 members are expected to increase earnings by 8% on average, hardly recessionary levels. Mr Cohen blames the sense of chaos on the sharp slowing of growth in the last half of this year. After setting a buoyant pace of more than 4% for four years, gross domestic product growth has suddenly decelerated to 3%, he says, making comparisons particularly brutal. At the same time, stock market declines prompted by rising interest rates and the bursting of the internet bubble have dented consumer confidence in spite of low unemployment and continuing growth. Some analysts also blame the changed securities rules in the US for some of the increase in profits warning. Under Regulation Fair Disclosure, companies must make all market-sensitive information available to investors at the same time. The rule, designed to stop Wall Street insiders gaining an unfair advantage, means companies have become more sensitive about releasing information privately. Even the optimists on Wall Street expect the spate of disappointing news to continue for a while. Chuck Hill at First Call-Thompson Financial points out that most companies wait until after the year has ended to give a definite update on their trading during the last month of the year. If so, we could be in for a very bleak January.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: OFT sets Abbey decision date
fields.body:
OFT sets Abbey decision date

Abbey National and Bank of Scotland could get an answer from regulators on their proposed merger by mid-January, the office of fair trading said yesterday.

Abbey and BoS presented their merger plans to the OFT last week, a move seen as challenging Lloyds TSB to come out into the open with an offer for Abbey.

The OFT will give its views to trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers, who is to decide by January 18, unless he asks for more time.

NTL beats its digital target

NTL said yesterday it had met its year-end target 12 days early by installing 500,000 digital cable television boxes in British homes. Chief executive Barclay Knapp added that the ntlworld free internet access package had signed its 500,000th subscriber, taking its customer base past the 1m mark.

An NTL spokesman admitted that digital roll-out in the London area remained slow and speeding it up would be a priority in the new year.

Cheques out at Co-op Bank

The Co-operative Bank yesterday moved closer to being a paper-less bank by replacing cheque encashments at counters with plastic cards.

Customers will be able to withdraw and deposit cash at the counter using their debit card free, with no need to fill in any forms.

Patrick Walsh, head of the Co-op's retail network, said fewer customers were using cheques in shops and other outlets because debit cards were quicker and easier. "As a bank with a strong ethical stance we are always looking to reduce the amount of paper we use."

Ethical trust to be scrapped

The £39m Friends Provident Ethical Investment Trust said yesterday it would wind itself up, subject to a vote by shareholders in the new year.

The board said it was disappointed by the performance of the trust, which traded at a 15% average discount to the value of its underlying assets in the six-months to the end of November. The trust was due to wind up at the end of next year.

Microsoft goes back to basics

Microsoft chief executive officer Steve Ballmer has asked company managers to "significantly reduce" some spending this financial year throughout its businesses, the Wall Street Journal website reported.

According to a company memo obtained by the site, Mr Ballmer said: "We all have a big incentive as shareholders to reignite the kind of cost-conscious culture that marked Microsoft's earlier years."

Mr Ballmer was said to have listed seven priorities, including pushing on with new internet initiatives and computing devices, as well as expanding older products such as Windows and Office, which still supply the bulk of the revenue.

webTitle: What dads in the park are watching on TV

fields.headline: Random Views
fields.standfirst: What dads in the park are watching on TV
fields.trailText: What dads in the park are watching on TV
fields.body:
James Banton:
"I must say I hate that advert that's got the free phones and Harry Hill. And he has that fox, it gets to me so much! I really hate Harry Hill, I think he's really creepy. Pointy collars, big shoes. Urgh. He's awful. Not funny at all. I don't like comedy generally- I watched those comedy awards and I thought it was all wrong, full of drunk comedians and the like. I like the Royle Family, though, but it's becoming quite tired, isn't it? The kids watch the Tweenies and they like Top Of The Pops and their Pocahontas video. I would like to 'lose' that video, I've seen it about 30 times. It's no surprise anymore."

Keith Barnes:
"What I like is Newsnight and Have I Got News For You, I think it's very funny. It's not a clever idea in itself, but the ideas are so good and it's so intelligently written. I like Graham Norton too, I think he's wonderful, a very smart man. I used not to watch television at all, but the kids love it so much. My partner and I watch TV together, but she likes the soaps and I couldn't care less about some characters I've never met doing things I'm not interested in."

Terry Packingham:
"I don't see a lot of TV, really. I like the Fawlty Towers re-runs and I even found myself watching Dad's Army a few months ago and I actually laughed! Don Estelle and Windsor Davies are a very good pair. I watched that programme, David Attenborough on the Armageddon angle, can't remember the real title, and I thought a lot was scaremongering, to be honest. It can't be all doom and gloom, can it? It's too much for people to watch. What do my children like? Oh, rubbish. They watch anything, and they get completely brainwashed. They want mobile phones and chocolates, and they don't like it when I say a mobile phone is too silly for a four year old. And chocolate will ruin their teeth."

 Sin Pattenden spoke to dads on Hampstead Heath, London.

webTitle: Last night's TV

fields.headline: Eurotrash and burn
fields.trailText: Look At Lolo | Five Steps To Tyranny | Brookside
fields.body:
Her name was Lolo. She was a showgirl (of sorts). But instead of being remembered for the yellow feathers in her hair and a dress cut down to there (quite short, I imagine), Lolo Ferrari is synonymous with giant cartoon breasts, a permanent wet pout of a mouth and, of course, death at 37. What a difference an "o" makes. An inflatable doll constructed by Dr Phibes, Lolo Ferrari was part wet dream, part nightmare.

Look At Lolo (Channel 4) was a revealing insight into the life and death of a woman whose insecurities drove her to reconstruct herself as a grotesque parody of the ideal female form. Under the watchful - not to mention creepy - eye of her exploitative husband, Lolo grew into what was essentially a freak show with a 54J bust. Her plastic surgeon claimed, barefaced, that her breasts were her happiness, but it was clear that Lolo enjoyed less than a thimbleful of joy in her life. Always on the look out for new opportunities - what else could she be but famous? - Lolo stumbled from porn star to pop star and failed at both. From Eurotrash to plain trash (and there are those who wouldn't see the difference between the two), Lolo's tale was a depressing one of self-loathing, abuse and the malice of men directed at wounded women. That's something to consider, if you are politically inclined, when judging Eurotrash's mélange of comedy Europeans as harmless nonsense. Life at the Copacabana (the hottest spot north of Havana) never seemed so good.

Now, there are three steps to heaven (whoa whoa whoa). This, we all know, or at least those of us familiar with the back catalogue of Eddie Cochran. What was less well known - until Sheena McDonald informed us - is that there are Five Steps To Tyranny (BBC2). These afford fewer sing-along opportunities. As this excellent, original and imaginative documentary made terribly clear, we could all be tyrants at heart and that isn't something you want to Chim Chim Cher-ee from the rooftops.

Employing simple yet frighteningly telling techniques to establish just how tribal, how narrow-minded and prejudiced we can be, Five Steps To Tyranny was both illuminating and unsurprising. Over and over, man's - and woman's - inhumanity to our fellow homo sapiens was underlined, from discussion of the genocide in Rwanda to football fans leaving rivals to writhe in pain on the pavement. Whilst at the time, in 1994, the first prompted comments of "It couldn't happen here", the fact that the two instances were placed side by side, effectively illustrated that it could indeed happen here. Many people like to feel superior to "savage" Africans (the first step to tyranny, incidentally, is feeling you are better than other people), but in actual fact, there is only a veneer hiding the savagery in our hearts.

Savagery is there, hiding in our bloodstream like a virus, waiting for an opportunity such as a devastating natural disaster - floods, say - or a charismatic leader to harness it, to multiply and go forth. Essential viewing, Five Steps To Tyranny was profoundly saddening but compulsive for it.

And speaking of atavistic behaviour, caution - and undergarments - were thrown to the wind in a Brookside (Channel 4) special as the Manor Park massive hit Liverpool town centre like a tsunami of hormones, Bacardi Breezers and cheap gold chains. Christmas time, mistletoe and wine, children nicking stuff from shops, adultery, betrayal and vomit: this is what the festive season is all about. As Jerome dallied behind Nikki's back - all resplendent with cascades of blonde, stringy hair - Tim figured "in for a penny" and tried a bit of drunk driving, seeking to add to the list of crimes which is already as long as your arm, if you have long arms. (And if you have long arms, you'll be hoping for knuckle protectors for Christmas so they don't bleed when you drag them on the ground waiting in the queue for the Next sale.) As Westlife asked only on Saturday: what becomes of the broken hearted? Obviously, they develop a devil-may-care attitude to their life and the lives of others.

This is perhaps a step to tyranny - or self-mutilation in Lolo Ferrari's case - that Sheena might like to add to her list. And she might well add "suffering 90 minutes of Brookside in one go" to Ten Things To Make You Go To Your Nearest Shopping Centre And Go Mad With An Axe.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Muppet Christmas Carol | Rocky II | Thelma and Louise | The Opposite Of Sex
fields.body:
The Muppet Christmas Carol
(Brian Henson, 1992)
7pm, Disney Channel

Apart from taking minor liberties with the original text - such as Kermit the Frog and Miss Piggy as Bob Cratchit and wife, the Great Gonzo as narrator Charles Dickens - this is a pretty straightforward reading of the Christmas tale - look on it as an early dose of festive spirit. Wackiest of all is Michael Caine as the old skinflint himself: "My name, is Ebenezer Scrooge..." The ghostly visitations are pretty scary, but this is great fun, from the golden age of Muppetry.

Rocky II
(Sylvester Stallone, 1979)
9pm, Carlton Cinema

The return bout between Stallone's Rocky Balboa, the people's champion, and world heavyweight boxing champ Apollo Creed (Carl Weathers). This time the Italian Stallion risks his eyesight, and reproachful wife Talia Shire lies in a post-natal coma - to give our emotions a pounding before the crunching climax.

Thelma and Louise
(Ridley Scott, 1991)
10pm FilmFour

The road movie that found a new gear, putting two women in the driving seat. Susan Sarandon and neglected wife Geena Davis head off on a weekend jaunt that quickly swerves out of control when they kill a rapist: the tone remains upbeat, often funny, but from here on they're on a road to nowhere. Harvey Keitel is the sympathetic cop, Brad Pitt a lover-man.

The Opposite Of Sex
(Don Roos, 1998)
11.45pm, Sky Premier

Christina Ricci's breasts point to something special in the opening scene. She adjusts them as though calibrating some secret weapon, then heads off to do battle with the world; but the early intimations of a truly subversive and original comedy are soon replaced by more conventional laughs. Still, it is fun, as Ricci insinuates her way into the home of half-brother Martin Donovan and proceeds to wreck his life; and Lisa Kudrow is a treat as Donovan's repressed, sharp-tongued friend.

webTitle: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Steve Lamacq - The Evening Session (8.0pm, Radio 1) | Connect
fields.body:
Steve Lamacq - The Evening Session (8.0pm, Radio 1) sees Steve having a chat with Radiohead in their local pub, where they later perform a set. Their 1997 angst-ridden album, OK Computer, was voted the greatest in the history of music in a recent music industry poll. Their last album was a bizarre collection of electronic tunes with scraping guitars and incomprehensible lyrics. That didn't stop it going straight to the top of the US album charts.

There is a growing crisis in cities such as Jakarta and Rio de Janeiro as they attract more and more of their country's rural poor. The authorities are finding it virtually impossible to provide adequate supplies of clean water for them. In Connect (9.0pm, Radio 4) Quentin Cooper talks to various technologists about some solutions they may be able to offer. Their answers range from the use of solar energy in purification plants to cloud-seeding. But such projects are usually depressingly expensive.

webTitle: A Country Diary

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Tamar Valley
fields.trailText: Tamar Valley
fields.body:
The smell of evergreens and wood-smoke pervades Cotehele's Great Hall, decorated with the Christmas garland of interwoven greenery and dried flowers, a log fire blazing on the wide hearth. Outside, in the mossy court, iris unguicularis bloom by lichened stonework below the granite-mullioned windows. Rare sunlight gleams on wet cobbles, reflecting a patch of brightness up into the vaulted archway hung with mistletoe. Nearby, Mrs Julyan's garden, sheltered inside yew hedges, has been laid out with pittisporum and eucalyptus bushes, cultivated beds edged with purple-flowering hebe. Cotoneaster berries are scattered on the mulched earth and there are rows of spiky Dutch iris leaves, luxuriant ferny foliage of anemones and tall paper whites, the perfumed florets sprawling and mud-splattered. Ice Folly narcissi and the Dan du Plessis hybrids are dormant under leaf mould.

This recent planting is the beginning of the National Trust's daffodil project, which will celebrate and reflect the special horticultural history of the Tamar Valley. With the help of funding from the National Gardens Scheme, there are plans to establish a permanent collection of the old-fashioned daffodils once common in the market gardens of the Edgcumbe estate. Surviving bulbs grow mainly in hedgerows and on neglected steep ground reverting to woodland. A few of the more prominent, original plots will be cleared of brambles, encouraging shaded-out bulbs to flower in situ. In these former commercial gardens clumps of tightly packed daffodil shoots are already emerging.

webTitle: Arts: The Human League play at an office Christmas party

fields.headline: Human remains
fields.standfirst: What are the Human League doing playing a bank's Christmas do?  Dave Simpson  reports
fields.trailText: What are the Human League doing playing a bank's Christmas do? Dave Simpson reports
fields.body:
The scene is the "premier" Leeds nightclub, Majestyks, normally host to Emmerdale actors, Leeds footballers and reams of blokes in orange shirts. The artistes are the Human League, hit-making giants of the 80s and early 90s, and universally recognised as one of the seminal synthesiser outfits of all time.

And the occasion? Well, you won't believe this. Philip Oakey, Susan Sulley and Joanne Catherall are playing my girlfriend's office party. Quite how the act that provided David Bowie with a vision of the future and spawned the pop colossus Dare have ended up at a commercial bank's "do" is beyond me. The event is a private affair. The fans aren't supposed to know about this, never mind the Guardian. We have sidled in courtesy of the "and guest" bit on the ticket.

This seems a considerably scaled-down example of the modern phenomenon whereby the likes of Sting and Elton get millions for playing exclusive gigs for sheikhs. Three microphone stands survey proceedings teasingly from the stage. There are, worryingly, no synthesisers. Thankfully, the DJ - an old skool, Bananarama-playing type - reassures us: "In 10 minutes! The Human League! Rocking back the 80s!" Gulp.

The League finally appear, in funereal black coats and dark glasses. Surely Sheffield's finest aren't embarrassed to be here? Suddenly, as Sound of the Crowd ends, off come the coats and shades, on go three bemused, ironic grins, and the audience erupts.

For eight songs (sung to backing tapes, but really only the audience makes it that different from Madonna at Brixton), men shake Philip Oakey's hand while women fall at his feet - although that might just be the combination of lager and high heels.

Oakey's hair has long since left him after the physical abuse it endured in the early 80s, but with the famous League Girls still drop-dead glitzy the trio look better than anyone who's ever shared a bill with Culture Club has a right to.

The band stick to their classic hits, but while the tunes are well-worn, the incongruity of the setting brings new vigour. Wonderfully, several people point at Phil and sing the "This is Phil talking..." rap with him in Love Action. When Oakey shouts "We're the Human League, from 30 miles away," you can almost imagine the business meeting that began "How much?! Only up the road?!"

It says everything about the League's dignity that they refrain from changing the lyrics to Don't You Want Me to "She was working as a bank tell-ah..." What should have been a sad affair feels like an event, like Vera Duckworth popping into the local boozer. There is something distasteful about legends reducing themselves like this for money, but also something rather fabulous about the unique access these affairs give to normal people. My girlfriend's already compiling a wish list of next year's turns: Kraftwerk, late 70s punk obscurities the Lurkers and the Rolling Stones.

Three microphone stands survey proceedings teasingly from the stage. There are, worryingly, no synthesisers. Thankfully, the DJ - an old skool, Bananarama-playing type - reassures us: "In 10 minutes! The Human League! Rocking back the 80s!" Gulp. The League finally appear, in funereal black coats and dark glasses. Surely Sheffield's finest aren't embarrassed to be here? Suddenly, as Sound of the Crowd ends, off come the coats and shades, on go three bemused, ironic grins, and the audience erupts. For eight songs (sung to backing tapes, but really only the audience makes it that different from Madonna at Brixton), men shake Philip Oakey's hand while women fall at his feet - although that might just be the combination of lager and high heels. Oakey's hair has long since left him after the physical abuse it endured in the early 80s, but with the famous League Girls still drop-dead glitzy the trio look better than anyone who's ever shared a bill with Culture Club has a right to. The band stick to their classic hits, but while the tunes are well-worn, the incongruity of the setting brings new vigour. Wonderfully, several people point at Phil and sing the "This is Phil talking..." rap with him in Love Action. When Oakey shouts "We're the Human League, from 30 miles away," you can almost imagine the business meeting that began "How much?! Only up the road?!" It says everything about the League's dignity that they refrain from changing the lyrics to Don't You Want Me to "She was working as a bank tell-ah..." What should have been a sad affair feels like an event, like Vera Duckworth popping into the local boozer. There is something distasteful about legends reducing themselves like this for money, but also something rather fabulous about the unique access these affairs give to normal people. My girlfriend's already compiling a wish list of next year's turns: Kraftwerk, late 70s punk obscurities the Lurkers and the Rolling Stones.

webTitle: Arts

fields.headline: On the trail of Turner
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Jones  visits the landscapes painted by Britain's greatest watercolourist
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones visits the landscapes painted by Britain's greatest watercolourist
fields.body:
In the car park of Duke's Wharf, Nottingham, under the sign announcing "24 Luxury Canal Side Apartments", you get a good view of the castle looming up in the winter mist, a neoclassical palace perched on a mass of sandstone. This appears to be the identical vista to JMW Turner's watercolour Nottingham, Nottinghamshire. Trouble is, you can't see the canal, which also features in Turner's image - part of his great series of Picturesque Views in England and Wales, for luxury apartments. A figure comes out of the dark, wearing a suit and tie in the icy evening. Would I like to see the show flat? And so a search for Turner's Britain leads to an introduction to riverside living in the 21st century.

Hi-tech industries have transformed the economy of Nottingham, explains Daniel, the estate agent, and there's a demand for this kind of inner-city home. Prices start at £100,000. There's a giant TV in the show flat, white furniture, and the view is just what I was looking for. From the front window you can see the castle like a dream image floating above the city, making you think not just of Turner but of Claude Lorrain, the 17th-century French master he set out to rival, whose paintings are full of fairytale castles. From the back window, you can see the canal, deserted, cleaned up.

This is the scene of Turner's golden, shimmering watercolour Nottingham, in which the water reflects the busy life of the city. Tonight it reflects the new national headquarters of the Inland Revenue on the far shore - another reason the city needs executive housing, explains Daniel. "And there's our Millennium Dome," he says, referring to a white, tent-like structure that houses leisure facilities for the civil servants to use after a hard day processing tax returns.

In Turner's Nottingham, people crowd on to boats about to pass through a newly opened lock. It's a political allegory. One of the boats even flies the Greek flag, expressing solidarity with the Byronic cause of Greek independence. These people are celebrating their own political triumph: Turner's watercolour was painted soon after the passing of the 1832 Reform Act, which radically enlarged the number of people who could vote. The grey smoke of stubble burning on Castle Rock alludes to the fact that, in 1831, after an earlier attempt to pass the act failed, the crowd at Nottingham's Goose Fair rioted and set fire to the castle owned by the anti-reform Duke of Newcastle.

Down the road, the Via Fossa bar exploits its medievalesque setting but with contemporary verve - none of your Olde Englande kitsch, but lots of wrought iron, reddish lighting, deep comfy seats. Would Turner have enjoyed a drink here? Acquaintances claimed he was extremely stingy, and would make excuses if they suggested he buy a bottle of wine.

It's the kind of titbit that has been passed down the years in place of biographical insight. Britain's greatest artist is also the most difficult to know. Biographers bounce off him. It's only when you get to page 300 of a recent tome that you realise you haven't learnt much beyond the basics: Joseph Mallord William Turner (1775-1851), son of a Covent Garden barber, began to draw and paint at an early age, worked as an architects' draughtsman and topographer, was admitted to the Royal Academy schools, was recognised early on as a landscape artist of genius, became a prominent Academician, yet died lonely but rich - regarded by Victorians as half-mad, his inarticulacy and lack of social graces having exiled him from polite society. Turner's extreme inability to express himself in words continues to make the man, as opposed to his universally enjoyable art, remote.

What we do know about JMW Turner is that he travelled. A lot. Apart from painting, it was the passion of his life. He spent several months every year touring Britain or the continent, his watercolours in his luggage, drawing everything he saw that came up to his standards of natural and human spectacle. Turner's art is, among other things, a testament to new possibilities for tourism in the 19th century, from the Alpine roads built by Napoleon to the steamer that took him to Fingal's Cave in the Hebrides.

Turner painted all over Europe; he also painted tropical and desert scenes he never saw. Yet at the core of his fame as the quintessential British artist are his British landscapes. A Londoner, he painted Thames vistas from Richmond to Margate, but he also painted Portsmouth, Norham Castle, Teesdale, sea towns from Whitby to Flint, medieval ruins from Conwy to Dover. Turner's watercolours and oil paintings constitute a visionary map of Britain.

Next year is the 150th anniversary of Turner's death, and if we can't find out much about Turner the man, we can still see a lot of the places he saw. Yet the more you look for it, the more you realise that Turner's Britain is not - and never was - an empirically verifiable place. In Turner's lifetime the map of Britain changed. The 1832 Reform Act changed the political topography of Britain, abolished rotten boroughs, created new constituencies. Turner's art can be seen as a painterly Reform Act, imagining the British landscape no longer as the province of a few aristocratic landowners but as the imaginative playground of us all.

It seems strange that a more urban Britain should have found its self-image in landscape art, but that is what happened in the Romantic era. The countryside became, for an increasingly towny nation, a view. It became picturesque. The story of British art from the pastoral portraits of Gainsborough and the classicised Snowdonian views of Richard Wilson in the 18th century through to Turner's last masterpieces of the 1840s, is the story of the discovery of a British landscape.

Today the British landscape is changing again, not just politically with the devolution of Wales and Scotland, but physically. Our land itself seems to have become unstable, coastlines threatening to change shape, rivers bursting their banks. This winter the country is looking Turneresque and you don't need to lash yourself to the mast of a ship in a storm - as Turner claimed to have done - to find yourself at the turbulent centre of his art. Just take a walk up London's Richmond Hill.

The view from Richmond Hill, once home to the Prince Regent and Mrs Fitzherbert, has been famous since the 17th century. Turner made it the subject of a watercolour, in which picnickers are dwarfed by a shining sky, the Thames landscape in front of them catching fire. He also did a vast oil painting of the scene as a birthday tribute to the Prince Regent in 1819, and called it England. Strolling up the hill today, past antique shops and posh houses, you can see Turner's painting in front of you.

But something is wrong. It's more Turner than Turner. The river is not a gentle, meandering ribbon. It's a torrent. Pushing at its banks, the Thames flows incredibly fast and the meadow between the hill and the river is partially flooded. Walking down to the shore, you see the river forming whirlpools and causing boats to strain at their moorings as it roars towards London. You think of Turner's visions of floods, typhoons, the Biblical Deluge.

Further up the Thames is the site of one of Turner's masterpieces. Rain, Steam and Speed - The Great Western Railway (1844) may be the most important painting of the 19th century. It was revered by the French Impressionists as an unprecedented attempt to paint the modern world. A steam train hurtles towards us out of a maelstrom of rain, cloud and golden light. Rain washes across the surface of the canvas from right to left while the river below gleams and the sky behind the train billows.

There is nothing fixed in this painting. The people fishing down by the river, looking up at the train, are insubstantial spirits. Only the material force of iron and brick, of industrial and natural energy, has any reality. Turner's contemporary Karl Marx described it best: all that is solid melts into air.

The viaduct in Turner's painting is a sturdy Victorian structure - an engineering marvel by Isambard Kingdom Brunel, boasting the longest brick arches in the world. It still exists and is still in use. You can find it crossing the Thames at Maidenhead. According to the Daily Telegraph Guide to Commuterland, the best, most expensive properties in town can be found on the Thames around Maidenhead Bridge.

The first sign that things are not right is the top of a park bench, with a plaque naming the person it commemorates, sticking out of the fast-moving water. Then you notice a wrought-iron footbridge whose two ends have vanished, leaving just a platform sticking up pointlessly. Across the river, the car park of Maidenhead Rowing Club has gone and the front door is in the river. Houses behind have sandbags against the flood.

Clambering across a fence and trespassing onto Railtrack property, you can climb the wooded bank towards the railway to try to get the exact view painted by Turner. It soon becomes clear that this pointless. Turner's painting is a view from above, as if he were looking down on the viaduct and river from a high hill. But there is no high hill.

Although Turner's details are recognisable, he transformed everything. The Thames shore is depicted as a deep valley, almost a gorge, but the land here is low-lying. Looking across this scene painted by Turner, you feel there is nothing stable in the world. If you were considering Constable and you found the scene of one of his most famous paintings flooded, you would say his reassuring vision of British rural life had been drowned. But this looks like Turner's revenge. He saw this landscape as grand, religious and historical, a place of tempests and wonders - but we tend to imagine our country as suburban, quiet, and go on holiday elsewhere if we crave spectacle.

This wild landscape is not Britain as we imagine it, but it is a Britain that Turner saw. Turner's paintings have come true. As the rivers burst their banks, this doesn't look like such a small, containable land after all. It looks sublime, cursed and blessed: a place of high drama.

In the no man's land of the flooded shore under Brunel's railway bridge a flock of Canadian geese play, seeming to enjoy this new space. It is a place that does not exist on any official map, this apocalyptic little corner of Turner's Britain.

 Turner: The Great Watercolours is at the Royal Academy, London W1 (020-7300 8000), until February 18. The Great Turner (1775-1851): A Tribute is at the National Gallery of Scotland, The Mound, Edinburgh (0131-624 6200), from January 1 to March 4.

webTitle: Energis gets a fix on Germany

fields.headline: Energis gets a fix on Germany
fields.trailText: Energis yesterday turned a blind eye to the growing uncertainty surrounding the valuations of telecoms companies by announcing an estimated €1bn (£606m) e-commerce acquisition that it believes will "fix" its position in the important German market.
fields.body:
Energis yesterday turned a blind eye to the growing uncertainty surrounding the valuations of telecoms companies by announcing an estimated €1bn (£606m) e-commerce acquisition that it believes will "fix" its position in the important German market.

Chief executive Mike Grabiner said Energis's takeover of web-hosting and applications services provider Ision was its largest to date and fitted its stated strategy of broadening its European operations.

"It fixes Germany for us and takes a major further step in our strategy to become the leading data and internet solutions provider in Europe," he said.

Shares in Energis fell 10% in early trading, reflecting uncertainty in the market at the price Energis was paying and the fact that the deal would delay the firm's profitability at a time when telecoms shares are out of favour because of their heavy debt levels.

"The price paid looks very full, is dilutive financially to existing shareholders and the asset quality is questionable," said Mike Williams, analyst at Deutsche Bank. Others fear Energis may need to raise further funds by issuing more shares at some stage next year. Later trading saw the shares recover to close down 19p at 480.5p in a mixed market for telecoms stocks.

Energis finance director Chris Hibbert denied that the deal was over-ambitious or that it was overpaying. "This is not a bold acquisition, it's an evolution of what we have being trying to do over the last two or three years. Compared to valuations we saw earlier in the year, it is a far better price."

Ision, based in Hamburg, specialises in complex webhosting and other internet products to large companies wanting to increase online business. Customers include Europe's largest online stockbroker Comdirect, Deutsche Bank and media group Bertelsmann.

It also owns more than a dozen internet hosting centres across the continent. In the nine months to September 30 Ision had revenues of £40.7m and pre-tax losses of £6.8m.

Energis believes the market Ision operates in should sustain strong growth for several years. The takeover involves a cash and shares payment of €812m to Swiss firm Distefora for its 75% stake and an offer for the remaining publicly traded shares which is likely to take the deal value to €1bn.

The move comes at a trying time for Energis. Wanadoo's recent takeover of Freeserve has cast some doubt on Energis's long-term relationship with the British internet firm. Their contract runs until September 2003.

Energis had secured a position to become the network provider to Richard Branson's People's Lottery but yesterday's decision by regulators to stick with Camelot is thought to have cost it £40-50m in annual revenues.

webTitle: Danny La Rue talks to  Lyn Gardner

fields.headline: I don't think God said, 'You've got to be in a frock all your life,' but I do feel I've got his support
fields.standfirst: Danny La Rue talks to  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: Danny La Rue talks to Lyn Gardner
fields.body:
It is half past two on a Friday afternoon, and at the New Victoria theatre in Woking there is a buzz in the air. This year's pantomime, Cinderella, is about to start in front of an audience composed largely of under-fives and their mums, plus a sprinkling of slightly sozzled twentysomething males.

The show begins. The under-fives are clearly here for Postman Pat, who is making a guest appearance as bearer of invitations for the royal ball. The reason for all the unaccompanied males suddenly becomes apparent with the appearance of Cinderella, who is played by Melinda Messenger. The men wave their wands around like excited five-year-olds.

But even they are stunned into silence by the arrival of the Baroness Voluptua, who sweeps on stage in a flurry of authority, red velvet, white fur and sparkles, looking like a cross between Barbara Cartland, a dominatrix and the Queen Mum.

"Who's that woman?" pipes up the child behind in awe. "That," replies his mother, "is Danny La Rue. He used to be famous."

It is hard to recall now just how famous La Rue used to be. During his heyday in the 1960s, he was Britain's highest-paid entertainer. He had his own club in the West End, where the likes of Princess Margaret, Marlene Dietrich and Grace Rainier ("Such a dirty laugh," he recalls) would flock to his late-night cabaret act, which was saucy enough to earn him the nickname Danny La Rude. He could single-handedly fill a West End theatre for months.

He was the first drag act ever to appear in a Royal Variety show in front of the Queen. In an era when the idea of men in frocks was still smutty, he made drag respectable outside the panto season.

Now he is 73, and like the Queen herself a cross between a national institution and a joke. Mention his name and some people snigger, but others go into rhapsodies about glamour, professionalism, the lost age of music hall and variety. Look up his website and it is full of messages not just from the devoted elderly female fans that you might expect, but from entire families who saw his Blackpool show last summer and lapped up this vision of a male old age pensioner pretending to be a woman in a rhinestone-studded gown.

Even La Rue himself finds it hard to explain his allure. "I think people often come out of curiosity, but then they get caught up in the glamour. And of course I've never been really draggy: all my ladies are rather grand. But really I don't know why people like me. Noël Coward once told me: 'Never try to define your success - you might lose it.' I believe in that."

He was born Danny Patrick Carroll in Ireland in 1928 and moved to Britain with his widowed mother when he was six. As a teenager he joined the navy, where he did a couple of the military drag shows that were popular at the time. After leaving the navy he worked mainly as a window dresser, although he remained stage struck. His career began almost by accident when he was spotted in an amateur drag show and signed to appear in a West End cabaret. He agreed as long as it wasn't under his own name. Danny La Rue was born.

Even now, you can see how pretty he must once have been, with his huge eyes and button nose. But he manoeuvres deftly around any questions concerning his sexuality and, unlike most drag artists, has never had a large gay following. When La Rue puts on the falsies and dresses up as Shirley Bassey, Marlene Dietrich, Tina Turner or even Baroness Voluptua, you can still quite clearly see the male in the female. In particular, when he sings the voice is undisguised, almost gravelly.

Whereas most drag acts - Barry Humphries's Dame Edna included - are based on the female shrew, La Rue's act is a celebration of femininity, not a parody of it. La Rue may drip diamonds and lay on the glamour with a trowel, but the make-up is almost understated, the hair unexaggerated, the cleavage considerably less obvious than that of Melinda Messenger. The bulging breasts, enormous bottoms, huge hair and squeaky voices so common when most men slip into drag are entirely absent, and therefore so is the misogyny. If all gender is about display and show, then La Rue's is the greatest performance of them all. He is an actor, not just a performer, and his natural medium has always been the theatre - never TV, which he has shunned and which has largely ignored him.

In other circumstances he might have been a straight actor, maybe even a successful one. But, as a strong believer in both destiny and God (he is a devout Catholic and has a little shrine to the Virgin Mary in his dressing room), he doesn't waste too much time on might-have-beens.

"I don't think God said, 'You've got to be in a frock all your life,' but I do feel I've got his support. I am very happy and I've been very lucky, but I do sometimes think it would nice to be cast other than as a woman. But I don't think the public would allow it. fields.bodyText: It is half past two on a Friday afternoon, and at the New Victoria theatre in Woking there is a buzz in the air. This year's pantomime, Cinderella, is about to start in front of an audience composed largely of under-fives and their mums, plus a sprinkling of slightly sozzled twentysomething males. The show begins. The under-fives are clearly here for Postman Pat, who is making a guest appearance as bearer of invitations for the royal ball. The reason for all the unaccompanied males suddenly becomes apparent with the appearance of Cinderella, who is played by Melinda Messenger. The men wave their wands around like excited five-year-olds. But even they are stunned into silence by the arrival of the Baroness Voluptua, who sweeps on stage in a flurry of authority, red velvet, white fur and sparkles, looking like a cross between Barbara Cartland, a dominatrix and the Queen Mum. "Who's that woman?" pipes up the child behind in awe. "That," replies his mother, "is Danny La Rue. He used to be famous." It is hard to recall now just how famous La Rue used to be. During his heyday in the 1960s, he was Britain's highest-paid entertainer. He had his own club in the West End, where the likes of Princess Margaret, Marlene Dietrich and Grace Rainier ("Such a dirty laugh," he recalls) would flock to his late-night cabaret act, which was saucy enough to earn him the nickname Danny La Rude. He could single-handedly fill a West End theatre for months. He was the first drag act ever to appear in a Royal Variety show in front of the Queen. In an era when the idea of men in frocks was still smutty, he made drag respectable outside the panto season. Now he is 73, and like the Queen herself a cross between a national institution and a joke. Mention his name and some people snigger, but others go into rhapsodies about glamour, professionalism, the lost age of music hall and variety. Look up his website and it is full of messages not just from the devoted elderly female fans that you might expect, but from entire families who saw his Blackpool show last summer and lapped up this vision of a male old age pensioner pretending to be a woman in a rhinestone-studded gown. And of course I've never been really draggy: all my ladies are rather grand. But really I don't know why people like me. Noël Coward once told me: 'Never try to define your success - you might lose it.' I believe in that." He was born Danny Patrick Carroll in Ireland in 1928 and moved to Britain with his widowed mother when he was six. As a teenager he joined the navy, where he did a couple of the military drag shows that were popular at the time. After leaving the navy he worked mainly as a window dresser, although he remained stage struck. His career began almost by accident when he was spotted in an amateur drag show and signed to appear in a West End cabaret. He agreed as long as it wasn't under his own name. Danny La Rue was born. Even now, you can see how pretty he must once have been, with his huge eyes and button nose. But he manoeuvres deftly around any questions concerning his sexuality and, unlike most drag artists, has never had a large gay following. When La Rue puts on the falsies and dresses up as Shirley Bassey, Marlene Dietrich, Tina Turner or even Baroness Voluptua, you can still quite clearly see the male in the female. webTitle: Passnotes

fields.headline: No: 1785
fields.standfirst: PlayStation 2
fields.trailText: PlayStation 2
fields.body:
Age:
A mere two months in the UK, but already stocks are running low.

Tell me about it. Can't find them for love nor money.
Now we know why.

Some unfathomably clever marketing scheme by Sony, I imagine.
Nope. Saddam Hussein.

What? Not content with executing his evil plan for world domination, the self-portrait-loving Iraqi dictator is now bent on ruining all the little children's Christmasses?
Looks that way. According to internet news service Ananova, the Baghdad-based tyrant has had up to 4,000 consoles shipped into the country over the past four months. The web is humming with the rumour, which received a major boost when it was picked up by the rightwing news site WorldNetDaily.

He's giving them to his immediate family, perhaps?
No.

Or as a seasonal gift for his government colleagues?
Same thing, isn't it?

Well what on earth for, then?
Apparently, several PlayStation 2s can be bundled together into a crude supercomputer powerful enough for a vast range of military uses.

But why choose a poxy video-games machine?
The transfer of almost all computer technology into Iraq is banned under UN sanctions - but toys aren't. And anyway, being a pariah state is a whole lot less burdensome when you've made it onto the high-score table of Q-Ball Billiards Master, or Ridge Racer V.

The Pentagon must be furious!
Indeed. "Applications for this system are potentially frightening... 12 to 15 PlayStations could provide enough computer power to control an Iraqi manned aerial vehicle," one intelligence source said. "But the Butcher of Baghdad will be laughing on the other side of his moustachioed face when he sees our Dreamcast-based missile defence system," he unfortunately didn't add.

Is there any precedent for this?
Remember the fabled Iraqi supergun that everyone thought was going to be made out of huge industrial pipes? Remember how those super-blaster water pistols were really popular that summer? Suspicious, no?

Do say:
"Never underestimate the power of PlayStation."
