webTitle: The day I found out my dad was a bank robber

fields.headline: The day I found out my dad was a bank robber
fields.standfirst: Allison Perkin  on finding out, at the age of 32, that her father was an infamous bank robber
fields.trailText: Allison Perkin on finding out, at the age of 32, that her father was an infamous bank robber
fields.body:
Anyone in their mid-30s with an ounce of rebellion in their soul will remember Daddy was a Bank Robber, by the Clash. I can remember sitting in my bedroom, playing that single over and over, memorising the words. I was the adopted daughter of a law-abiding Dorset schoolteacher and how I craved the romance of it all. I had absolutely no idea then, as a music- and crime-obsessed teenager, that two decades on I would attend the funeral of a real-life bank robber, called Bobby King, and that I would be present at the funeral because he was my father.

I was 32 when I found out the identity of my parents. For years they had simply been names in letters that my adoptive parents had received from the Children's Society. My "putative" (such an insulting word) father's occupation was given as "painter and decorator", presumably it was considered potentially prejudicial to inform prospective parents that they were about to adopt the child of a criminal. Like many adopted people my origins were shrouded in mystery, secrecy and, worse, misinformation.

Searching for birth-parents is not an easy task, either practically or emotionally, and it wasn't until my birth-mother contacted the Children's Society herself that I had any success. After finding her it was relatively straightforward to locate Bob; his infamy certainly sped up the process. One night, fuelled by a desperate need to know and rather too much wine, I rehearsed my words, found the courage and telephoned him. The emotional impact of hearing my father's voice for the first time was without precedent; it was such an absurd thing to be doing - phoning a total stranger in order to tell him that I was his daughter.

Getting the words out was an enormous struggle: all I wanted to do was to slam down the phone and forget the whole awful mess. I had no idea how he was going to react. Although by this time I was pretty sure of my facts, I was only too aware that if he decided to refute what I was saying there would be very little I could say or do. As I was soon to discover, his reaction to my garbled news was actually very much in character: "Fucking hell love, are you sure?"

It was an extraordinary journey, travelling from Brighton to London to meet Bob for the first time.

Thankfully, most of us meet our parents long before we're 32. In most families, even if a mother or father is not there, evidence of them is. Bob's absence from my life had been complete: no photos, no family anecdotes. All I had to go on was the brief, fabricated reference to him in my adoption papers, rather vague recollections of his criminal tendencies from my birth-mother and one fraught telephone conversation. I was in such a state I found it almost impossible to navigate the underground. I remember staring at the tube map, clutching the directions Bob had given me over the phone, on the verge of tears. I was convinced that if I'd lost the ability to read, then I certainly wouldn't be able to speak to a stranger who was also, apparently, my father.

Despite the stressful journey, I arrived early at Bob's aptly chosen venue, a pub called the Starting Gate. It was an unusually hot day, which didn't help matters. I was horribly sticky, feeling sick and shaky. Ordering a pint of Guinness, it was all I could do not to confide in the barmaid the reasons for my all too evident distracted demeanour. Instead I chose a table with a clear view of the door, pretended to read the Guardian and thanked God that I hadn't yet given up smoking. As neither of us had the foresight to plan how we would recognise each other, I was obsessed by the horrifying notion that I might accuse the wrong man of being my father. Such a ghastly mistake wouldn't have seemed out of place on such a peculiar day.

It is perhaps hard to believe, but as soon as Bob walked into the bar, recognition was immediate. I watched him order his drink, walk towards me, holding his tobacco - the same brand as mine - and his Guardian and I was certain, absolutely certain, that this was my father. There was something about his posture and the shape of his face. Even before I heard him speak, he reminded me of me.

During the next four hours or so, we entertained each other with stories of our lives and perhaps surprisingly, we liked each other. It was a surreal experience sitting in unfamiliar surroundings, opposite someone who both was and was not my father, and yet I remember it fondly. We were both at pains to put each other at ease, and initial fears gradually vanished. There was so much to tell.

I had recently qualified as an English teacher but it had taken me rather a long time to get there. Like my birth-mother, I'd had my first child as an unmarried teenager although, unlike her, I was able to keep my baby. The terrific support I'd received from my parents enabled me to pass some A-levels and go to university. Studying for a degree in literature, I'd further complicated things by having a second child at a ridiculously impractical time. I described sitting my finals with a newborn daughter sleeping in her pram just outside the exam hall, nipping out to breastfeed, in between struggling with essays on feminist theory - the irony was not lost on Bob. He was delighted that I had such great parents and was more than a little relieved to find that I had at least some understanding of going about life unconventionally.

Bob's tales of the crimes he'd committed, his conviction for armed robbery and his 10-year stretch in prison were turned into comic routines as he beautifully imitated the voices of lawyers and social workers. I was astounded by the extent of his involvement in the criminal underground. He told me that in prison he had a choice, either become an obsessive body-builder or an obsessive reader: he opted for the latter and was delighted to find that I loved the same, somewhat obscure books. Imagined or real, I am still staggered by the common ground we found. On subsequent occasions friends of mine met Bob and were equally struck by the uncanny resemblances, particularly by the mannerisms that we shared. Before finding my birth-parents I had never really given much credence to genetic inheritance, always believing that environmental factors were of primary importance. I am still struggling to understand how I could possibly have inherited characteristics from a father I had never known.

Long-held assumptions I'd had about my identity, about my place in the world, were shifted in the space of an afternoon. Not only had I met this most unusual man, I also discovered that he already had two sons. Having grown up as the eldest of two adopted daughters, I was suddenly also the younger sister of two half brothers.

Understandably, my fascination was overwhelming. Who were they? Where were they and what did they do? My head spun with questions. Bob was happy to talk about my brothers, clearly proud of the fact that both had steered clear of crime. Convinced that they would be as curious as I was, Bob promised to tell them both of my existence.

Returning home that day I was both elated and exhausted. I now had some understanding of the affair that had led to my birth, my origins had finally become less mysterious. The following day I received a postcard from Bob; scrawled on the back was an extract from a poem.

    I can wade Grief -
    Whole Pools of it -
    I'm used to that -
    But the least push of Joy
    Breaks up my feet -

Perhaps Bob was better suited to the hardships of prison life than to the potential joys of fatherhood. He could never be a father to me in the way my adopted father has been. Meeting my birth-father served to deepen the love and gratitude I feel towards my mum and dad, and the conflicting loyalties I experienced after the initial exhilarating rush of excitement at finding Bob were often agonising. I had absolutely no idea how to fit this man into my life. The emotional fall-out was enormous, and finding any resolution was unfortunately hindered by Bob's habit of drinking large amounts at rather inappropriate times. Contact became difficult and despite good intentions we gradually lost touch. Instead I found myself in bookshops searching the true-crime section for his name, I listened to him talking on radio programmes and learned about his involvement in films through newspaper articles.

The impact of adoption upon ordinary people is full of irony and paradox: I learned that I am the daughter of a man who successfully stole from a bank only two doors away from where my adoptive parents were then living, and that only months before finding out who he was, I had watched him in a TV documentary on violent crime describing how best to organise an armed robbery, totally innocent of the fact he was my father. I have still to reconcile being the daughter of a man capable of demanding money from people by waving a shotgun and yet able to express himself through the poetry of Emily Dickinson.

No matter how much Bob deviated from the long-imagined fantasy father I invented as a child, I am very glad that I found him when I did. Hearing Daddy was a Bank Robber on a jukebox the other day, I was astonished to find that I can still remember all the words. With a distinct sense of irony, I realised that the song I learned so very long ago still has the power to move me.

The 'liberal' bank robber
by Duncan Campbell

Bobby King, who died aged 59 in October, was one of the most active bank robbers of his generation, taking advantage of the period in London before heavy security at banks and the cleansing of the corrupt detectives who would take bribes to look the other way. He once described himself as on "the liberal wing" of bank robbers in that his shotgun cartridges were loaded with sand not gunpowder so that anyone hit by them would receive a bruise rather than a fatal wound.

He came from an infamous group of young criminals in Hornsey, north London and, for a few years in the early 70s, carried out a series of spectacular robberies. He was a "face", part of the criminal world regarded as successful in their field. But he came unstuck in 1973 when Bertie Smalls, with whom he had carried out a number of robberies, turned supergrass and gave evidence against King and 20 others in exchange for his own freedom.

Jailed for 18 years and already weary of the prison culture, King started to catch up on his neglected education, eventually taking an Open University degree and carrying out a study of the effect of the Quaker movement on liberal thought. On his release after serving 10 years, he worked initially on a project to divert young criminals from jail by confronting them with their victims. The idea was to make use of his reputation and criminal experience to persuade the teenagers of the boredom of prison life.

He also acted as a consultant, undercover reporter or interviewee on a number of programmes and films on crime, including the BBC's The Underworld and Crime Desk, World in Action and the feature film Face, in which he gave advice to the cast one night in the Nobody Inn in Islington on how to prepare for and carry out a robbery. The secret, he explained to the actors who included Ray Winstone, Robert Carlyle and Damon Albarn, was that you knew you would never get caught.

He had written for the Guardian about crime and had wanted before his sudden death to write about the experience of finding his daughter. Now she has fulfilled his wish.

He once described himself as on "the liberal wing" of bank robbers in that his shotgun cartridges were loaded with sand not gunpowder so that anyone hit by them would receive a bruise rather than a fatal wound. He came from an infamous group of young criminals in Hornsey, north London and, for a few years in the early 70s, carried out a series of spectacular robberies. He was a "face", part of the criminal world regarded as successful in their field. But he came unstuck in 1973 when Bertie Smalls, with whom he had carried out a number of robberies, turned supergrass and gave evidence against King and 20 others in exchange for his own freedom. Jailed for 18 years and already weary of the prison culture, King started to catch up on his neglected education, eventually taking an Open University degree and carrying out a study of the effect of the Quaker movement on liberal thought. On his release after serving 10 years, he worked initially on a project to divert young criminals from jail by confronting them with their victims. The idea was to make use of his reputation and criminal experience to persuade the teenagers of the boredom of prison life. He also acted as a consultant, undercover reporter or interviewee on a number of programmes and films on crime, including the BBC's The Underworld and Crime Desk, World in Action and the feature film Face, in which he gave advice to the cast one night in the Nobody Inn in Islington on how to prepare for and carry out a robbery. The secret, he explained to the actors who included Ray Winstone, Robert Carlyle and Damon Albarn, was that you knew you would never get caught. He had written for the Guardian about crime and had wanted before his sudden death to write about the experience of finding his daughter. Now she has fulfilled his wish.

webTitle: Business: Serco friends find a buy

fields.headline: Serco friends find a buy
fields.trailText: It is amazing what a chat with a friendly analyst can do. Take Serco, the mid cap business services group. It shares shot up 57.5p, or 11.56%, to 555p yesterday after analysts at investment bank Merrill Lynch returned from a pre-closed season meeting with the company and promptly upgraded the shares to a "buy".
fields.body:
It is amazing what a chat with a friendly analyst can do. Take Serco, the mid cap business services group. It shares shot up 57.5p, or 11.56%, to 555p yesterday after analysts at investment bank Merrill Lynch returned from a pre-closed season meeting with the company and promptly upgraded the shares to a "buy".

According to the Merrill analysts, trading at Serco is buoyant, with margins expected to see continued upward progress in 2001. The contract pipeline also looks healthy, with 25 bids on the table of which the analysts think four to six will come to fruition over the next six to 12 months.

Even if they do not, Serco's revenues for next year already look secure. Some 70% of 2001 and 65% of 2002's turnover is booked. Looking further ahead, should Serco win the contract to run the National Air Traffic System it could lead to a radical surge in the group's earnings growth.

webTitle: Business: At this price? Mayflower

fields.headline: At this price?  Mayflower
fields.trailText: Mayflower, the Buckinghamshire maker of car and truck bodies which boasts former prime minister John Major as one of its directors, has a distant admirer.
fields.body:
Mayflower, the Buckinghamshire maker of car and truck bodies which boasts former prime minister John Major as one of its directors, has a distant admirer.

John Harvey, a private investor who resides in Barbados and is said to have an activist streak, has been quietly building a stake since September. It emerged yesterday that Mr Harvey is now the company's biggest shareholder. After acquiring a further 3.26m shares early this month he has a 6.29% stake.

Since Mr Harvey first appeared theories about his intentions have abounded. Some believe he might broker a takeover, others claim he has spotted a bargain.

Whatever his intentions - and it should be noted that Mr Harvey has had meetings with Mayflower's management - should investors be tempted to follow his lead?

On the face of it, Mayflower is cheap. Its shares, about 220p at the start of the year, closed at 76.5p last night. Based on forecasts provided by Old Mutual this puts the Mayflower on a price earnings ratio of 5.1 times, astonishing for a company with a solid growth record.

But there is a reason for the lowly rating - the US truck market. It is estimated that second half truck production in America will be down 40%. With 37% of Mayflower's turnover last year coming from the US, analysts have been quick to reduce their profits forecasts. HSBC Securities for example recently reduced its full year pretax profits to £50m. In 1999, Mayflower made £55m.

Combined with a slowing British bus market - 42% of turnover last year - and a high level of debt, about £218m at the half-year stage, it is not surprising that investors are not interested.

There seems to be little chance things will get better in the near future. The US motor market is expected to continue its decline next year and hopes of a takeover seem remote, although on the basis of historic cashflows a management buyout is possible. Avoid, for the time being.

fields.trailText: In the primary school league tables published in the broadsheet section of the Guardian on December 7, Tower Hamlets was mistakenly omitted by the Department for Education and Employment from the table of local education authorities with the most improved primary schools for the period 1997-2000. According to the measure used, Tower Hamlets should have been ranked second, and one of its schools, Mowlam School, should have been listed as the third most improved primary school. Elsewhere in the published tables, St Mary's School in   Lambeth was ranked joint first with another school that did not have the same aggregate score for maths, English and science. St Mary's should have been first.

webTitle: Letters: Too late for nursing grievances

fields.headline: Too late for those nursing grievances
fields.trailText: I agree with Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing when she says the nurses' pay award "won't bring fast progress in encouraging nurses back to the health service" (NHS pay deal 'will fuel staff crisis', December 19).
fields.body:
I agree with Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing when she says the nurses' pay award "won't bring fast progress in encouraging nurses back to the health service" (NHS pay deal 'will fuel staff crisis', December 19). However, the haemorrhage of trained and quality nurses from the service might have been foreseen.

As a clinical ward sister in a Sheffield hospital in the late 80s I was aghast at the ways in which health service managers, nurse (yes nurse) managers and some senior doctors systematically bullied nurses into changes to their already unsociable shift patterns, squeezing nurses further in search of greater cost effectiveness and efficiency.

The belief was that nurses were powerless and would put up with any amount of poor conditions (not to mention low pay). They were wrong. I, like many of my colleagues, left the profession and will not return. Now, over a decade later, governments and managers seek to lure nurses back. They offer incentives, improved and flexible shift patternsbut it is too late for many of us who have built up new careers. Managers simply reap what they have sown.
Dr Rosemary Gillespie
Portsmouth
sr_gillespie@onetel.net.u

 Your leader (December 19) made sound points about the unfair treatment of some non-nursing professions in the NHS covered by the pay review body (PRB). But there are tens of thousands of NHS professionals not covered by the P RB who have been treated even less favourably by the NHS and are due to receive a lower salary increase than those just announced.

These include health-care scientists and technicians, pharmacists, physicists, clinical scientists and biochemists, speech and language therapists, psychologists, counsellors, health advisors and chaplains.

These groups also make a major contribution to preventative and rehabilitative care, but earn far less than their direct comparators in nursing grades. For example a graduate entry biomedical scientist earns less than £10,000. So it is hardly surprising that as a result there are issues of recruitment and retention for many non-PRB staff.
Roger Lyons
General secretary, MSF

webTitle: Letters: Black men take the rap

fields.headline: Black men take the rap
fields.trailText: Gary Younge (Comment, December 18) wants to conduct an attitudinal survey amongst young black males to find out why so many walk away from their children.
fields.body:
Gary Younge (Comment, December 18) wants to conduct an attitudinal survey amongst young black males to find out why so many walk away from their children. Such a survey might well produce similar results to those conducted in the US, which have found that black males aspire to marriage and long-term committed relationships in similar proportions to other ethnic groups. I don't wish to sound unromantic, but clearly such aspirations are more likely to be realised if the male has a secure job and a decent income.

However, many black men in the UK are denied the opportunity to play a full role in the lives of their children through no fault of their own - Richard Berthoud found that although the qualifications achieved by young Caribbean males were on average not much worse than those of white males, they were twice as likely to be unemployed. You play by the rules, you get an education, and you end up filling shelves in a supermarket.

Even more demoralising for the young black male must be the greater relative economic success of their female counterparts, all of which might help explain why some look for a sense of self-worth in an adversarial street culture and find comfort in the often misogynistic lyrics of rap and dancehall. Obviously the root causes of family instability are complex, but a good starting point must be the lack of equal opportunities in the labour market.
David Boyle
London david.r.boyle@btinternet.com

 I am confused (Asians fly the flag for traditional families, December 18). If "half of British-born Caribbean men and one-third of the women who are in relationships [have] chosen a white partner", and problems such as "subordination of women" and "irresponsible parenting" are "better sorted out within the relevant communities", does this mean that all those white partners have no say? Or that they now belong to their partners' "community" rather than their own "community"? Or does it mean that someone has noticed that for a great many families there is more than one "community" involved, and is allowing for the existence of a mixed community, made up of mixed families?

And if so, please could they tell the census, because otherwise my daughter is going to have to choose whether to tick Black African like Daddy, or White British like Mummy, or Black British ("but I'm white too") or Other, which is a big and dispiriting decision for a seven-year-old. At present, we both tick Other because if we have to be put in a box we want to go in the same one.
Louisa Young
Author, Baby Love louisa@louisayoung.demon.co.uk

Your interesting report pointing to ethnic variation in family life, particularly by Caribbean families, concludes that the "traditional" family is in decline. Professor Berthoud rightly argues against drawing ethnocentric conclusions. The research recently undertaken by myself and Professor Harry Goulbourne on Caribbean families in Britain, which used both qualitative and quantitative data, concluded (amongst other things) that Caribbean families were, indeed, diverse but they were also close, supportive and successful, and retained powerful and functional links across the oceans and the generations.

It also cautioned against attempting to identify "the traditional" Caribbean family, and pointed to the dangers of too easy a comparison between "traditional" and contemporary, or between different ethnic groups. But then good news, sound sense, and the Caribbean are rarely, if ever, reported.
Prof Mary Chamberlain
Oxford Brookes University

fields.trailText: Hugo Young's evenhandedness over Hague (Stirring up trouble, December 19) reminds me of Robert Frost's lines:  I am a liberal/I mean, so altruistically moral/I never take my own side in a quarrel .
fields.body:
Hugo Young's evenhandedness over Hague (Stirring up trouble, December 19) reminds me of Robert Frost's lines: I am a liberal/I mean, so altruistically moral/I never take my own side in a quarrel .
A Sivanandan
Institute of Race Relations

 Re Frank Dobson's involvement in ridiculing William Hague (Report, December 16): don't forget Ken Livingstone got elected.
David Monk
Saffron Walden, Essex

 I am still waiting for that nice Mr William Hague to write claiming he is 86 and can do the Quick Crossword in so many seconds. Can't he recognise a stonking good bandwagon when he sees one or is he afraid people will accuse him of playing the "elderly crossword" card?
Daniel de Iongh
Edinburgh

Kim Howells blames a cultural change for increased consumer debt (Credit card frenzy, December 19). The government has contributed to this shift with student loans - most will now start their working lives with large debts.
Maggie Watson
London

Albion, Wanderers and Caledonian Thistle? Has the choice of the three new cities (Finale to hard fought battle, December 18) got anything to do with their football teams not having to change their names?
Andy Bone
Brighton

Re "King" George (Letters, December 16): George W comes after George V. The next one will be George X. Obvious, innit?
David Bradnack
Aylesbury, Bucks

Why Santa doesn't exist (Proof that Santa exists, Science, October 14): if he did exist, on the presents it would say "Happy Xmas from Santa".
Nathan Graham (age 7)
London

webTitle: Leader: The people's Croesus

fields.headline: The people's Croesus
fields.standfirst: Does Sir Elton sum up our society?
fields.trailText: Does Sir Elton sum up our society?
fields.body:
We live, according to how you read it, in a parliamentary democracy, an elective dictatorship, or a branch of the Brussels superstate. But we also, it transpired today, live under an edoarchy. That at least is how the novelist Fay Weldon appeared to describe the condition of Britain when invited by the BBC Today programme to name her hero and villain for the year now ending. Her villain was Sir Richard Branson (not a good day for him yesterday) for, as she said, trying to run a railway like an airline. Her hero was the mega-spending multimillionaire entertainer Sir Elton John, revealed in a recent court case to be a man who happily goes out on a whim and blows a fortune on fripperies. He deserved her nomination, she argued in tones only lightly salted with sarcasm, for his willingness to spend huge sums on self-decoration and self-aggrandisement and his apparent determination to acquire all the antiques and goodies the globe had to offer.

The word edoarchy does not appear in the dictionary, and unless she derives it from the Edo, a people of south-west Nigeria noted for their 16th-century bronze sculptures, it may be her own invention. If so, it has to be said in the interests of scholarship - well, all right then, pedantry - that Fay Weldon has coined a naughty word. Though "edo," I eat, or consume, comes from the Latin, its partner "archy" is Greek, and it used to be a precept of philologists that such sources should never be mixed. There are those who still shun the word television on these grounds. A purist might prefer teleopsis (Greek) or proculvision (Latin), but it's rather too late for that now.

Will edoarchy enter the language? Or will it join the stock of neologisms coined early one morning or dead by the next? With its juxtaposition of vowels it is an awkward word, not tripping easily off the tongue. As for Sir Elton, assuming that he was listening, he is probably on his way to Nigeria now, with his eye out for all those bronze sculptures.

webTitle: Leader: Equitable? Not very

fields.headline: Equitable? Not very
fields.standfirst: This messy business deserves an inquiry
fields.trailText: This messy business deserves an inquiry.
fields.body:
There ought to be an immediate independent inquiry into the affairs of Equitable Life because of the worrying implications for the savings industry. This is not a Maxwell-style scandal: not a case of fraudsters taking money out - but of a pension fund being too generous to a relatively small section of its customers at the expense of hundreds of thousands of others (including, we need to say, many who work at the Guardian). Important issues need to be sorted out quickly. The first is to establish the facts. Equitable Life says that it is solvent after making provisions of £1.5bn for "guaranteed annuities" forced on it by a House of Lords judgment (after lower courts had ruled the other way). But if it is solvent, why did so many companies, including the Prudential, look at its books and shy away from a takeover? A million policyholders have a right to know.

Second, it has emerged that as long as two years ago a letter was sent from the Treasury to the Financial Services Authority, the relevant City watchdog, raising "serious questions" about the company's solvency. Yet for years Equitable's annual report made no mention of the £1.5bn bill it might have faced if the House of Lords had ruled against it. There are also unanswered questions about the Lords ruling. Was it too narrow in its interpretation of the law? Did it spend too much time on the legality of the rights of those eligible for guaranteed annuities and not enough on the consequences for Equitable's other policyholders? They have rights too. webTitle: Letters: Good advert for the ASA

fields.headline: Good advert for the ASA
fields.trailText: As one of the 730 who protested over the billboard "soft porn" advertisement featuring a naked Sophie Dahl, I am pleased by the Advertising Standards Authority's decision to remove the poster ('Offensive' Opium poster to be removed, December 19).
fields.body:
As one of the 730 who protested over the billboard "soft porn" advertisement featuring a naked Sophie Dahl, I am pleased by the Advertising Standards Authority's decision to remove the poster ('Offensive' Opium poster to be removed, December 19). When I first contacted the billboard owners, Maiden, I received the reply that "it was not Maiden's intention for this poster to cause any offence" and "to be assured that we do take complaints from members of the public seriously". My complaint, together with that of parents near the school where I teach in Rochdale, were acted on swiftly.

I also contacted the Advertising Standards Authority, which had agreed that the advertisement was OK for targeted media but not appropriate for positioning near a school. The ASA has said that the poster was in breach of the code of conduct and is now being taken down throughout the country. It has listened to what people are saying, as many women felt very offended by the poster, myself included. A victory for common decency.
Cllr Alison Firth
Manchester

Though expressed in flowery terms, AC Grayling's last paragraph (Last Word on Sex, December 16) tells us clearly that the Sophie Dahl ad turns him on. It "adds delight and flavour to the world".

No, it doesn't. It's only another addition to the relentless barrage of images we are subjected to every day that tell women (and small girls) how they should look and behave. Ads which truly celebrated heterosexual sex would show two people, one of whom would have to be a man. When I can get my kicks from ads showing gorgeous young men with erections, preferably displayed on huge street hoardings, so the children can enjoy them, too, we could have a less one-sided debate. But perhaps AC Grayling might find such ads a bit rude.
Ruby Lescott
London

AC Grayling finds it "beautiful and erotic". A Sheffield road safety officer believes it a "great distraction to drivers" (Letters, December 16). I'm with the Sheffield woman who sprayed "Porn = Abuse" on the hoarding. Thanks for cutting through the bullshit.
Gill Greenwood
Sheffield

Good to see the Guardian reporting on its front page the decision of the ASA ordering the withdrawal of an advert because the image is "too sexually suggestive and degrading to women". And then printing the image. Brilliant.
Mick Gosling
London mgosling@stokenew.demon.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Inaccurate sporting information

fields.headline: Ian's lesson
fields.trailText: I know exactly how Norman Belson feels about the inaccurate information presented as the unvarnished truth regarding the educational background of some of our sporting heroes (Letters, December 19).
fields.body:
I know exactly how Norman Belson feels about the inaccurate information presented as the unvarnished truth regarding the educational background of some of our sporting heroes (Letters, December 19). I have lost count of the number of times I have read in the tabloid press that Ian Botham was a pupil at Millfield School, which has an enviable sporting reputation. Sadly, it is simply untrue. Ian spent his formative years in Yeovil where he attended Milford Junior School, the real cause of the confusion, before going on to Buckler's Mead Secondary Modern School which he left in 1971 to pursue his career in cricket. It says much for Ian's ability and application that from this umpromising background, he developed into the finest all-rounder this country has ever produced.
Alun Morgan
Yeovil, Somerset ciderspace@ntlworld.com

webTitle: Letters Middle East war comes home

fields.headline: M East war comes home
fields.trailText: Permit me to applaud your courage and honesty in publishing Ahdaf Soueif's account of ordinary Palestinian lives under occupation (In the shadow of Israel, December 18).
fields.body:
I have been one of those irritating people bombarding you with unpublished letters ever since the beginning of the Al-Aqsa Intifada, pleading you to come out strongly against Israel's continuing suppression and massacre of a people struggling for their land and their freedom.

Permit me, then, to applaud your courage and honesty in publishing Ahdaf Soueif's account of ordinary Palestinian lives under occupation (In the shadow of Israel, December 18). Ms Soueif's exposure of Israel's murderous regime in the occupied territories will make a difference to the British attitude to the Palestine question. I can only hope that having made a welcome break from the rest of British media's frankly racist attitude to Palestine, you will carry on the good work.
Pablo Mukherjee
St John's College, Cambridge upm20@cam.ac.uk

 As a regular Manchester Guardian and Guardian reader for 55 years I have come across both pro and anti-Israel reporting of the Middle East conflict in your paper. Ahdaf Soueif takes the biscuit. Her anti-Israel bias is transparent. She would have us believe that all Israelis have horns and that butter would not melt in any Palestinian's mouth. What I find astonishing is the attitude of the editor who passed this one-sided, pro-Palestinian propaganda for publication. Where is your celebrated fair-mindedness?
Harold Saunders
Manchester hardor@lineone.net

 It must not be forgotten, primarily, that there are always two sides to the coin. One might otherwise adopt Pirandello's bizarre logic: Cosi e se vi pare (Right you are - if you think you are).
Maresa Elliot
London

webTitle: Under fire Mexico holds its breath as Popocatepetl erupts

fields.headline: Under fire Mexico holds its breath as Popocatepetl erupts
fields.trailText: A volcano 40 miles outside Mexico City erupted on Monday night, spitting red-hot rocks into the sky and prompting the evacuation of nearly 50,000 people.
fields.body:
A volcano 40 miles outside Mexico City erupted on Monday night, spitting red-hot rocks into the sky and prompting the evacuation of nearly 50,000 people.

The interior minister, Santiago Creel, said yesterday that the Popocatepetl volcano had calmed down but added that a critical period was now approaching.

President Vicente Fox, who called for caution and calm in a late-night address to the nation on Monday, was expected to tour the refugee shelters yesterday.

The overnight eruptions, televised live, lit up the sky with bright red sprays and turned the cone into a twinkling incandescent carpet.

It was "Popo's" most intense activity since historical records began with the Spanish conquest nearly 500 years ago. Constant monitoring started in 1994 after an eruption ended 70-odd years of slumber.

No injuries or major damage was reported, although many feared further eruptions could melt a glacier and send an avalanche of acidic sludge towards abandoned villages. The last catastrophic eruption happened 1,200 years ago.

There were warnings of ash showers in nearby towns. The 18 million people of Mexico City, north-west of the 5,451-metre (17,884-feet) volcano, was not expected to be affected because of southerly winds.

webTitle: Mother sacked by firm wins test case for parents

fields.headline: Mother sacked by firm wins test case for parents
fields.trailText: A single mother who was sacked after asking to leave work to collect her sick son from school won a claim for unfair dismissal yesterday in the first case to test regulations allowing parents time off if their child falls ill.
fields.body:
A single mother who was sacked after asking to leave work to collect her sick son from school won a claim for unfair dismissal yesterday in the first case to test regulations allowing parents time off if their child falls ill.

Julie Percy, 35, from Baguley, Manchester, is the first parent to win a claim under the maternity and parental leave regulations which came into force last year, giving parents the right to take a "reasonable amount" of time off to care for a dependant.

In March, Ms Percy, who worked as a secretary for Metcalfe and Co, chartered surveyors, received a call from her eight-year-old son's school telling her he had a temperature and a discharge from his ear and needed to see a doctor. She immediately told her boss, Michael Oates, who appeared "irritated". Five minutes later, a colleague told her she was being sacked for being unreliable.

An employment tribunal in Manchester reached a unanimous decision in favour of Ms Percy, after reserving judgment in October. A compensation payout, based on loss of earnings, is to be decided. But Ms Percy found a new job one
day after being dismissed from the £11,000 a year post, so she will receive only one day's pay.

"This claim is not about money, it is about the principle of parents' rights," she said yesterday. "It is wrong to say that single mothers are the only ones who suffer.

"The issues of sick children affect any couple where both parents work. I realised I had my commitments to work and I did not want to leave them without a secretary but Thomas had a very infectious complaint. I just wanted to do what was best."

Ms Percy had worked at the company for six weeks. Mr Oates told the tribunal he sacked her because she was unreliable, impolite and had an attitude problem. She had arrived 30 minutes late for work on another occasion because her son was ill. But she had also been praised by the firm and had been given two bottles of wine as a reward for good work.

Mr Oates said Ms Percy did not ask to go and pick up her son, but told him she was leaving, presenting the decision as a fait accompli. He said he regarded this as an example of a bad attitude and "the last straw".

The employment tribunal
rejected the company's claim that Ms Percy was sacked not because she had to pick up her child, but because of the way she asked.

Her solicitor, John Cook, said three similar claims had been lodged in different parts of the country but this was the first ruling under the regulations which were added to the 1996 Employment Rights Act. He said the case would set a precedent for parents.

"There has been a plethora of changes in employment law in the past two years and companies need to be aware of this before taking such drastic action," he said.

"Employees now have more rights than ever, regardless of how long they have worked for the company."

Christine Gowdridge, director of Maternity Alliance, which campaigns for balance between work and childcare, said: "This case is quite extraordinary because there is a very straightforward legal right to take time off if your child is sick and particularly in an emergency.

"It is quite right that the claim was won and maybe it will publicise this little known right that everyone has to care for a sick dependant, even an elderly relative."

webTitle: Tesco imports 2,500 PlayStation 2 consoles to meet demand

fields.headline: Tesco imports 2,500 PlayStation 2 consoles to meet demand
fields.trailText: A "grey market" hoard of this year's must-have Christmas present, the Sony PlayStation 2 games console, has been spirited into Britain by Tesco, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
A "grey market" hoard of this year's must-have Christmas present, the Sony PlayStation 2 games console, has been spirited into Britain by Tesco, it was revealed yesterday.

About 2,500 have been imported from a "secret location" in northern Europe and will go on sale in five Tesco stores today, despite the efforts of Sony strictly to control supplies across the continent.

It is the first consignment in British stores since the launch last month, when Sony was criticised for allocating only 165,000 consoles for sale in Britain.

The supermarket chain has drafted in extra security at its stores in Watford, Peterborough, Newcastle, Cardiff and Inverness, and buyers will be restricted to one console each.

Tesco began its "grey market" ordering with a consignment of Levi jeans in 1997.

Tesco's actions are likely to inflame relations with Sony. In September last year the chain had to withdraw "grey market" versions of PlayStation because accessories were not genuine Sony parts. Sony won an injunction to stop sales until consoles were relabelled.

webTitle: Business: Bush unhappy with Greenspan

fields.headline: Bush starts on a friendly footing with his father's whipping boy
fields.standfirst: Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: Former president George Bush was not shy about making clear his unhappiness with Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, blaming him for responding too slowly to the recession that contributed to Bush's electoral defeat in 1992.
fields.body:
Former president George Bush was not shy about making clear his unhappiness with Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, blaming him for responding too slowly to the recession that contributed to Bush's electoral defeat in 1992.

Now Bush's son, president-elect George W. Bush, and his team appear poised to enjoy much warmer relations with the central bank chief - at least at the outset.

If experience is any guide, the temperature of the relationship could drop if the Fed chairman publicly disagrees with important Bush initiatives or if economic growth falters seriously.

Until this week, the two men had met only casually, but Bush had publicly supported President Clinton's decision to reappoint Greenspan to a fourth term.

On the other hand, Greenspan, a Republican, and vice president-elect Dick Cheney have been good friends since the Ford administration when Greenspan was chairman of the president's council of economic advisers and Cheney was White House chief of staff.

Nonetheless, there are already public differences between Bush and Greenspan. Bush has proposed a $1.6bn (£1bn) cut in income taxes, the sort of large tax reduction the Fed chairman has opposed in congressional testimony for several years. Greenspan has said it would be much better "to let the surpluses run" in the federal budget and pay down the national debt to keep interest rates low and encourage business investment.

Greenspan has also said that if the alternative to a tax cut was more spending, he would favour a tax cut. Based on the large amount of additional spending approved in the fiscal 2001 budget this week, tax-cut supporters might argue that Greenspan's position supports their case.

There has been some speculation that Greenspan might endorse the tax cut as a way to gain political favour with the new president.

Another point of contention could be Greenspan's opposition to investing any of the social security trust fund in the stock and bond markets because of the danger that the money might be invested to achieve political objectives. Bush has proposed diversion of a portion of the payroll tax to individual stock and bond accounts.

During Greenspan's 14 years as chairman, he and the Fed have generally marched to the beat of their own drummer, not that of whichever president was in office. At times, the Fed has been used as a political whipping boy by administration officials, particularly while the elder Bush was president.

Then-Treasury secretary Nicholas Brady, who was appointed by President Reagan but also served under Bush for a full four years, had a mantra whenever he was asked about Fed policy. "There's room for interest rates to be lower."

Under Clinton things changed, partly because he appointed mainstream economists to key positions and they came up with relatively conservative economic forecasts on which to base each year's budget projections. Treasury secretary Robert Rubin, a financial markets expert from Goldman Sachs, and those economists convinced Clinton that it would be in the administration's interest never to praise or blame the Fed publicly for interest-rate decisions.

Many Fed officials have said privately, and some publicly, that they cannot conceive of having a better working relationship with an administration. One of the ingredients has been Clinton's grasp of the intricacies of economic policy and the Fed's role in shaping it.

Bush, as he himself has said, will rely on "experts" for policy advice. As far as the Fed is concerned, he will be relying particularly on Lawrence B. Lindsey, an economist whose title in the new administration has not been announced. Two months ago, in a campaign debate with a representative of Vice-President Gore, Lindsey said he expects Bush to continue the Clinton administration's "wise" policy of refraining from public comment on Fed actions.

Another unknown is who Bush will name as Treasury secretary, usually the administration's most important official on economic policy.

During the Clinton years, Greenspan met the Treasury secretary almost weekly. In contrast, Brady found the meetings so frustrating that he finally cancelled them.

Washington Post

webTitle: The best management consulting scene

fields.headline: The best management consulting scene
fields.standfirst: Charlie's Angels
fields.trailText: Charlie's Angels
fields.body:
The offices of Corwin Enterprises. In order to carry out a surveillance operation, Alex Munday (Lucy Liu) is masquerading as an efficiency consultant, with cohorts Dylan Sanders (Drew Barrymore) and Natalie Cook (Cameron Diaz) in male drag as her assistants. As the three stride through a pool of workers, a diminutive woman (Melissa McCarthy) approaches.

"I'm Doris... I had you on the schedule for next week. I don't know what's happened."

"That's what I'm here to figure out", Alex replies briskly.

"The efficiency expert, eh?"

"Yes. I am."

Alex carries on walking, leaving Doris behind.

"Bitch."

Alex doesn't even look back.

"I heard that."

Entering a lecture room full of geekish technicians, Alex cracks a black cane across the desk and begins addressing the staff.

webTitle: Benefits loophole leads to injustices

fields.headline: Benefits loophole leads to injustices
fields.standfirst: A benefits loophole means that paying your welfare contributions could act against those applying for help, reports Robert Bennett
fields.trailText: A benefits loophole means that paying your welfare contributions could act against those applying for help, reports Robert Bennett.
fields.body:
Norman McKillop-Concannon is an angry man. And he has good reason to be - having spent eight weeks sleeping on the tiled floor of an empty council flat after the benefits agency turned down his plea for help because of what appears a glaring anomaly.

The 54-year-old Sheffield engineer has worked most of his life. He has experienced redundancy two or three times when the city's engineering industry hit hard times, but has always managed to find another job quickly. He has always paid his dues and kept his national insurance payments up-to-date against the day when his luck would change.

And it did change. Five years ago, his skin reacted to a new industrial lubricating oil and he developed a painful and ugly looking dermatitis - a condition which left him with an allergic reaction to most oils.

Unable to work in the trade he knew, he took a succession of caretaking jobs. Each time, though, the skin condition came back and forced him out. He coped until May, when he had to give up a job as a gardener/ handyman in Dore after the skin condition flared again. Without a wage, he had to apply for housing benefit.

This was when the problems started. Mr McKillop-Concannon became one of thousands of people let down by CSL, the company which took over the administration of housing benefits from Sheffield council's in-house service. Such a backlog of claims built up that hundreds of tenants faced eviction.

Mr McKillop-Concannon was one of those who were evicted. He lost the furnished flat he had lived in for 27 years. But he bears no grudge against his landlady - and he even shrugs his shoulders over CSL's record. "These things happen," he said, "and there are other people who've been hit a lot harder than me."

The deep resentment he carries around with him stems from what happened next. Knowing he was about to become homeless, he contacted the council's housing department which found him an unfurnished flat in the Broomhall area of Sheffield. All he needed was some basic furniture - a cooker and a bed - and he could start rebuilding his life again.

Not a problem, he thought. He went to the benefits agency and applied for a community care grant from the social fund to buy the basics. But his application was turned down - he was left to sleep on the hard, tiled floor of the flat, unable to cook for himself, and nursing a growing anger.

"I don't want anyone to go through what I've gone through," he said. "I have had to put up with so much crap from an organisation that's supposed to be there to meet social need, but doesn't seem to give a damn about people.

"For three months I've been told to fill in this form and that form, and never once has anyone asked me how I'm coping. Never once have they asked me if I needed any extra help or suggested somewhere I could go for help."

After filling out the forms, the agency told him he did not qualify for a grant because he was not receiving income support or income-based jobseeker's allowance. "After looking at your application and personal circumstances, we have decided the qualifying conditions for a payment from the social fund are not satisfied," said the letter turning down his application.

At first, Mr McKillop-Concannon thought it was just a mistake: after all, he was getting jobseeker's allowance. "But," he said, "it wasn't the right kind of jobseeker's allowance, apparently."

His allowance did not count because it was contribution-based, not means-tested. "In other words, the fact that I had paid my contributions up-to-date meant I couldn't get the help I needed. It's insane. I was sleeping on the floor; I didn't have a cooker and I still couldn't get help because I'd been such a good boy and paid into the system.

"What was worse was the way I was treated. I was made to feel like a scrounger - like someone begging for help they had no right to. They treated me as if I was trying to con the system."

Mr McKillop-Concannon was told he would have to wait six months. Only then would he become qualified for means-tested benefits, in turn qualifying him for help from the social fund. "If I hadn't qualified for contribution-based support - if I hadn't paid my stamps - I could have got help straight away," he said. "It's madness."

His complaints and requests for a review produced another rejection and, at the end of August, he applied for a crisis loan. That was turned down, too. Sleeping on the floor with nothing to cook on did not amount to a risk to the "health or safety" of a 54-year-old. But he appealed again and, after an interview, his application was reconsidered and he has received a loan of £320.

There is now a bed and a cooker in his flat and, thanks to the concern of the caretaker of his block of flats, he has a three-piece suite and a couple of bits and pieces that somebody else threw out. The housing benefit he applied for in May finally arrived last month, but he has just been diagnosed as clinically depressed - the first time in his life he has ever been "anywhere near depression".

The benefits agency admits that cases such as Mr McKillop-Concannon's are "a difficult area". A spokesman said: "On the other hand, we have to have rules to prevent people who can afford to live off their own income from claiming the benefits that are there for people who can't - and given that fact, a line has to be drawn somewhere."

webTitle: Young people learn vital independence skills

fields.headline: Young people learn vital independence skills
fields.standfirst: Young people want independence, yet some just can't cope when they get a place of their own.  Lynne Wallis on a project that helps them to learn from their mistakes
fields.trailText: Young people want independence, yet some just can't cope when they get a place of their own. Lynne Wallis on a project that helps them to learn from their mistakes
fields.body:
Why are there so many homeless young people? The withdrawal of welfare benefits from most 16 and 17-year-olds must be one factor, but another is that many young adults simply lack the basic skills to live independently.

One organisation seeking to address this is the Brunswick Centre Young People's Project in Newcastle upon Tyne, a drop-in centre for impoverished and homeless l6 to 25-year-olds, which is running courses to help its users secure and keep tenancies. "Things like how to keep a rent book or get your electricity turned on sound obvious," said course facilitator Tracey Morgan. "But if you've never done it, how do you know what to do? Lots of young people don't cope because they've never learned how to live alone."

The Brunswick's "independent living skills" course has been so successful that, last month, 35 representatives of charities and voluntary organisations - from the YMCA to Barnardo's - went to Newcastle to learn how to teach the course to young people in housing difficulty in their own areas.

The majority of teenagers who secure tenancies run into financial difficulties and rent arrears. But there are other problems, such as how to tell unwanted visitors to stop coming round, taking drugs and causing trouble. "Many young people living alone lack the confidence and assertiveness to say no, so they lose their tenancies as a result," said Ms Morgan. "We need to get them to understand what assertiveness is, that it's different from aggression, and to develop that quality. When we teach this session, it's interesting when the most dominant person in the group usually loses control as the other members gain confidence."

The Brunswick, which operates out of a room made available by a church in the centre of Newcastle, has about 170 clients on its books. One is Sean Wilkinson, a charming and sociable 21-year-old who completed the course two years ago.

Mr Wilkinson had broken up with his girlfriend, with whom he shared a flat. Subsequently, he become homeless and, like one in three people who live rough, developed mental health problems. He found himself living on the streets of Newcastle after a spell in a psychiatric hospital. Eventually, an organisation called Stepping Stones picked him up. He recalls: "They got me a flat with the Richmond Fellowship, which gives accommodation to people with mental health problems, but I still have to budget and pay for electricity, food, phone and gas. I couldn't have done it without the help I've had here. I got into such a mess with money in the past. I ran up debts of £700 after I split up with my partner."

Ms Morgan helped Mr Wilkinson draw up a payment plan for his debts and a budget for day-to-day living. He's still signed off sick, but is decorating his flat and has high hopes of pursuing his interest in cooking when he is better. "I've already passed the NVQ," he said. "I'd love to own my own restaurant one day. I know I'm good."

Care leavers constitute up to half of all homeless people. Ros Kelly, who has studied the independent living skills course to take back to Barnardo's, where she helps vulnerable young people to secure accommodation, said: "Care leavers are so institutionalised, they haven't got a clue how to look after themselves. They've never cooked a meal or washed a shirt. They've grown up thinking, 'No matter how badly I behave, someone will look after me.' Well, they soon find out that's just not true."

She believes the reason that so many young people leave home at l6 is "abuse in all its varieties", usually involving poverty and, quite often, a step-parent the teenager does not get on with. But sometimes it is just the impatience and intolerance of parents. "Kids at l6 can be a pain in the neck, and they're often chucked out at that age by parents who forget they get over that stage and usually turn out OK," Kelly said. "In other instances, though, it's outright violence and sexual abuse."

Having so far taught one group of 14-year-olds, Kelly believes course participants need to have a failed tenancy behind them to appreciate what can go wrong. And there needs to be a change in attitude to these common failures. "Young people need to realise it's normal to leave home, make a mess of it, and try again," she said. "Currently, they are made to feel failures by a system which doesn't always appreciate these kids haven't got an open door at home."

On a weekday afternoon, the Brunswick Centre is full of young people chatting, feeding children and getting advice from staff member Theresa Carey. Compared to other big cities, Newcastle has a large stock of accommodation for the homeless, although many bed spaces are held by long-term residents.

Ms Carey said: "The YMCA is proud of the fact that people stay in its supported accommodation so long, but it's not good because it's institutionalising them. Some become part of a subculture, moving from hostel to hostel. But when the time comes to move on and live independently, they can't do it. Bills come in and they throw them away. Supported accommodation should be short-term, because it detracts from the skills young people need to live their own lives."

webTitle: How carers and clients feel about assisted bathing

fields.headline: How carers and clients feel about assisted bathing
fields.standfirst: David Brindle  on a taboo-breaking book that reveals what carers and their clients feel about a greatly overlooked aspect of social care
fields.trailText: David Brindle on a taboo-breaking book that reveals what carers and their clients feel about a greatly overlooked aspect of social care.
fields.body:
For many disabled and frail elderly people, assisted bathing is a godsend. "It's become the rose of my week," says one. "It's lovely, like being a baby again," says another. But despite such appreciation, and the critical importance of enabling people to continue living independently, help with bathing is a greatly overlooked aspect of social care.

Why? According to Julia Twigg, author of a new book from which the above comments are taken, there remains a real taboo on discussion of bodily needs. In social services, moreover, the prevailing culture rarely permits proper consideration of the intensely personal nature of helping somebody to wash. "Much has been written on managerial issues," she said, "but very little that addresses the frontline realities of giving such care."

Yet these realities raise a host of fascinating and challenging questions. Typically, an elderly person who as an adult may never have been seen naked by anybody except their spouse - and possibly not even by them - is expected to welcome a stranger into their home to help them with a most private act. That stranger, often young, may never before have seen an older person unclothed, in a society where ageing bodies are not visible.

And the generational differences do not end with physical appearance. Ms Twigg recounts one episode where a young (female) care worker sought to wash the hair of an elderly (male) client. "How dare you!" he shouted. "I've never washed my hair in 30-odd years!"

The book, Bathing - the Body and Community Care, is a first and ambitious attempt to look comprehensively at what the author describes as a "missing dimension" in the analysis of community care. It is based on a study, funded by the economic and social research council, of assisted bathing services in two sharply contrasting localities: a relatively wealthy area of inner London, where clients included the titled, and a deprived coastal district, where most clients were defined as lower-middle or working class.

In all, 30 recipients of bathing help - 21 women and nine men - were interviewed either directly or, in the cases of three people with dementia, through their carers. Interviews were also conducted with 34 care workers - 31 women and three men - employed by social services or voluntary/private sector agencies, as well as four community nurses, three day centre staff and five frontline managers.

Ms Twigg, reader in social policy at the University of Kent, found that receiving help had been an unwelcome development for most of the clients. "Crossing this boundary ... marks a major shift in people's lives," she writes. Nevertheless, most approached the issue "with stoicism".

One woman said: "Well, at the beginning I didn't like being personally washed, of course, but after six years I haven't got any more hold-ups [sic] about that ..." Another said that "you pretend it doesn't matter", but added: "There are some people who are very liberated and I don't know, they sunbathe and wash naked ... well, I am too old, a generation not thinking that way."

Some had set their own boundaries, such as insisting on washing intimate areas themselves. "She would do underneath if I let her," said one woman of her care worker, "but I said: 'No, if you don't mind Doreen, I'd rather do underneath myself.'"

Most women clients were adamant that they would not want a male bathing assistant. But this was not always a product of past prudishness: one woman confessed to having "liked fun and games in my time, but not now - no". As well as consciousness of their ageing bodies, this may reflect an acute awareness of what Ms Twigg describes as the inherently unequal power dynamics of assisted bathing - an inequality emphasised by gender difference.

"One person, strong and able, stands above and over another who is frail and physically vulnerable, forced to rely on their strength and goodwill," the author writes. "Being naked in the face of someone who is not, contains a powerful dynamic of domination and vulnerability, and it is often used in situations of interrogation and torture as a means of subjugating the individual."

For the care worker, the initial experience of assisted bathing can be equally disconcerting. One London client, named as Sir Peter, said: "It's rather bad luck on the girls, scrubbing old gentlemen's backs." One worker admitted: "It was a shock how, you know, I look at a person's body and say: 'Gosh, their body was like mine and look what it deteriorates to.'"

Such deterioration does not begin and end with appearances. As one worker confided: "When Mrs Jones isn't quite so well one day, and you've got diarrhoea from the toilet to the front door, you know you've got to be able to have a bit of stomach for the job to actually be able to clear that up."

The work, of course, tends to be poorly paid. Yet several workers in the study had degrees or were transitional staff, on their way to other roles in the care sector, such as social work or graduate nursing, or "resting" from their mainstream occupation. One worker was a dancer; another a singer-songwriter.

Many of the London workers were black, with race emerging as a key theme at that study site. As Ms Twigg acknowledges, some of the clients had "fairly racist" views that created potential tension. She quotes one woman saying: "I may be wrong here, but I think most white people, we have similar toilet habits - they may have quite different ones." Another said: "I'm sorry I have to say, I'm not anti-racial [sic] at all but some of these black girls are very arrogant and belligerent and rude."

In general, the black workers had become inured to such views. One said that "if I hear it and I find it offensive, then I'll be like 'oh, you're so cheeky, how can you say that?'" But one (male) worker, from Sierra Leone, turned the tables, remarking that in Africa "we don't have social care ... the relatives take care of their old people".

Ms Twigg confesses that writing the book was not an altogether comfortable experience. "I wanted to write about this topic, and not write in an evasive way," she said, "but I did put things down on the page and then ask myself: 'Can I really say this about Mrs so-and-so?'

"There was a tension between a wish to be unevasive and a wish not to lessen, to demean the people I was writing about. I found that quite difficult at the time and I suppose that it is one of the reasons this remains such a taboo area."

 Bathing - the Body and Community Care is published by Routledge at £15.99

"Being naked in the face of someone who is not, contains a powerful dynamic of domination and vulnerability, and it is often used in situations of interrogation and torture as a means of subjugating the individual." For the care worker, the initial experience of assisted bathing can be equally disconcerting. One London client, named as Sir Peter, said: "It's rather bad luck on the girls, scrubbing old gentlemen's backs." One worker admitted: "It was a shock how, you know, I look at a person's body and say: 'Gosh, their body was like mine and look what it deteriorates to.'" Such deterioration does not begin and end with appearances. As one worker confided: "When Mrs Jones isn't quite so well one day, and you've got diarrhoea from the toilet to the front door, you know you've got to be able to have a bit of stomach for the job to actually be able to clear that up." The work, of course, tends to be poorly paid. Yet several workers in the study had degrees or were transitional staff, on their way to other roles in the care sector, such as social work or graduate nursing, or "resting" from their mainstream occupation. One worker was a dancer; another a singer-songwriter. Many of the London workers were black, with race emerging as a key theme at that study site. As Ms Twigg acknowledges, some of the clients had "fairly racist" views that created potential tension. She quotes one woman saying: "I may be wrong here, but I think most white people, we have similar toilet habits - they may have quite different ones." Another said: "I'm sorry I have to say, I'm not anti-racial [sic] at all but some of these black girls are very arrogant and belligerent and rude." In general, the black workers had become inured to such views. One said that "if I hear it and I find it offensive, then I'll be like 'oh, you're so cheeky, how can you say that?'" But one (male) worker, from Sierra Leone, turned the tables, remarking that in Africa "we don't have social care ... the relatives take care of their old people". Ms Twigg confesses that writing the book was not an altogether comfortable experience. "I wanted to write about this topic, and not write in an evasive way," she said, "but I did put things down on the page and then ask myself: 'Can I really say this about Mrs so-and-so?' "There was a tension between a wish to be unevasive and a wish not to lessen, to demean the people I was writing about. I found that quite difficult at the time and I suppose that it is one of the reasons this remains such a taboo area."  Bathing - the Body and Community Care is published by Routledge at £15.99

webTitle: The wisdom of watching pennies

fields.headline: The wisdom of watching pennies
fields.trailText: Angela Roberts left home at l6 following difficulties with her parents. Now 21, and recovering from a drink problem, she has a three-year-old daughter, Nicole, and a new baby, Callum.
fields.body:
Angela Roberts left home at l6 following difficulties with her parents. Now 21, and recovering from a drink problem, she has a three-year-old daughter, Nicole, and a new baby, Callum.

Ms Roberts has lived independently since the age of 17 and has had three different tenancies, but has consistently run into financial problems. Until now. "I had a key meter for the gas which I couldn't always afford to charge, I had no bed for Nicole, and I was totally stressed with worry - I wasn't coping," she confessed. But then she saw a sign at the Brunswick for the living skills course and signed up.

"When young people get flats for the first time, they don't know where to go for cheap things - and that was my downfall," she said. "Now I know all the cheapest shops in town and I use them. I manage on £103 a week for the three of us. I've just had my benefit cut because the child support agency says I haven't told them enough about Nicole's father - the truth is that I didn't get the forms they insist they sent me - so I have to watch every penny.

"I use second-hand shops for cots and things like that, and put something in my bank account every week for the children. In January, I'm going back to college so I can get a decent job and support them."

webTitle: Children in care unlock emotions through poetry

fields.headline: Children in care unlock emotions through poetry
fields.standfirst: Anger, despair, joy and disappointment -  David Brindle  on a moving publication that offers an insight into the roller-coaster of emotions experienced by children in care
fields.trailText: Anger, despair, joy and disappointment - David Brindle on a moving publication that offers an insight into the roller-coaster of emotions experienced by children in care
fields.body:
Children in care must be haunted by what has happened to them, but all too often lack an outlet for their feelings. A new publication from Essex social services sets out to remedy that.

A Suitcase Full of Emotions is a slim volume of poems, stories and drawings by children and young people who are, or have been, in the department's care. Some contributions are funny; many are heart-rendingly sad. All offer a rare insight into why youngsters end up in care and their experiences there - bad and good.

In an impressive coup, Essex persuaded Andrew Motion, the poet laureate, to write a foreword to the collection. He calls it a "very touching" record of life for those in care. "But they also show care for themselves: care for words, for shape, for rhythm, for coherence and for self-expression," he said.

Seventeen-year-old Becky, one of the contributors, is now living with a family after being in children's homes. She said that at times she "found it easier to express my feelings in writing than to speak to people". John, also 17, said: "Writing was a very good way for me to release frustration and aggression and I would like to write some more in the future."

Sandra Coward, manager of children's residential services in Essex, said she has seen so much creative writing by youngsters that a publication was a natural progression. "There are some powerful messages to take on board. Many of the children have experienced a great deal of pain in their lives and that comes through very strongly in the book."

One of the most moving contributions is by Rosemary, 16, who writes in despair on being told she is to leave the home where she has settled and found the kind of support she never had from her mother.

"Love was a hard word for my mum - she did not like to cuddle me, I was only there to be shouted at and be hit when she was in anger," Rosemary said. "I think my life was supposed to be hard and [to] live without a dad who did not love me, a mum who rejected me because she had no one else to hurt except me - me, the person who looks like the person who hurt her so badly.

"For 16 years it has been hard and upsetting and ruined, but people say it will only get better in years to come. It won't, it will get harder to live alone and everything is still dragging along [because] of what's happened to me for 16 bloody years and I will never forget the hurt, heart-broken sexual abuse - used, not loved - that happened to me, it will come with me no matter where I will go or where I will end up."

I'd Like

I'd like to go home,

For them to leave me

alone,

I'd like hope in my Life

Not loads of strife.

I'd like to have my mother,

Or someone who cares,

Someone who wants me,

And will always be there.

I don't want much more

From my not so short life

Just someone to listen

And not WALK AWAY!

 Jodie, who wrote this poem for a forum organised by the It's My Life young people's group and Essex children's rights services.

A Notice

If you're happy, you will be and feel better

Don't feel sad feel happy, families don't want to see you sad.

Jump up and turn around and make a change,

a new start is just what you need

Be happy on home contact

Be nice to people in the home

Respect children's things, do not be naughty

or take the things and break them.

Be happy just what you want

Try and be good you never know,

you might go home with your Mum.

 Kimberley, 10, who lived in an Essex children's home

A suitcase full of emotions

Why must I always run

Forever searching

Always seeking

Never reaching

The bed left unmade

Coffee cups remain dirty

Goodbye!! never spoken

I gave you a suitcase

Full of emotions

Full of Hopes

Full of fears

Even the last of my secrets I

Gave to you

Leaving myself open wide

Vulnerable, defenceless

Exposed, torn away

All of myself on display

Every secret uncovered

All rocks left unturned

And still you come back for more

 Denise, 14, who lives in an Essex children's home

 A Suitcase Full of Emotions is on sale at Chelmsford library at £2. It can also be ordered by telephoning 01245-434247 or 01245-434179.

webTitle: Homeless face advice merry-go-round

fields.headline: Homeless face advice merry-go-round
fields.standfirst: Big money has been spent to stop us giving to beggars, but where is the funding for decent hostels for homeless people?
fields.trailText: Big money has been spent to stop us giving to beggars, but where is the funding for decent hostels for homeless people, asks Rodney Hedley
fields.body:
Homelessness tsar Louise Casey has advised us all, via a £400,000 advertising campaign, not to give money to beggars but give to charities that will help the homeless. But how helpful are these charities?

Appeals from housing charities are everywhere. They emphasise how they are dealing with the real social problems lurking behind the immediate tasks of sorting out accommodation. As one charity worker said to me recently: "Getting a roof over their head is the easiest thing to do; getting them to manage staying there is the real challenge."

I want to recount the experience of a 16-year-old woman who, on leaving foster care, was put into pretty awful bed and breakfast accommodation by her local social services department.

She was placed in a room in a filthy hotel in west London, with some dubious co-tenants. She had lost hope in her social worker, who did not seem to have the time or knowledge to find her more suitable accommodation.

The young woman visited my grant-making charity, the Hilden Charitable Fund, and, armed with the London Hostel Directory, she wrote to 24 homelessness charities explaining her circumstances and asking for help in finding a hostel place. In fact, her words were: "Maybe you could place me in the right direction."

Of the 24 agencies, seven did not reply. The other 17 all wrote back to her within three weeks. The letters were all written in a friendly way and most, but not all, of the agencies encouraged her to contact them by phone, giving a named member of staff.

However, only six charities had possible accommodation on offer for 16 to 18-year-olds. Eight of the charities referred the young woman to other charities, but they were charities already approached as part of the original 24.

So what are the lessons from this exercise? It was reassuring that the majority of charities did reply. The friendly letters were in stark contrast to her experience of the local council housing and social services departments. The replies gave her much confidence and helped her eventually find a good hostel. She is now settled there and is rebuilding her life.

But there are a few worrying things from this case study. Almost 30% of the agencies approached did not bother to reply - surely an unacceptable level.

This particular young woman was resourceful and wrote to a large number of charities, but most young people, especially those in difficult circumstances, may contact only a few. The chances of getting no help in such instances are therefore quite high.

Moreover, just as the friendly replies gave the girl some confidence - "some heart", as she put it - lack of response clearly lowered her motivation. And this was a young person already feeling unsupported by her social worker.

If we add to the seven charities that did not reply, the eight which referred her to other agencies, we have an advice merry-go-round. When homelessness agencies quote their advice statistics, we need to be clear how meaningful that advice is - otherwise we are simply double counting. They were hardly pointing the girl in the right direction.

Of course, the nub of the problem is the shortage of hostel provision for 16 to 18-year-olds. Of the six agencies that could offer provision, four turned out to be fully booked and the other two would have meant her moving to the other side of London. Fortunately, she eventually did find a good quality hostel - provided by the offender rehabilitation charity, Nacro, although she has no criminal history - near her family and her former school friends.

Odd, isn't it, that taxpayers' money is freely available to pay hefty sums for poor quality bed and breakfast accommodation, where no support is given, in contrast to funding enough decent hostels?

 Rodney Hedley is secretary to the trustees of the Hilden Charitable Fund, which is at 34 North End Road, London W14 0SH.
