webTitle: Social worker's death prompts reforms

fields.headline: Social worker's death prompts reforms
fields.standfirst: Inquiry criticises care agencies' poor safety procedures
fields.trailText: Inquiry criticises care agencies' poor safety procedures, writes Raekha Prasad
fields.body:
Two years after social worker Jenny Morrison was stabbed to death by a client in a south London hostel, health and social services have begun to overhaul the system that failed her. Following an inquiry into the killing, the regional NHS office has promised further checks to ensure reforms are implemented.

Ms Morrison, 51, had almost 20 years' experience as a social worker. On the day she died, she went to the Thurleigh Road hostel in Balham because of a deterioration in the condition of her client, Anthony Joseph, a paranoid schizophrenic.

The inquiry reported last week that when she went, unaccompanied, with Joseph into the hostel's isolated lounge - a room with no panic alarms and no easy escape route - she had not been told he had previously been convicted for carrying a knife, had threatened mental hospital staff and had a history of sleeping with a machete under his pillow. In addition, she was unaware that he had spoken about "demons" torturing him and that he had said she "would be brave" to see him.

Within minutes of their meeting, Joseph went to the hostel kitchen, fetched a knife and stabbed her more than 100 times. There was only one member of staff, a woman, on duty at the hostel.

Joseph has been convicted of manslaughter on grounds of diminished responsibility and sent to Broadmoor special hospital indefinitely.

The independent inquiry, chaired by barrister Peter Herbert, found that the risks Joseph posed to himself and others were "systematically underestimated". The inquiry report criticises Wandsworth council, which runs the hostel, and the South West London and St George's mental health trust, which coordinated his care, for "serious management and systems failures".

Ms Morrison had planned to meet Joseph in the company of the hostel's manager and deputy manager, but had problems with her car and had to get a lift, arriving before they did. Irrespective of this, the report criticises the hostel's failure to meet Wandsworth's own minimum requirement of at least two care staff on duty at all times.

In addition, it finds that inadequate, "ad hoc" sharing of vital information among professionals increased the likelihood of a fatality occurring. Neither Morrison nor the hostel staff were informed that Joseph had threatened his mother with a knife.

Hostel staff had also not been told that he had previously been charged with possession of a kitchen knife, or that he had made threatening phone calls to two nurses at the Maudsley hospital, south London,where he had been a patient.

Finally, the inquiry found there had been a three-week delay between hostel staff noticing that Joseph's behaviour had deteriorated and Ms Morrison being informed.

Joseph had become Ms Morrison's client in 1998 when he was discharged from Springfield. In contrast to his earlier discharge from the Maudsley, he received no written care plan, no risk assessment in accordance with the care programme approach, no systematic monitoring of his medication and no out-patient follow-up. The hostel was also found to lack proper emergency procedures.

The inquiry panel recommended improved hospital discharge procedures, staff training programmes, management procedures and supervision of medication. The council and the trust say they have already done much of this, but the London NHS region says it will be checking up.

Mr Herbert says the findings have national implications for mental health services. If Department of Health guidelines had been followed, there would have been less risk of a serious incident occurring.

webTitle: Town protests over asylum hostel plan

fields.headline: Town protests over asylum hostel plan
fields.standfirst: The spirit of the Socialist Republic of South Yorkshire was forged in the strikes of the 70s and 80s. But a row over a hostel for asylum seekers is now tarnishing the area's caring image
fields.trailText: The spirit of the Socialist Republic of South Yorkshire was forged in the strikes of the 70s and 80s. But a row over a hostel for asylum seekers is now tarnishing the area's caring image
fields.body:
A plan to open a hostel for asylum seekers has been thrown out after angry residents raised a storm of protest. They told their local council they feared that young children and elderly people would be put at risk and there would be a breakdown of law and order. The council said it understood their fears and turned down the proposal. Nobody was being racist, said councillors, but the hostel would be better placed somewhere else.

Such episodes may not be headline news these days, but this didn't take place in a shires village or a well-heeled suburb of a commuter belt town. It happened last month in a pit village near Rotherham, in the heartland of what was once known as the Socialist Republic of South Yorkshire. The planning board of Rotherham borough council, on which Labour holds 58 of the 66 seats, refused to give the go-ahead for 30 men to be given refuge in the village of Wath upon Dearne while their applications for asylum were being processed.

Those who remember the political action that centred on Sheffield and the nearby towns of Barnsley, Doncaster and Rotherham in the 70s and 80s may find it hard to believe that this could have happened in what was once a hotbed of socialism. After all, South Yorkshire threw open its arms to refugees from Chile who fled the Pinochet regime. Those asylum seekers - and others from across the globe - were warmly welcomed by communities throughout the county. In Sheffield, it was almost a state occasion when political activists were called to the City Hall ballroom to attend yet another welcoming party for refugees. What mattered above all else was that asylum seekers were made to feel at home.

And at home they felt. Few Saturdays went by in South Yorkshire without a demonstration in support of some cause or other, and refugees were actively encouraged to march side by side with their new found friends. This was where the victorious miners' strikes of 1972 and 1974 were masterminded. It was here that Sheffield city council continually attempted to frustrate the Conservative government of the 80s, and the council's new leader, a youthful David Blunkett, had the red flag flown over the town hall to the annoyance of Thatcher and her ministers.

Throughout the mines, the railways and the steel and engineering works, the socialist message rang out. Here, and overseas, fellow workers could count on the support of the rank and file in South Yorkshire. That, it seems, is no longer the way in at least one part of the "socialist republic".

In October, residents of Wath upon Dearne, a former mining community on the outskirts of Rotherham, learned that a planning application had gone before the borough council to change the use of a former residential nursing home to a 30-bed hostel for asylum seekers. Rotherham businessman Terry Watson, owner of the building, had tried for more than a year to find a buyer. It had stood empty as he sought to sell it as a nursing home, flats or a hotel, but he had been unable to stimulate any interest.

Mr Watson had reached an agreement with Safe Haven, a not-for-profit body, backed by a group of housing associations and sponsored by the Home Office, to turn the building into a hostel for refugees catering for up to 30 single men aged 18 to 30.

But the plan triggered an outcry among locals. Feelings ran high at public meetings. A petition, with more than 700 signatures, and numerous letters from individual residents were sent to the council demanding the scheme be thrown out.

Residents argued that the hostel should be sited on a council estate, not in a private residential area; that there would be an increase in crime, including vandalism and "social disorder"; and that property prices would fall. One resident claimed that parents would be "terrified of letting their children play out". Another asked: "Can we be assured there are no child abusers, drug addicts or convicted rapists among them?"

Only one local stood up in defiance and supported the plan. Ged Dempsey, a delegate to Rotherham trades council and a member of a number of human rights groups, called on the local authority to join with the trades council and local churches "to assist in demystifying, informing, challenging and breaking down the barriers to the issues involved".

Through the trades council, Mr Dempsey wrote to union branches and churches urging them to support his stand that asylum seekers were entitled to basic human rights and had been unjustly "stigmatised, alienated and segregated". He pointed out that the TUC's annual congress had agreed unanimously to defend the rights of asylum seekers.

He was later supported by a number of churchmen. The Rev Tim Leach, of All Saints Church in the village, was one of two who attended a public meeting and spoke on behalf of accepting the refugees. He said: "Among local residents, there were a good few who were not against the proposal. Regrettably, those who were against it were most vociferous."

Labour member Sheila Walker, who chairs the board, told the meeting: "I know what a close-knit community they are in Wath and this is not prejudice. This is nothing to do with racism. Another Labour councillor, Margaret Clark, said: "We live in a multicultural town, but some parts of Rotherham are more multicultural than others."

It was also stressed that the council considered there was a general lack of support services in the area, which would mean refugees having to travel five miles into Rotherham - a journey "inconvenient, unsettling and unsustainable".

He said: "If you take the line of argument about a lack of facilities to an ultimate conclusion, you would say that any area of the country which presently has no facilities for either asylum seekers or Britain's black and ethnic community should never accommodate people from these communities. webTitle: Charity links with NHS to take hearing aids into digital age

fields.headline: Charity links with NHS to take hearing aids into digital age
fields.standfirst: Alison Benjamin  reports on how the RNID has linked up with the government to modernise services for people with hearing problems
fields.trailText: Alison Benjamin reports on how the RNID has linked up with the government to modernise services for people with hearing problems
fields.body:
University Hospital Birmingham last week became the fourth NHS trust in England to launch a new-style audiology service, complete with state-of-the-art digital hearing aids, as part of a £10m project to bring services into the 21st century. The Royal National Institute for Deaf People (RNID) is at the forefront of this programme which warrants the label "groundbreaking" as much for its implementation, as its likely impact. For it is one of the first examples of a charity co-managing a Department of Health project.

The relationship between the RNID, the department and fellow partners - the NHS's purchasing and supplies agency and the Medical Research Council's institute of hearing research - has been testing. Initial discussions constantly verged on breakdown.

In one corner, the RNID was arguing for digital hearing aids to be universally available, insisting that the NHS's purchasing power - by far the largest in the world, with 600,000 aids bought each year - could reduce the £2,000 retail price to £75. In the other corner, NHS purchasing and supplies was challenging this premise and denying the figures. The charity also had to fight against the project becoming totally research-focused, instead of being the first wave of a national implementation stategy.

Five million people could benefit from wearing a hearing aid. This number includes more than half of all people over 60. Yet only 2m have one, and of these, a third hardly use them. Technology some 30 years out of date - which accounts for hearing aids that whistle and amplify background noise as much as speech - plus waiting lists of up to 18 months for a hearing aid test are just two of the reasons for the low take-up.

"Audiology is a derelict service," said John Lowe, director of technology at the RNID. "It's often out the back of a hospital, has no soundproof rooms to conduct hearing tests, is underfunded and staff morale is low. It's not a priority. After all, people don't die of hearing loss."

The first-wave project intends to evaluate the costs and benefits of digital hearing aids and to examine the most effective ways to provide them through the NHS. But it is not just about 20 NHS trusts buying the latest technology and making it widely available. It is about modernising the whole service. This involves recruiting extra staff, working with IT departments, buying computer equipment, developing new service protocols and training staff in those protocols, and in fitting digital hearing aids.

Having embarrassed the government, by highlighting the gulf between NHS hearing aids and their hi-tech counterparts available privately for £2,000, the RNID was asked by the health department in January to co-manage the project. Mr Lowe admits this came as a shock and was not easy for a campaigning organisation to accept.

"We had to think carefully if our involvement would be good or bad," he said. "We were flattered and we didn't want to respond to that. In the end, we thought the project would be more effective if we became part of the team." Having made clear that involvement would not silence its campaign to get the project rolled out across all audiology clinics, the charity took up the challenge.

The department says partnership-working is a key government objective. "We are using the RNID because of its expertise," said a spokesman, adding that views of the National Deaf Children's Society and British Deaf Association were also taken on board through a project reference group.

The RNID's project management role entailed recruiting a first-wave team, comprising a full-time member of staff responsible for the day-to-day running of the project, an assistant and a project audiologist - seconded on a part-time basis from the Royal Berkshire hospital in Reading - to advise on equipment, training and service delivery. In addition, much of Mr Lowe's time and that of James Strachan, RNID chief executive, is going into the project - not to mention the work of the charity's communications team in producing newsletters for audiology departments.

According to the charity, all this is paid for out of the £4m allocated by government for the project's first year. Some £2m is paying for digital hearing aids, £1.4m for computer equipment and the rest for extra staffing and training across the 15 trusts involved since April. Another five go live next April.

Approaching half of the 240 audiology departments in England applied to become a first-wave project. The 20 selected represent a cross-section - from large, well-equipped city clinics to small, rural outfits. The Royal United hospital in Bath has been fitting the Starkey Gemini behind-the-ear digital hearing aid since the end of September. Andrew Reid, the hospital's head of audiology, said: "It is a lot of stuff for the 10 staff to learn. There is ongoing training in using new audiology equipment and specialised computer software to programme the aids."

Independent researchers are based at each of the 20 trusts. Their job is to examine the cost benefits of digital hearing aids, compared to the analogue variety, using quality of life measures. They will also test whether two digital aids are better than one and the effectiveness of four different aids.

The audiology service currently costs the NHS £57m a year or £95 a person (£45 for the analogue hearing aid and £50 for the service). The RNID expects this to increase to a maximum of £138m a year or £230 a person (£150 for a digital aid and £80 for an improved service), although it firmly believes the cost of digital aids can be brought down with economies of scale once the project is rolled out to all audiology departments by 2004. The government has committed an initial £25m for this.

With partnership a much maligned term, Mr Strachan likens the charity's role vis-a-vis the government, to a joint business venture. "This is not contracting out," he said. "It is closer to seconding our expertise and knowledge to the Department of Health with both sides having contractual obligations."

Despite having started work in February, the contract was only signed last month after RNID lawyers advised that it could not be held to the delivery of a government project. Contract wording was changed to "best endeavours to coordinate".

For other charities thinking of taking a similar route, Mr Strachan said the key was to identify a problem and provide a solution by putting yourself in the shoes of government. "We came in as a catalyst, telling government that we could affect the lives of millions for relatively little money. Now that must be music to most ministers' ears."

Joy of hearing classical music

Kathleen Brown, 85, has had a hearing aid for 10 years. Last week she was fitted with a digital model at Bath's Royal United hospital. "Now I can hear what my two sons and their families are saying," she said. "I used to wear my old hearing aid all the time, but it was inadequate. I used to see they were talking, but because I couldn't hear the words, I'd ask a question and find out that was what they'd been talking about. It made me feel really stupid, especially when I was in a shop or having my eyes tested and my daughter-in-law had to act as an interpreter.

"When I was at prayer meetings I couldn't hear a word, so I'd turn up my hearing aid and there'd be a hissing noise. It was very embarrassing. People would turn round and look. Still I couldn't hear a word. I had to be in direct line with someone to hear what they were saying."

Mrs Brown said her lack of hearing stopped her going out and meeting new people. Now she is looking forward to getting back to her prayer meetings and listening to her collection of classical CDs and the radio without annoying the neighbours. "I love my music" she said. "It will be lovely to hear it without having to make it so loud."

Who it affects

 About 8.7m people in the UK (one in seven) have a hearing loss; three-quarters are over 60.

 Thirteen children in every 10,000 are born deaf or become deaf while very young - four of the 13 being profoundly deaf.

 Analogue hearing aids amplify sound, including background noise, which can drown out speech.

 Digital hearing aids can process sounds more precisely and can be finely adjusted to suit individuals and different sound environments.

webTitle: Where is the funding for hostels for the homeless?

fields.headline: Home begins at charity
fields.standfirst: Big money has been spent to stop us giving to beggars, but where is the funding for decent hostels for homeless people?
fields.trailText: Big money has been spent to stop us giving to beggars, but where is the funding for decent hostels for homeless people?
fields.body:
Homelessness tsar Louise Casey has advised us all, via a £400,000 advertising campaign, not to give money to beggars but give to charities that will help the homeless. But how helpful are these charities?

Appeals from housing charities are everywhere. They emphasise how they are dealing with the real social problems lurking behind the immediate tasks of sorting out accommodation. As one charity worker said to me recently: "Getting a roof over their head is the easiest thing to do; getting them to manage staying there is the real challenge."

I want to recount the experience of a 16-year-old woman who, on leaving foster care, was put into pretty awful bed and breakfast accommodation by her local social services department.

She was placed in a room in a filthy hotel in west London, with some dubious co-tenants. She had lost hope in her social worker, who did not seem to have the time or knowledge to find her more suitable accommodation.

The young woman visited my grant-making charity, the Hilden Charitable Fund, and, armed with the London Hostel Directory, she wrote to 24 homelessness charities explaining her circumstances and asking for help in finding a hostel place. In fact, her words were: "Maybe you could place me in the right direction."

Of the 24 agencies, seven did not reply. The other 17 all wrote back to her within three weeks. The letters were all written in a friendly way and most, but not all, of the agencies encouraged her to contact them by phone, giving a named member of staff.

However, only six charities had possible accommodation on offer for 16 to 18-year-olds. Eight of the charities referred the young woman to other charities, but they were charities already approached as part of the original 24.

So what are the lessons from this exercise? It was reassuring that the majority of charities did reply. The friendly letters were in stark contrast to her experience of the local council housing and social services departments. The replies gave her much confidence and helped her eventually find a good hostel. She is now settled there and is rebuilding her life.

But there are a few worrying things from this case study. Almost 30% of the agencies approached did not bother to reply - surely an unacceptable level.

This particular young woman was resourceful and wrote to a large number of charities, but most young people, especially those in difficult circumstances, may contact only a few. The chances of getting no help in such instances are therefore quite high.

Moreover, just as the friendly replies gave the girl some confidence - "some heart", as she put it - lack of response clearly lowered her motivation. And this was a young person already feeling unsupported by her social worker.

If we add to the seven charities that did not reply, the eight which referred her to other agencies, we have an advice merry-go-round. When homelessness agencies quote their advice statistics, we need to be clear how meaningful that advice is - otherwise we are simply double counting. They were hardly pointing the girl in the right direction.

Of course, the nub of the problem is the shortage of hostel provision for 16 to 18-year-olds. Of the six agencies that could offer provision, four turned out to be fully booked and the other two would have meant her moving to the other side of London. Fortunately, she eventually did find a good quality hostel - provided by the offender rehabilitation charity, Nacro, although she has no criminal history - near her family and her former school friends.

Odd, isn't it, that taxpayers' money is freely available to pay hefty sums for poor quality bed and breakfast accommodation, where no support is given, in contrast to funding enough decent hostels?

fields.bodyText: Homelessness tsar Louise Casey has advised us all, via a £400,000 advertising campaign, not to give money to beggars but give to charities that will help the homeless. But how helpful are these charities? Appeals from housing charities are everywhere. They emphasise how they are dealing with the real social problems lurking behind the immediate tasks of sorting out accommodation. As one charity worker said to me recently: "Getting a roof over their head is the easiest thing to do; getting them to manage staying there is the real challenge." I want to recount the experience of a 16-year-old woman who, on leaving foster care, was put into pretty awful bed and breakfast accommodation by her local social services department. She was placed in a room in a filthy hotel in west London, with some dubious co-tenants. She had lost hope in her social worker, who did not seem to have the time or knowledge to find her more suitable accommodation. The young woman visited my grant-making charity, the Hilden Charitable Fund, and, armed with the London Hostel Directory, she wrote to 24 homelessness charities explaining her circumstances and asking for help in finding a hostel place. In fact, her words were: "Maybe you could place me in the right direction." Of the 24 agencies, seven did not reply. The other 17 all wrote back to her within three weeks. The letters were all written in a friendly way and most, but not all, of the agencies encouraged her to contact them by phone, giving a named member of staff. However, only six charities had possible accommodation on offer for 16 to 18-year-olds. Eight of the charities referred the young woman to other charities, but they were charities already approached as part of the original 24. So what are the lessons from this exercise? It was reassuring that the majority of charities did reply. The friendly letters were in stark contrast to her experience of the local council housing and social services departments. The replies gave her much confidence and helped her eventually find a good hostel. She is now settled there and is rebuilding her life. But there are a few worrying things from this case study. Almost 30% of the agencies approached did not bother to reply - surely an unacceptable level. This particular young woman was resourceful and wrote to a large number of charities, but most young people, especially those in difficult circumstances, may contact only a few. The chances of getting no help in such instances are therefore quite high. Moreover, just as the friendly replies gave the girl some confidence - "some heart", as she put it - lack of response clearly lowered her motivation. And this was a young person already feeling unsupported by her social worker. If we add to the seven charities that did not reply, the eight which referred her to other agencies, we have an advice merry-go-round. webTitle: What carers and their clients feel about assisted bathing

fields.headline: Suds law
fields.standfirst: David Brindle  on a taboo-breaking book that reveals what carers and their clients feel about assisted bathing
fields.trailText: David Brindle on a taboo-breaking book that reveals what carers and their clients feel about assisted bathing
fields.body:
For many disabled and frail elderly people, assisted bathing is a godsend. "It's become the rose of my week," says one. "It's lovely, like being a baby again," says another. But despite such appreciation, and the critical importance of enabling people to continue living independently, help with bathing is a greatly overlooked aspect of social care.

Why? According to Julia Twigg, author of a new book from which the above comments are taken, there remains a real taboo on discussion of bodily needs. In social services, moreover, the prevailing culture rarely permits proper consideration of the intensely personal nature of helping somebody to wash. "Much has been written on managerial issues," she says, "but very little that addresses the frontline realities of giving such care."

Yet these realities raise a host of fascinating and challenging questions. Typically, an elderly person who as an adult may never have been seen naked by anybody except their spouse - and possibly not even by them - is expected to welcome a stranger into their home to help them with a most private act. That stranger, often young, may never before have seen an older person unclothed, in a society where ageing bodies are not visible.

And the generational differences do not end with physical appearance. Twigg recounts one episode where a young (female) care worker sought to wash the hair of an elderly (male) client. "How dare you!' he shouted. "I've never washed my hair in 30-odd years!"

The book, Bathing - the Body and Community Care, is a first and ambitious attempt to look comprehensively at what the author describes as a "missing dimension" in the analysis of community care. It is based on a study, funded by the economic and social research council, of assisted bathing services in two sharply contrasting localities: a relatively wealthy area of inner London, where clients included the titled, and a deprived coastal district, where most clients were defined as lower-middle or working class.

In all, 30 recipients of bathing help - 21 women and nine men - were interviewed either directly or, in the cases of three people with dementia, through their carers. Interviews were also conducted with 34 care workers - 31 women and three men - employed by social services or voluntary/private sector agencies, as well as four community nurses, three day centre staff and five frontline managers.

Twigg, reader in social policy at the University of Kent, found that receiving help had been an unwelcome development for most of the clients. "Crossing this boundary ... marks a major shift in people's lives," she writes. Nevertheless, most approached the issue "with stoicism".

One woman said: "Well, at the beginning I didn't like being personally washed, of course, but after six years I haven't got any more hold-ups [sic] about that ..." Another said that "you pretend it doesn't matter", but added: "There are some people who are very liberated and I don't know, they sunbathe and wash naked ... well, I am too old, a generation not thinking that way."

Some had set their own boundaries, such as insisting on washing intimate areas themselves. "She would do underneath if I let her," said one woman of her care worker, "but I said: 'No, if you don't mind Doreen, I'd rather do underneath myself.'"

Most women clients were adamant that they would not want a male bathing assistant. But this was not always a product of past prudishness: one woman confessed to having "liked fun and games in my time, but not now - no". As well as consciousness of their ageing bodies, this may reflect an acute awareness of what Twigg describes as the inherently unequal power dynamics of assisted bathing - an inequality emphasised by gender difference.

"One person, strong and able, stands above and over another who is frail and physically vulnerable, forced to rely on their strength and goodwill," the author writes. "Being naked in the face of someone who is not, contains a powerful dynamic of domination and vulnerability, and it is often used in situations of interrogation and torture as a means of subjugating the individual."

For the care worker, the initial experience of assisted bathing can be equally disconcerting. One London client, named as Sir Peter, said: "It's rather bad luck on the girls, scrubbing old gentlemen's backs." One worker admitted: "It was a shock how, you know, I look at a person's body and say: 'Gosh, their body was like mine and look what it deteriorates to.'"

Such deterioration does not begin and end with appearances. As one worker confided: "When Mrs Jones isn't quite so well one day, and you've got diarrhoea from the toilet to the front door, you know you've got to be able to have a bit of stomach for the job to actually be able to clear that up."

The work, of course, tends to be poorly paid. Yet several workers in the study had degrees or were transitional staff, on their way to other roles in the care sector, such as social work or graduate nursing, or "resting" from their mainstream occupation. One worker was a dancer; another a singer-songwriter.

Many of the London workers were black, with race emerging as a key theme at that study site. As Twigg acknowledges, some of the clients had "fairly racist" views that created potential tension. She quotes one woman saying: "I may be wrong here, but I think most white people, we have similar toilet habits - they may have quite different ones." Another said: "I'm sorry I have to say, I'm not anti-racial [sic] at all but some of these black girls are very arrogant and belligerent and rude."

In general, the black workers had become inured to such views. One said that "if I hear it and I find it offensive, then I'll be like 'oh, you're so cheeky, how can you say that?'" But one (male) worker, from Sierra Leone, turned the tables, remarking that in Africa "we don't have social care ... the relatives take care of their old people".

Twigg confesses that writing the book was not an altogether comfortable experience. "I wanted to write about this topic, and not write in an evasive way," she says, "but I did put things down on the page and then ask myself: 'Can I really say this about Mrs so-and-so?'

"There was a tension between a wish to be unevasive and a wish not to lessen, to demean the people I was writing about. I found that quite difficult at the time and I suppose that it is one of the reasons this remains such a taboo area."

&##149; Bathing - the Body and Community Care is published by Routledge at £15.99

webTitle: Robert Bennett on the injustice of a benefits loophole

fields.headline: Bedtime story
fields.standfirst: Robert Bennett on the injustice of a benefits loophole
fields.trailText: Robert Bennett on the injustice of a benefits loophole
fields.body:
Norman McKillop-Concannon is an angry man. And he has good reason to be - having spent eight weeks sleeping on the tiled floor of an empty council flat after the benefits agency turned down his plea for help because of what appears a glaring anomaly.

The 54-year-old Sheffield engineer has worked most of his life. He has experienced redundancy two or three times when the city's engineering industry hit hard times, but has always managed to find another job quickly. He has always paid his dues and kept his national insurance payments up-to-date against the day when his luck would change.

And it did change. Five years ago, his skin reacted to a new industrial lubricating oil and he developed a painful and ugly looking dermatitis - a condition which left him with an allergic reaction to most oils.

Unable to work in the trade he knew, he took a succession of caretaking jobs. Each time, though, the skin condition came back and forced him out. He coped until May, when he had to give up a job as a gardener/ handyman in Dore after the skin condition flared again. Without a wage, he had to apply for housing benefit.

This was when the problems started. McKillop-Concannon became one of thousands of people let down by CSL, the company which took over the administration of housing benefit from Sheffield council's in-house service. Such a backlog of claims built up that hundreds of tenants faced eviction.

McKillop-Concannon was one of those who were evicted. He lost the furnished flat he had lived in for 27 years. But he bears no grudge against his landlady - and he even shrugs his shoulders over CSL's record. "These things happen," he says, "and there are other people who've been hit a lot harder than me."

The deep resentment he carries around with him stems from what happened next. Knowing he was about to become homeless, he contacted the council's housing department which found him an unfurnished flat in the Broomhall area of Sheffield. All he needed was some basic furniture - a cooker and a bed - and he could start rebuilding his life again.

Not a problem, he thought. He went to the benefits agency and applied for a community care grant from the social fund to buy the basics. But his application was turned down - he was left to sleep on the hard, tiled floor of the flat, unable to cook for himself, and nursing a growing anger.

"I don't want anyone to go through what I've gone through," he says. "I have had to put up with so much crap from an organisation that's supposed to be there to meet social need, but doesn't seem to give a damn about people.

"For three months I've been told to fill in this form and that form, and never once has anyone asked me how I'm coping. Never once have they asked me if I needed any extra help or suggested somewhere I could go for help."

After filling out the forms, the agency told him he did not qualify for a grant because he was not receiving income support or income-based jobseeker's allowance. "After looking at your application and personal circumstances, we have decided the qualifying conditions for a payment from the social fund are not satisfied," said the letter turning down his application.

At first, McKillop-Concannon thought it was just a mistake: after all, he was getting jobseeker's allowance. "But," he now says, "it wasn't the right kind of jobseeker's allowance, apparently."

His allowance did not count because it was contribution-based, not means-tested. "In other words, the fact that I had paid my contributions up-to-date meant I couldn't get the help I needed. It's insane. I was sleeping on the floor; I didn't have a cooker and I still couldn't get help because I'd been such a good boy and paid into the system.

"What was worse was the way I was treated. I was made to feel like a scrounger - like someone begging for help they had no right to. They treated me as if I was trying to con the system."

McKillop-Concannon was told he would have to wait six months. Only then would he become qualified for means-tested benefits, in turn qualifying him for help from the social fund. "If I hadn't qualified for contribution-based support - if I hadn't paid my stamps - I could have got help straight away," he says. "It's madness."

His complaints and requests for a review produced another rejection and, at the end of August, he applied for a crisis loan. That was turned down, too. Sleeping on the floor with nothing to cook on did not amount to a risk to the "health or safety" of a 54-year-old. But he appealed again and, after an interview, his application was reconsidered and he has received a loan of £320.

There is now a bed and a cooker in his flat and, thanks to the concern of the caretaker of his block of flats, he has a three-piece suite and a couple of bits and pieces that somebody else threw out. The housing benefit he applied for in May finally arrived last month, but he has just been diagnosed as clinically depressed - the first time in his life he has ever been "anywhere near depression".

The benefits agency admits that cases such as McKillop-Concannon's are "a difficult area". A spokesman says: "On the other hand, we have to have rules to prevent people who can afford to live off their own income, from claiming the benefits that are there for people who can't - and given that fact, a line has to be drawn somewhere."

webTitle: Front...to back

fields.headline: Front...to back
fields.trailText: Fizzled out
fields.body:
Fizzled out A fire which started in a faulty fridge motor at a luxury home in Sevenoaks, Kent, was extinguished when six bottles of champagne exploded and doused it.
Metro, 6.12.00 (Heather Gould, Newcastle upon Tyne)

Flight delayed A racing pigeon has been retired after returning to its home in West Kingsdown, Kent, seven years after being released in Nottingham.
East Anglian Daily Times, 27.11.00 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Parking fee An 8ft x 20ft garage in Chelsea, west London, has been sold to a young City worker for £120,000.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 5.12.00 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Angle wrangle Dustbin collections in Blackburn and Darwen, Lancashire, have been banned by council officials if the lids are open by more than 45 degrees.
Lancashire Evening Telegraph, 8.11.00 (R Pandor, Blackburn)

Snack attack A man was jailed for attempting to rob a bank in Torbay, Devon, by sticking a Twiglet into a cashier's ribs and telling her it was a gun.
Torbay and South Devon Herald Express, 6.12.00 (John Hoyle, Broadhempston)

Hard but fair The chief character witness for an 18-year-old youth appearing at Flintshire magistrates court on a charge of driving while disqualified was the police sergeant who arrested him.
Mold and Buckley Chronicle, 1.12.00 (L Sylvia, Wrexham)

Down in price Valley Parade, the football stadium of Premiership relegation strugglers Bradford City, is up for sale at £140 in a Yorkshire version of the Monopoly board game.
Bradford Telegraph and Argus, 29.11.00

Santa sentries A team of former soldiers has been hired by the Tesco supermarket chain to guard a 660-acre pine plantation to prevent thefts of Christmas trees.
York Evening Press, 8.12.00 (C Milton, Haxby)

Baa-baas? The referee of a rugby match at Churchdown, Gloucestershire, ordered the teams to carry on playing after all attempts had failed to get a sheep off the pitch.
Western Daily Press, 7.12.00 (Hetty Fletcher, Budleigh Salterton)

Self-service Two sacks of mail found dumped in a street in Newcastle upon Tyne had a note attached, saying: 'Please deliver these - it is my day of rest.'
Newcastle Evening Chronicle, 4.12.00 (K Jensen, Hartlepool)

No tea dance Planning permission has been sought to convert a former Temperance Society hall in Keighley, Yorkshire, into a nightclub.
Bradford Telegraph and Argus, 28.11.00 (John Rossington, Bradford)

Hopeful sign A woman from Southampton has had the national lottery's new logo tattooed on her back in the hope that it will bring her luck.
Southampton Daily Echo, 1.12.00 (K Popple, Southampton)

Shell shocks Shopkeepers in Bridlington, Yorkshire, are asking young customers to provide proof they are 18 if they want to buy eggs, following a series of incidents in which eggs were thrown at elderly people.
Metro Midlands, 4.12.00 (Stanley A Holland, Bournville)

Goldilocked The owner of a flat in Gloucester came home to find a burglar asleep in his bed.
Sunday Independent, 3.12.00 (Carol Pink, Bigbury-on-Sea)

webTitle: Ecological criteria for planning offer hope for green homes

fields.headline: A life less ordinary
fields.standfirst: Ecological criteria for planning offer hope for green homes
fields.trailText: Ecological criteria for planning offer hope for green homes
fields.body:
Five years ago "Peter" bought 20 hectares (50 acres) of West Country woodland for £30,000. Instead of a bathroom, he has a stream to wash in. Rather than a flush loo, he has a compost toilet. People might say he's roughing it, but Peter says he's simply combining the old ways with the best of the new.

A tarpaulin is the only protection from the elements. The main "room" is a part of the woods. He also has two comfortable "benders" - traditional gypsy dwellings with tarpaulin cover over bent hazel poles, with a raised floor. Mod cons include phone, laptop and email.

Peter has never made a secret of living in the woods and has a good working relationship with neighbouring landowners, who are helping him try to establish a new public footpath across the woods. "What is the point of having these magnificent native woodlands if they can't be shared," he says.

But neither does he - and a growing number of people who have taken to building their own "green homes" - advertise his presence. A sympathetic local planner received a complaint about him but advised Peter to keep his head down and get on with it. He can see a value in what Peter's doing. "If I had to chase every hippie out of a wood round here I wouldn't be able to get my job done," he says. But not all planners take that attitude.

For the meantime, Peter is content to manage his wood, understanding that some day soon, even though he owns the land, he may have this most modest home pulled down under a planning enforcement order.

Woodland is popular for many renegade builders. It's easier to keep out of the way and there's a supply of heating and building material. As soon as the issue of planning permission comes up, though, the problems start. On advice from planners, council committees are ruling that the vast majority of those who do this are illegal.

Those that build first and answer questions later are forced into hiding. But the longer they are resident, the more likely they'll be able to stay, so there are many people around the country keeping their heads down.

Simon Ormerod built without permission. With a lifelong interest in renewable energy, he set out in 1994 to design a house that didn't need mains gas or electricity. The planners refused to answer his written requests. On his second attempt to get planning permission for his earth-sheltered dwelling near Wadebridge, Cornwall, he went to see the local director of planning, who was less than sympathetic. "Try this and I'll have you out within a fortnight," Ormerod was told.

When he was finally granted planning five years later, one of the councillors on the committee wanted to know why he didn't ask first. "I did, but you turned me down twice," he replied.

Cotswold sculptor Jack Everett and his partner, Emma Iveson, wanted to build their own home. Seventeen years ago they bought a disused quarry and woods for £1,000. They are determined to look after the land and make it the permanent family home.

Three wooden buildings have been built since - a comfortable tai chi practice space, a studio and the couple's modest home. Strong wooden piles support tiered floor spaces within the steep sloping quarry. Woodburning stoves, fed from the surrounding woods, keep the open-plan spaces warm. Water is harvested from the roofs, stored in tanks under the building and pumped up to the bath, hot tub and sauna. Sheep's wool and thick cork insulate the walls, floors and roofs of the buildings, and a low-flush composting system deals with kitchen and human waste.

Over the years, they've spent about £25,000 on the three buildings. "Since we both live and work from the quarry, that's not bad," Everett says. "The difficulty is that the renewal of temporary planning permission creates phases of corrosive insecurity.

"The planners can force you to take it down or return it to the state it was in before you repaired it. Or they will do it themselves, then charge and fine you out of existence."

They are now living openly with their three children in the quarry, but back in the early 90s it was a clandestine existence. Today, they're good friends with their neighbours and they have a comfortable home, but the fear of demolition remains.

Tony Wrench's turf-roofed home in the Pembrokeshire national park, Brithdir Mawr, was spotted by planners from the air in October 1998. He and his "lost tribe" have been given notice to pull the house down by local planners. Now that he has appealed, the Welsh Assembly looks set finally to decide its fate.

But help may be at hand. Ecological criteria can now be used when considering the "sustainability" of projects, and legally binding conditions can be put on planning permission. The 15 criteria drawn up by planning consultancy Chapter 7 is being increasingly seen as a test for rural development. They take into account car use, effect on the landscape, building materials, water and other utilities, biodiversity and social accountability.

The criteria will be an acid test for planners and volume developers alike. Only if they're prepared to explore the use of well-defined ecological standards such as these will they gain "sustainable"credibility.

For those who decide to build, the rewards can be a long time coming. Members of the Kingshill community, near Glastonbury, who have been living in fear of eviction from their own land for more than six years, have only just got full planning permission.

 The Chapter 7 website is at www.oneworld.org/tlio/chapter7/

webTitle: RNID links with  government to take hearing aids into the digital age

fields.headline: Sound advice
fields.standfirst: Alison Benjamin  reports on how the RNID has linked up with the government to take hearing aids into the digital age
fields.trailText: Alison Benjamin reports on how the RNID has linked up with the government to take hearing aids into the digital age
fields.body:
University Hospital Birmingham last week became the fourth NHS trust in England to launch a new-style audiology service, complete with state-of-the-art digital hearing aids, as part of a £10m project to bring services into the 21st century. The Royal National Institute for Deaf People (RNID) is at the forefront of this programme which warrants the label "groundbreaking" as much for its implementation, as its likely impact. For it is one of the first examples of a charity co-managing a Department of Health project.

The relationship between the RNID, the department and fellow partners - the NHS's purchasing and supplies agency and the Medical Research Council's institute of hearing research - has been testing. Initial discussions constantly verged on breakdown.

In one corner, the RNID was arguing for digital hearing aids to be universally available, insisting that the NHS's purchasing power - by far the largest in the world, with 600,000 aids bought each year - could reduce the £2,000 retail price to £75. In the other corner, NHS purchasing and supplies was challenging this premise and denying the figures. The charity also had to fight against the project becoming totally research-focused, instead of being the first wave of a national implementation stategy.

Five million people could benefit from wearing a hearing aid. This number includes more than half of all people over 60. Yet only 2m have one, and of these, a third hardly use them. Technology some 30 years out of date - which accounts for hearing aids that whistle and amplify background noise as much as speech - plus waiting lists of up to 18 months for a hearing aid test are just two of the reasons for the low take-up.

"Audiology is a derelict service," says John Lowe, director of technology at the RNID. "It's often out the back of a hospital, has no soundproof rooms to conduct hearing tests, is underfunded and staff morale is low. It's not a priority. After all, people don't die of hearing loss."

The first-wave project intends to evaluate the costs and benefits of digital hearing aids and to examine the most effective ways to provide them through the NHS. But it is not just about 20 NHS trusts buying the latest technology and making it widely available. It is about modernising the whole service. This involves recruiting extra staff, working with IT departments, buying computer equipment, developing new service protocols and training staff in those protocols, and in fitting digital hearing aids.

Having embarrassed the government, by highlighting the gulf between NHS hearing aids and their hi-tech counterparts available privately for £2,000, the RNID was asked by the health department in January to co-manage the project. Low admits this came as a shock and was not easy for a campaigning organisation to accept.

"We had to think carefully if our involvement would be good or bad," he says. "We were flattered and we didn't want to respond to that. In the end, we thought the project would be more effective if we became part of the team." Having made clear that involvement would not silence its campaign to get the project rolled out across all audiology clinics, the charity took up the challenge.

The department says partnership-working is a key government objective. "We are using the RNID because of its expertise," says a spokesman, adding that views of the National Deaf Children's Society and British Deaf Association were also taken on board through a project reference group.

The RNID's project management role entailed recruiting a first-wave team, comprising a full-time member of staff responsible for the day-to-day running of the project, an assistant and a project audiologist - seconded on a part-time basis from the Royal Berkshire hospital in Reading - to advise on equipment, training and service delivery. In addition, much of Lowe's time and that of James Strachan, RNID chief executive, is going into the project - not to mention the work of the charity's communications team in producing newsletters for audiology departments.

According to the charity, all this is paid for out of the £4m allocated by government for the project's first year. Some £2m is paying for digital hearing aids, £1.4m for computer equipment and the rest for extra staffing and training across the 15 trusts involved since April. Another five go live next April.

Approaching half of the 240 audiology departments in England applied to become a first-wave project. The 20 selected represent a cross-section - from large, well-equipped city clinics to small, rural outfits. The Royal United hospital in Bath has been fitting the Starkey Gemini behind-the-ear digital hearing aid since the end of September. Andrew Reid, the hospital's head of audiology, says: "It is a lot of stuff for the 10 staff to learn. There is ongoing training in using new audiology equipment and specialised computer software to programme the aids."

Independent researchers are based at each of the 20 trusts. Their job is to examine the cost benefits of digital hearing aids, compared to the analogue variety, using quality of life measures. They will also test whether two digital aids are better than one and the effectiveness of four different aids.

The audiology service currently costs the NHS £57m a year or £95 a person (£45 for the analogue hearing aid and £50 for the service). The RNID expects this to increase to a maximum of £138m a year or £230 a person (£150 for a digital aid and £80 for an improved service), although it firmly believes the cost of digital aids can be brought down with economies of scale once the project is rolled out to all audiology departments by 2004. The government has committed an initial £25m for this.

With partnership a much maligned term, Strachan likens the charity's role vis-a-vis the government, to a joint business venture. "This is not contracting out," he says. "It is closer to seconding our expertise and knowledge to the Department of Health with both sides having contractual obligations."

Despite having started work in February, the contract was only signed last month after RNID lawyers advised that it could not be held to the delivery of a government project. Contract wording was changed to "best endeavours to coordinate".

For other charities thinking of taking a similar route, Strachan says the key is to identify a problem and provide a solution by putting yourself in the shoes of government. "We came in as a catalyst, telling government that we could affect the lives of millions for relatively little money. Now that must be music to most ministers' ears."

Joy of hearing classical music

Kathleen Brown, 85, has had a hearing aid for 10 years. Last week she was fitted with a digital model at Bath's Royal United hospital. "Now I can hear what my two sons and their families are saying," she says. "I used to wear my old hearing aid all the time, but it was inadequate. I used to see they were talking, but because I couldn't hear the words, I'd ask a question and find out that was what they'd been talking about. It made me feel really stupid, especially when I was in a shop or having my eyes tested and my daughter-in-law had to act as an interpreter.

"When I was at prayer meetings I couldn't hear a word, so I'd turn up my hearing aid and there'd be a hissing noise. It was very embarrassing. People would turn round and look. Still I couldn't hear a word. I had to be in direct line with someone to hear what they were saying."

Brown says her lack of hearing stopped her going out and meeting new people. Now she is looking forward to getting back to her prayer meetings and listening to her collection of classical CDs and the radio without annoying the neighbours. "I love my music" she says. "It will be lovely to hear it without having to make it so loud."

Who it affects

 About 8.7m people in the UK (one in seven) have a hearing loss; three-quarters are over 60.

 Thirteen children in every 10,000 are born deaf or become deaf while very young - four of the 13 being profoundly deaf.

 Analogue hearing aids amplify sound, including background noise, which can drown out speech.

 Digital hearing aids can process sounds more precisely and can be finely adjusted to suit individuals and different sound environments.

webTitle: Profile:   Fiona Reynolds, new head of the National Trust

fields.headline: The hunt for solutions
fields.trailText: Profile: Fiona Reynolds, new head of the National Trust
fields.body:
The woman set to take the helm of the National Trust claims not to have a personal view on hunting. Yet the hunting bill was one of the priorities in the Queen's speech and the trust still allows hunting on its land. Fiona Reynolds, the 42-year-old director-general designate, insists that "my challenge is to look at a whole range of other things".

These things include managing one of Britain's largest charities with more than 2.5m members, 612,000 acres of land and 600 miles of coastline. On top of this, there is the upkeep of 250 historic houses, gardens and industrial buildings and 60m visitors a year to entertain. Annual expenditure on conservation and maintenance is £148m.

Sitting in an armchair at the trust's headquarters overlooking St James Park in London, Reynolds appears feisty, full of energy and ready to shake off the dusty image of the 105-year-old charity. "The trust has to some extent a caricature image, not necessarily a negative one, but an image of grand country houses," she says. "Whereas the breadth of what we do in relation to the countryside, and the huge responsibility as a land manager, mean we should be seen as a much more influential body.

"I'm hoping to draw together some clear ambitions for the trust, including the leadership role we can play in relation to the countryside and regeneration of land."

One of Reynolds's key concerns is what she sees as a general resignation that the countryside is in crisis. "I think the trust has a really powerful role to play in helping to find solutions. Our experience of investing in solutions which are economically viable, as well as environ- mentally and socially sustainable, gives us the opportunity to show other landowners and people in the countryside what is possible."

Reynolds, a married mother of three, talks as if she has been part of the National Trust furniture for a long time. In fact she has, joining a regional committee in her early 20s - "probably one of the youngest ever", she lets slip. Along with a local group called the Save Sutton House campaign, Reynolds fought successfully for the trust to restore the rare Tudor house it owned in Hackney, east London. At the time, it was boarded up and inhabited by squatters and the trust was at a loss to know what to do. Reynolds and her team fulfilled a vision of making it accessible for community use and education. "We wanted to make it a place where children could come in and really explore."

She is also proud of her campaigning role at the Council for the Protection of Rural England (CPRE), where she was director from 1992-98 and tackled issues such as housing development, energy supply and transport. At the end of her tenure, she was awarded a CBE for services to agro-environment and conservation.

As well as her experience of campaigning on countryside issues, Reynolds has just spent two years on the inside track of government as director of the women's unit at the Cabinet Office. "That experience was enormously important, understanding how policy is made and implemented and working on issues that cut across different departments," she says.

Although she was happy there, a friend spotted the National Trust's advertisement for a new director-general - a bait she found "pretty irresistible". The incumbent, Martin Drury, who has been with the trust for 27 years, retires from the £110,000-plus post at the end of the month.

Although she does not officially start until January, Reynolds has already embarked on a punishing schedule of visits to properties, from tin mines in Cornwall to a lighthouse on the north-east coast. She disagrees with the idea of the trust handing over some of its enormous wealth to other charities, but does applaud the increasing practice of working in partnership. "I've been struck by how we are almost acting like an RDA [regional development agency] or an investment agency, because we raise money through a whole range of mechanisms, including from our members, and then distribute it around the country."

Reynolds is very definite about the trust's number one stakeholder. "I have a very clear view that the people to whom the trust is accountable are the public. It was founded in 1895 for public benefit." However, she acknowledges the "crucial" role of members and points to some evidence that the membership is getting younger. Reasons for joining are also becoming more environmental, rather than to gain a season ticket to land and properties.

Reynolds would also like to capitalise on increasing public interest in the quality of food and organic production. "We are quite interested in the marketing of rare breeds or other forms of products from the land that we can show have been farmed sensitively. One thing that is certain - the issue of environmental responsibility has been rising up the agenda in the trust for the last 20-30 years. We have been making tremendous efforts to show that we think and act as green as we can."

Reynolds borders on evangelical with her vision for the future. "Our dependence on volunteers is extraordinary - there are just under 4,000 full-time staff in the trust but nearly 40,000 volunteers - half the work the trust does is done by volunteers, which is an extraordinary figure. The trust sees providing opportunities and rewarding volunteers as one of the main ways it can get its job done and involve people and help spread the message about what the trust does.

"Inclusiveness is a very 'pc' word, but actually a very meaningful one, and it is very important for an organisation like the trust. It is an amazing thing to have been here for 100 years and I want to make sure it lasts another 100 when all of us will be gone. And the reason it will be is because we have tapped into the hearts and minds of people. This is what will provide it with the sustenance to ensure its survival."

On top of this, there is the upkeep of 250 historic houses, gardens and industrial buildings and 60m visitors a year to entertain. Annual expenditure on conservation and maintenance is £148m. Sitting in an armchair at the trust's headquarters overlooking St James Park in London, Reynolds appears feisty, full of energy and ready to shake off the dusty image of the 105-year-old charity. "The trust has to some extent a caricature image, not necessarily a negative one, but an image of grand country houses," she says. "Whereas the breadth of what we do in relation to the countryside, and the huge responsibility as a land manager, mean we should be seen as a much more influential body. "I'm hoping to draw together some clear ambitions for the trust, including the leadership role we can play in relation to the countryside and regeneration of land." One of Reynolds's key concerns is what she sees as a general resignation that the countryside is in crisis. "I think the trust has a really powerful role to play in helping to find solutions. Our experience of investing in solutions which are economically viable, as well as environ- mentally and socially sustainable, gives us the opportunity to show other landowners and people in the countryside what is possible." Reynolds, a married mother of three, talks as if she has been part of the National Trust furniture for a long time. In fact she has, joining a regional committee in her early 20s - "probably one of the youngest ever", she lets slip. Along with a local group called the Save Sutton House campaign, Reynolds fought successfully for the trust to restore the rare Tudor house it owned in Hackney, east London. At the time, it was boarded up and inhabited by squatters and the trust was at a loss to know what to do. Reynolds and her team fulfilled a vision of making it accessible for community use and education. "We wanted to make it a place where children could come in and really explore." She is also proud of her campaigning role at the Council for the Protection of Rural England (CPRE), where she was director from 1992-98 and tackled issues such as housing development, energy supply and transport. At the end of her tenure, she was awarded a CBE for services to agro-environment and conservation. As well as her experience of campaigning on countryside issues, Reynolds has just spent two years on the inside track of government as director of the women's unit at the Cabinet Office. "That experience was enormously important, understanding how policy is made and implemented and working on issues that cut across different departments," she says. Although she was happy there, a friend spotted the National Trust's advertisement for a new director-general - a bait she found "pretty irresistible". The incumbent, Martin Drury, who has been with the trust for 27 years, retires from the £110,000-plus post at the end of the month. Although she does not officially start until January, Reynolds has already embarked on a punishing schedule of visits to properties, from tin mines in Cornwall to a lighthouse on the north-east coast. She disagrees with the idea of the trust handing over some of its enormous wealth to other charities, but does applaud the increasing practice of working in partnership. "I've been struck by how we are almost acting like an RDA [regional development agency] or an investment agency, because we raise money through a whole range of mechanisms, including from our members, and then distribute it around the country." Reynolds is very definite about the trust's number one stakeholder. "I have a very clear view that the people to whom the trust is accountable are the public. It was founded in 1895 for public benefit." However, she acknowledges the "crucial" role of members and points to some evidence that the membership is getting younger. Reasons for joining are also becoming more environmental, rather than to gain a season ticket to land and properties. Reynolds would also like to capitalise on increasing public interest in the quality of food and organic production. "We are quite interested in the marketing of rare breeds or other forms of products from the land that we can show have been farmed sensitively. One thing that is certain - the issue of environmental responsibility has been rising up the agenda in the trust for the last 20-30 years. We have been making tremendous efforts to show that we think and act as green as we can." Reynolds borders on evangelical with her vision for the future. "Our dependence on volunteers is extraordinary - there are just under 4,000 full-time staff in the trust but nearly 40,000 volunteers - half the work the trust does is done by volunteers, which is an extraordinary figure. The trust sees providing opportunities and rewarding volunteers as one of the main ways it can get its job done and involve people and help spread the message about what the trust does. "Inclusiveness is a very 'pc' word, but actually a very meaningful one, and it is very important for an organisation like the trust. It is an amazing thing to have been here for 100 years and I want to make sure it lasts another 100 when all of us will be gone. And the reason it will be is because we have tapped into the hearts and minds of people. This is what will provide it with the sustenance to ensure its survival."

webTitle: Readers' letters

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Cambridge count | Battle of Hastings | Appropriate behaviour? | Spending power
fields.body:
Cambridge count

The Cambridge councillors spouting off about why they don't think a winter shelter is needed for the homeless in the city this year (Letters, December 13) miss out a vital piece of information - the council very recently did a street count and found 19 people sleeping rough, with an additional four people sleeping on the floor of one of the local hostels.

This was after the extra 20 move-on places, which the councillors seem to think is the total answer, had been made available for the homeless and quickly filled up. The hostel and shelter spaces that then became freed had been filled up too. So Alexander Masters' figures in his Society article were, after all, pretty accurate.

Like him, I am alarmed by the intense opposition to a winter shelter this year, from central and local government. Does it take a death on the streets to make people take note? But I forgot, we've recently had one: someone died from exposure while sleeping rough in Cambridge, and it seems that no one took a blind bit of notice.

Winter shelters are far from being the total solution, but they are a vital part of it. As the councillors say, local frontline workers support the provision of move-on housing. They also want a winter shelter but cannot say so, for fear of losing their jobs and fear of their agencies' money being cut.

Incidentally, the new permanent housing which has been made available by the council, and which was so quickly filled, only replaces the housing that local charity Wintercomfort set up but had to dismantle after the arrest of its director, Ruth Wyner, and project manager, John Brock, the so-called Cambridge Two.

Lucy Kyle
Cambridge

Battle of Hastings

Although arguably the largest and most rapid development in the history of Hastings took place during the last century, it is far from a "Victorian seaside town" (Road rage, December 13).

King Harold is recorded as calling into the harbour here in 1066 to call on the already long-established fishing community to back him in his forthcoming battle with the Normans. The name itself is derived from the Saxon "Haestingas", meaning "the place of Haesting".

The town had survived well over a millennium before the arrival of the Victorians, with fishing, agriculture and iron smelting its main industries.

It was during the Victorian era that the rot began to set in, with, for example, despoilation of the beautiful coast to have a "prom". This has continued to the present day, and Roger Harrabin is right to identify the influx of large numbers of people from poor areas of London adding to the depression within the town.

I fear that the despoilation of this once most beautiful of towns and its surrounds is set to continue with the building of a pointless, and environmentally-damaging bypass very much on the cards.

Steve Potter
Hastings

Appropriate behaviour?

As a trainer of "appropriate adults", I was concerned at some of the points made by Karen Liebreich and her role as a voluntary appropriate adult (AA) in Hounslow, west London (Lessons for life, December 13).

Given that one of the main roles of the AA is to support the young person in the hostile environment of the police station, and if necessary challenge the police, she should not be accepting "rides home in squad cars". She also does not seem to realise that at the time she is being the AA, all the young people she is working with are innocent. All her deductions seem based on an assumption of guilt.

She does not seem to have queried the appropriateness of the questioning of those with "special needs", or sought an alternative AA with learning difficulties training. Her simplistic attitudes to parenting, education, benefits and family transmission theories raise serious concerns about the level of training she has been given by social services or the young offender team she is representing.

Research for the royal commission on criminal justice, conducted more than 10 years ago, found that many AAs did not understand the role, colluded with police and rarely opened their mouths in the interview. It seems that things have not changed much since then.

Denis W Jones

Seaford, East Sussex

 Does Hounslow pay an allowance and mileage to their appropriate adults? If so, I might not have to worry about "a recently arrived Somali boy" making it back in the dark on his own to his "undoubtedly depressing hostel" and explaining to his aunt about final warnings, court appearances and recent "interrogation" in a police station.

Am I alone in remembering when this service to children was given greater priority by local authorities?

Stephen Boote
Liverpool

Spending power

You state (Pump action, December 6) that total spending by "local" - parish and small town - councils cannot exceed £3.50 per elector in a financial year (often known colloquially as the "free resource" although, of course, it is not "free" at all).

This is incorrect. Local councils have a wide range of powers enshrined in legislation, and they can spend as much as they wish - or they think their electorate will stand - in exercising those powers. A local council is only restricted in spending on functions for which there is no defined statutory authority. If a council wants to carry out activities not specifically permitted in legislation, then it is limited to the total of the free resource.

Louise Fuller
town clerk, Loughton town council, Essex

 Write to Guardian Society, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; or fax 020-7713 4154 or email society@theguardian.com Please supply your full address. Letters may be edited

webTitle: The poetry of children in care

fields.headline: Power of the pen
fields.standfirst: Anger, despair, joy and disappointment -  David Brindle  on a moving publication that offers an insight into the roller-coaster of emotions experienced by children in care
fields.trailText: Anger, despair, joy and disappointment - David Brindle on a moving publication that offers an insight into the roller-coaster of emotions experienced by children in care
fields.body:
Children in care must be haunted by what has happened to them, but all too often lack an outlet for their feelings. A new publication from Essex social services sets out to remedy that.

A Suitcase Full of Emotions is a slim volume of poems, stories and drawings by children and young people who are, or have been, in the department's care. Some contributions are funny; many are heart-rendingly sad. All offer a rare insight into why youngsters end up in care and their experiences there - bad and good.

In an impressive coup, Essex persuaded Andrew Motion, the poet laureate, to write a foreword to the collection. He calls it a "very touching" record of life for those in care. "But they also show care for themselves: care for words, for shape, for rhythm, for coherence and for self-expression," he says.

Seventeen-year-old Becky, one of the contributors, is now living with a family after being in children's homes. She says that at times she "found it easier to express my feelings in writing than to speak to people". John, also 17, says: "Writing was a very good way for me to release frustration and aggression and I would like to write some more in the future."

Sandra Coward, manager of children's residential services in Essex, says she has seen so much creative writing by youngsters that a publication was a natural progression. "There are some powerful messages to take on board. Many of the children have experienced a great deal of pain in their lives and that comes through very strongly in the book."

One of the most moving contributions is by Rosemary, 16, who writes in despair on being told she is to leave the home where she has settled and found the kind of support she never had from her mother.

"Love was a hard word for my mum - she did not like to cuddle me, I was only there to be shouted at and be hit when she was in anger," Rosemary says. "I think my life was supposed to be hard and [to] live without a dad who did not love me, a mum who rejected me because she had no one else to hurt except me - me, the person who looks like the person who hurt her so badly.

"For 16 years it has been hard and upsetting and ruined, but people say it will only get better in years to come. It won't, it will get harder to live alone and everything is still dragging along [because] of what's happened to me for 16 bloody years and I will never forget the hurt, heart-broken sexual abuse - used, not loved - that happened to me, it will come with me no matter where I will go or where I will end up."

I'd Like

I'd like to go home,

For them to leave me

alone,

I'd like hope in my Life

Not loads of strife.

I'd like to have my mother,

Or someone who cares,

Someone who wants me,

And will always be there.

I don't want much more

From my not so short life

Just someone to listen

And not WALK AWAY!

 Jodie, who wrote this poem for a forum organised by the It's My Life young people's group and Essex children's rights services.

A Notice

If you're happy, you will be and feel better

Don't feel sad feel happy, families don't want to see you sad.

Jump up and turn around and make a change,

a new start is just what you need

Be happy on home contact

Be nice to people in the home

Respect children's things, do not be naughty

or take the things and break them.

Be happy just what you want

Try and be good you never know,

you might go home with your Mum.

 Kimberley, 10, who lived in an Essex children's home

A suitcase full of emotions

Why must I always run

Forever searching

Always seeking

Never reaching

The bed left unmade

Coffee cups remain dirty

Goodbye!! never spoken

I gave you a suitcase

Full of emotions

Full of Hopes

Full of fears

Even the last of my secrets I

Gave to you

Leaving myself open wide

Vulnerable, defenceless

Exposed, torn away

All of myself on display

Every secret uncovered

All rocks left unturned

And still you come back for more

 Denise, 14, who lives in an Essex children's home

A Suitcase Full of Emotions is on sale at Chelmsford library at £2. It can also be ordered by telephoning 01245-434247 or 01245-434179.
