webTitle: Projects to help the homeless young

fields.headline: Homing instinct
fields.standfirst: Young people want independence, yet some just can't cope when they get a place of their own.  Lynne Wallis on a project that helps them to learn from their mistakes
fields.trailText: Young people want independence, yet some just can't cope when they get a place of their own. Lynne Wallis on a project that helps them to learn from their mistakes
fields.body:
Why are there so many homeless young people? The withdrawal of welfare benefits from most 16 and 17-year-olds must be one factor, but another is that many young adults simply lack the basic skills to live independently.

One organisation seeking to address this is the Brunswick Centre Young People's Project in Newcastle upon Tyne, a drop-in centre for impoverished and homeless l6 to 25-year-olds, which is running courses to help its users secure and keep tenancies. "Things like how to keep a rent book or get your electricity turned on sound obvious," says course facilitator Tracey Morgan. "But if you've never done it, how do you know what to do? Lots of young people don't cope because they've never learned how to live alone."

The Brunswick's "independent living skills" course has been so successful that, last month, 35 representatives of charities and voluntary organisations - from the YMCA to Barnardo's - went to Newcastle to learn how to teach the course to young people in housing difficulty in their own areas.

The majority of teenagers who secure tenancies run into financial difficulties and rent arrears. But there are other problems, such as how to tell unwanted visitors to stop coming round, taking drugs and causing trouble. "Many young people living alone lack the confidence and assertiveness to say no, so they lose their tenancies as a result," says Morgan. "We need to get them to understand what assertiveness is, that it's different from aggression, and to develop that quality. When we teach this session, it's interesting when the most dominant person in the group usually loses control as the other members gain confidence."

The Brunswick, which operates out of a room made available by a church in the centre of Newcastle, has about 170 clients on its books. One is Sean Wilkinson, a charming and sociable 21-year-old who completed the course two years ago.

Wilkinson had broken up with his girlfriend, with whom he shared a flat. Subsequently, he become homeless and, like one in three people who live rough, developed mental health problems. He found himself living on the streets of Newcastle after a spell in a psychiatric hospital. Eventually, an organisation called Stepping Stones picked him up. He recalls: "They got me a flat with the Richmond Fellowship, which gives accommodation to people with mental health problems, but I still have to budget and pay for electricity, food, phone and gas. I couldn't have done it without the help I've had here. I got into such a mess with money in the past. I ran up debts of £700 after I split up with my partner."

Morgan helped Wilkinson draw up a payment plan for his debts and a budget for day-to-day living. He's still signed off sick, but is decorating his flat and has high hopes of pursuing his interest in cooking when he is better. "I've already passed the NVQ," he says. "I'd love to own my own restaurant one day. I know I'm good."

Care leavers constitute up to half of all homeless people. Ros Kelly, who has studied the independent living skills course to take back to Barnardo's, where she helps vulnerable young people to secure accommodation, says: "Care leavers are so institutionalised, they haven't got a clue how to look after themselves. They've never cooked a meal or washed a shirt. They've grown up thinking, 'No matter how badly I behave, someone will look after me.' Well, they soon find out that's just not true."

She believes the reason that so many young people leave home at l6 is "abuse in all its varieties", usually involving poverty and, quite often, a step-parent the teenager does not get on with. But sometimes it is just the impatience and intolerance of parents. "Kids at l6 can be a pain in the neck, and they're often chucked out at that age by parents who forget they get over that stage and usually turn out OK," Kelly says. "In other instances, though, it's outright violence and sexual abuse."

Having so far taught one group of 14-year-olds, Kelly believes course participants need to have a failed tenancy behind them to appreciate what can go wrong. And there needs to be a change in attitude to these common failures. "Young people need to realise it's normal to leave home, make a mess of it, and try again," she says. "Currently, they are made to feel failures by a system which doesn't always appreciate these kids haven't got an open door at home."

On a weekday afternoon, the Brunswick Centre is full of young people chatting, feeding children and getting advice from staff member Theresa Carey. Compared to other big cities, Newcastle has a large stock of accommodation for the homeless, although many bed spaces are held by long-term residents.

Carey says: "The YMCA is proud of the fact that people stay in its supported accommodation so long, but it's not good because it's institutionalising them. Some become part of a subculture, moving from hostel to hostel. But when the time comes to move on and live independently, they can't do it. Bills come in and they throw them away. Supported accommodation should be short-term, because it detracts from the skills young people need to live their own lives."

The wisdom of watching pennies

Lynne Wallis

Angela Roberts left home at l6 following difficulties with her parents. Now 21, and recovering from a drink problem, she has a three-year-old daughter and a new baby, Callum.

Roberts has lived independently since the age of 17 and has had three different tenancies, but has consistently run into financial problems. Until now. "I had a key meter for the gas which I couldn't always afford to charge, I had no bed for Nicole, and I was totally stressed with worry - I wasn't coping," she confesses. But then she saw a sign at the Brunswick for the living skills course and signed up.

"When young people get flats for the first time, they don't know where to go for cheap things - and that was my downfall," she says. "Now I know all the cheapest shops in town and I use them. I manage on £103 a week for the three of us. I've just had my benefit cut because the child support agency says I haven't told them enough about Nicole's father - the truth is that I didn't get the forms they insist they sent me - so I have to watch every penny.

"I use second-hand shops for cots and things like that, and put something in my bank account every week for the children. In January, I'm going back to college so I can get a decent job and support them."

"I'd love to own my own restaurant one day. I know I'm good." Care leavers constitute up to half of all homeless people. Ros Kelly, who has studied the independent living skills course to take back to Barnardo's, where she helps vulnerable young people to secure accommodation, says: "Care leavers are so institutionalised, they haven't got a clue how to look after themselves. They've never cooked a meal or washed a shirt. They've grown up thinking, 'No matter how badly I behave, someone will look after me.' Well, they soon find out that's just not true." She believes the reason that so many young people leave home at l6 is "abuse in all its varieties", usually involving poverty and, quite often, a step-parent the teenager does not get on with. But sometimes it is just the impatience and intolerance of parents. "Kids at l6 can be a pain in the neck, and they're often chucked out at that age by parents who forget they get over that stage and usually turn out OK," Kelly says. "In other instances, though, it's outright violence and sexual abuse." Having so far taught one group of 14-year-olds, Kelly believes course participants need to have a failed tenancy behind them to appreciate what can go wrong. And there needs to be a change in attitude to these common failures. "Young people need to realise it's normal to leave home, make a mess of it, and try again," she says. "Currently, they are made to feel failures by a system which doesn't always appreciate these kids haven't got an open door at home." On a weekday afternoon, the Brunswick Centre is full of young people chatting, feeding children and getting advice from staff member Theresa Carey. Compared to other big cities, Newcastle has a large stock of accommodation for the homeless, although many bed spaces are held by long-term residents. Carey says: "The YMCA is proud of the fact that people stay in its supported accommodation so long, but it's not good because it's institutionalising them. Some become part of a subculture, moving from hostel to hostel. But when the time comes to move on and live independently, they can't do it. Bills come in and they throw them away. Supported accommodation should be short-term, because it detracts from the skills young people need to live their own lives." The wisdom of watching pennies Lynne Wallis Angela Roberts left home at l6 following difficulties with her parents. Now 21, and recovering from a drink problem, she has a three-year-old daughter and a new baby, Callum. Roberts has lived independently since the age of 17 and has had three different tenancies, but has consistently run into financial problems. Until now. "I had a key meter for the gas which I couldn't always afford to charge, I had no bed for Nicole, and I was totally stressed with worry - I wasn't coping," she confesses. But then she saw a sign at the Brunswick for the living skills course and signed up. "When young people get flats for the first time, they don't know where to go for cheap things - and that was my downfall," she says. "Now I know all the cheapest shops in town and I use them. I manage on £103 a week for the three of us. I've just had my benefit cut because the child support agency says I haven't told them enough about Nicole's father - the truth is that I didn't get the forms they insist they sent me - so I have to watch every penny. "I use second-hand shops for cots and things like that, and put something in my bank account every week for the children. In January, I'm going back to college so I can get a decent job and support them."

webTitle: Malcolm  Dean: Bench mark of concern

fields.headline: Bench mark of concern
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: Whitehall whispers suggest Jack Straw had only one purpose in setting up the review of magistrates' courts published last week: replacing lay members, who date back to 1361, with professional stipendiaries
fields.body:
Whitehall whispers suggest Jack Straw had only one purpose in setting up the review of magistrates' courts published last week: replacing lay members, who date back to 1361, with professional stipendiaries, now called district judges. One anonymous aide said: "What we expect this research to prove is that lay magistrates are at best adequate and at worst appalling."

Coinciding with William Hague's speech on crime, the report sank without trace as reporters concentrated on the Tory leader.

The report provides critics of lay magistrates with powerful ammunition. Comparing the work of the 96 full-time stipendiaries with that of the 30,400 lay magistrates, the researchers said court practitioners (lawyers and court advisers) found stipendiaries were more efficient, consistent, ready to question lawyers, and in command of the proceedings. Lawyers confessed that when appearing before a stipe, they were more diligent in their preparation, and tried to be more precise and concise.

Further research found stipendiaries dealt with cases much faster - on like-for-like caseloads, 30% faster. Surely then, the modernisers' case for replacing amateurs with professionals is complete? Not quite. First remember the volume: 96% of all court business is carried out by magistrates - 2m cases - with 90% of it by lay members. They cannot be replaced quickly. It took two decades for stipes to double from 50 to 96.

Then consider cost: a full-time stipe costs £90,000 a year, compared to £495 which the average magistrate receives in expenses and lost earnings. True, this huge disparity disappears when indirect costs (courts, administration), stipendiaries' higher caseloads, and a Treasury opportunity cost weighting (lay magistrates doing other things) are taken into account.

But arguments don't stop there. Some 80% of lay magistrates may be drawn from managerial classes (with 40% retired and only 4% under 40), but they are still more representative than stipendiaries, achieving a 50:50 gender representation and 5% drawn from ethnic minorities. Stipes are overwhelmingly male, white and middle class.

There is an even more important reason for protecting the lay bench. In a society sending record numbers to prison, they are far more restrained than professionals. Their imprisonment and remand rates are half as high. They may not be representative, but they are more in touch with communities. They were also found to be more courteous to defendants, use simpler language and show more concern to distressed witnesses. Widen their ranks, certainly, but resist their removal.

webTitle: Inquiry criticises care agencies' poor safety procedures

fields.headline: Death prompts reforms
fields.standfirst: Inquiry criticises care agencies' poor safety procedures
fields.trailText: Inquiry criticises care agencies' poor safety procedures
fields.body:
Two years after social worker Jenny Morrison was stabbed to death by a client in a south London hostel, health and social services have begun to overhaul the system that failed her. Following an inquiry into the killing, the regional NHS office has promised further checks to ensure reforms are implemented.

Morrison, 51, had almost 20 years' experience as a social worker. On the day she died, she went to the Thurleigh Road hostel in Balham because of a deterioration in the condition of her client, Anthony Joseph, a paranoid schizophrenic.

The inquiry reported last week that when she went, unaccompanied, with Joseph into the hostel's isolated lounge - a room with no panic alarms and no easy escape route - she had not been told he had previously been convicted for carrying a knife, had threatened mental hospital staff and had a history of sleeping with a machete under his pillow. In addition, she was unaware that he had spoken about "demons" torturing him and that he had said she "would be brave" to see him.

Within minutes of their meeting, Joseph went to the hostel kitchen, fetched a knife and stabbed her more than 100 times. There was only one member of staff, a woman, on duty at the hostel.

Joseph has been convicted of manslaughter on grounds of diminished responsibility and sent to Broadmoor special hospital indefinitely.

The independent inquiry, chaired by barrister Peter Herbert, found that the risks Joseph posed to himself and others were "systematically underestimated". The inquiry report criticises Wandsworth council, which runs the hostel, and the South West London and St George's mental health trust, which coordinated his care, for "serious management and systems failures".

Morrison had planned to meet Joseph in the company of the hostel's manager and deputy manager, but had problems with her car and had to get a lift, arriving before they did. Irrespective of this, the report criticises the hostel's failure to meet Wandsworth's own minimum requirement of at least two care staff on duty at all times.

In addition, it finds that inadequate, "ad hoc" sharing of vital information among professionals increased the likelihood of a fatality occurring. Neither Morrison nor the hostel staff were informed that Joseph had threatened his mother with a knife.

Hostel staff had also not been told that he had previously been charged with possession of a kitchen knife, or that he had made threatening phone calls to two nurses at the Maudsley hospital, south London,where he had been a patient.

Finally, the inquiry found there had been a three-week delay between hostel staff noticing that Joseph's behaviour had deteriorated and Morrison being informed.

Joseph had become Morrison's client in 1998 when he was discharged from Springfield. In contrast to his earlier discharge from the Maudsley, he received no written care plan, no risk assessment in accordance with the care programme approach, no systematic monitoring of his medication and no out-patient follow-up. The hostel was also found to lack proper emergency procedures.

The inquiry panel recommended improved hospital discharge procedures, staff training programmes, management procedures and supervision of medication. The council and the trust say they have already done much of this, but the London NHS region says it will be checking up.

Herbert says the findings have national implications for mental health services. If Department of Health guidelines had been followed, there would have been less risk of a serious incident occurring.

webTitle: Psychiatrists may boycott white paper's treatment powers

fields.headline: Law and disorder
fields.standfirst: Psychiatrists may boycott white paper's treatment powers
fields.trailText: Psychiatrists may boycott white paper's treatment powers
fields.body:
Ministers are expected today to set out in a white paper how they aim to make it easier to administer compulsory treatment of people with serious mental disorders. But a survey has suggested that a majority of psychiatrists disagree with the plans and a sizeable minority may even be prepared to boycott them.

The impetus for some of the proposed changes has come from high-profile cases such as that of Michael Stone, who in 1996 attacked Josie Russell and killed her mother and sister after his personality disorder was deemed untreatable.

According to draft proposals, new legislation would allow detention of people with such severe anti-social disorders - even if they could not be diagnosed with a specific clinical condition and even, in some cases, if they had committed no crime. For people with treatable mental illness, doctors would be able to force them to take medication even if they were living at home. At present, this can be done only if they are admitted to hospital.

The survey, part of which was recently published in the British Journal of Psychiatry, involved nearly 1,200 psychiatrists. Almost two-thirds disagree with the plan for detaining people with personality disorders, and almost a third said they might boycott it.

The plan for compulsory community treatment was less vehemently opposed, but a third said they disagreed and more than a sixth would consider a boycott.

Mike Crawford, a psychiatrist at St Mary's hospital, London, who carried out the survey, is personally worried that there is no clinical evidence of treatment of personality disorder. "I don't think anyone can say with any confidence that anti-social people can be treated," he says. While welcoming some government reforms, he believes that in this case ministers are being too heavy-handed.

"The government is focusing on preventing very rare incidents," he says. "Is it right to impose legislation on thousands and thousands of people with mental illness because a few commit crimes? We don't have specific legislation to imprison people with alcohol problems."

Crawford also says compulsory drug regimens for people living at home is the wrong approach. He says: "My experience is, if you spend more time building relationships with people it's better in the long run. I don't think you can ever force any one to have treatment outside of hospital - people can always refuse to turn up for their appointments. If you can develop a partnership with the patients, and develop a treatment plan, there's a greater likelihood they'll carry that through."

The number of cases of compulsory treatment would rise under the new system, Crawford says, as availability of hospital beds would no longer limit the number of patients sectioned. "At the moment, the limited number of beds does make you think carefully about whether they should be admitted," he says.

Some of the government's proposals are welcomed by groups such as the Zito Trust. Michael Howlett, director of the mental health charity, says community treatment orders could help mentally ill people avoid admission to hospital. "At the moment they have had to be ill enough to be sectioned. These could help them get treatment before that happens."

But most other groups in the sector are less supportive of the proposals. Crawford says: "There's a moral issue about whether society should be able to make somebody do something they don't want to do. It should not be done lightly."

webTitle: NHS loses top woman to Oxfam

fields.headline: Charity scoop
fields.standfirst: NHS loses top woman to Oxfam
fields.trailText: NHS loses top woman to Oxfam
fields.body:
Less than two weeks after taking up what had been described as "the second most important job" in NHS management, Barbara Stocking has quit to become director of aid charity Oxfam. The timing of the announcement that she is to leave her post as director of the NHS modernisation agency - the body tasked with rolling out the NHS plan reforms - has stunned the health service.

There will also be disappointment that one of the NHS's most experienced, and high-profile, women managers is leaving the service, reinforcing concerns that it cannot hold on to its top female talent and role models.

It emerged this week that NHS chief executive Nigel Crisp knew that 49-year-old Stocking's "hat was in the ring" for the Oxfam job - and that she would take it if offered - when he appointed her in November. Although the modernisation agency job was billed as "for an initial period of six months," and as a "secondment" from her principal job as director of NHS south-east region, there was no suggestion that she had not joined the agency for the long haul. The Department of Health website refers to her as "the new head of the agency".

But Stocking, who had unsuccessfully applied for the NHS chief executive post, which went to Crisp in October, has told the Guardian that when he approached her about the job, she had warned him that she was considering "doing something different".

She says: "He was really anxious to get the modernisation agency moving quickly. That was why we agreed it was a secondment and that, in due course, the job would be advertised."

In what now looks ironic, Crisp came under fire at the time for appearing to breach equal opportu nities policy by appointing Stocking without first advertising the job.

A Department of Health spokesman says that her appointment was always intended as a stop gap: "Clearly, we felt that Barbara was an outstanding candidate to get the agency off to a flying start. It was always on the understanding that it was for a start-up period."

This still leaves the questions of why such an important position was not advertised straight away, and whether, if Stocking had decided against the Oxfam job, she would have had to "re-apply" for the modernisation job next spring.

The modernisation agency was set up by Alan Milburn, health secretary, to spread good management practice across the health service and help health professionals implement the NHS plan. It has already sent teams into hospital trusts with the longest out-patient waiting lists, but will equally be working to identify the best performing organisations and reward them with more power to take decisions locally.

At Oxfam, Stocking will manage a £90m budget and a worldwide staff of 2,600. She replaces David Bryer, who is leaving the charity's top job after 10 years. The post was advertised at a salary of £75,000 - some £5,000 less than she was reportedly earning four years ago when director of the NHS Anglia and Oxford region.

Stocking, who lives in Oxford, where Oxfam is based, says: "I was very tempted by the modernisation job, but at the time it came up I had almost made up my mind [that she would leave the NHS]."

The lure of the Oxfam job was too great, she says. "I've always admired it as an influential and humanitarian aid agency that really works for people on the ground, in terms of their own development."

webTitle: South Yorkshire town experiences problems over asylum seekers

fields.headline: Gripes of Wath
fields.standfirst: The spirit of the Socialist Republic of South Yorkshire was forged in the strikes of the 70s and 80s. But a row over a hostel for asylum seekers is now tarnishing the area's caring image
fields.trailText: The spirit of the Socialist Republic of South Yorkshire was forged in the strikes of the 70s and 80s. But a row over a hostel for asylum seekers is now tarnishing the area's caring image
fields.body:
Aplan to open a hostel for asylum seekers has been thrown out after angry residents raised a storm of protest. They told their local council they feared that young children and elderly people would be put at risk and there would be a breakdown of law and order. The council said it understood their fears and turned down the proposal. Nobody was being racist, said councillors, but the hostel would be better placed somewhere else.

Such episodes may not be headline news these days, but this didn't take place in a shires village or a well-heeled suburb of a commuter belt town. It happened last month in a pit village near Rotherham, in the heartland of what was once known as the Socialist Republic of South Yorkshire. The planning board of Rotherham borough council, on which Labour holds 58 of the 66 seats, refused to give the go-ahead for 30 men to be given refuge in the village of Wath upon Dearne while their applications for asylum were being processed.

Those who remember the political action that centred on Sheffield and the nearby towns of Barnsley, Doncaster and Rotherham in the 70s and 80s may find it hard to believe that this could have happened in what was once a hotbed of socialism. After all, South Yorkshire threw open its arms to refugees from Chile who fled the Pinochet regime. Those asylum seekers - and others from across the globe - were warmly welcomed by communities throughout the county. In Sheffield, it was almost a state occasion when political activists were called to the City Hall ballroom to attend yet another welcoming party for refugees. What mattered above all else was that asylum seekers were made to feel at home.

And at home they felt. Few Saturdays went by in South Yorkshire without a demonstration in support of some cause or other, and refugees were actively encouraged to march side by side with their new found friends. This was where the victorious miners' strikes of 1972 and 1974 were masterminded. It was here that Sheffield city council continually attempted to frustrate the Conservative government of the 80s, and the council's new leader, a youthful David Blunkett, had the red flag flown over the town hall to the annoyance of Thatcher and her ministers.

Throughout the mines, the railways and the steel and engineering works, the socialist message rang out. Here, and overseas, fellow workers could count on the support of the rank and file in South Yorkshire. That, it seems, is no longer the way in at least one part of the "socialist republic".

In October, residents of Wath upon Dearne, a former mining community on the outskirts of Rotherham, learned that a planning application had gone before the borough council to change the use of a former residential nursing home to a 30-bed hostel for asylum seekers. Rotherham businessman Terry Watson, owner of the building, had tried for more than a year to find a buyer. It had stood empty as he sought to sell it as a nursing home, flats or a hotel, but he had been unable to stimulate any interest.

Watson had reached an agreement with Safe Haven, a not-for-profit body, backed by a group of housing associations and sponsored by the Home Office, to turn the building into a hostel for refugees catering for up to 30 single men aged 18 to 30.

But the plan triggered an outcry among locals. Feelings ran high at public meetings. A petition, with more than 700 signatures, and numerous letters from individual residents were sent to the council demanding the scheme be thrown out.

Residents argued that the hostel should be sited on a council estate, not in a private residential area; that there would be an increase in crime, including vandalism and "social disorder"; and that property prices would fall. One resident claimed that parents would be "terrified of letting their children play out". Another asked: "Can we be assured there are no child abusers, drug addicts or convicted rapists among them?"

Only one local stood up in defiance and supported the plan. Ged Dempsey, a delegate to Rotherham trades council and a member of a number of human rights groups, called on the local authority to join with the trades council and local churches "to assist in demystifying, informing, challenging and breaking down the barriers to the issues involved".

Through the trades council, Dempsey wrote to union branches and churches urging them to support his stand that asylum seekers were entitled to basic human rights and had been unjustly "stigmatised, alienated and segregated". He pointed out that the TUC's annual congress had agreed unanimously to defend the rights of asylum seekers.

He was later supported by a number of churchmen. The Rev Tim Leach, of All Saints Church in the village, was one of two who attended a public meeting and spoke on behalf of accepting the refugees. He says: "Among local residents, there were a good few who were not against the proposal. Regrettably, those who were against it were most vociferous."

Rotherham's planners took everything into consideration and recommended to the planning board that the application be granted, stating: "The premises shall be used as a hostel for asylum seekers only and for no other purpose. Asylum seekers occupying the premises shall be referred by the Home Office or local housing authority." But when board members started to discuss the plan, a very different view emerged.

Labour member Sheila Walker, who chairs the board, told the meeting: "I know what a close-knit community they are in Wath and this is not prejudice. This is nothing to do with racism. It's about whether this is the right place, and in our opinion it is not." Another Labour councillor, Margaret Clark, said: "We live in a multicultural town, but some parts of Rotherham are more multicultural than others."

webTitle: Morrison fires up the giant killers

fields.headline: Morrison fires up the giant killers
fields.trailText: Having already dismissed Leicester and Tranmere Rovers, respectively the winners and runners-up in last season's competition, Crystal Palace have grounds for insisting their name is on the trophy this time. Clinton Morrison's winner with eight minutes left at Selhurst Park strengthened that belief last night.
fields.body:
Having already dismissed Leicester and Tranmere Rovers, respectively the winners and runners-up in last season's competition, Crystal Palace have grounds for insisting their name is on the trophy this time. Clinton Morrison's winner with eight minutes left at Selhurst Park strengthened that belief last night.

It was a magnificent effort in which he first outwitted Emerson Thome before placing his volley neatly into the far corner. And, unlike the start of the half when Mikael Forssell's goal was immediately cancelled by Alex Rae, this time the first division side held on to book their semi-final place against Liverpool.

Peter Reid decided not to risk Niall Quinn whose recurring back problem has curtailed his midweek appearances. The Sunderland manager gave Stefan Schwarz his first full game since he ruptured a tendon nine months ago and a rare call up for Stanislav Varga who has struggled following an impressive debut on the opening day of the season.

Sunderland were cut apart, seeking the offside flag, when Clinton Morrison accepted a diagonal pass from Fan Zhiyi. Thomas Sorensen succeeded in taking the sting out of the shot and Darren Williams cleared from beneath the crossbar.

Palace had enough possession and zest to encourage their supporters but it was some time before they could claim a chance to rival that. Meanwhile Danny Dichio, the replacement for Quinn, missed when found by Alex Rae's quick free-kick and a similar opportunity was created on the half hour following Dichio's nod on. Julio Arca had time to select his corner of the net but allowed Aleksandrs Kolinko to get a hand to it.

A goal on either occasion would have helped Sunderland better absorb the pressure in their own penalty area that increased the nearer it came to the half-time whistle. From some distance away Tommy Black put his free-kick direct on goal and Sorensen was grateful to see it pass the wrong side of the post.

Later the diminutive midfielder went for glory and ignored the sensible option of a cutback when discovering space tight to the by-line. Then Morrison was only inches away himself as Palace finished the half on the up.

They immediately picked up the momentum again and led two minutes after the restart. Sorensen miscued as he attempted to hammer a back pass back up field and Morrison was composure itself as he strode on to the loose ball before squaring it into Forssell's path, and the flame-haired Finn calmly rolled it into the empty net.

The lead, so spiritedly pursued, was to last barely 60 seconds however, before Arca crossed from the right, Dichio cushioned his header and Rae supplied the finish. Dichio was quickly back, firing low at Kolinko who fielded it cleanly as he did when Rae broke free once more down the right.

So were Sunderland beginning to gain the upper hand? Not so - Palace twice struck the cross bar around the hour, firstly from Forssell in what would have been a stunning individual effort and then from Morrison in the very next move.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: City lights eclipsed by Venus

fields.headline: City lights eclipsed by Venus
fields.trailText: Man City 1 - 2 Ipswich
fields.body:
Manchester City's 20-year wait to reach a cup semi-final was extended yet further last night when the Ipswich defender Mark Venus scored a dramatic winner 19 minutes into extra-time.

His effort earned Town a semi-final date with Birmingham in the new year and settled a contest that City had dominated for the opening 45 minutes and in which the home side hit the woodwork three times, including an ef fort from Paulo Wanchope in the first extra period.

But in the 109th minute of a contest replayed after last week's rain abandonment, Venus played a pass towards Jamie Scowcroft which Jeff Whitley could only help back into the path of the Ipswich player to advance unmarked and beat Nicky Weaver.

In fact Town were still in the game only because of the City goalkeeper's error on the hour when he fumbled a David Johnson header on the line to leave Matt Holland with a simple tap-in to equalise and send the tie into extra-time.

The Bermudian striker Shaun Goater had given City early hope of an end to that long wait as he and Paulo Wanchope, Joe Royle's first-choice forward partnership, had put on a superb display in the first half with fine movement off the ball and good understanding.

An early challenge won by Andy Morrison, City's former club captain playing for the first time in 14 months because of injury and cup-tied team-mates, sent Wanchope goalwards only for the move to grind to a halt with a poor pass to Jeff Whitley.

That attack was followed by another launched by the Costa Rican who appeared on the right wing and crossed for Goater, but he headed wide.

With City now brimming with confidence and eager to attack, a goal arrived in the 10th minute. Danny Tiatto, the tenacious Australian full-back, won a challenge on the edge of the area and slipped the ball square to Goater who switched it neatly from his right to left foot and steered a shrewdly judged shot in off the post.

Minutes later Goater won a tackle on the edge of the area and thundered a fearsome left-foot shot against the angle of post and bar. Then, after City forced a series of corners, the ball fell for Wanchope whose shot on the turn from 15 yards flew through a crowded box and forced Richard Wright into a diving stop.

Midway in the half Gerard Wiekens also shaved the outside of the post with a long-range shot after a lay-off from Shaun Wright-Phillips, by which time Ipswich had at least drawn Weaver into action - the City goalkeeper beating Croft to a loose ball just outside his area after Fabian Wilnis had blazed at goal from 25 yards, and then saving at the second attempt a Jamie Scowcroft header.

Ipswich, perhaps surprised at still being in the contest, sent on Jermaine Wright as a half-time replacement for Herman Hreidarsson, which had an immediate impact.

Scowcroft picked him out two minutes after the restart with a pass that put him in on goal for Ipswich's best chance, an opening he wasted with a quick but inaccurate shot.

Wright was soon Town's best bet, his pace clearly a problem to City's experienced but slow back line.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Business: Bonus bonanza brought home

fields.headline: Bonus bonanza brought home
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The average selling price of a London home at upmarket estate agent Savills has topped £1m for the first time - and is being driven still higher by this year's record City bonus payouts.
fields.body:
The average selling price of a London home at upmarket estate agent Savills has topped £1m for the first time - and is being driven still higher by this year's record City bonus payouts.

Reporting profits up 20% in the past six months, chief executive Aubrey Allen said the lull in the property market seen in the summer had ended and business was now "very active".

He said London prices had been moving up in the past couple of months and the outlook for the new year - as City bankers walk away with record bonuses - was very positive.

Many of the huge City payouts - one investment bank alone is handing out more than 50 £1m cheques this month - will be directed straight into new property. "It is wonderful for us," Mr Allen said. "It is music to our ears. We almost want to start phoning them up.

"There are literally people walking through the door and saying 'I've got another £100,000 to spend'."

Savills' own staff might soon be joining their ranks. The agency operates its own bonus system for which the payout date has been brought forward from April to December.

Last year the group's top earner banked a £600,000 bonus and Mr Allen said this year looked "pretty good" too. He estimated that around 100 staff would receive bonuses of between £50,000 and £150,000.

Savills' turnover in the six months to the end of October was up 71% and profits climbed from £8.8m to £10.6m.

Richard Jewson, the chairman, said the group was trading strongly but sounded a warning that nervous stock markets could test confidence. The shares closed unchanged at 218.5p.

webTitle: Classical:  BBC Phil/ Weller

fields.headline: BBC Phil/ Weller
fields.standfirst:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
****
fields.trailText:
Bridgewater Hall, Manchester
****
fields.body:
Bruckner's Ninth Symphony is one of the surest crowd-pullers in the orchestral repertory, but the reasons for this are unclear. He never finished the last movement, and nobody has made a reconstruction that has found favour. So what survives are two slow movements that both give new meaning to the notion of rambling, and a central scherzo that is almost too schematic. More than that, it is in many ways written against the orchestra, with textural details, dynamic contrasts and rhythms that are effectively impossible to achieve. Anyone looking at the score can easily sympathise with Bruckner's much-derided pupils who were so concerned to rewrite his compositions in a more user-friendly way.

But then that may be why a successful performance of this massive torso can be such an overwhelming experience. The BBC Philharmonic put everything magically in place, and Walter Weller is a conductor who can steer them confidently through the maze without ever losing control of the broader picture.

To do this he needed to allow some details to take care of themselves, which they didn't always do. But there were beautifully turned oboe and flute solos from Jennifer Galloway and Richard Davis. Also noteworthy were the trumpet playing of Patrick Addinall, whose restraint must be a major component in avoiding the bombastic, and the superbly controlled horn section. The silky string textures in the last movement were particularly unforgettable. More than that, though, Weller managed that fine balance between logic and rhapsody that must be at the centre of any sympathetic Bruckner interpretation.

Beethoven's First Piano Concerto, which opened the concert, came as near to perfection as we can hope for. John Lill recently recorded all the Beethoven concertos with Weller, and their partnership was flawless. To say that everything was relaxed and light may give the wrong impression: this performance was also teeming with struggle, as it should be. But the matching visions of conductor and pianist resulted in a marvellous range of colours. The BBC Philharmonic responded with playing that was both perfect and stunningly idiomatic.

More than that, though, Weller managed that fine balance between logic and rhapsody that must be at the centre of any sympathetic Bruckner interpretation. Beethoven's First Piano Concerto, which opened the concert, came as near to perfection as we can hope for. John Lill recently recorded all the Beethoven concertos with Weller, and their partnership was flawless. To say that everything was relaxed and light may give the wrong impression: this performance was also teeming with struggle, as it should be. But the matching visions of conductor and pianist resulted in a marvellous range of colours. The BBC Philharmonic responded with playing that was both perfect and stunningly idiomatic.

webTitle: Jazz: Jane Monheit/ Scott Hamilton

fields.headline: Jane Monheit/ Scott Hamilton
fields.standfirst:
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
***
fields.trailText:
Pizza Express Jazz Club, London

***
fields.body:
You hear "Rita Hayworth" muttered as often as "Ella Fitzgerald" at Jane Monheit's gigs, which are like walking on to a 1940s movie set, right down to the black-tie outfits for the band and the chanteuse's sultry toss of her cascading hair. The time warp happened at the Soho Pizza Express, at the end of the 23-year-old American's current tour, which consolidates a big year in her life.

Monheit has been the classic jazz discovery of the year for singing - and behaving on stage - in a manner that was in its prime 30 years before she was born. And despite the Rita Hayworth look, the Ella Fitzgerald sound is more to the point, because Monheit is a performer of light, effortless swing, a projector of a guileless optimism, and a possessor of a remarkable vocal technique that invests the smallest sound with momentum as well as texture.

In one way, her new show was livelier and less mannered than her showcase performance in London earlier in the year. She was more confident, and therefore breezier, and less inclined to self-conscious vampy posing. In addition, Scott Hamilton was guesting on tenor sax.

Like Monheit, but 30 years previously, Hamilton once got it in the neck for being a young curator of an old style, the Stan Getz school of swing-sax. The demise of most of his heroes has left Hamilton at the top of his particular tree, and his masterly control of acceleration and delay, laconically expressive bell notes and warbles, and luxurious sensuality on ballads (at times he's very reminiscent of the late Ronnie Scott at his best) were both imposing stand-alone features of this gig, and sensitive embellishments of, and contrasts to, Monheit's world.

It would have been a fine mainstream jazz gig except for Monheit's initially touching but ultimately misguided choice of following the buoyant and delicately phrased They Can't Take That Away From Me - with shrewd fills and interjections from Hamilton and pianist David Berkman - with a repertoire of Christmas songs. At times, Monheit's relaxed timing and faultless intonation almost elevated the music from the cheesiness, but Santa Claus is Coming to Town, sung straight at 11.30 in a Soho nightclub, is something of a ball-and-chain on the most sublime of musical sensibilities.

At the moment Monheit is a wonderful singer with nothing to sing about. When she does, anything could happen.

webTitle: All together now

fields.headline: All together now
fields.standfirst: Charles Handy on why work-sharing works
fields.trailText: Charles Handy on why work-sharing works
fields.body:
It is the new mantra of the organisation. "We are no longer able or willing to guarantee your future," it runs. "You are responsible for your own career and your own destiny. We will provide you with opportunities to develop your skills and experience, but employability, not employment, is the best we can offer." We are, in effect, all mercenaries now, on hire whatever the cause, useful only as long as we can perform.

That may make good sense for the organisation, but it is changing our society. Ask someone for their business card these days and many will have more than one to offer - a reflection of their different bits and pieces of work. Sixty per cent of Britain's businesses have only one employee, which is why the statistics for self-employment understate the real degree of independence in work: we call ourselves businesses, not "the self-employed". And now those of us inside institutions are encouraged to think of ourselves as independent.

"In such a world, it is wise and prudent not to make long-term plans or invest in the distant future," writes Zygmunt Bauman, one of Britain's most distinguished philosophers, "not to get tied down too firmly to any particular place, group or cause, even an image of oneself, because one might find oneself not just un-anchored and drifting but without an anchor altogether; it is prudent to be guided in today's choices not by the wish to control the future, but by the reluctance to mortgage it. In other words, 'to be provident' means now, more often than not, to avoid commitment . To be free to move when opportunity knocks. To be free to leave when it stops knocking."

Bauman is worried by the privatisation of society: not the vogue for turning every state activity into a business - although that is part of it - but the fact that we now increasingly belong to, or are committed to, nothing besides ourselves.At work, our loyalty and responsibility is first to ourselves and our future, second to our current group or project and only last - and minimally - to the organisation that is currently paying us. But without commitment, there is no sense of responsibility for others, and without responsibility towards others, there is no need for morality. Anything goes.

This may all be a rational response to a chaotic world, but it makes for a lonely world, one in which the neighbourhood is a jungle to be warily watched, the stranger a beast to hide from, our home a privatised prison. Life does not have to be like this. Bauman argues for a return to something like the Greek polis, which combined individual autonomy with a shared responsibility for decisions that affected all in the community. Independence and togetherness need each other for either to work.

I am hesitant about communities but hopeful of the possibilities that could lie in our work organisations. Shared work, not shared neighbours, may well be the only way in which independence and togetherness can be combined. There is nothing more exciting than losing oneself in a cause that is bigger than oneself, something that makes self-denial worthwhile, where pride in the work and passion for its purpose are the driving forces and where success is shared, not hugged to oneself in secret.

Opportunities for pride, passion and a sense of togetherness will be needed more than money if organisations are going to get the most out of their independents. Independents, for their part, while cherishing the freedom independence brings, will find it is a lonely business and may willingly trade some of that freedom for a bit of togetherness and shared purpose.

Pride, passion and togetherness may be unusual words to apply to organisations. They are words too often missing from our privatised world. You do find them, however, in parts of the voluntary world, in the arts and hospitals and schools, places where money is not the prime motivator. Maybe there are things that business can learn from these sectors, instead of it always being the other way around. Money, for all its charms and uses, is not in itself enough - as independents eventually discover.

 Charles Handy is an independent writer and broadcaster on business and work. Richard Reeves returns in a fortnight.

webTitle: Classical: Rousing tribute to Glock

fields.headline: Rousing tribute to Glock
fields.standfirst:
Glock: A Celebration
St John's, London/Radio 3
*****
fields.trailText:
Glock: A Celebration
St John's, London/Radio 3
*****
fields.body:
William Glock, who died in June at the age of 82, was the most influential figure in British music in the second half of the 20th century. As a teacher and performer at the Bryanston and Dartington Summer Schools, he had encouraged generations of performers and composers, but it was his imagination and unswerving radicalism as the BBC's Controller of Music in the 1960s and 70s that made the widest impact, banishing the parochialism of British music forever and bringing a huge range of unfamiliar music, old and new, to his audiences in the concert hall and on the radio.

The roll call of the great and the good, composers, performers and administrators who flocked to St John's for the BBC's celebration, testified to Glock's importance. He would have delighted in the programme put together to honour him. The kind of diverse, elegant planned concert he used to devise himself, it managed, in two and a half hours, to cover almost every one of his own enthusiasms, from Bach and Haydn, to Boulez and Carter.

The programme began and ended, appropriately, with Boulez, for it was his stewardship of the BBC Symphony Orchestra between 1971 and 1975 that put the seal on Glock's reign at the BBC. Oliver Knussen conducted the London Sinfonietta in Dérive, while Boulez himself was reunited with the BBC Symphony to end the concert with a luminous account of his "... cummings ist der dichter...", the tightest, most perfect fusion of text and music.

Haydn's E flat Piano Trio, played with conversational intimacy by Imogen Cooper, Isabelle Faust and Natalie Clein, and Cooper's delicate, moulded account of Schubert's German Dances recalled Glock's own considerable abilities as a pianist and chamber musician. And if Roberto Gerhard was one of Glock's more questionable enthusiasms, at least Leo, Gerhard's final ensemble work, is an effective piece, pungently given by Knussen and the Sinfonietta.

There had to be Elliott Carter too, for Glock had championed his music in this country long before his importance was recognised in the rest of Europe or the US. The ASKO Concerto, first performed in January this year, was the ideal choice - lithe, perfectly structured and unrestrainedly ebullient.

This really was a celebration, not a sombre remembrance. The only elegiac note was struck by Stravinsky's Symphonies of Wind Instruments, written to commemorate Debussy, and delivered by Boulez and the BBCSO with superb forcefulness.

Altogether, it was a wonderful, generous occasion, and a worthy tribute in memory of a great man.

webTitle: Pop: Crispian Mills, rock 'n' roll caricature

fields.headline: Crispian Mills, rock 'n' roll caricature
fields.standfirst:
Crispian Mills
Leadmill, Sheffield
**
fields.trailText:
Crispian Mills

Leadmill, Sheffield

**
fields.body:
Never underestimate the damage caused by putting a foot into a mouth. In 1997, Crispian Mills's band Kula Shaker were the (clown) princes of Britpop. Some unfunny comments about Adolf Hitler later (even joking about burning swastikas on stage was an extremely bad idea), and Kula Shaker's career went down faster than a lead parachute. Three years on, the controversy is more or less forgotten, but also, it seems, is Mills.

The nation's penchant for retro psychedelic pastiche was not long-lasting, and the appeal of actress Hayley's son is - in Spinal Tap terms - "more selective". Even the Leadmill's staff have trouble remembering who he is - the ticket office advertises "Crispin Hunt".

As the crowd huddle together to keep warm, Mills bounds on stage with arms aloft. It's hard to know whether to laugh at his foolishness or applaud his determination. Apart from the fact that several hundred thousand Kula Shaker fans are in denial, little else has changed. Mills is still haunted by haplessness. When he announces that the drummer "is going to do a hi-hat solo", the PA system blows up in horror. Less hilariously, Kula songs form two-thirds of the set, and the rest - with such Spinal Tap-ish titles as One Louder - sound exactly like Kula Shaker.

Leather jacket sprayed gold, flaxen hair inherited from Hayley, Crisp is still a bonkers caricature of one of those 1960s rockers Mum will have told him all about in childhood. The house of Mills seems particularly rooted in the past. He may well have recently started listening to late-1960s David Bowie. Even the cover versions - Hawkwind's Hurry on Sundown and Deep Purple's Hush - are left-overs from Kula Shaker days. What can the poor boy do except play in an olde-worlde rock 'n' roll band?

Despite everything, Mills is hard to dislike. With his Tommy Steele manner and fascination with knights and Arthurian legends, he would make an excellent, eccentric curator at the British Museum. Sadly, his pop career is going the way of his interview technique, lost in a psychedelic fog.

webTitle: House sales fall 19%

fields.headline: House sales fall 19%
fields.standfirst: Static prices and bad weather depress market
fields.trailText: Static prices and bad weather depress market.
fields.body:
Sellers are quitting the property market amid static prices while bad weather and flooding is deterring buyers, according to a report yesterday from the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors.

Property sales were down 19% in November from the levels a year ago and the number of new properties coming on to surveyors' books is drying up, said the organisation.

Surveyors in some regions, notably East Anglia, reported a sharp slowdown in sales. "Very few properties now coming on to the market, bringing a substantial reduction in activity generally," said John Pocock of Cambridge surveyors Pocock & Shaw.

"The level of instructions has dramatically decreased," added David Potter of Potter & Co in Norwich. "The winter months and the incessant rain have meant that the market has remained static," said Anthony Jamieson of Clarke Gammon in Guildford, Surrey.

But the shortage of houses for sale and expectations of falling interest rates are beginning to push up prices. The institution said its November survey showed 22% more surveyors reporting rises than those reporting falls, up from 7% in the October. Levels of confidence are highest in Yorkshire & Humberside, for long one of the lowest property price areas in Britain.

"The market is still strong in this area and there are very few properties being placed on the market, so prices have edged upwards again in the last month or so," said Philip Mills of Norman Brown in Bedale, North Yorkshire.

The institution also said yesterday it believes house prices will rise by an average of 6% a year over the next two years, a significant slowdown after 2000's 12% increase.

webTitle: Theatre: The Rivals

fields.headline: Toytown sparring for Sheridan's Rivals
fields.standfirst:
The Rivals
Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Rivals
Barbican, London

***
fields.body:
I was puzzled by the critical ecstasies that greeted Lindsay Posner's revival of Sheridan's delightful comedy in Stratford this spring. It struck me then, as it does on its Barbican transfer, as a good, decent, middle-of-the-road revival of the kind that a company such as Prospect used to take around the country. Not a patch, however, on the National's 1983 production where Bath, with its crescents, parades and abbeys, became not just the play's setting but also its protagonist.

Ashley Martin-Davis opts for a similiar design idea in that tiny, detachable Georgian houses are trundled about the stage to create the illusion of Bath. But the effect is more Toytown than spa-town and rarely does Posner's production set the play's romantic misunderstandings against a defined social context, as Peter Wood's did. Seeing Sir Anthony Absolute tetchily at breakfast or his son, Jack, in his clothes-laden lodgings was to learn how situation reveals character; here the action, mostly taking place in front of a pinewood proscenium arch, rarely suggests the hectic gossip-ridden bustle of Sheridan's Bath.

The compensation is that the focus is on the actors - and many of the performances are very good. Best of all is Wendy Craig's Mrs Malaprop, who, far from being the usual affected grotesque, is a real woman hungry for love and desperately proud of her verbal expertise; it is just her misfortune that she mangles almost every word she speaks.

Given the profusion of Sheridan's examples, it does seem gratuitous to tinker with lines such as "my affluence over my niece is very small": here we get, for the sake of a dirty laugh, "effluence". But Craig, who started in John Osborne plays at the Royal Court, reminds us what an excellent actress she is.

To watch the light slowly dawning as she realises that it is the dashing Captain Absolute who has secretly referred to her as "a weatherbeaten old she-dragon" is to see a woman's self-esteem crumbling into dust.

Benjamin Whitrow and David Tennant score as the Absolutes, père et fils. If the former is all buoyant, stick-waggling lechery, the latter suggests he has inherited his father's capricious temper. And Robert Portal transforms Bob Acres, the country squire who imagines himself in love with Emily Raymond's petulant Lydia Languish, from a rustic booby into a preening dandy who goes to fight a duel in beribboned shoes and fetching little tricorne hat.

Posner has clearly thought carefully about the characters; but, while his production offers a perfectly pleasant evening, it still looks a bit decontextualised on the big Barbican stage.

* Until April 17. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

webTitle: A&L abandons online bank for 'mass affluent'

fields.headline: A&L abandons online bank for 'mass affluent'
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Mortgage bank Alliance & Leicester has ditched plans for an online private bank aimed at the "mass affluent".
fields.body:
Mortgage bank Alliance & Leicester has ditched plans for an online private bank aimed at the "mass affluent".

The bank has poured £15m into building the new wealth-management service - which was due to launch early next year - but now intends to absorb the developments into its existing multi-channel operation, using traditional branches and the telephone as well as the web. A spokesman said that A&L had never been certain of the appeal and viability of internet only banking: "We have always been in the sceptics camp as far as standalone internet strategy is concerned".

He added that the A&L had now concluded that wealthier customers with cash to invest are likely to demand a more personal service: "They want options," he said. "Some will be happy to transact largely through the internet but the majority will want some form of personal touch."

Last night the A&L's decision to ditch its standalone plans was being interpreted as an acknowledgement that the Alliance & Leicester brand name is not one which would automatically attract "mass affluent" customers - usually defined as those with more than £50,000 to invest.

Building the right image would have demanded sub stantial marketing resources.

webTitle: End of grants spell triple woe for students

fields.headline: End of grants spell triple woe for students
fields.trailText: The National Union of Students (NUS) today slammed a report from the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) which showed student debt has tripled since grants were phased out.
fields.body:
The National Union of Students (NUS) today slammed a report from the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) which showed student debt has tripled since grants were phased out.

According to the DfEE's report, entitled Changing Student Finances: Income, Expenditure and the Take-up of Student Loans Among Full-time and Part-time Higher Education Students in 1998/99, the average student debt was £777 in the 1995/96 academic year. But by 1998/99, student debt had soared to £2,473 a year.

Students leaving university after a three-year course can now expect to have debts of around £7,500.

The report also found that 87% of students now say they experience financial hardship. Some 60% of students said money problems had negatively affected their academic performance. More worryingly, 61% said the funding system had deterred their friends from going to university, especially black students, women over 25, and those from poorer backgrounds.

Tuition fees are seen as the major factor in increasing costs for students since 1996, with 35% paying the full £1,000 towards their fees and 21% paying some of the fees.

Owain James, NUS national president, said: "The DfEE's own Student Income and Expenditure survey is a damning indictment of the government's student funding system. Their figures show student hardship is widespread. But this survey was carried out before the abolition of the maintenance grant in England and Wales, so the picture today is likely to be much worse.

"What more evidence does the government need? The Scottish parliament has rejected their funding system. In England, applications from poorer students have fallen. The government must act now to return maintenance grants to those from the poorest backgrounds, as received by Scottish students."

Meanwhile, the government welcomed the figures as evidence that most higher education students received enough financial support to meet their essential costs.

Education and Employment minister Tessa Blackstone said: "The survey evidence confirms that the great majority of full-time students are taking out new fairer income loans which are interest-free in real terms with repayment linked to income. Students are generally receiving the support they need from loans, grants and contributions from their parents, but we recognise that further, targeted support is needed for some disadvantaged groups."

This targeted help is to include, amongst other things, mature student bursaries and childcare grants to help out lone parents, identified as the highest debt group with an average debt of £4,747 a year.
